• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0  (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Operational energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Amount of food waste generated, percentage diverted from the waste stream
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of food waste and unsaleable food generated in metric tons.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Food waste is defined as food and inedible parts for which the entity has no further use and removed from the food supply chain.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Food is defined per the Food Loss and Waste Accounting and Reporting Standard, Version 1.0 (FLW Standard) as any substance—whether processed, semi-processed, or raw—that is intended for human consumption. “Food” includes drinks, and any substance that has been used in the manufacture, preparation, or treatment of food. “Food” also includes material that has spoiled and is no longer fit for human consumption. It does not include cosmetics, tobacco, or substances used only as drugs. It does not include processing agents used along the food supply chain, for example, water to clean or cook raw materials or cooking oil used in food preparation.
• Inedible parts are defined per the FLW Standard as components associated with a food that, in a particular food supply chain, are not intended to be consumed by humans. Examples of inedible parts associated with food could include bones, rinds, and pits or stones. “Inedible parts” do not include packaging. What is considered inedible varies among entities, changes over time, and is influenced by a range of variables including culture, socioeconomic factors, availability, price, technological advances, international trade, and geography.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Unsaleable food is defined per the Food Waste Reduction Alliance (FWRA) as food that is safe for human consumption, but is no longer able to be sold due to quality, over-production, or labeling issues.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of food waste and unsaleable food generated excludes (a) what is discarded off-site by customers and (b) packaging materials, such as boxes, wrapping, or plastic containers.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Where packaging is not separated from food prior to its disposal, the entity shall obtain an estimate for the amount of food waste excluding the packaging material based on the Guidance on FLW Quantification Method .

Accounting Metric: Amount of food waste generated, percentage diverted from the waste stream
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of food waste or unsaleable food that was diverted or rescued.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Food waste is considered diverted if it has been:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Unsaleable food is considered rescued if it has been donated to social service agencies and/or charitable organizations.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The entity may disclose the percentage of the total unsaleable food generated that was rescued.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The following disposal methods are not considered to be diversion from the waste stream or rescued:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Landfilling
• Incineration, including for energy recovery
• Dumping to land or sea
• Disposal via sewer and wastewater treatment plants
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The entity shall calculate the percentage as the sum of the (1) weight of food waste that has been diverted from the waste stream (in metric tons) plus the (1) weight of unsaleable food that has been rescued (in metric tons) divided by the total weight of food waste and unsaleable food generated (in metric tons).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity’s expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems that pose a data security risk.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, and/or implementation that could be exploited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data security risk is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, or nations through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities it has identified, including, but not limited to, operational procedures, management processes, structure of products, selection of business partners, employee training, and use of technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the degree to which its approach is aligned with an external standard or framework and/or legal or regulatory framework for managing data security, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ISO/IEC 27001:2013—Information technology—Security techniques—Information security management systems—Requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, Version 1.1, April 16, 2018, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC’s Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity’s approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: High-risk food safety violation rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rate of high-risk food safety violations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: High-risk (or “critical”) violations are defined as violations that, if left uncorrected, directly relate to the transmission of foodborne illnesses, the adulteration of food products, and/or the contamination of food-contact surfaces.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes food safety inspections conducted by local health departments, state health departments, or other relevant agencies that govern food safety at the entity’s retail locations and distribution centers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the percentage as the total number of inspected locations that received high-risk violations divided by the total number of food safety inspections that were conducted at the entity’s retail locations and distribution centers during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: High-risk food safety violation rate
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the number of notices of violation received related to food safety at its retail locations and distribution centers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A notice of violation is defined as an advisory and administrative violation for any food-safety-related issue including, but not limited to, issues related to facilities’ hygienic practices, product allergen labeling, product contamination, food and color additive violations, and other food safety issues covered by relevant regulations (e.g., U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, U.S. Federal Meat Inspection Act, U.S. Poultry Products Inspection Act, and U.S. Egg Products Inspection Act).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) notices of violation include, but are not limited to Warning Letters , Untitled Letters , Administrative Detention , or Section 305 Notices.
• U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) notices of violation include, but are not limited to, Notice of Warning , product withholdings and suspensions, and regulatory control actions.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of food-safety-related recalls it issued.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A food-safety-related recall is defined as removal of a marketed product that occurs when there is reason to believe that a food may cause consumers to become ill.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of units of food products that were subject to food-safety-related recalls it issued.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of units of food products that were subject to food-safety-related recalls that were private-label products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A private-label product is defined as a store-brand product packaged for sale with a retailer’s brand name, whether manufactured by the retailer or by another manufacturer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of units of private-label food products that were subject to food-safety-related recalls divided by the total number of units of food products that were subject to food-safety-related recalls.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes voluntary recalls initiated by the entity and involuntary recalls requested and/or mandated by regulatory authorities [e.g., China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)].

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes market withdrawals, which are defined as an entity’s removal or correction of a distributed product that involves a minor violation that would not be subject to legal action by regulatory authorities or that involves no violation (e.g., normal stock rotation practices).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of recalls that were voluntarily issued and the percentage of recalls that were involuntarily issued.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls, (2) number of units recalled, (3) percentage of units recalled that are private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of the total number of units recalled that is assigned by the FDA as a Class I Recall.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A Class I Recall is defined as a situation in which there is a reasonable probability that the use of, or exposure to, a violative product will cause serious adverse health consequences or death.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total revenue from the sales of its products that are labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Products that are labeled to promote health and nutrition attributes contain labels and other written, printed, or graphic matter on the article itself, on any containers and wrappers, or otherwise accompanying the article that promote health and nutrition attributes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Consistent with the American Marketing Association’s definition of marketing, products are considered to be marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes when the entity communicates, delivers, and exchanges offerings that promote the product’s health and nutrition attributes.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes
Technical Protocol: The scope of products labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes includes products that contain one or more of the following labels and/or marketing claims:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Additives (e.g., artificial sweeteners, colors, preservatives, and industrially produced trans fats) have been eliminated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Fat, saturated fat, sodium, and cholesterol are equal to or less than the requirements for the use of the term “healthy” and related terms in the Guidance for Industry: A Food Labeling Guide (January 2013) prescribed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Beneficial nutrients (e.g., vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, protein, and fiber) meet or exceed the requirements for the use of the term “healthy” and related terms as prescribed in the FDA’s Guidance for Industry: A Food Labeling Guide (January 2013).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: A relative claim, such as “light,” “reduced,” or “less” can be made regarding the product’s added sugar content, consistent with the FDA’s Guidance for Industry: A Food Labeling Guide (January 2013).

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes
Technical Protocol: The scope of products labeled and/or marketed to promote health and nutrition attributes excludes products that are labeled organic, free of genetically modified organism (GMO) ingredients, and gluten-free.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its efforts to identify concerns, the products and ingredients related to those concerns, and resulting risks and opportunities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant efforts to discuss include, but are not limited to, risk assessments, organization of long-term health or toxicology studies, and procedures for receiving and reviewing consumer concerns.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how identified concerns and risks are managed and communicated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant efforts to discuss include, but are not limited to, labeling transparency, phasing out, substituting, or using more sustainable ingredients, updating product portions and product mix, improving the nutritional content of its products, and/or taking other measures to address consumer concerns, trends, and preferences.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may discuss implementation of relevant food ingredient and additive standards, such as those under the CODEX Alimentarius International Food Standards of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and the World Health Organization (WHO) as a strategy to manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity may discuss whether strategies are related to or associated with a formal health and nutrition initiative or strategy (e.g., WHO Global Strategy on Diet, Physical Activity and Health), including regional, national, international, or industry-specific programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its use of certification programs that address consumer concerns and preferences over ingredients, additives, and potential allergens.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Certifications may include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• USDA Organic
• Non-GMO Project Verified
• Certified Gluten-Free

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to identify and manage products and ingredients related to nutritional and health concerns among consumers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss any significant complaints, such as those resulting in significant lawsuits, relating to nutritional and health concerns associated with products and/or ingredients, and any efforts to mitigate the related future risks.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with industry or regulatory labeling and/or marketing codes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of substantiated incidents of non-compliance with labeling- and/or marketing-related regulatory code(s), statute(s), or other requirement(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Labeling- and/or marketing-related non-compliance incidents include those with products with labels that are misbranded or use deceptive acts of advertising.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of labeling- and/or marketing-related non-compliance incidents include, but are not limited to, U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA) Untitled Letters and Warning Letters (and the non-U.S. equivalents), and the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) issued cease-and-desist orders, civil penalties, and corrective advertising remedies (and the non-U.S. equivalents).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Examples of labeling- and/or marketing-related regulatory code(s), statute(s), or other requirement(s) include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• U.S. Fair Packaging and Labeling Act (Title 15, Chapter 39)
• U.S. Federal Food and Drugs Act of 1906 (Title 21, Chapter 1)
• U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (Title 21, Chapter 9)
• U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Act (Title 15, Chapter 2)

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with industry or regulatory labeling and/or marketing codes
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes the entity’s private-label products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A private-label product is defined as a store-brand product packaged for sale with a retailer’s brand name, whether manufactured by the retailer or by another manufacturer.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with industry or regulatory labeling and/or marketing codes
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose other incidents of non-compliance or violations with voluntary third-party, industry, or internal codes related to labeling and/or marketing, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Advertising Self-Regulatory Council (ASRC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Children’s Advertising Review Unit (CARU) of the ASRC

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices, such as those related to enforcement of U.S. laws and regulations on nutrient content claims, health claims, other unfair or deceptive claims, and/or misbranded labeling.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Federal Food and Drugs Act of 1906
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled as (1) containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and (2) non-GMO
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its revenue from products sold during the reporting period that are labeled as (1) containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs), and separately, (2) not containing GMOs (non-GMOs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: GMOs are defined as organisms, with the exception of human beings, in which the genetic material has been altered in a way that does not occur naturally by mating and/or natural recombination, consistent with EU Directive 2001/18/EC.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled as (1) containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and (2) non-GMO
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the revenue from its products that are labeled as (1) containing GMOs and (2) non-GMO in markets subject to GMO labeling regulation, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Maine LD 718, HP 490
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Vermont H. 112 Act 0120
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Connecticut House Bill 6527
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: EU Directive 2001/18/EC
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Regulation EC 1829/2003
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Other U.S. state or federal regulation, as enacted

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products labeled as (1) containing genetically modified organisms (GMOs) and (2) non-GMO
Technical Protocol: For the purposes of this disclosure, products that are third-party certified to standards for which non-GMO is inherent to the certification (e.g., U.S. Department of Agriculture Organic certification) shall be considered to be labeled “non-GMO.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of in-store and distribution center employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the average hourly wage paid to in-store and distribution center employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In-store employees include butchers and meat cutters; cashiers; first-line supervisors/managers of retail sales workers; food preparation workers; and stock clerks and order fillers. These employees are generally classified in the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) Standard Occupation Classification under the Food and Beverage Stores subsector (NAICS 445).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Distribution center employees include industrial truck and tractor operators; laborers and freight, stock, and material movers; shipping, receiving, and traffic clerks; stock clerks and order fillers; and transportation, storage, and distribution managers. These employees are generally classified in the BLS Standard Occupation Classification under the Warehousing and Storage subsector (NAICS 493).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The average hourly wage shall be calculated as the total wages, excluding overtime pay, paid to in-store and distribution center employees for the reporting period divided by the number of regular hours worked, excluding overtime hours, by in-store and distribution center employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of in-store and distribution center employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of in-store and distribution center employees that earn minimum wage for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial report.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Minimum wage is defined as the locally mandated minimum wage applicable for each employee.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For countries or regions with no minimum wage requirement, the 10th percentile hourly wage of all wage earners in that country or region shall be used.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the percentage by dividing the number of in-store and distribution center employees that earn minimum wage by the total number of in-store and distribution center employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of in-store and distribution center employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes corporate employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of in-store and distribution center employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the sensitivity of its costs and profit margins to future adjustments in minimum wage, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The likelihood of a minimum wage increase in the regions where the entity operates, and the regions in which this is more likely to occur
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage of its current in-store and distribution center employees whose salaries are near the current minimum wage, and whose salaries may necessitate an increase given a change in minimum wage regulations
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The magnitude of the financial impact that a minimum wage increase would likely have on the entity

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its employees in the active workforce that were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Active workforce is defined as the maximum number of unique employees employed at any time during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Collective bargaining agreements are defined as a mechanism or tool of negotiation by which a union has a collective interest in negotiations to the benefit of several employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in the active workforce who were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period divided by the active workforce.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees employed by the entity, including full-time, part-time, and temporary employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of work stoppages involving 1,000 or more workers lasting one full shift or longer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of work stoppages includes strikes and lockouts.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• A strike is defined as a temporary stoppage of work by a group of employees (not necessarily union members) to express a grievance or enforce a demand.
• A lockout is defined as a temporary withholding or denial of employment during a labor dispute to enforce terms of employment upon a group of employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total days idle as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Days idle is defined as the aggregate number of work days lost as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Total days idle shall be calculated as the sum of the products of the number of workers involved in each work stoppage and the number of days the respective work stoppage was in effect.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with: (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Labor violation is defined as violations including, but not limited to, those relating to wages, work hours, overtime, and meal and rest breaks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Employment discrimination is defined as discrimination on the basis of age, disability, compensation, genetic information, harassment, national origin, pregnancy, race/color, religion, retaliation, sex, and sexual harassment.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with: (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with: (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with: (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with: (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Americans with Disabilities Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Equal Pay Act of 1963
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: U.S. Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: U.S. Pregnancy Discrimination Act (PDA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: U.S. Rehabilitation Act of 1973
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: U.S. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Revenue from products third-party certified to environmental or social sustainability sourcing standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its revenue from products that are third-party certified to an environmental or social sustainability standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental standards are defined as standards that address environmental impacts related to the production of agricultural products such as, protection of primary forests, maintenance of surface water and groundwater quality, and implementation of integrated pest management (IPM) solutions or an Organic System Plan.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Social standards are defined as standards that address social impacts related to the production of agricultural products such as, compensation of the workforce, training and continual monitoring of health and safety risks associated with applications of agrochemicals, and child-labor practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Examples of certifications to third-party environmental and social standards include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Bonsucro
• Fairtrade International
• Fair Trade USA
• Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO)
• Roundtable on Responsible Soy (RTRS)
• Rainforest Alliance
• SA8000
• U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Organic
• UTZ Certified

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Revenue from products third-party certified to environmental or social sustainability sourcing standards
Technical Protocol: The entity may additionally break down the disclosure by product category and certification type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A product category is defined as a group of related products that offer a similar general functionality (e.g., meat, produce, packaged goods).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Certification types may be grouped based on the topic or scope of the standard, and can include animal welfare, working conditions, organic, sustainable fishing or harvesting.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Percentage of revenue from (1) eggs that originated from a cage-free environment and (2) pork produced without the use of gestation crates
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of revenue from eggs sold that originated from a cage-free environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Eggs that originated from a cage-free environment are produced by hens housed in a building, room, or area that allows for unlimited access to food, water, and provides the freedom to roam within the area during the laying cycle.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The scope also includes eggs that originated from a free-range environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the revenue from eggs sold that originated from a cage-free environment divided by the total revenue from eggs sold.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Percentage of revenue from (1) eggs that originated from a cage-free environment and (2) pork produced without the use of gestation crates
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of revenue from pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A gestation crate is defined as an enclosure for housing an individual breeding sow, where the enclosure fulfills the animal’s static space requirements but does not allow for dynamic movement, such as turning around, and is typically non-bedded, with concrete floors and metal stalls.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the revenue from pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates divided by the total revenue from pork sold.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategic approach to managing its environmental and social risks that are present within, or arise out of, its food and food products supply chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental and social risks may include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Impacts on crop and livestock production due to climate change (e.g., changing average temperatures and water stress) that may affect cost and availability of produce, meat, poultry, dairy, and processed foods products
• Animal feed price increases resulting from environmental and social factors and/or tightening environmental regulations that may have price impacts on meat, poultry, and dairy
• Fuel economy regulations that affect transportation costs
• Labor rights and immigration reforms that affect food prices and availability
• International trade barriers and/or varying levels of food safety oversight in a global market
• Commercial catch limits that could affect the supply of seafood products
• Animal welfare, human rights, or related supply chain incidents that may result in reputational damage
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant strategies to discuss may include, but are not limited to, supplier screening, diversification of suppliers, supplier training programs on environmental best management practices, supplier engagement on labor and human rights issues, and maintenance of a supply chain code of conduct, supply chain audits, and certifications.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity may identify which products or product lines present risks to its operations, the risks that are represented, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate such risks.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its animal welfare standards applicable to its supply chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Animal welfare standards are defined as policies for beef, pork, poultry, and/or dairy production conditions, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Animal treatment and handling
• Housing and transportation conditions
• Slaughter facilities and procedures
• Use of antibiotics and hormones
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Any targets the entity has related to animal welfare standards and its progress toward those targets.
• Any requirements for suppliers related to animal welfare standards
• How, if in any way, animal welfare standards are addressed in supplier contracts

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its use of animal welfare certifications, where certifications include, but are not limited to: Animal Welfare Approved, Certified Humane Program, Food Alliance Certified, and Global Animal Partnership 5-Step Animal Welfare Rating Program.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of animal protein sold, by animal protein type, that is produced without medically important antibiotics.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Medically important antibiotics (or “medically important antimicrobial drugs”) are defined according to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) Veterinary Feed Directive (VFD) as all three tiers (“critically important,” “highly important,” and “important”) of antimicrobial drugs listed in Appendix A to its Guidance for Industry (GFI) #152 to be “medically important.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage is calculated as the carcass (or dressed) weight of animal protein purchased that did not receive medically important antibiotics at any stage of its life divided by the total carcass (or dressed) weight of animal protein purchased.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategies to reduce the environmental impacts of packaging, such as optimizing packaging weight and volume for a given application, or using alternative materials, including those that are renewable, recycled, recyclable, or compostable.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging
Technical Protocol: Relevant disclosure may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Design innovations, including strategies to optimize the amount of material used; packaging weight, shape, and size; product-to-package ratio; cube utilization; and void fill
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation of the “Essential Requirements” in Article 9, Annex II of the EU Directive on Packaging and Packaging Waste (94/62/EC), which includes minimization of packaging weight and volume to the amount needed for safety, hygiene, and consumer acceptance of the packed product; minimization of noxious or hazardous constituents; and suitability for reuse, material recycling, energy recovery, or composting
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Performance on the Global Protocol on Packaging Sustainability 2.0 metrics for Packaging Weight and Optimization and/or Assessment and Minimization of Substances Hazardous to the Environment

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its strategies as they relate to primary, secondary, and tertiary packaging of its private-label products as well as the packaging of products from its vendors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Primary packaging is designed to come into direct contact with the product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Secondary packaging is designed to contain one or more primary packages together with any protective materials, where required.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Tertiary packaging is designed to contain one or more articles or packages, or bulk material, for the purposes of transport, handling, and/or distribution. Tertiary packaging is also known as “distribution” or “transport” packaging.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: A private-label product is a store-brand product packaged for sale with a retailer’s brand name, whether manufactured by the retailer or by another manufacturer.

Disclosure Topic: Management of Environmental & Social Impacts in the Supply Chain
Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its use of Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) analysis in the context of its approach to environmental impact reduction and maximization of product efficiency, including weight reduction and transportation efficiency.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: When discussing improvements to the environmental efficiency of packaging products, improvements may be discussed in terms of LCA functional unit service parameters (i.e., time, extent, and quality of function).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was withdrawn from all sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water sources include surface water (including water from wetlands, rivers, lakes, and oceans), groundwater, rainwater collected directly and stored by the entity, and water and wastewater obtained from municipal water supplies, water utilities, or other entities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose portions of its supply by source if, for example, significant portions of withdrawals are from non-freshwater sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fresh water may be defined according to the local laws and regulations where the entity operates. Where there is no legal definition, fresh water shall be considered to be water that has less than 1,000 parts per million of dissolved solids per the U.S. Geological Survey.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Water obtained from a water utility in compliance with U.S. National Primary Drinking Water Regulations can be assumed to meet the definition of fresh water.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was consumed in its operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water consumption is defined as:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall analyze all of its operations for water risks and identify activities that withdraw and consume water in locations with High (40–80 percent) or Extremely High (>80 percent) Baseline Water Stress as classified by the World Resources Institute’s (WRI) Water Risk Atlas tool, Aqueduct.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water withdrawn in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water withdrawn.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water consumed in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water consumed.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its water management risks associated with water withdrawals, water consumption, and discharge of water and/or wastewater.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks associated with water withdrawals and water consumption include risks to the availability of adequate, clean water resources, including, but not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Environmental constraints—such as operating in water-stressed regions, drought, concerns of aquatic impingement or entrainment, interannual or seasonal variability, and risks due to the impact of climate change
• Regulatory and financial constraints—such as volatility in water costs, stakeholder perceptions and concerns related to water withdrawals (e.g., those from local communities, non-governmental organizations, and regulatory agencies), direct competition with and impact from the actions of other users (e.g., commercial and municipal users), restrictions to withdrawals due to regulations, and constraints on the entity’s ability to obtain and retain water rights or permits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Risks associated with the discharge of water and/or wastewater, include, but are not limited to, the ability to obtain rights or permits related to discharges, compliance with regulations related to discharges, restrictions to discharges, the ability to maintain control over the temperature of water discharges, liabilities and/or reputational risks, and increased operating costs due to regulation, stakeholder perceptions and concerns related to water discharges (e.g., those from local communities, non-governmental organizations, and regulatory agencies).

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe water management risks in the context of:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: How risks may vary by withdrawal source, including surface water (including water from wetlands, rivers, lakes, and oceans), groundwater, rainwater collected directly and stored by the entity, and water and wastewater obtained from municipal water supplies, water utilities, or other entities; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: How risks may vary by discharge destinations, including surface water, groundwater, or wastewater utilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the potential impacts that water management risks may have on its operations and the timeline over which such risks are expected to manifest.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Impacts may include, but are not limited to, those associated with costs, revenues, liabilities, continuity of operations, and reputation.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its short-term and long-term strategies or plan to mitigate water management risks, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of its strategy, plans, goals and/or targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or water-consuming operational processes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Any water management goals and/or targets it has prioritized, and an analysis of performance against those goals and/or targets.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Goals and targets may include, but are not limited to, those associated with reducing water withdrawals, reducing water consumption, reducing water discharges, reducing aquatic impingements, improving the quality of water discharges, and regulatory compliance.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The activities and investments required to achieve the plans, goals and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Disclosure of strategies, plans, goals, and/or targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: For water management targets, the entity shall additionally disclose:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Whether the target is absolute or intensity-based, and the metric denominator if it is an intensity-based target.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The timelines for the water management plans, including the start year, the target year, and the base year.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The percentage reduction or improvement from the base year, where the base year is the first year against which water management targets are evaluated toward the achievement of the target.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its water management practices result in any additional lifecycle impacts or tradeoffs in its organization, including tradeoffs in land use, energy production, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and why the entity chose these practices despite lifecycle tradeoffs.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with water quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of instances of non-compliance, including violations of a technology-based standard and exceedances of quantity and/or quality-based standards.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with water quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents governed by national, state, and local statutory permits and regulations, including, but not limited to, the discharge of a hazardous substance, violation of pretreatment requirements, or total maximum daily load (TMDL) exceedances.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with water quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall only include incidents of non-compliance that resulted in a formal enforcement action(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Formal enforcement actions are defined as governmental actions that address a violation or threatened violation of water quantity and/or quality laws, regulations, policies, or orders, and can result in administrative penalty orders, administrative orders, and judicial actions, among others. For example, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides guidance on the scope of formal enforcement actions in, Informal and Formal Actions, Summary Guidance and Portrayal on EPA Websites.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with water quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: Violations shall be disclosed, regardless of their measurement methodology or frequency. These include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Continuous discharges, limitations, standards, and prohibitions that are generally expressed as maximum daily, weekly average, and monthly averages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-continuous discharges and limitations that are generally expressed in terms of frequency, total mass, maximum rate of discharge, and mass or concentration of specified pollutants.

Accounting Metric: Amount of animal litter and manure generated, percentage managed according to a nutrient management plan
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount, in metric tons, of animal litter and manure generated at its facilities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of animal litter and manure includes both dry and liquid manures and litter.

Accounting Metric: Amount of animal litter and manure generated, percentage managed according to a nutrient management plan
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of animal litter and manure generated from facilities that implement a nutrient management plan divided by the total amount of animal litter and manure generated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A nutrient management plan is defined as a documented management practice that addresses the generation, collection, treatment, storage, and agronomic use of all manure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: At a minimum, the nutrient management plan shall meet the minimum specific elements of the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) Comprehensive Nutrient Management Plan (CNMP), which include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Background and Site Information
• Manure and Wastewater Handling and Storage
• Farmstead Safety and Security
• Land Treatment Practices
• Soil and Risk Assessment Analyses
• Nutrient Management according to the criteria in the Nutrient Management Conservation Practice (Code 590)
• Recordkeeping
• References

Accounting Metric: Amount of animal litter and manure generated, percentage managed according to a nutrient management plan
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes facilities that the entity owns and operates, facilities from which it contracts animal production (e.g., independent producers), and facilities that otherwise supply animal protein to the entity (e.g., for processing by the entity).

Accounting Metric: Amount of animal litter and manure generated, percentage managed according to a nutrient management plan
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes production areas and land treatment areas.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Production area includes the animal confinement area, storage areas for feed and other raw materials, animal mortality facilities, and manure-handling containment or storage areas.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Land treatment area includes land under control of the entity and/or its contracted suppliers (e.g., independent producers), whether it is owned, rented, or leased, to which manure or process wastewater is, or might be, applied for crop, hay, or pasture production or other uses.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of pasture and grazing land managed to Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) conservation plan criteria
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of pasture and grazing land that is managed to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) conservation plan criteria.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Land shall be considered to be managed to NRCS conservation plan criteria if its management follows the planning process described by the National Planning Procedures Handbook and management practices outlined in the National Range and Pasture Handbook (NRPH), USDA NRCS, Grazing Lands Technology Institute Revision 1, December 2003.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the area of pasture and grazing land managed to NRCS conservation plan criteria divided by the total area of pasture and grazing land.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of pasture and grazing land managed to Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) conservation plan criteria
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes land defined by the NRPH as rangeland, which includes grazed forest, naturalized pasture, pastureland, hayland, and grazed and hayed cropland.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes land from operations that the entity owns and operates, operations with which it contracts animal production (e.g., independent producers), and operations that otherwise supply animal protein to the entity (e.g., for processing by the entity).

Accounting Metric: Animal protein production from concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of animal protein production from concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: CAFOs are defined according to U.S. 40 CFR 40, Part 122.23, “Concentrated animal feeding operations.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The amount shall be calculated as the carcass (or dressed) weight of animal protein.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Carcass is defined according to U.S. 9 CFR 301.2 as all parts, including viscera, of any slaughtered livestock.

Accounting Metric: Animal protein production from concentrated animal feeding operations (CAFOs)
Technical Protocol: The scope includes animal protein from operations that the entity owns and operates, operations with which it contracts animal production (e.g., independent producers), and operations that otherwise supply animal protein to the entity (e.g., for processing by the entity).

Accounting Metric: Global Food Safety Initiative (GFSI) audit (1) non-conformance rate and (2) associated corrective action rate for (a) major and (b) minor non-conformances
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its facilities' (1) non-conformance rates with Global Food Safety Initiative (GFSI) recognized food safety certification programs for (a) major non-conformances, and separately, (b) minor non-conformances.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A major non-conformance is defined by the relevant GFSI-recognized certification program and includes the highest severity of non-conformances and required escalation by auditors. Major non-conformances may arise from a significant risk to food safety, non-compliance with relevant regulatory requirements, and/or failure to adequately address prior minor non-conformances. Major non-conformances must be corrected in accordance with the relevant GFSI-recognized certification program under audit.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A minor non-conformance is defined by the relevant GFSI-recognized certification program and is by itself not indicative of a systemic problem.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the non-conformance rates as the total number of non-conformances (in each respective category) identified among its facilities divided by the number of facilities audited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure includes audit results from facilities that are owned and/or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Global Food Safety Initiative (GFSI) audit (1) non-conformance rate and (2) associated corrective action rate for (a) major and (b) minor non-conformances
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the (2) corrective action rates associated with its facilities’ (a) major non-conformances, and separately, (b) minor non-conformances.
