Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of restaurants that were inspected at least once by a food safety oversight body during the reporting period divided by the total number of restaurants in operation during the reporting year.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of restaurants inspected by a food safety oversight body, (2) percentage receiving critical violations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its inspected restaurants that received critical violations from a food safety oversight body.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical violation is defined as any violation issued by a food safety oversight body that, if left uncorrected, directly relate to the transmission of foodborne illnesses, the adulteration of food products, and/or the contamination of food-contact surfaces.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of inspected restaurants that received critical violations during the reporting period divided by the total number of restaurants that were inspected at least once by a food safety oversight body during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of restaurants inspected by a food safety oversight body, (2) percentage receiving critical violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include both company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of restaurants inspected by a food safety oversight body, (2) percentage receiving critical violations
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its approach to assuring food safety in its operations in regions where inspections are not routinely conducted.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls issued and (2) total amount of food product recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of food safety-related recalls issued.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A food safety-related recall is defined as removal of a marketed product that occurs when there is reason to believe that a food may cause consumers to become ill.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls issued and (2) total amount of food product recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total amount, in metric tons, of food product subject to recalls.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls issued and (2) total amount of food product recalled
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes voluntary recalls initiated by the entity and involuntary recalls requested and/or mandated by regulatory authorities [e.g., China Food and Drug Administration (CFDA) and U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)].

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls issued and (2) total amount of food product recalled
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include both company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of recalls issued and (2) total amount of food product recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of recalls that were voluntarily issued and the percentage of recalls that were involuntarily issued.

Accounting Metric: Number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks, percentage resulting in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) investigation
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of incidents of confirmed foodborne illness outbreak associated with its restaurants.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Foodborne illness is defined as sickness resulting from different disease-causing microbes or pathogens, poisonous chemicals, or other toxins that can contaminate foods.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Foodborne illness outbreak is defined as two or more cases of foodborne illness occurring during a limited period of time with the same organism, and that are associated with either the same food-service operation, such as a restaurant, or the same food product.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • In the case of botulism, a single case is considered an outbreak due to the severity of the illness and the possibility that a source food may cause others to become seriously ill.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks are defined as those that were investigated by national, state, local, and/or regional public health officials and found to be valid cases of foodborne illness outbreak.

Accounting Metric: Number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks, percentage resulting in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) investigation
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks that resulted in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) investigation.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Outbreaks that resulted in investigation by the U.S. CDC may include those that involve large numbers of people, severe or unusual illness, or widespread outbreaks that affect many states at once.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope excludes those investigations that were conducted exclusively at the local or state level and successfully concluded.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage is calculated as the total number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks that reached the level of severity resulting in U.S. CDC investigation divided by the total number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks that occurred within the U.S. CDC’s jurisdiction.

Accounting Metric: Number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks, percentage resulting in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) investigation
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include both company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: Number of confirmed foodborne illness outbreaks, percentage resulting in U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) investigation
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe its approach to ensuring food safety in its restaurants.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant discussion include, but is not limited to internal food safety audits, implementation of the Council to Improve Foodborne Outbreak Response (CIFOR) Foodborne Illness Response Guidelines for Owners, Operators, and Managers of Food Establishments, or other measures to assure compliance with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) Food Code or equivalent national guidelines (e.g., EU General Principles of Food Law or Chinese National Food Safety Standards).

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of meal options that are consistent with applicable national dietary guidelines.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: National dietary guidelines include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Dietary Guidelines for Americans
• Dietary Guidelines for Chinese Residents
• EU Food-Based Dietary Guidelines
• Other guidelines provided by national governmental agencies or regulators that contain daily nutritional values and are substantially equivalent to the guidelines referenced above.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A meal option is defined as an entrée, side, and beverage for limited service restaurants and an entrée and a beverage for full service restaurants.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• The entity shall use menu items that are commonly paired together by customers, advertised together as combinations, or are placed together as a specially promoted meal combination to determine possible meal combinations.
• For restaurants where choices are generally à la carte, the entity shall use a consistent approach for calculating meal options using menu items generally paired together as meals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall use the nutritional content for the standard menu items that are served to the customer by default, without a request for item or ingredient substitutes or additions, to calculate the nutritional content of a meal option.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The percentage is calculated as the number of possible combinations of meal options that are consistent with one-third of the daily nutritional values in the applicable national dietary guidelines divided by the total number of possible combinations of meal options offered by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) its revenue from the combinations of meal options that are consistent with the applicable national dietary guidelines.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include both company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: If meal options in a portion of an entity’s operations are not tracked in such a manner that allows for precise measurement, estimation is acceptable.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In such a case, the entity shall disclose the estimation methodology used to calculate the sales of combinations of meal options, and the percentage of operations for which it was employed.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of children’s meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines for children and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of children’s meal options that are consistent with applicable national dietary guidelines for children.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A children’s meal option is one that is directly targeted at children aged 2-11 years old.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: National dietary guidelines for children are defined as international, national, regional, or industry guidelines or criteria developed to promote healthy diets among children. National dietary guidelines for children include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• China National Dietary Guideline for School Children
• EU Food and Nutrition Policy for Schools 
• U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Nutrition Standards in the National School Lunch and School Breakfast Programs 
• Other guidelines provided by national governmental agencies or regulators that contain daily nutritional values for children and are substantially equivalent to the guidelines referenced above
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: A meal option is defined as an entrée, side, and beverage for limited service restaurants and an entrée and a beverage for full service restaurants.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• The entity shall use menu items that are commonly paired together by customers, advertised together as combinations, or are placed together as a specially promoted meal combination to determine possible meal combinations.
• For restaurants where choices are generally à la carte, the entity shall use a consistent approach for calculating meal options using menu items generally paired together as meals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The entity shall use the nutritional content for the standard menu items that are served to the customer by default, without a request for item or ingredient substitutes or additions, to calculate the nutritional content of a meal option.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The percentage is calculated as the number of possible combinations of meal options that are consistent with one-third of the daily nutritional values in the applicable national dietary guidelines divided by the total number of possible combinations of meal options offered by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of children’s meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines for children and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) its revenue from the combinations of meal options that are consistent with the applicable national dietary guidelines for children.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of children’s meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines for children and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include sales from both company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Percentage of children’s meal options consistent with national dietary guidelines for children and (2) revenue from these options
Technical Protocol: If children’s meal options in a portion of an entity’s operations are not tracked in such a manner that allows for precise measurement, estimation is acceptable.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In such a case, the entity shall disclose the estimation methodology used to calculate the sales of combinations of children’s meal options, and the percentage of operations for which it was employed.

Accounting Metric: Number of advertising impressions made on children, percentage promoting products that meet national dietary guidelines for children
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of advertising impressions made on children.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An advertising impression is a measure of the number of times an advertisement is seen, heard, watched, or read.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Advertising impressions include, but are not limited to, those made through media such as television, radio, print, the Internet (company-owned and third-party websites), mobile apps, interactive games (including advergames), video games, computer games, DVDs and other video formats, word-of-mouth, and licensed characters, celebrity and movie tie-ins.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Children are defined as age 12 and under.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The number of advertising impressions made on children is calculated as the expected share of children in the audience (viewers, listeners, readers, or visitors) at the time of the media buy multiplied by the expected total number of advertising impressions made, regardless of whether the advertising is primarily directed to children.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • The number of advertising impressions made on children shall be calculated regardless of whether the expected share of children in the audience is above or below any quantitative thresholds used to determine whether the advertising is primarily directed to children. For example, the 35% threshold used in the Children’s Food and Beverage Initiative (CFBAI) Program and Core Principles Statement, 4th Edition , is not applicable to the above calculation of advertising impressions made on children.

Accounting Metric: Number of advertising impressions made on children, percentage promoting products that meet national dietary guidelines for children
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of advertising impressions made on children that promote products which meet national dietary guidelines for children.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: National dietary guidelines for children are defined as international, national, regional, or industry guidelines or criteria developed to promote healthy diets among children. National dietary guidelines for children include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• China National Dietary Guideline for School Children
• EU Food and Nutrition Policy for Schools 
• U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Nutrition Standards in the National School Lunch and School Breakfast Programs 
• Other guidelines provided by national governmental agencies or regulators that contain daily nutritional values for children and are substantially equivalent to the guidelines referenced above
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage is calculated as the number of advertising impressions made on children that promote products that national dietary guidelines for children divided by the total number of advertising impressions made on children.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for restaurant employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the voluntary employee turnover rate for restaurant employees as a percentage.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Restaurants employees are defined as employees that work on-site at a restaurant.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the voluntary turnover rate as the total number of employee-initiated voluntary separations (e.g., resignations, retirement) during the reporting period, divided by the total number of employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for restaurant employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the (2) the involuntary employee turnover rate for restaurant employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the involuntary turnover rate as the total number of entity-initiated separations (e.g., dismissal, downsizing, redundancy, non-renewal of contract) during the reporting period, divided by the total number of employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for restaurant employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes entity-owned restaurants.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for restaurant employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes franchise restaurants.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for restaurant employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes corporate staff and executives.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage, by region and (2) percentage of restaurant employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the average hourly wage paid to restaurant employees for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Restaurant employees are defined as non-manager employees earning an hourly wage at company-owned and franchise locations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the average hourly wage as the total wages, including tips but excluding overtime pay, paid to restaurant employees for the reporting period divided by the number of regular hours worked, excluding overtime hours, by restaurant employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage, by region and (2) percentage of restaurant employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of restaurant employees that earn minimum wage before tips.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Minimum wage is defined as the locally mandated minimum wage applicable for each employee.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For countries or regions with no minimum wage requirement, the 10th percentile hourly wage of all wage earners in that country or region shall be used.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the percentage by dividing the number of restaurant employees that earn minimum wage by the total number of restaurant employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage, by region and (2) percentage of restaurant employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes salaried and corporate employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage, by region and (2) percentage of restaurant employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the average prevailing minimum wage, weighted on an hours-worked basis, for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial reporting.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage, by region and (2) percentage of restaurant employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the sensitivity of its costs and profit margins to future adjustments in minimum wage, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The likelihood of a minimum wage increase in the regions where the entity operates, and the regions in which this is more likely to occur
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage of its current in-store and distribution center employees whose salaries are near the current minimum wage, and whose salaries may necessitate an increase given a change in minimum wage regulations
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The magnitude of the financial impact that a minimum wage increase would likely have on the entity

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Labor violation is defined as violations including, but not limited to, those relating to wages, work hours, overtime, and meal and rest breaks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Employment discrimination is defined as discrimination on the basis of age, disability, compensation, genetic information, harassment, national origin, pregnancy, race/color, religion, retaliation, sex, and sexual harassment.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with (1) labor law violations and (2) employment discrimination
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Americans with Disabilities Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Equal Pay Act of 1963
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: U.S. Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: U.S. Pregnancy Discrimination Act (PDA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: U.S. Rehabilitation Act of 1973
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: U.S. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

Accounting Metric: Percentage of food purchased that (1) meets environmental and social sourcing standards and (2) is certified to third-party environmental and/or social standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of food purchased that meets both environmental and social sourcing standards.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental standards are defined as standards that address environmental impacts related to food production such as, protection of natural resources and improvements in resource efficiency.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Social standards are defined as standards that address social impacts related to food production such as, treatment of workers and community, animal health and welfare, and food quality and safety.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated as the cost of food (and food products) purchased that meets environmental and social standards divided by the total cost of food (and food products) purchased.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of environmental and/or social standards includes programs, guidelines, best practices, criteria, codes of conduct, and certifications that are developed internally, through industry initiatives, or by third-parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Examples of environmental and social sourcing standards include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5:
• Global Roundtable for Sustainable Beef Principles & Criteria for Defining Global Sustainable Beef 
• IDH Sustainability Initiative Fruits and Vegetables (SIFAV) 
• Sustainable Agriculture Initiative (SAI) Platform, Principles & Practices for Dairy Farming, Sustainable Fruit Production, Sustainable Green Coffee Production, and Sustainable Production of Arable & Vegetable Crops

Accounting Metric: Percentage of food purchased that (1) meets environmental and social sourcing standards and (2) is certified to third-party environmental and/or social standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of food purchased that has been certified to a third-party environmental and/or social standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the cost of food (and food products) purchased that has been certified to a third-party environmental and/or social standard divided by the total cost of food (and food products) purchased.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of certifications to third-party environmental and social standards include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Fairtrade International
• Fair Trade USA
• Marine Stewardship Council
• Rainforest Alliance Certified
• Roundtable on Responsible Soy (RTRS)
• Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO)

Accounting Metric: Percentage of food purchased that (1) meets environmental and social sourcing standards and (2) is certified to third-party environmental and/or social standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall generally indicate which third-party environmental and social standards it uses.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) eggs that originated from a cage-free environment and (2) pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of eggs purchased that originated from a cage-free environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Eggs that originated from a cage-free environment are produced by hens housed in a building, room, or area that allows for unlimited access to food, water, and provides the freedom to roam within the area during the laying cycle.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The scope also includes eggs that originated from a free-range environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of eggs purchased that originated from a cage-free environment divided by the total number of eggs purchased.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) eggs that originated from a cage-free environment and (2) pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A gestation crate is defined as an enclosure for housing an individual breeding sow, where the enclosure fulfills the animal’s static space requirements but does not allow for dynamic movement, such as turning around, and is typically non-bedded, with concrete floors and metal stalls.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of pork purchased that was produced without the use of gestation crates divided by the total weight of pork purchased.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Weight of production shall be calculated using carcass weight or retail weight (where the entity has sourced pork or pork products that have already been processed).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) eggs that originated from a cage-free environment and (2) pork that was produced without the use of gestation crates
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include eggs and pork purchased for company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategic approach to managing its environmental and social risks that are present within, or arise out of, its food and food products supply chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental and social risks may include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Impacts on crop and livestock production due to climate change (e.g., changing average temperatures and water stress) that may affect cost and availability of produce, meat, poultry, dairy, and processed foods products
• Animal feed price increases resulting from environmental and social factors and/or tightening environmental regulations that may have price impacts on meat, poultry, and dairy
• Fuel economy regulations that affect transportation costs
• Labor rights and immigration reforms that affect food prices and availability
• International trade barriers and/or varying levels of food safety oversight in a global market
• Commercial catch limits that could affect the supply of seafood products
• Animal welfare, human rights, or related supply chain incidents that may result in reputational damage
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant strategies to discuss may include, but are not limited to, supplier screening, diversification of suppliers, supplier training programs on environmental best management practices, supplier engagement on labor and human rights issues, and maintenance of a supply chain code of conduct, supply chain audits, and certifications.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity may identify which products or product lines present risks to its operations, the risks that are represented, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate such risks.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its animal welfare standards applicable to its supply chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Animal welfare standards are defined as policies for beef, pork, poultry, and/or dairy production conditions, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Animal treatment and handling
• Housing and transportation conditions
• Slaughter facilities and procedures
• Use of antibiotics and hormones
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Any targets the entity has related to animal welfare standards and its progress toward those targets
• Any requirements for suppliers related to animal welfare standards
• How, if in any way, animal welfare standards are addressed in supplier contracts

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its use of animal welfare certifications, where certifications include, but are not limited to: Animal Welfare Approved, Certified Humane Program, Food Alliance Certified, and Global Animal Partnership 5-Step Animal Welfare Rating Program.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage environmental and social risks within the supply chain, including animal welfare
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of animal protein sold, by animal protein type, that is produced without medically important antibiotics.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Medically important antibiotics (or “medically important antimicrobial drugs”) are defined according to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) Veterinary Feed Directive (VFD) as all three tiers (“critically important,” “highly important,” and “important”) of antimicrobial drugs listed in Appendix A to its Guidance for Industry (GFI) #152 to be “medically important.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage is calculated as the carcass (or dressed) weight of animal protein purchased that did not receive medically important antibiotics at any stage of its life divided by the total carcass (or dressed) weight of animal protein purchased.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross revenue and (2) revenue net of excise taxes from (a) non-tobacco nicotine products and (b) heated tobacco products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) gross revenue from (a) non-tobacco nicotine products, and separately, (b) heated tobacco products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Non-tobacco nicotine products are defined as products that deliver nicotine to users, but do not contain tobacco, including, but not limited to, electronic cigarettes, electronic vaporizers, and pharmaceutical nicotine-replacement therapy products (e.g., gums, lozenges, and patches).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Heated tobacco products are defined as non-combustible, tobacco products that deliver nicotine to users through a heating device.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Gross revenue is defined as total sales revenue including excise and sales taxes.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross revenue and (2) revenue net of excise taxes from (a) non-tobacco nicotine products and (b) heated tobacco products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) revenue net of excise taxes from (a) non-tobacco nicotine products and (b) heated tobacco products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Revenue net of excise taxes is calculated as total sales revenue less the corresponding local, state, and federal excise tax.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to assess risks and opportunities associated with "tobacco harm reduction" products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its process to assess risks and opportunities associated with “tobacco harm reduction” products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: “Tobacco harm reduction” products deliver nicotine through alternative sources with reduced exposure to harmful chemicals as compared to combustible tobacco products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: “Tobacco harm reduction” products may include, but are not limited to, nicotine-replacement therapy products, non-tobacco nicotine products including electronic cigarettes and electronic vaporizers, and heated tobacco products.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to assess risks and opportunities associated with "tobacco harm reduction" products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope, success, and growth plans related to its current “tobacco harm reduction” product portfolio and, where relevant, its plans to introduce future products and product categories.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to assess risks and opportunities associated with "tobacco harm reduction" products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss risks it faces related to its “tobacco harm reduction” products, such as technical challenges with bringing the products to market, consumer and public perceptions of the safety of the products, regulatory risks, reputational risks, and other risks.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to assess risks and opportunities associated with "tobacco harm reduction" products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss opportunities presented by “tobacco harm reduction” products such as the ability to capture new market segments and the ability to contribute to reducing cigarette smoking.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of the process to assess risks and opportunities associated with "tobacco harm reduction" products
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity shall discuss whether risks and opportunities associated with its “tobacco harm reduction” products and strategies pertain differently to different product segments and/or geographic markets.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing, labeling, and/or advertising practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and/or labeling practices, such as those related to enforcement of laws and regulations on nutrient content claims, health claims, other unfair or deceptive claims, and/or misbranded labeling.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing, labeling, and/or advertising practices
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing, labeling, and/or advertising practices
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing, labeling, and/or advertising practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing, labeling, and/or advertising practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: EU Tobacco Advertising Directive
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Family Smoking Prevention and Tobacco Control Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Tobacco Master Settlement Agreement

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its marketing policy and relevant positions on Article 11: Packaging and labelling of tobacco products, and Article 13: Tobacco advertising, promotion, and sponsorship of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC).

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its marketing policy and relevant positions on WHO FCTC Article 11 related to packaging and labeling practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Usage of terms such as “low tar,” “light,” “ultra light,” “mild,” or other terms, descriptors, trademarks, figures, or signs that directly or indirectly imply that a particular tobacco product is less harmful than other tobacco products
• Design and positioning of product health warnings and messages that meet “Effective Packaging and Labelling Requirements” outlined in Article 11 of the WHO FCTC and defined by relevant national authorities, including the location, size, use of pictorials, color, message content, language, source attribution, and the regular rotation of health warnings and messages
• Product packaging and labeling information on the relevant constituents and emissions of tobacco products

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its marketing policy and relevant positions on WHO FCTC Article 13 related to direct tobacco advertising, promotion, and sponsorship (TAPS) practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Communication through audio, visual or audiovisual means including print (newspaper, magazines, or signs), television, radio, films, DVDs, videos and CDs, games (computer games, video games or online games), theater, or other live performances
• Outdoor displays (including billboards and signage on transit vehicles and in transit stations)
• Point-of-sale advertising, signage, and product displays in retail stores
• Other digital communication platforms, including the Internet and mobile phones

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its marketing policy and relevant positions on WHO FCTC Article 13 related to the entity’s marketing policy on indirect TAPS practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Free distribution of tobacco and related products in the mail or through other means
• Promotional discounts
• “Brand stretching”— connecting a tobacco brand name with non-tobacco products or services, which likely associates the products and/or services
• “Brand sharing” — connecting a non-tobacco brand name with tobacco products or services, which likely promotes a tobacco product or tobacco use either directly or indirectly
• Placement of tobacco products and/or tobacco brand names in television, films, and other audiovisual entertainment products, including on the Internet
• Tobacco company-sponsored events, including “corporate social responsibility” programs

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall apply to the entity’s practices globally.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall describe any materially different practices that it employs in different markets.

Accounting Metric: Description of the company’s marketing policy and relevant positions on Articles 11 and 13 of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (WHO FCTC)
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe instances and/or geographies where its marketing policies are not aligned with the WHO FCTC.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: Covered employees are defined as the entity's employees subject to filing the following forms:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Form U4 (Uniform Application for Securities Industry Registration or Transfer) with the Central Registration Depository (CRD) of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Form U5 (Uniform Termination Notice for Securities Industry Registration) with the CRD of the FINRA
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Form U6 (Uniform Disciplinary Action Reporting Form) with the CRD of the FINRA
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Form BD (Uniform Application for Broker-Dealer Registration) with the Investment Adviser Registration Depository (IARD) of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Form BDW (Uniform Request for Broker-Dealer Withdrawal) with the IARD of the SEC

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include all covered employees that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period in the calculation.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: Investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, and other regulatory proceedings include those disclosed by a covered employee on Form U4 in section 14, Form U5 in section 7, Form U6, Form BD, or Form BDW.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings by dividing the numerator by the denominator, using the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In the numerator, the entity shall include the number of covered employees that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • In instances where the first investment-related investigation, consumer-initiated complaint, private civil litigation, or other regulatory proceeding involving the covered employee occurs at the time of employment with the entity, and when the instance requires filing an update to the aforementioned forms, the entity shall include these covered employees in the numerator.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: In the denominator, the entity shall include the number of covered employees that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of financial product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with the lack of information transparency, including those related to false advertising, lack of transparency in small print, marketing to vulnerable groups (e.g., small investors), transparency of fees, mis-selling products, overcharging clients, and legal responsibility of the firm with respect to transparent information and fair advice.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes the Rules of the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA), including, but not limited to, rules 2210 and 2211.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of financial product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of financial product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of financial product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to informing customers about its products and services, including the focus on transparency of the content, communication method, frequency of communication, and responsibility for communication.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: Relevant content includes, but is not limited to, topics such as risk, suitability, investment alternatives, and the disclosure of conflicts of interest.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant risks include those related to complex or high-yield products that may be subject to volatility, credit risk exposure, sensitivity to interest rates, liquidity concerns, or otherwise may be misaligned with client risk tolerance.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant aspects of suitability are those addressed in the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority’s (FINRA) suitability rules, where entities “and their associated persons must have a reasonable basis to believe” that a transaction or investment strategy involving securities that they recommend as suitable for the customer. This reasonable belief must be based on the information obtained through the reasonable due diligence of the firm or associated person to ascertain the customer’s investment profile.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Relevant conflicts of interest include those related to services (e.g., research) paid for by clients’ commissions, the allocation of trades among clients, and rules for the entity's employees’ personal accounts (PAs).

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe compliance with industry best practices, including codes of conduct and codes of ethics, as a measure of its management approach to ensuring high Standards of Commercial Honor and Principles of Trade and Communications and Disclosures according to sections 2010 and 2200 of the FINRA manual.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how its representatives’ compensation structures are linked to incentives for sales of specific products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to, any direct linkages between employees’ compensation and incentives for sales of specific products, which may include changes in fixed salaries, bonuses and other awards, and targets for volumes or quantities in sales of certain products or services.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of total compensation that is variable and directly linked to sales targets for the relevant pool of employees.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe communication methods it uses to provide information about its products and services to current and prospective clients.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Communication methods include, but are not limited to, client statements, supplemental brochures, product prospectuses, website listings, or verbal communications.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the style of communication it uses, such as the use of legal disclaimers in plain English.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: When necessary, the entity shall describe differences in communication strategies, content, or method between retail customers and institutional clients.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to informing customers about products and services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how its communication strategy is developed and executed, including, but not limited to, internal controls the entity has in place to ensure compliance with its communication strategy.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose gender representation for all employees and racial/ethnic group representation for its U.S. employees by employee category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The following employee categories shall be used: (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: Gender and racial/ethnic group representation shall be disclosed in percentages, where the percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in each gender or racial/ethnic group in each employee category divided by the total number of employees in the respective employee category.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet, where each employee category for disclosure is defined by corresponding job categories and descriptions in the Instruction Booklet:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Executive management includes Executives/Senior Level Officials and Managers: individuals who plan, direct and formulate policies, set strategy and provide the overall direction of enterprises/organizations for the development and delivery of products or services, within the parameters approved by boards of directors or other governing bodies. Residing in the highest levels of organizations, these executives plan, direct or coordinate activities with the support of subordinate executives and staff managers. They include, in larger organizations, those individuals within two reporting levels of the CEO, whose responsibilities require frequent interaction with the CEO. Examples of these kinds of managers are: chief executive officers, chief operating officers, chief financial officers, line of business heads, presidents or executive vice presidents of functional areas or operating groups, chief information officers, chief human resources officers, chief marketing officers, chief legal officers, management directors and managing partners.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-executive management includes First/Mid-Level Officials and Managers: individuals who serve as managers, other than those who serve as Executive/Senior Level Officials and Managers, including those who oversee and direct the delivery of products, services or functions at group, regional or divisional levels of organizations. These managers receive directions from the Executive/Senior Level management and typically lead major business units. They implement policies, programs and directives of executive/senior management through subordinate managers and within the parameters set by Executive/Senior Level management. Examples of these kinds of managers are: vice presidents and directors, group, regional or divisional controllers; treasurers; human resources, information systems, marketing, and operations managers. The First/Mid-Level Officials and Managers subcategory also includes those who report directly to middle managers. These individuals serve at functional, line of business segment or branch levels and are responsible for directing and executing the day-to-day operational objectives of enterprises/organizations, conveying the directions of higher level officials and managers to subordinate personnel and, in some instances, directly supervising the activities of exempt and non-exempt personnel. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Professionals is defined as the following: most jobs in this category require bachelor and graduate degrees, and/or professional certification. In some instances, comparable experience may establish a person’s qualifications. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: All other employees includes those employees who are not classified as executive management, non-executive management, or professionals.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For non-U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in a manner generally consistent with the definitions provided above, though in accordance with, and further facilitated by, any applicable local regulations, guidance, or generally accepted definitions.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the gender of its employees as female, male, or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the racial/ethnic group of its U.S. employees in accordance with the EEO-1 Survey Instruction Booklet and use the following categories: Asian, Black or African American, Hispanic or Latino, White, Other (which includes Native American or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, and “Two or More Races” classifications), or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental disclosures on gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by country or region.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental contextual disclosures on factors that significantly influence gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation, such as the country or region where employees are located.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by employee category in the following table formats:

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Amount of assets under management, by asset class, that employ (1) integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, (2) sustainability themed investing, and (3) screening
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of assets under managements (AUM), that employ (1) integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, (2) sustainability themed investing, and (3) screening.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: AUM shall be defined broadly as per Section 203A of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 Section 203A as, “the securities portfolios with respect to which an adviser provides continuous and regular supervisory or management services.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Integration of ESG issues is defined as the systematic and explicit inclusion of material ESG factors into investment analysis and investment decisions, as aligned with the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Sustainability themed investing is defined as investment in themes or assets specifically related to sustainability (for example clean energy, green technology or sustainable agriculture), as aligned with the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Screening, including (a) negative/exclusionary, (b) positive/best-in-class, and (c) norms-based, is defined by the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The scope of disclosure includes both passive and active strategies.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Amount of assets under management, by asset class, that employ (1) integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, (2) sustainability themed investing, and (3) screening
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down its disclosure by asset class: (a) equities, (b) fixed income, (c) cash equivalents/money market instruments, and (d) other (e.g., real estate and commodities).

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Amount of assets under management, by asset class, that employ (1) integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, (2) sustainability themed investing, and (3) screening
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify and disclose the amount of any AUM managed using more than one ESG integration strategy (e.g., screening and integration).

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in its investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The definition of incorporation of ESG factors is aligned with that of the Global Sustainable Investment Alliance (GSIA) and includes the use of ESG information in investment decision-making processes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of ESG factors/issues are provided in the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018, section “ESG issues.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Incorporation of ESG factors include the following approaches, consistent with the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Screening, including (a) negative/exclusionary, (b) positive/best-in-class, and (c) norms-based
• Sustainability themed investment, defined as investment in themes or assets specifically related to sustainability (for example clean energy, green technology or sustainable agriculture)
• Integration of ESG, defined as the systematic and explicit inclusion of material ESG factors into investment analysis and investment decisions
• A combination of the above

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: When relevant, the entity shall discuss its approach to incorporation of ESG factors in selecting external fund managers and fiduciary managers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall describe its oversight/accountability approach to assessing the quality of incorporation of ESG factors by external fund managers and fiduciary managers, which includes, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Formal oversight individuals and/or bodies involved
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Criteria used in assessing the quality of ESG incorporation

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include investment and/or wealth management services where the entity maintains decision-making power, regardless of strategy and asset class.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall exclude execution and/or advisory services where investment decision-making power remains with clients.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: When relevant, the description of the entity’s approach to incorporation of ESG factors in its investment and/or wealth management activities shall be broken down by asset class or by style employed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to, the differences in the entity’s approaches to incorporation of ESG factors in:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Public equity, fixed income, private equity, or alternative asset classes
• Passive versus active investment strategies
• Fundamental, quantitative, and technical analyses of investments

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe policies that determine its approach to incorporation of ESG factors in its investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall exclude discussion of the entity’s proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures, which is included in metric FN-AC-410a.3, “Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures.”

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to implementation of the aspects of the entity’s ESG incorporation practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Parties responsible for day-to-day incorporation of ESG factors
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Approach to conducting ESG-related research
• Approach to incorporating ESG factors into investment strategies

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its oversight/accountability approach to the incorporation of ESG factors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Formal oversight individuals and/or bodies involved
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Criteria used in assessing the quality of ESG incorporation

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether it conducts scenario analysis and/or modeling in which the risk profile of future ESG trends is calculated at the portfolio level.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ESG trends include, but are not limited to, climate change, natural resource constraints, human capital risks and opportunities, and cybersecurity risks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall describe the types of portfolios and/or strategies where it executes scenario analysis and/or modeling.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The entity is not required to provide such disclosure at the individual portfolio and/or strategy level.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss ESG trends that it views as broadly applicable in terms of their impact on sectors and industries as well as the trends it views as sector- or industry-specific.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe whether it incorporates ESG factors in strategic asset allocation and/or allocation of assets between sectors or geographic markets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall describe the types of portfolios and/or strategies where it incorporates ESG factors in strategic asset allocation and/or allocation of assets between sectors or geographic markets.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The entity is not required to provide such disclosure at the individual portfolio and/or strategy level.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment and/or wealth management processes and strategies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how ESG factors are incorporated in the assessment of and influence the entity’s views on:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Time horizon of investments
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Risk and return profiles of investments
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Traditional fundamental factors such as economic conditions, central bank policy, industry trends, and geopolitical risks

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to proxy voting, including, but not limited to, its process for making proxy voting decisions, including its approach to defining materiality.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to, elements highlighted in the PRI’s Reporting Framework for Direct – Listed Equity Active Ownership:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The scope of the entity’s voting activities
• The objectives of the entity’s voting activities
• How, if at all, the entity’s voting approach differs among markets
• Whether the entity has a default position of voting in favor of management in particular markets or on particular issues
• Whether and how local regulatory or other requirements influence the entity’s approach to voting
• Whether the entity votes by proxy or in person by attending annual general meetings (AGMs) (or a combination of both)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall describe its approach to determining support for proposals, including its approach to defining materiality.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The scope of disclosure includes proposals addressing Environmental and Social (ES) issues
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall describe how it communicates its proxy voting policy to clients as well as to the public.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • The entity may provide the link to its formal proxy voting policy.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its process of making proxy voting decisions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but not be limited to, the elements highlighted in the PRI’s Reporting Framework for Direct – Listed Equity Active Ownership, which include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Use of internal research team and/or third-party service providers
• Review and monitoring process for service provider recommendations

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to communicating its voting decisions to company management, including the rationale for voting for/against the management’s recommendations.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to engagement on ES issues.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The entity’s objectives for undertaking engagement activities
• Whether the entity’s engagements related to ES issues are primarily proactive to ensure that ES issues are well-managed in a preventive manner, or reactive to address issues that may have already occurred
• The outcomes the entity seeks from engaging with companies on ES issues (e.g., influencing corporate practice, improve the quality of ES disclosure)
• The entity’s staff that carries out the engagement (e.g., specialized in-house engagement teams, fund managers or equity/credit analysts, more senior-level roles)
• The roles of individuals at the portfolio companies the entity seeks to engage with (e.g., board members, board chair, CEO, corporate secretary, investor relations managers)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall describe how it communicates its engagement policy to clients as well as to the public.
