Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The entity may provide the link to its formal engagement policy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure includes all asset classes, portfolios, and/or strategies where the entity conducts engagement on ES issues.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how the outcomes of its proxy voting and engagement activities inform its investment decision-making process.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• How the entity decides what information to pass on to investment decision-makers
• How the entity monitors the use of the information passed on in investment decision-making

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its escalation process for engagements when company dialogue is failing.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The escalation process includes, but is not limited to, tactics highlighted in the International Corporate Governance Network (ICGN) Global Stewardship Principles:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Expressing concerns to corporate representatives or non-executive directors, either directly or in a shareholder meeting
• Expressing the entity’s concern collectively with other investors
• Making a public statement
• Submitting shareholder resolutions
• Speaking at general meetings
• Submitting one or more nominations for election to the board as appropriate and convening a shareholder meeting
• Seeking governance improvements and/or damages through legal remedies or arbitration
• Exit or threat to exit from the investment

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how its ES engagement strategy fits into the entity’s overall engagement strategy.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Management & Advisory
Accounting Metric: Description of proxy voting and investee engagement policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose additional quantitative measures related to its proxy voting and engagement activities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Number of engagements, percentage of those in-person
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Number of staff involved in proxy voting and engagement activities

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice or other related financial industry laws or regulations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The European Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: The U.S. Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 9: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 10: The U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall exclude the amount of monetary losses disclosed in metric FN-AC-270a.2.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall also include enforcements related to activities adjudicated by federal regulators with an enforcement mandate broader than the financial industry, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) enforced by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) enforced by the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The Specially Designated Nationals List enforced by the U.S. Treasury Department through its Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC)

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the processes and policies that are set forth within its whistleblower program, including, but not limited to, internal compliance programs, whistleblower hotline details (e.g., if it is managed by an independent third-party), reference to and publication of the hotline number (e.g., within corporate compliance manuals or code of ethics), whistleblower incentives for reporting violations, and methods for submitting tips.

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include the entity’s compliance with applicable whistleblower regulations, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) [18 U.S.C. § 1514A]
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFPA) [12 U.S.C. § 5567]

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include a discussion of any violations of whistleblower regulations and any corrective actions the entity has implemented as a result of violations.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of open-end fund assets under management by category of liquidity classification
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of open-end fund assets under management (AUM) in (1) highly liquid investments, (2) moderately liquid investments, (3) less liquid investments, and (4) illiquid investments, as defined by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Open-end funds are defined as a management company which is offering for sale or has outstanding any redeemable security of which it is the issuer, in accordance to Section 5(a)(1) of the Investment Company Act of 1940.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Highly liquid investments are defined as cash and any investment reasonably expected to be convertible to cash in current market conditions in three business days or less without the conversion to cash significantly changing the market value of the investment, in accordance to SEC Rule 22e-4, section III. C.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Moderately liquid investments are defined as any investment reasonably expected to be convertible to cash in current market conditions in more than three calendar days but in seven calendar days or less without the conversion to cash significantly changing the market value of the investment, in accordance to SEC Rule 22e-4, section III. C.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Less liquid investments are defined as any investment reasonably expected to be sold or disposed of in current market conditions in seven calendar days or less without the sale or disposition significantly changing the market value of the investment, but where the sale or disposition is reasonably expected to settle in more than seven calendar days, in accordance to SEC Rule 22e-4, section III. C.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Illiquid investments are defined as any investment that may not reasonably be expected to be sold or disposed of in current market conditions in seven calendar days or less without the sale or disposition significantly changing the market value of the investment, in accordance to SEC Rule 22e-4, section III. C.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of open-end fund assets under management by category of liquidity classification
Technical Protocol: The percent shall be calculated as the value of open-end fund AUM in each respective liquidity category divided by the entity's total open-end fund AUM.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs, including requirements set forth by SEC Rule 22e-4, into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its liquidity management process around reducing the risk of funds not meeting their redemption obligations and mitigating dilution of the interest of fund shareholders.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the redemption practices that its funds employ.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the frequency with which it reviews the liquidity risk of its funds.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the liquidity risk factors it uses in assessing, managing, and reviewing the liquidity risk of its funds.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall describe the scenarios, such as normal and reasonably foreseeable stressed conditions.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its funds which are not subject to Rule 22e-4.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall describe the number of its funds that have redeem-in-kind policies and under what conditions they will be executed, in accordance with form N-1A.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Redemption-in-kind is defined as the right to satisfy redemption requests by investors through distribution of the underlying portfolio assets rather than by selling those assets and handing over cash.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of liquidity risk management programs into portfolio strategy and redemption risk management
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to swing pricing, in accordance with form N-CEN, including the number of funds with policies allowing swing pricing and the number of funds for each given level of maximum swing.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Swing pricing is defined as a process of adjusting the net asset value (NAV) of a fund’s shares to pass on to purchasing or redeeming shareholders more of the costs associated with their trading activity.

Accounting Metric: Total exposure to securities financing transactions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of exposure to securities financing transactions (SFTs), including off-balance sheet items.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: SFTs are defined as any transaction where securities are used to borrow cash, or vice versa, including repurchase agreements (repos), securities lending activities, and sell/buy-back transactions, where ownership of the securities temporarily changes in return for cash temporarily changing ownership, in accordance to the U.S. Securities Financing Transactions Regulation (SFTR).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Off-balance sheet items include commitments (including liquidity facilities), whether or not unconditionally cancellable, direct credit substitutes, acceptances, standby letters of credit and trade letters of credit, in accordance to the "Basel III: Finalising post-crisis reforms."

Accounting Metric: Total exposure to securities financing transactions
Technical Protocol: Calculation methodologies shall follow guidance from the Bank for International Settlements’ "Basel III: Finalising post-crisis reforms" items 50 to 56.

Accounting Metric: Total exposure to securities financing transactions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the above references used to calculate the exposure to securities financing transactions normative references; thus, any future updates made to them shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Net exposure to written credit derivatives
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its net exposure to written credit derivatives.

Accounting Metric: Net exposure to written credit derivatives
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate its net exposure to written credit derivatives as the maximum notional payout of written credit derivatives less the maximum notional payout of purchased credit derivatives on the same reference names, provided:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The credit protection purchased is on a reference obligation which ranks pari passu with, or is junior to, the underlying reference obligation of the written credit derivative in the case of single name credit derivatives; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The remaining maturity of the credit protection purchased is equal to or greater than the remaining maturity of the written credit derivative.

Accounting Metric: Net exposure to written credit derivatives
Technical Protocol: For additional guidance the entity shall refer to items 32 to 49 and their accompanying notes in the Bank for International Settlements’ “Basel III: Finalising post-crisis reforms.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity's expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters,Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which account holders were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique account holders who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same account holder shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems that pose a data security risk.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, and/or implementation that could be exploited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data security risk is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, or nations through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities it has identified, including, but not limited to, operational procedures, management processes, structure of products, selection of business partners, employee training, and use of technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and procedures for disclosing the events of breaches to its customers in a timely manner.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity‘s disclosure shall include a discussion of data and system security efforts that relate to new and emerging cyber threats and attack vectors facing the financial services industry.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emerging cyber threats include, but are not limited to, cyber threats arising from the use of near-field communication payment systems, mobile banking, and web-based banking.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Attack vectors include, but are not limited to, ransomware, loan stacking schemes, money mule schemes, and Remote Access Attacks.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the regulatory environment in which it operates related to data security.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Discussion shall include, but is not limited to, data security policies and procedures that the entity adopted as a result of regulatory compliance efforts or voluntarily as an industry best practice.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the degree to which its approach is aligned with an external standard or framework and/or legal or regulatory framework for managing data security, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ISO/IEC 27001:2013—Information technology—Security techniques—Information security management systems—Requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, Version 1.1, April 16, 2018, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The New York State Department of Financial Services 23 NYCRR 500, “Cybersecurity Requirements for Financial Services Companies”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships: Risk Management Guidance,” October 30, 2013

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC’s Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity’s approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces, but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of loans outstanding qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of loans outstanding qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development, and the total amount outstanding of these loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Loans qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development are defined in accordance with the U.S. Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council’s (FFIEC) definition of community development loans, pursuant to the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 (CRA).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The scope of disclosure includes (1) Small Farm and Small Business loans and (2) Community Development Loans as defined by the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting .
• The scope of disclosure excludes (1) Home Mortgage Loans, (2) Consumer Loans, and (3) Other Loan Data as defined by the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting .

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of loans outstanding qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide the number and amount of loans outstanding qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development in accordance with the guidance to Schedule RC-C of the Consolidated Report of Condition and Income (Call Report).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of loans outstanding qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting a normative reference, thus any future updates made to it shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of past due and nonaccrual loans qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of loans past due and nonaccrual qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development, and the total amount past due and nonaccrual of these loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Loans qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development are defined in accordance with the U.S. Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council’s (FFIEC) definition of community development loans, pursuant to the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) of 1977.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The scope of disclosure includes (1) Small Farm and Small Business loans and (2) Community Development Loans as defined by the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting .
• The scope of disclosure excludes (1) Home Mortgage Loans, (2) Consumer Loans, and (3) Other Loan Data as defined by the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting .
• The scope of disclosure includes loans originated and purchased by the entity, reported in accordance with the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting .

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of past due and nonaccrual loans qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide the number and amount of loans past due and nonaccrual qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development in accordance with the guidance to Schedule RC-N of the Consolidated Report of Condition and Income (Call Report).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) amount of past due and nonaccrual loans qualified to programs designed to promote small business and community development
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the FFIEC’s Guide to CRA Data Collection and Reporting a normative reference, thus any future updates made to it shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Number of no-cost retail checking accounts provided to previously unbanked or underbanked customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of no-cost checking accounts that are held by unbanked or underbanked customers as of the end of the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: No-cost checking accounts are defined as bank accounts providing core services without extra fees, monthly or annual maintenance fees, or minimum average balance requirements.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Core services include, but are not limited to, access to a debit card, access to internet and mobile banking, and access to deposits or withdrawals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Unbanked customers are defined by the U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's National Survey of Unbanked and Underbanked Households as individuals and families who have rarely, if ever, held a checking account, a savings account, or other type of transaction or check cashing account at an insured depository institution.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: A household is categorized as underbanked if it had a checking or savings account and used one of the following products or services from an alternative financial services (AFS) provider in the past 12 months: money orders, check cashing, international remittances, payday loans, refund anticipation loans, rent-to-own services, pawn shop loans, or auto title loans.

Accounting Metric: Number of no-cost retail checking accounts provided to previously unbanked or underbanked customers
Technical Protocol: The entity may additionally disclose the number of no-cost checking accounts opened and closed during the reporting period by unbanked and underbanked customers.

Accounting Metric: Number of participants in financial literacy initiatives for unbanked, underbanked, or underserved customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of individuals that participated in financial literacy initiatives for unbanked, underbanked, or underserved customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of financial literacy initiatives includes, but is not limited to, educational programs, workshops, seminars, courses, counseling, and community partnerships.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Unbanked customers are those in households without a checking or savings account who may rely on alternative financial services (AFS), such as payday loans, non-bank money orders, non-bank check cashing services, non-bank remittances, rent-to-own services, pawn shops, or refund anticipation loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Underbanked customers are in households that have a checking and/or a savings account but may still regularly use AFS.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Underserved customers include those who are unbanked, underbanked, or otherwise have limited access to mainstream financial services, often due to limited or no credit history. These customers commonly include young adults, immigrants and/or non-native English speakers, the elderly, ethnic minorities, low-income customers (i.e., with less than $30,000 in household income), and members of the military.

Accounting Metric: Number of participants in financial literacy initiatives for unbanked, underbanked, or underserved customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the total number of unique individuals who are documented to have participated in at least one initiative conducted by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure shall include participants in ongoing programs in the case that active participation can be documented during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Number of participants in financial literacy initiatives for unbanked, underbanked, or underserved customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include both individual retail customers and relevant commercial customers (e.g., small and medium enterprises and minority owned business).

Accounting Metric: Number of participants in financial literacy initiatives for unbanked, underbanked, or underserved customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include financial literacy initiatives provided by the entity directly as well as by third-parties for which a contractual agreement to provide such initiatives exists with the entity.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Commercial and industrial credit exposure, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its commercial and industrial credit exposure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate its exposure in accordance with the guidance to Schedule RC-C and Schedule RC-I of the Consolidated Report of Condition and Income (Call Report).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The reported value shall include the notional amount of direct outstanding and unfunded legally binding lending commitments net of amounts distributed (e.g., syndicated or participated) to other financial institutions.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Commercial and industrial credit exposure, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down its commercial and industrial credit exposure by industry.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall use the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) for classifying counterparties.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The entity shall use the NAICS 3 Digit Subsector code-level breakdown in its disclosure.
• The entity shall use the latest version of the NAICS available at the time of disclosure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose its exposure to at least the 10 largest industries by monetary amount of exposure, or to industries representing at least 2 percent of the overall portfolio monetary exposure.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Commercial and industrial credit exposure, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider guidance to Schedule RC-C and Schedule RC-I of the Call Report a normative reference, thus any future updates made to it shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to the incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into its credit analysis.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The definition of incorporation of ESG factors is aligned with that of the Global Sustainable Investment Alliance (GSIA) and includes the use of ESG information in the investment decision-making processes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of ESG factors/issues are provided in the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018, section “ESG issues.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Credit analysis is defined as method to calculate the creditworthiness of a business or organization, i.e., their ability to honor debt obligations, which seeks to identify the appropriate level of default risk associated with financing such business, organization, or project.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how ESG factors are incorporated in the assessment of and influence the entity’s perspectives on:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Traditional macroeconomic factors such as the economic conditions, central bank monetary policy, industry trends, and geopolitical risks that affect creditworthiness of borrowers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Traditional microeconomic factors such as supply and demand for products or services that affect financial conditions and operational results of borrowers as well as their creditworthiness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Overall creditworthiness of a borrower
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Maturity or tenor of a loan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Expected loss, including probability of default, exposure at default, and loss given default
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Value of posted collateral

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose additional quantitative measures related to its approach to the incorporation of ESG factors in credit analysis, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Number of commercial and industrial loans and project finance screened according to the Equator Principles (EP III) (or equivalent) by EP Category
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Number of loans for which a review of environmental or social risks was performed, e.g., by the entity’s Environmental and Social Risk Management (ESRM) group?

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include commercial and industrial lending as well as project finance.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe policies that determine its approach to the incorporation of ESG factors in credit analysis.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how it incorporates ESG factors when estimating credit losses over the contractual term of the entity’s financial assets.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to implementation of the aspects of the entity’s ESG incorporation practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Parties responsible for day-to-day incorporation of ESG factors
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Approach to conducting ESG-related research
• Approach to incorporating ESG factors into assessing creditworthiness of borrowers

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its oversight/accountability approach to the incorporation of ESG factors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Formal oversight individuals and/or bodies involved
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Criteria used in assessing the quality of ESG incorporation

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether it conducts scenario analysis and/or modeling in which the risk profile of future ESG trends is calculated at the portfolio level of commercial and industrial credit exposure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ESG trends include, but are not limited to, climate change, natural resource constraints, human capital risks and opportunities, and cybersecurity risks.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss ESG trends that it views as broadly applicable in terms of their impact on sectors and industries, as well as the trends it views as sector- or industry-specific.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may further provide the discussion in the context of geographic exposure of its commercial and industrial credit portfolio.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Credit Analysis
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in credit analysis
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe significant concentrations of credit exposure to ESG factors, including, but not limited to, carbon-related assets, water-stressed regions, and cybersecurity risks.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The European Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: The U.S. Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 9: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 10: The U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall also include enforcements related to activities adjudicated by federal regulators with an enforcement mandate broader than the financial industry, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) enforced by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act enforced by the U.S. Department of Justice
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The Specially Designated Nationals List enforced by the U.S. Treasury Department through its Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC)

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the processes and policies that are set forth within its whistleblower program, including, but not limited to, internal compliance programs, whistleblower hotline details (e.g., if it is managed by an independent third-party), reference to and publication of the hotline number (e.g., within corporate compliance manuals or code of ethics), whistleblower incentives for reporting violations, and methods for submitting tips.

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include the entity’s compliance with applicable whistleblower regulations, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) [18 U.S.C. § 1514A]
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFPA) [12 U.S.C. § 5567]

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include a discussion of any violations of whistleblower regulations and any corrective actions the entity has implemented as a result of violations.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its Globally Systematically Important Bank (G-SIB) score for the following categories: (1) Size, (2) Cross-jurisdictional activity, (3) Interconnectedness, (4) Substitutability, (5) Complexity, and (6) Overall score.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The G-SIB scores are defined and shall by calculated according to the methodology established by the Bank of International Settlements' (BIS) Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) in Global systematically important banks: updated assessment methodology and the higher loss absorbency (HLA) requirement, July 2013.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The set of indicators used in calculation of the G-SIB score is outlined by the BCBS in the Reporting instructions and the Reporting template.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The entity shall refer to the Reporting instructions and the Reporting template for the relevant reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The G-SIB score calculation is provided by the BCBS in the technical summary. The BCBS further provides:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
•  Denominators used for score calculation for the relevant reporting period
• The cut-off score used to identify the G-SIBs and bucket thresholds used to allocate G-SIBs to buckets for the purposes of calculating the specific HLA requirements for each institution

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: If the G-SIB score is not available at the time of issuance of the annual report for the respective reporting period, the entity shall disclose the latest available G-SIB score.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the above references used to determine the G-SIB score to be normative references, thus any future updates made to them shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests and capital planning reports inform the entity’s decisions and are incorporated into capital planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Stress tests include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
•  U.S. Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) 
•  U.S. Dodd-Frank Act supervisory stress testing 
•  The Bank of England stress test 
•  The European Union-wide banking stress testing 
•  Monetary Authority of Singapore Annual Industry-Wide Stress Testing exercise 
•  The China Banking Regulatory Commission’s (CBRC) Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP) 
•  Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA)  industry stress test

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how the stress test results inform its approach with respect to its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategy.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose its stress test results along with the discussion.

Accounting Metric: Number of account holders whose information is used for secondary purposes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of unique account holders whose information is used for secondary purposes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Account holder information includes information that pertains to an account holder‘s attributes or actions, including, but not limited to, account statements, transaction records, records of communications, content of communications, demographic data, behavioral data, location data, and/or personally identifiable information (PII).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Demographic data are defined as the quantifiable statistics that identify and distinguish a given population. Examples of demographic data include gender, age, race/ethnicity, knowledge of languages, disabilities, mobility, home ownership, and employment status.
• Behavioral data are defined as the product of tracking, measuring, and recording individual behaviors such as online browsing patterns, buying habits, brand preferences, and product usage patterns.
• Location data are defined as data describing the physical location or movement patterns of an individual, such as Global Positioning System (GPS) coordinates or other related data that would enable identifying and tracking an individual‘s physical location.
• PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Secondary purpose is defined as the intentional use of data by the entity (i.e., not a breach of security) that is outside the primary purpose for which the data was collected. Examples of secondary purposes include, but are not limited to, selling targeted ads, improving the entity’s products or service offerings, and transferring data or information to a third-party through sale, rental, or sharing.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same individual shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: Number of account holders whose information is used for secondary purposes
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include the account holders whose information is used by the entity itself for secondary purposes as well as the account holders whose information is provided to affiliates or non-affiliates and may be used by those parties for secondary purposes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Affiliate is defined as a third party that directly or indirectly controls, is controlled by, or is under common control with the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-affiliates are all third parties other than the entity and its affiliates.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with customer privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with incidents relating to customer privacy.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with customer privacy
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with customer privacy
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with customer privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with customer privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission’s Privacy and Gramm-Leach-Bliley Acts
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board’s Regulation P
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Japan’s Personal Information Protection Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Hong Kong’s Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Australia’s Privacy Act

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity’s expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which account holders were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique account holders who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same account holder shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of account holders affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Card-related fraud losses from (1) card-not-present fraud and (2) card-present and other fraud
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of card-related fraud losses it incurred during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Card-related fraud losses from (1) card-not-present fraud and (2) card-present and other fraud
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose card-related fraud losses as (1) card-not-present (CNP) and (2) card-present and other fraud losses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: CNP fraud is characterized by the unauthorized use of a credit card number, the security code printed on the card, and/or the cardholder's address details for a transaction in a non-face-to-face setting with a merchant. CNP fraud includes that which is conducted online, through mail, or over the phone.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Card-present fraud is characterized by the unauthorized use of a physical credit card for a transaction in a face-to-face setting with a merchant.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: “Other fraud" includes identify theft and any fraudulent transaction that cannot be classified as CNP fraud.

Accounting Metric: Card-related fraud losses from (1) card-not-present fraud and (2) card-present and other fraud
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate card-related fraud losses as the total value of account holder transactions refunded to account holders (card holders) due to fraud.

Accounting Metric: Card-related fraud losses from (1) card-not-present fraud and (2) card-present and other fraud
Technical Protocol: The scope shall include losses from the unauthorized use of revolving consumer credit, debit, and pre-paid debit cards, including instances of card-present fraud and instances of CNP fraud, where the entity is liable for losses (e.g., such as when a merchant is using a chargeback protection service).

Accounting Metric: Card-related fraud losses from (1) card-not-present fraud and (2) card-present and other fraud
Technical Protocol: The scope shall also include transactions determined to be fraudulent that the entity charged back to merchants (and/or their acquiring banks), including those related to CNP fraudulent activity.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems that pose a data security risk.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, and/or implementation that could be exploited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data security risk is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, or nations through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities it has identified, including, but not limited to, operational procedures, management processes, structure of products, selection of business partners, employee training, and use of technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and procedures for disclosing the events of breaches to its customers in a timely manner.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity‘s disclosure shall include a discussion of data and system security efforts that relate to new and emerging cyber threats and attack vectors facing the financial services industry.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emerging cyber threats include, but are not limited to, cyber threats arising from the use of near-field communication payment systems, mobile banking, and web-based banking.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Attack vectors include, but are not limited to, ransomware, loan stacking schemes, money mule schemes, and Remote Access Attacks.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the regulatory environment in which it operates related to data security.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Discussion shall include, but is not limited to, data security policies and procedures that the entity adopted as a result of regulatory compliance efforts or voluntarily as an industry best practice.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the degree to which its approach is aligned with an external standard or framework and/or legal or regulatory framework for managing data security, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ISO/IEC 27001:2013—Information technology—Security techniques—Information security management systems—Requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, Version 1.1, April 16, 2018, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The New York State Department of Financial Services 23 NYCRR 500, “Cybersecurity Requirements for Financial Services Companies”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) Bulletin 2013-29, “Third-Party Relationships: Risk Management Guidance,” October 30, 2013

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC’s Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity’s approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces, but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration for covered employees that is variable and linked to the amount of products and services sold
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of total remuneration of its covered employees accrued during the reporting period that is variable.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Variable remuneration is defined as all remuneration which is not fixed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Remuneration is fixed where all the conditions for its award and its amount:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Covered employees are defined as individuals employed by the entity that are engaged in the activities of directly selling products or services to customers or potential customers.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For the U.S. workforce, covered employees include those categorized by the entity in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet as: (1) Sales Workers and (2) First/Mid Offs & Mgrs. – Sales Managers.
• For the non-U.S. workforce, covered employees include those categorized by the entity into categories equivalent to (1) Sales Workers and (2) First/Mid Offs & Mgrs. – Sales Managers, though in accordance with, and further facilitated by, any applicable local regulations, guidance, or generally accepted definitions.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration for covered employees that is variable and linked to the amount of products and services sold
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage by dividing the aggregate amount of the variable remuneration linked to the amount of products and services sold of the entity’s covered employees by the aggregate amount of the total remuneration of the entity’s covered employees.

Accounting Metric: Approval rate for (1) credit and (2) pre-paid products for applicants with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the approval rate for its (1) credit and (2) pre-paid products for all applicants, each broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Pre-paid products include pre-paid accounts and cards, excluding checking accounts, share draft accounts, or negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts.

Accounting Metric: Approval rate for (1) credit and (2) pre-paid products for applicants with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the approval rate as the total number of applications approved from applicants in the FICO category divided by the total number of applications received from applicants in the FICO category.

Accounting Metric: Approval rate for (1) credit and (2) pre-paid products for applicants with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes applications the entity approved or denied during the reporting period, regardless of when the application was received.

Accounting Metric: Approval rate for (1) credit and (2) pre-paid products for applicants with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity may summarize the disclosure in the following table:

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the average fees from add-on products for all customers, broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Add-on products include, but are not limited to, debt protection, identity theft protection, credit score tracking, and other products that are supplementary to the credit provided by the card itself and are offered at additional cost to consumers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the average fees from add-on products as the total amount of revenue generated from add-on products from customers in the FICO category divided by the total number of the entity’s customers in each respective FICO category.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the average Annual Percentage Rate (APR) for all customers, broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the average APR for all accounts assessed interest during the reporting period as the annualized ratio of total finance charges to the total average daily balances, against which the finance charges were assessed (excluding accounts for which no finance charges were assessed).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Definitions of finance charge and detailed calculation of APR are aligned with those in the Regulation Z of the Truth in Lending Act.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) average age of accounts in months for all customers, broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the average age of accounts (in months) from the date that each active account was opened until the close of the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (4) the average number of trade lines for all customers, broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the average number of trade lines per customer as the total number of trade lines held by customers in each FICO category divided by the total number of customers in the respective FICO category.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (5) the average annual fees for pre-paid products for all customers, broken down by FICO scores below or equal to 660, and above 660.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Pre-paid products include pre-paid accounts and cards, excluding checking accounts, share draft accounts, or negotiable order of withdrawal (NOW) accounts.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the average annual fees for pre-paid products as the total amount of revenue generated from pre-paid products from customers in the FICO category divided by the total number of the entity’s customers in the FICO category.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average fees from add-on products, (2) average APR, (3) average age of accounts, (4) average number of trade lines, and (5) average annual fees for pre-paid products, for customers with FICO scores above and below 660
Technical Protocol: The entity may summarize the disclosure in the following table:

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) during the reporting period where the entity was a defendant in the complaint.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes complaints filed through the CFPB’s Consumer Complaint Database.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of complaints filed with the CFPB that resulted in monetary or non-monetary relief.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Monetary relief and non-monetary relief are as disclosed by the CFPB.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes complaints filed during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of complaints filed with the CFPB that were disputed by consumers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Complaints disputed by consumers are as disclosed by the CFPB.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes complaints filed during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (4) the percentage of complaints filed with the CFPB that resulted in investigation by the CFPB.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Complaints resulted in investigation by CFPB are as disclosed by the CFPB.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes complaints filed during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include the complaints filed regarding the following product categories specified by the CFPB:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Credit Card or Prepaid Card
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Student Loan Private
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Vehicle Loan or Lease
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Payday Loan, Title Loan, or Personal Loan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Money Transfer, Virtual Currency, or Money Service

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, the following issues specified by the CFPB:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Selling Practices
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Transparent Information
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Adverting and Marketing
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Fees and Interest
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Add-on Products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Servicing the Account
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Application Process
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: Closing the Account

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), (2) percentage with monetary or non-monetary relief, (3) percentage disputed by consumer, (4) percentage that resulted in investigation by the CFPB
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide breakdown by type of product, issue, and company response type referencing the CFPB data.
