Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with selling and servicing of products
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure Act of 2009 (CARD Act)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The U.S. Regulation Z - Truth in Lending Act (TILA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.S. Unfair, Deceptive and Abusive Acts and Practices (UDAAP)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The U.S. Service members Civil Relief Act (SCRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The U.S. Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: The EU Payment Services Directive
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 9: The EU Directive on Consumer Rights

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the (1) number and (2) average duration in minutes of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: Trading halts are defined as temporary suspensions in the trading of a security by the entity for reasons, which may include, but are not limited to: anticipation of a news announcement, correction of an order imbalance, or regulatory reasons.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: Suspensions usually occur to allow market participants to digest information or company developments that may have a material effect on trading activity, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Changes related to the financial health of the company
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Major corporate transactions, including restructurings or mergers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Significant positive or negative information about its products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Changes in key management individuals
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Legal or regulatory developments that affect the company’s ability to conduct business
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: When the company releases information without notifying the exchange in advance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Another company announces an unsolicited tender offer for the company whose stock is now subject to the trading halt

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: Trading pause is defined as temporary short-term (e.g., for five minutes) suspension in the trading of a security by the entity due to extreme volatility or erratic trading.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes suspension of trading by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) (e.g., due to failure of a company to filing periodic reports) and by market-wide circuit breakers required by the SEC (e.g., due to market-wide volatility).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) average duration of (a) halts related to public release of information and (b) pauses related to volatility
Technical Protocol: The entity may summarize the disclosure in the following table:

Accounting Metric: Percentage of trades generated from automated trading systems
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its total trades generated by automated or algorithmic trading systems.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Automated or algorithmic trading is defined as the use of electronic platforms for entering trading orders with an automated algorithm that executes pre-programmed trading instructions.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• This includes high-frequency trading.
• This excludes program trading.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of trades generated from automated trading systems
Technical Protocol: The percentage of trades shall be calculated as the volume of trades executed (i.e., bought, sold, and sold short) by an automated algorithm divided by the total volume of trades.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of trades generated from automated trading systems
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes trades occurring on public exchanges, in dark pools, or through other trading systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of alert policy regarding timing and nature of public release of information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its alert policy relating to listed companies’ public release of information or company developments that may affect a stock price (positively or negatively), such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Changes related to the financial health of the company
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Major corporate transactions, including restructurings or mergers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Significant positive or negative information about its products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Changes in key management individuals
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Legal or regulatory developments that affect the company’s ability to conduct business

Accounting Metric: Description of alert policy regarding timing and nature of public release of information
Technical Protocol: Relevant aspects of an alert policy to describe include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Timing of release of information in relation to market hours
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Newspaper agencies and wire services, such as a specification of which outlets should be notified
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The mechanisms of alert to the exchange (e.g., by telephone, fax, or email) and public disclosure (e.g., website, social media, or press release)

Accounting Metric: Description of alert policy regarding timing and nature of public release of information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its provisions for halting, delaying, or pausing trading when it is necessary to ensure fair, complete, and transparent access to information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The number and duration of halts and pauses shall be disclosed in FN-EX-410a.1.

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies for companies listed on its exchange(s) related to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: If policies are rules-based (i.e., companies must meet certain structural or performance criteria) or if they are disclosure-based (i.e., companies must disclose certain information)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: If rules or disclosures are a requirement of listing (and/or continued listing) or if compliance is voluntary for listed companies (i.e., recommended or encouraged by the entity)

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: The scope shall be limited to rules, requirements, and disclosures that are additional to size, distribution, and financial criteria for an initial public offering (IPO) and/or continued listing.

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: Governance information includes, but is not limited to, rules and disclosures related to board structure and independence, committees of the board, and codes of conduct or ethics.

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: Environmental information may include issues relating to the quality and functioning of the natural environment and natural systems, including, but not limited to, greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, biodiversity loss, climate change, air quality, energy and water efficiency, waste management, land use and other ecological impact, per the PRI Reporting Framework – Main Definitions.

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: Social information may include issues relating to the rights, well-being, and interests of people and communities, including, but not limited to, human rights, labor standards in the supply chain; child, slave, and bonded labor; worker health and safety; employee diversity and inclusion; and access and affordability; per the PRI Reporting Framework – Main Definitions.

Accounting Metric: Description of policy to encourage or require listed companies to publicly disclose environmental, social, and governance (ESG) information
Technical Protocol: Examples of encouraging companies to meet ESG rules or disclosure standards include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Promoting and facilitating transfer of information among regulators, investors, and companies
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Participation in disclosure programs such as the Sustainable Stock Exchange Initiative

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The European Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The European Securities and Market Authority (ESMA) (i.e., MiFID (II), MiFIR)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: The U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 9: The U.S. Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall also include enforcements related to activities adjudicated by federal regulators with an enforcement mandate broader than the financial industry, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) enforced by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act enforced by the U.S. Department of Justice
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The Specially Designated Nationals List enforced by the U.S. Treasury Department through its Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC)

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes for identifying and assessing conflicts of interest
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its processes for identifying and assessing conflicts of interest, such as the use of corporate policies, monitoring procedures, dedicated personnel, or board oversight.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes for identifying and assessing conflicts of interest
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe efforts to minimize conflicts of interest including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Education, interpretation, or guidance to broker-dealer members with respect to regulatory compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Technical mechanisms to enforce compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Ceding some self-regulatory powers to FINRA or equivalent (i.e., through a 17d-2 agreement)

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of significant market disruptions and (2) duration of downtime
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the (1) number and (2) duration in hours of significant market disruptions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A significant market disruption is defined as an event when the exchange ceases to function according to its typical manner and causes or threatens to cause steep market declines.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of significant market disruptions and (2) duration of downtime
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes trading halts and pauses disclosed in metric FN-EX-410a.1, suspensions of trading by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) (e.g., due to failure of a company to file periodic reports), or market-wide circuit breakers required by the SEC (e.g., due to market-wide volatility).

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity's expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to prevent technology errors, security breaches, and market disruptions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and practices to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data across its data platforms.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of data includes, but is not limited to, information provided to and held by third parties, such as regulators (e.g., the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data platforms include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Trading services and technologies, such as software, data feeds, and member services (e.g., messaging or information services)
• IT infrastructure, such as co-location facilities and low-latency connectivity equipment

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to prevent technology errors, security breaches, and market disruptions
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks that the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity’s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose gender representation for all employees and racial/ethnic group representation for its U.S. employees by employee category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The following employee categories shall be used: (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: Gender and racial/ethnic group representation shall be disclosed in percentages, where the percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in each gender or racial/ethnic group in each employee category divided by the total number of employees in the respective employee category.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet, where each employee category for disclosure is defined by corresponding job categories and descriptions in the Instruction Booklet:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Executive management includes Executives/Senior Level Officials and Managers: individuals who plan, direct and formulate policies, set strategy and provide the overall direction of enterprises/organizations for the development and delivery of products or services, within the parameters approved by boards of directors or other governing bodies. Residing in the highest levels of organizations, these executives plan, direct or coordinate activities with the support of subordinate executives and staff managers. They include, in larger organizations, those individuals within two reporting levels of the CEO, whose responsibilities require frequent interaction with the CEO. Examples of these kinds of managers are: chief executive officers, chief operating officers, chief financial officers, line of business heads, presidents or executive vice presidents of functional areas or operating groups, chief information officers, chief human resources officers, chief marketing officers, chief legal officers, management directors and managing partners.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-executive management includes First/Mid-Level Officials and Managers: individuals who serve as managers, other than those who serve as Executive/Senior Level Officials and Managers, including those who oversee and direct the delivery of products, services or functions at group, regional or divisional levels of organizations. These managers receive directions from the Executive/Senior Level management and typically lead major business units. They implement policies, programs and directives of executive/senior management through subordinate managers and within the parameters set by Executive/Senior Level management. Examples of these kinds of managers are: vice presidents and directors, group, regional or divisional controllers; treasurers; human resources, information systems, marketing, and operations managers. The First/Mid-Level Officials and Managers subcategory also includes those who report directly to middle managers. These individuals serve at functional, line of business segment or branch levels and are responsible for directing and executing the day-to-day operational objectives of enterprises/organizations, conveying the directions of higher level officials and managers to subordinate personnel and, in some instances, directly supervising the activities of exempt and non-exempt personnel. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Professionals is defined as the following: most jobs in this category require bachelor and graduate degrees, and/or professional certification. In some instances, comparable experience may establish a person’s qualifications. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: All other employees includes those employees who are not classified as executive management, non-executive management, or professionals.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For non-U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in a manner generally consistent with the definitions provided above, though in accordance with, and further facilitated by, any applicable local regulations, guidance, or generally accepted definitions.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the gender of its employees as female, male, or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the racial/ethnic group of its U.S. employees in accordance with the EEO-1 Survey Instruction Booklet and use the following categories: Asian, Black or African American, Hispanic or Latino, White, Other (which includes Native American or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, and “Two or More Races” classifications), or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental disclosures on gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by country or region.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental contextual disclosures on factors that significantly influence gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation, such as the country or region where employees are located.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management, (2) non-executive management, (3) professionals, and (4) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by employee category in the following table formats:

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Revenue from (1) underwriting, (2) advisory, and (3) securitization transactions incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall report the total revenue earned from transactions in which the entity incorporates integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Integration of ESG factors is defined as the systematic and explicit inclusion of material ESG factors into underwriting, advisory, and securitization activities and may include, but is not limited to, review of transactions by the entity’s Environmental and Social Risk Management (ESRM) group and/or screening (exclusionary, inclusionary, or benchmarked).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The entity shall describe how ESG factors are integrated in the aforementioned activities.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Revenue from (1) underwriting, (2) advisory, and (3) securitization transactions incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down the revenue from transactions by key business activities including (a) underwriting, (b) advisory, and (c) securitization.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Underwriting is defined as activities in which the entity raises investment capital from investors on behalf of corporations and governments that are issuing either equity or debt securities. It includes public offerings and private placements, including local and cross-border transactions and acquisition financing of a wide range of securities and other financial instruments, including loans. Underwriting also covers derivative transactions entered into with public and private sector clients in connection with the entity’s underwriting activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Advisory is defined as activities in which the entity provides financial advice to institutional clients on a fee basis. It excludes wealth management and asset management activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Securitization is defined as the process through which the entity creates a financial instrument by combining other financial assets and then marketing different tiers of the repackaged instruments to investors. It may include securitization of residential and commercial mortgages, corporate bonds, loans, and other types of financial assets by selling these assets to securitization vehicles (e.g., trusts, corporate entities, and limited liability companies) or through a re-securitization.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Revenue from (1) underwriting, (2) advisory, and (3) securitization transactions incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down the revenue from transactions by industry.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall use the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) for classifying transactions.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The entity shall use the NAICS 3 Digit Subsector code-level breakdown in its disclosure.
• The entity shall use the latest version of the NAICS available at the time of disclosure.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Revenue from (1) underwriting, (2) advisory, and (3) securitization transactions incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide disclosure for at least the 10 largest industries by monetary amount of exposure, or to industries representing at least 2 percent of the overall monetary amount of exposure.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) total value of investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall report the number of proprietary investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) total value of investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall report the value of proprietary investments and loans incorporating integration of ESG factors.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) total value of investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes the entity’s investing and relationship lending activities across various asset classes, including debt securities and loans, public and private equity securities, infrastructure, and real estate. These activities include investing directly in publicly and privately traded securities and in loans, and also through certain investment funds that the entity manages and through funds managed by external parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure excludes commercial, consumer, and mortgage lending activities.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) total value of investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: Integration of ESG factors is defined as the systematic and explicit inclusion of material ESG factors into traditional fundamental financial analysis through the consideration of qualitative risks and opportunities, quantitative metrics, and the incorporation of ESG variables into models to inform the entity ’s decision-making processes involved in proprietary investing and lending.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) total value of investments and loans incorporating integration of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, by industry
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down the number and value of investments and loans by industry.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall use the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) for classifying investees and borrowers.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The entity shall use the NAICS 3 Digit Subsector code-level breakdown in its disclosure.
• The entity shall use the latest version of the NAICS available at the time of disclosure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose its exposure to at least the 10 largest industries by monetary amount of exposure, or to industries representing at least 2 percent of the overall portfolio monetary exposure.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in its investment banking and brokerage activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The definition of incorporation of ESG factors is aligned with that of the Global Sustainable Investment Alliance (GSIA) and includes the use of ESG information in the investment decision-making processes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of ESG factors/issues are provided in the PRI Reporting Framework – Main definitions 2018, section “ESG issues.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of investment banking and brokerage activities include, but are not limited to, (a) underwriting, (b) advisory, (c) securitization, (d) investing and lending, and (e) securities services.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Underwriting is defined as activities in which the entity raises investment capital from investors on behalf of corporations and governments that are issuing either equity or debt securities. It includes public offerings and private placements, including local and cross-border transactions and acquisition financing of a wide range of securities and other financial instruments, including loans. Underwriting also covers derivative transactions entered into with public and private sector clients in connection with the entity’s underwriting activities.
• Advisory is defined as activities in which the entity provides financial advice to institutional clients on a fee basis. It excludes wealth management and asset management activities.
• Securitization is defined as the process through which the entity creates a financial instrument by combining other financial assets and then marketing different tiers of the repackaged instruments to investors. It may include securitization of residential and commercial mortgages, corporate bonds, loans, and other types of financial assets by selling these assets to securitization vehicles (e.g., trusts, corporate entities, and limited liability companies) or through a re-securitization.
• Investing and lending includes short-term and long-term investing and relationship lending activities across various asset classes such as debt securities and loans, public and private equity securities, infrastructure, and real estate.
• Securities services include (i) financing services (for the entity clients’ securities trading activities through margin loans that are collateralized by securities), (ii) securities lending services (borrowing and lending securities to cover institutional clients’ short sales, borrowing securities to cover the entity’s short sales, otherwise to making deliveries into the market, broker-to-broker securities lending, and third-party agency lending activities), and (iii) other prime brokerage services (clearing and settlement services).

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to implementation of the aspects of the entity’s ESG incorporation practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Parties responsible for day-to-day incorporation of ESG factors
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Approach to conducting ESG-related research
• Approach to incorporating ESG factors into products and services

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its oversight/accountability approach to the incorporation of ESG factors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The discussion shall include, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Formal oversight individuals and/or bodies involved
• Roles and responsibilities of employees involved
• Criteria used in assessing the quality of ESG incorporation

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether it conducts scenario analysis and/or modeling in which the risk profile of future ESG trends is calculated across its investment banking and brokerage activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Where relevant, the entity shall disclose whether such scenario analysis is performed for specific business activities, including (a) underwriting, (b) advisory, (c) securitization, (d) investing and lending, and (e) securities services lines of business.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: ESG trends include, but are not limited to, climate change, natural resource constraints, human capital risks and opportunities, and cybersecurity risks.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss ESG trends that it views as broadly applicable in terms of their impact on sectors and industries as well as trends it views as sector- or industry-specific.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may further provide the discussion in the context of geographic exposure of its portfolio, by line of business.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe significant concentrations of exposure to ESG factors, including, but not limited to, carbon-related assets, water-stressed regions, and cybersecurity risks.

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how ESG factors are incorporated in the assessment of, and influence the entity’s perspectives on:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Traditional macroeconomic factors such as the economic conditions, central bank monetary policy, industry trends, and geopolitical risks that affect risk profile of clients or individual transactions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Traditional microeconomic factors such supply and demand for products or services which affect financial conditions and operational results of clients as well as their creditworthiness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Time horizon of investments and loans
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Risk and return profiles of investments and loans
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Risk profiles of (a) underwritten debt and equity securities, (b) advisory transactions (e.g., mergers and acquisitions), and (c) securitized assets

Disclosure Topic: Incorporation of Environmental, Social, and Governance Factors in Investment Banking & Brokerage Activities
Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in investment banking and brokerage activities
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose additional quantitative measures related to its approach to incorporation of ESG factors in investment banking and brokerage activities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Number of investment banking and brokerage transactions screened according to Equator Principles (EP III) (or equivalent) by EP Category
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Number of investment banking and brokerage transactions for which a review of environmental or social risks was performed, e.g., by the entity’s Environmental and Social Risk Management (ESRM) group

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The European Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.K Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The U.S. Federal Reserve Board
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: The U.S. Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 9: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 10: The U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with fraud, insider trading, anti-trust, anti-competitive behavior, market manipulation, malpractice, or other related financial industry laws or regulations
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall also include enforcements related to activities adjudicated by federal regulators with an enforcement mandate broader than the financial industry, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) enforced by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act enforced by the U.S. Department of Justice
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The Specially Designated Nationals List enforced by the U.S. Treasury Department through its Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC)

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the processes and policies that are set forth within its whistleblower program, including, but not limited to, internal compliance programs, whistleblower hotline details (e.g., if it is managed by an independent third-party), reference to and publication of the hotline number (e.g., within corporate compliance manuals or code of ethics), whistleblower incentives for reporting violations, and methods for submitting tips.

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include the entity’s compliance with applicable whistleblower regulations, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) [18 U.S.C. § 1514A]
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFPA) [12 U.S.C. § 5567]

Accounting Metric: Description of whistleblower policies and procedures
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include a discussion of any violations of whistleblower regulations and any corrective actions the entity has implemented as a result of violations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide the total number of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: Covered employees are defined as the entity's employees subject to filing the following forms:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Form U4 (Uniform Application for Securities Industry Registration or Transfer) with the Central Registration Depository (CRD) of the U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Form U5 (Uniform Termination Notice for Securities Industry Registration) with the CRD of the FINRA
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Form U6 (Uniform Disciplinary Action Reporting Form) with the CRD of the FINRA
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Form BD (Uniform Application for Broker-Dealer Registration) with the Investment Adviser Registration Depository (IARD) of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Form BDW (Uniform Request for Broker-Dealer Withdrawal) with the IARD of the SEC

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include all covered employees that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period in the calculation.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: Investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, and other regulatory proceedings include those disclosed by a covered employee on Form U4 in section 14, Form U5 in section 7, Form U6, Form BD, or Form BDW.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings by dividing the numerator by the denominator, using the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In the numerator, the entity shall include the number of covered employees with a record of investment-related investigations, consumer-initiated complaints, private civil litigations, or other regulatory proceedings that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • In instances where the first investment-related investigation, consumer-initiated complaint, private civil litigation, or other regulatory proceeding involving the covered employee occurs at the time of employment with the entity, and when the instance requires filing an update to the aforementioned forms, the entity shall include these covered employees in the numerator.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: In the denominator, the entity shall include the number of covered employees that were employed by the entity at any time during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, by party
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, that were filed against the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A mediation is defined as a non-judicial, non-binding dispute resolution method in which an impartial third party mediator facilitates negotiations between disputing parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: An arbitration is defined as a non-judicial, binding or non-binding dispute resolution method in which several impartial third-party arbitrators resolve the dispute by majority vote.

Accounting Metric: Number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, by party
Technical Protocol: Mediation and arbitration cases shall include, but are not limited to, those filed through the U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) or the American Arbitration Association (AAA).

Accounting Metric: Number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, by party
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include mediation and arbitration cases related to controversies that include, but are not limited to, breach of contract, promissory notes, commissions, clearing disputes, breach of fiduciary duty, misrepresentation, negligence, and omission of facts.

Accounting Metric: Number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, by party
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall exclude mediation and arbitration cases related to wrongful termination, compensation, discrimination, and harassment controversies.

Accounting Metric: Number of mediation and arbitration cases associated with professional integrity, including duty of care, by party
Technical Protocol: The entity shall break down the number of mediation and arbitration cases by counterparty as following: (1) clients, (2) employees, and (3) other parties.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes the Rules of the U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to ensuring professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its policies to ensure professional integrity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes aspects of professional integrity related to negligence, breach of fiduciary duty, misrepresentation, omission of facts, and malpractice.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to ensuring professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The scope of ensuring professional integrity includes, but is not limited to, policies, training, and implementation of codes of ethics as well as investigations, enforcements, and disciplinary procedures relating to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Conflicts of interest, such as mitigation and transparency of potential or perceived conflicts
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to the U.S. Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA’s) rules 2241 , 2242 , and 2310(b)(3) .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Oversight of advisory services and recommendations
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to FINRA’s rule 2110.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Maintenance and reporting of accurate data
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to FINRA’s rule 6893.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Protection of confidential business information, including accuracy, retention, and destruction of business records and documents
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Fair pricing
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to FINRA’s rule 2121 .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Employee training on relevant regulations
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 6: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to FINRA’s rule 1250(b) .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Processes for internal investigations for malpractice or negligence
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 7: • Disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, instances related to FINRA’s rules 3110 and 3120 .

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to ensuring professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss compliance with industry best practices, including codes of conduct and codes of ethics, as a measure of its management approach to ensuring quality of work and professional integrity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall discuss its approach to ensuring compliance with sections 2010 and 2200 of the FINRA manual.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its Globally Systematically Important Bank (G-SIB) score for the following categories: (1) Size, (2) Cross-jurisdictional activity, (3) Interconnectedness, (4) Substitutability, (5) Complexity, and (6) Overall score.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The G-SIB scores are defined and shall by calculated according to the methodology established by the Bank of International Settlements' (BIS) Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) in Global systematically important banks: updated assessment methodology and the higher loss absorbency (HLA) requirement, July 2013.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The set of indicators used in calculation of the G-SIB score is outlined by the BCBS in the Reporting instructions and the Reporting template.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The entity shall refer to the Reporting instructions and the Reporting template for the relevant reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The G-SIB score calculation is provided by the BCBS in the technical summary. The BCBS further provides:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
•  Denominators used for score calculation for the relevant reporting period
• The cut-off score used to identify the G-SIBs and bucket thresholds used to allocate G-SIBs to buckets for the purposes of calculating the specific HLA requirements for each institution

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: If the G-SIB score is not available at the time of issuance of the annual report for the respective reporting period, the entity shall disclose the latest available G-SIB score.

Accounting Metric: Global Systemically Important Bank (G-SIB) score, by category
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the above references used to determine the G-SIB score to be normative references, thus any future updates made to them shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests and capital planning reports inform the entity’s decisions and are incorporated into capital planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Stress tests include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
•  Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) 
•  Dodd-Frank Act supervisory stress testing 
•  The Bank of England stress test 
•  The European Union-wide banking stress testing 
•  Monetary Authority of Singapore Annual Industry-Wide Stress Testing exercise 
•  The China Banking Regulatory Commission’s (CBRC) Regulatory Consistency Assessment Programme (RCAP) 
•  Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA)  industry stress test

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how the stress test results inform its approach with respect to its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategy.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to incorporation of results of mandatory and voluntary stress tests into capital adequacy planning, long-term corporate strategy, and other business activities
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose its stress test results along with the discussion.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration that is variable for Material Risk Takers (MRTs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of remuneration for its employees classified as Material Risk Takers (MRTs) that is variable.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall consider its employees as MRTs if their actions have a material impact on the risk exposure of the entity. Such employees generally exhibit characteristics that include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The employee is a member of the management body in its management or supervisory function.
• The employee is a member of senior management.
• The employee heads a material business unit and/or is responsible for risk management within a business unit.
• The employee is responsible for initiating credit proposals or structuring credit products, which can result in material credit risk exposure for the entity.
• The employee is responsible for taking, approving, or vetoing a decision on transactions on the trading book, which can result in material risk exposure for the entity.
• The amount of total remuneration of the employee puts them in the top 10 percent of the highest paid employees of the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Variable remuneration is defined as all remuneration which is not fixed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Remuneration is fixed where all the conditions for its award and its amount:

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration that is variable for Material Risk Takers (MRTs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage by dividing the aggregate amount of the variable remuneration of the entity’s MRTs by the aggregate amount of the total remuneration of the entity’s MRTs.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration that is variable for Material Risk Takers (MRTs)
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of total remuneration that is variable for employees not classified as MRTs.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of total remuneration that is variable for Material Risk Takers (MRTs)
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the number of employees classified as MRTs, provided at the group level and broken down by geographic segment, if the number of MRTs is above 10.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of variable remuneration of Material Risk Takers (MRTs) to which malus or clawback provisions were applied
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of the variable remuneration for employees classified as Material Risk Takers (MRTs) to which malus or clawback provisions were applied during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall consider its employees as MRTs if their actions have a material impact on the risk exposure of the entity. Such employees generally exhibit characteristics that include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The employee is a member of the management body in its management or supervisory function.
• The employee is a member of senior management.
• The employee heads a material business unit and/or is responsible for risk management within a business unit.
• The employee is responsible for initiating credit proposals or structuring credit products, which can result in material credit risk exposure for the entity.
• The employee is responsible for taking, approving, or vetoing a decision on transactions on the trading book, which can result in material risk exposure for the entity.
• The amount of total remuneration of the employee puts them in the top 10 percent of the highest paid employees of the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Variable remuneration is defined as all remuneration which is not fixed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Remuneration is fixed where all the conditions for its award and its amount:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Malus and clawback provisions are defined as explicit ex-post risk adjustment mechanisms where the entity adjusts remuneration of the MRTs based on mechanisms that include, but are not limited to, lowering awarded cash remuneration or reduction of the number or value of the instruments awarded.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of variable remuneration of Material Risk Takers (MRTs) to which malus or clawback provisions were applied
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage by dividing the aggregate amount of the variable remuneration of the entity’s MRTs to which malus or clawback provisions were applied by the aggregate amount of the variable remuneration of the entity’s MRTs, prior to when malus or clawback provisions were applied.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of variable remuneration of Material Risk Takers (MRTs) to which malus or clawback provisions were applied
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of the variable remuneration of employees not classified as MRTs to which malus or clawback provisions were applied during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies around supervision, control, and validation of traders’ pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its policies regarding the supervision, control, and validation processes for the pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Level 3 assets and liabilities are those whose values are based on prices or valuation techniques that require use of unobservable Level 3 inputs.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The definition of Level 3 inputs is aligned with the definitions of the Financial Accounting Standards Board’s (FASB) Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures (Topic 820), No. 2010-06, January 2010 and the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 13 — Fair Value Measurement .

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies around supervision, control, and validation of traders’ pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its policies on supervision of pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities by traders to avoid intentional mispricing of assets.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies around supervision, control, and validation of traders’ pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its controls and validation mechanisms for assumptions and inputs used for the pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies around supervision, control, and validation of traders’ pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the structure of incentive packages for employees responsible for the supervision, control, and validation of the estimates used for the pricing of Level 3 assets and liabilities.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes legal proceedings related to truthful advertising, transparency of small print, marketing to vulnerable groups (e.g., small investors), transparency of fees, mis-selling products, overcharging clients, and legal responsibility of the firm with respect to transparent information and fair advice.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with marketing and communication of insurance product-related information to new and returning customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, federal, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Financial Industry Regulatory Authority’s (FINRA) rules 2210 and 2211
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: New York’s Codes, Rules and Regulations Title 11, Chapter IX, Parts 215, 219 and 224
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: California’s Insurance Code, Part 1, Chapter 3, Article 1

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its complaints-to-claims ratio.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the ratio as the number of complaints the entity received across all insurance segments and regions during the reporting period per 1,000 claims that have been filed across all segments and regions during the same reporting period.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include all complaints reported by all state insurance departments to the National Association of Insurance Commissioners' (NAIC) Consumer Information Source that are included on the Closed Complaints Reports for all subsidiaries of the entity.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include only confirmed complaints, which are defined as complaints in which the final resolution by the respective state upheld the consumer's complaint position and exclude complaints classified as “No Action Requested/Required” or “Complaint Withdrawn” in the “Final decisions regarding complaints” section of the Closed Complaint Counts by Code Report.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include complaints classified to any of the categories in the “Reasons why complaints were submitted” section of the Closed Complaints Counts by Code Report, including the Underwriting, Marketing & Sales, Claim Handling, and Policyholder Service sections.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Complaints-to-claims ratio
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity may additionally disclose the complaints-to-claims ratio by product segment (e.g., commercial, consumer), insurance type (e.g., property, casualty, life), geographic region, or other breakdown.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Customer retention rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its customer retention rate.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Customer retention rate
Technical Protocol: The rate shall be calculated as following: (Total number of customers at close of reporting period - new customers added during the reporting period) / (customers at the close of the previous reporting period - customers involuntarily terminated during the reporting period - attrition of customers in employer-sponsored plans).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Involuntarily terminated customers—those whose coverage was terminated by the entity due to nonpayment fraud or intentional misrepresentation of material facts—shall be excluded from the calculation.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Attrition of customers in employer-sponsored plans (e.g., life insurance plans) due to turnover (voluntary or involuntary) shall be excluded from the calculation.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Fair Advice for Customers
Accounting Metric: Customer retention rate
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity may additionally disclose the retention rate by product segment (e.g., commercial, consumer), insurance type (e.g., property, casualty, life), geographic region, or other breakdown.
