Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may access the list through the FDA’s MedWatch Safety Information and Adverse Event Reporting Program by navigating to the “Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products” subsection of the “Safety Information” section of the MedWatch: The FDA Safety Information and Adverse Event Reporting Program.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The safety alerts are organized into four categories:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Drugs and Therapeutic Biological Products
• Medical Devices
• Special Nutritional and Cosmetic Products
• Products with Undeclared Drug Ingredients
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall disclose all listings associated with the entity that appear in the Drugs and Therapeutic Biological Products list, including trade names for which the entity has patents or active ingredients or classes of product that it manufactures and markets.

Accounting Metric: List of products listed in the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) MedWatch Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products database
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose all drugs and therapeutic biological products associated with the entity for which the FDA staff in the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research (CDER) and Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research (CBER) have identified potential safety issues.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A list of products is available in the “Potential Signals of Serious Risks/New Safety Information Identified from the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System (FAERS) (formerly AERS)” page under the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System (FAERS).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose all listings associated with the entity that appear in the list, including trade names for which the entity has patents or active ingredients or classes of product that it manufactures and markets.

Accounting Metric: List of products listed in the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) MedWatch Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products database
Technical Protocol: If the entity manufactures a product with an active ingredient or a product in a product class listed in these databases but has evidence that the listing does not apply to its specific products, it shall provide such evidence.

Accounting Metric: Number of fatalities associated with products as reported in the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of fatalities associated with all drugs and biologic products it manufactures.

Accounting Metric: Number of fatalities associated with products as reported in the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall include all fatalities that occurred during the reporting period for which it is disclosing, even if the adverse event began in a prior period.

Accounting Metric: Number of fatalities associated with products as reported in the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System
Technical Protocol: The entity may access a list of fatalities through the FDA Adverse Event Reporting System (FAERS).

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of recalls for drug products that the entity manufactures, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Recalls are defined as actions taken by an entity to remove a product from the market, including those conducted on the entity's own initiative, by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) request, or by FDA order under statutory authority.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Drugs are defined by the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic (FD&C) Act sec. 201(g)(1) as articles intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease, and articles (other than food) intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of man or other animals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Drugs include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Pharmaceutical prescription products as well as over-the-counter medications
• Biological products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure shall include recalls associated with all devices manufactured by the entity or by its subsidiaries.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss notable recalls such as those that affected a significant number of units of one product or those related to serious injury or fatality. For such recalls the entity should provide:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Description and cause of the recall issue
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The total number of units recalled
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The cost to remedy the issue
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Whether the recall was initiated voluntarily or at the request of the FDA or non-U.S. national regulatory authority
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Corrective actions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any other significant outcomes (e.g., legal proceedings or customer fatalities)

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify all products manufactured by it or its subsidiaries for which it is listed as the recalling firm in the “Biologics” and “Drugs” product types in Food and Drug Administration (FDA) enforcement reports.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Entities may review the weekly enforcement reports published by the FDA, which are publicly available on the “Recalls, Market Withdrawals, & Safety Alerts” subsection of the FDA’s “Safety” webpage. These reports contain all recalls by product type, product description, code info, classification, reason for recall, and recalling firm.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose recalls in non-U.S. markets that have been initiated voluntarily, at the request of a non-U.S. national regulatory authority, or by order of a non-U.S. national regulatory authority under statutory authority.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose recalls initiated voluntarily that have not been reported to the FDA (or national regulatory authority) and/or are not listed in an FDA enforcement report.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of drug units that were subject to a recall.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose, in addition to the total number of drug recalls, the percentage of recalls that were:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: FDA requested
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: FDA mandated

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: For FDA-initiated recalls, the entity may disclose the FDA classification of each recall, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Class I
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Class II
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Class III

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: For each recalled product, the entity may disclose revenues from 12 months prior to the date of recall. This 12-month period may extend beyond the reporting period for which the entity is disclosing; the figure is intended to indicate annual revenues associated with the product such that the financial impact of the recall can be gauged.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: If a recall relates to only a subset of a product (e.g., specific lots or a particular style), then the entity should indicate the scope of the recall; and, if the entity is disclosing revenue associated with the recall, it should be limited to the portion of the product affected by the recall.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of product accepted for take-back, reuse, or disposal
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of unused product, in metric tons, that is accepted through take-back initiatives.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Unused product includes that which is expired, unwanted, waste, or excess.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Product take-back includes reclaiming unused products from end-consumers or medical facilities for redistribution or disposal.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Biopharmaceutical reuse programs include redistribution initiatives aimed at providing medication to underserved populations, subject to state or local laws.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Disposal of biopharmaceutical products includes, but is not limited to, high-temperature incineration that must be conducted in accordance with federal or state laws governing management of unused pharmaceuticals, such as the Controlled Substance Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), and the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of product accepted for take-back, reuse, or disposal
Technical Protocol: For initiatives that are co-funded by the entity, it shall prorate the amount of product accepted for take-back by its percentage contribution to the funding of the initiative.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of product accepted for take-back, reuse, or disposal
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss systemic efforts related to end-of-life management of its products, including, but not limited to those intended to prevent:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Back-market sales
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Abuse
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Release into the environment

Accounting Metric: Total amount of product accepted for take-back, reuse, or disposal
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose expenditures for funding of programs or initiatives that are financially supported and administered by the entity as well as initiatives funded by the entity that are administered by third parties for the express purpose of product take-back.

Accounting Metric: Number of FDA enforcement actions taken in response to violations of current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMP), by type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number and type of Food and Drug Administration (FDA) enforcement actions taken during the reporting period in response to current good manufacturing practice (cGMP) (or regional equivalent) violations at its facilities. Enforcement actions include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Form 483s
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Warning letters
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Seizures
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Recalls
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Consent decrees

Accounting Metric: Number of FDA enforcement actions taken in response to violations of current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMP), by type
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes facilities that are owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Description of methods and technologies used to maintain traceability of products throughout the supply chain and prevent counterfeiting
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the type and sophistication of technology it uses to maintain traceability and serialization, as well as to prevent counterfeiting of its products, including, but not limited to, the use of barcode technology and radio frequency identification (RFID) tagging, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Counterfeit drugs are defined as drugs sold under a product name without proper authorization. Counterfeiting can apply to both brand name and generic products, where the identity of the source is mislabeled in a way that suggests that it is the authentic, approved product. Counterfeit products may include products that lack the active ingredient, contain an insufficient or excessive quantity of the active ingredient, contain the wrong active ingredient, or have fake packaging.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Traceability refers to the ability to track identifying information (e.g., chemical composition, supplier, production date, production location, or processing history) of a product throughout various stages of manufacturing and distribution (such as raw material sourcing, manufacturing, distribution, and retail).

Accounting Metric: Description of methods and technologies used to maintain traceability of products throughout the supply chain and prevent counterfeiting
Technical Protocol: Relevant elements of the product supply chain include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Drug wholesale and distribution
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Manufacturing
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Pharmacy retail
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Transportation logistics

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Customers include, but are note limited to, patients and physicians
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Business partners include, but are not limited to, suppliers, wholesalers, retailers, and hospitals
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Counterfeit drugs are defined as drugs sold under a product name without proper authorization. Counterfeiting can apply to both brand name and generic products, where the identity of the source is mislabeled in a way that suggests that it is the authentic, approved product. Counterfeit products may include products that lack the active ingredient, contain an insufficient or excessive quantity of the active ingredient, contain the wrong active ingredient, or have fake packaging

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall include recommended actions for the respective parties to minimize risks of counterfeiting.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall include a description of the entity’s mechanisms for product recall.

Accounting Metric: Number of actions that led to raids, seizure, arrests, and/or filing of criminal charges related to counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of instances in which it took action to alert and/or aid regulatory authorities or law enforcement agencies with respect to counterfeiting, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The provision of information or evidence that led to raids or arrests of counterfeiters or the seizure of counterfeit products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The filing of criminal charges against counterfeiters

Accounting Metric: Number of actions that led to raids, seizure, arrests, and/or filing of criminal charges related to counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: Relevant authorities and agencies include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The British Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Authority (MHRA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The Australian Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA)

Accounting Metric: Number of actions that led to raids, seizure, arrests, and/or filing of criminal charges related to counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: If the entity collaborated with other entities, such as manufacturers, wholesalers, or pharmacies, it may disclose these instances but should indicate which other entities were involved.

Accounting Metric: Number of actions that led to raids, seizure, arrests, and/or filing of criminal charges related to counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall also provide a description of actions taken, including—where relevant—the parties involved, role of the entity, type and value of products in question, and outcome of the action.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as the U.S. False Claims Act.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the aspects of its code of ethics that relate to ethical marketing and off-label promotion, including describing how it defines and/or what it considers “off-label promotion.”

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: A corporate policy, code of conduct, guideline, or contractual term that is similar in intent to a code of ethics shall be treated as equivalent for the purposes of this metric.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the mechanisms it has in place to ensure compliance with its code, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disciplinary actions for violations
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Training
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Internal audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Regulatory review committees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Training

Accounting Metric: Discussion of talent recruitment and retention efforts for scientists and research and development personnel
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategy to attract and retain talent, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Mentorship programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Career development programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Leadership training
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Incentive structures

Accounting Metric: Discussion of talent recruitment and retention efforts for scientists and research and development personnel
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the following elements of recruitment and retention programs, including associated quantitative metrics:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Overview
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Participation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Effectiveness

Accounting Metric: Discussion of talent recruitment and retention efforts for scientists and research and development personnel
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall focus on scientists and other personnel that are directly involved in research and development of activities for new biopharmaceutical products.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) executives/senior managers, (b) mid-level managers, (c) professionals, and (d) all others
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose voluntary and involuntary employee turnover for all employees by the following employee categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Executives/senior managers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Mid-level managers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Professionals
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: All others

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) executives/senior managers, (b) mid-level managers, (c) professionals, and (d) all others
Technical Protocol: The entity shall classify all employees according to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission EEO-1 Job Classification Guide and record the number of employees employed at any time during the reporting period in each classification.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) executives/senior managers, (b) mid-level managers, (c) professionals, and (d) all others
Technical Protocol: For each category of employee, the entity shall calculate monthly voluntary turnover.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary turnover shall be calculated as the total number of employee-initiated, voluntary separation (such as resignation or retirement) for each month divided by the average number of employees for the month (the sum of the employees on the entity’s payroll at each pay period / number of pay periods).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose its annual voluntary turnover rate, calculated by adding the 12 monthly turnover figures together and multiplying by 100 to arrive at a percentage.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) executives/senior managers, (b) mid-level managers, (c) professionals, and (d) all others
Technical Protocol: For each category of employee, the entity shall calculate monthly involuntary turnover.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Involuntary turnover shall be calculated as total number of entity-initiated separation (such as dismissal, downsizing, redundancy, or expiry of contract) for each month divided by the average number of employees for the month (the sum of the employees on the entity’s payroll at each pay period / number of pay periods).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose its annual involuntary turnover rate which is calculated by adding the 12 monthly turnover figures together and multiplying by 100 to arrive at a percentage.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) entity's facilities and (2) Tier I suppliers' facilities participating in the Rx-360 International Pharmaceutical Supply Chain Consortium audit program or equivalent third-party audit programs for integrity of supply chain and ingredients
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of its facilities that participate in the Rx-360 International Pharmaceutical Supply Chain Consortium audit program or equivalent third-party audit programs for integrity of supply chain and ingredients.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An equivalent third-party audit program is one conducted by an external auditing agency and that contains the same integrity of supply chain and integrity of ingredient requirements as the Rx-360 program.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes facilities that are owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) entity's facilities and (2) Tier I suppliers' facilities participating in the Rx-360 International Pharmaceutical Supply Chain Consortium audit program or equivalent third-party audit programs for integrity of supply chain and ingredients
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of its Tier I suppliers’ facilities (limited to facilities with which the entity conducts business) that participate in the Rx-360 (or equivalent) audit program.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Tier I suppliers are those that transact directly with the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may limit its disclosure to those suppliers that in aggregate account for greater than or equal to 90 percent of its supplier spending.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with corruption and bribery
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery and corruption.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with corruption and bribery
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with corruption and bribery
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with corruption and bribery
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with corruption and bribery
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Federal Anti-Kickback Statute
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe aspects of any code of ethics that relate to the entity’s interactions with health care professions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Health care professionals include individuals or entities which are involved in the provision of health care services and/or items to patients, such as physicians, dentists, pharmacists, and nurses. Additionally, the term includes those who purchase, lease, recommend, use, arrange for the purchase or lease of, or prescribe the entity’s products, but do not necessarily provide health care services directly, such as purchasing agents, practice managers, and group purchasing organizations (GPOs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of the disclosure includes the content (topics such as food and entertainment, training and education, and participation in committees that set formularies) and scope (type and percentage of staff to which it relates) of the code of ethics.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: A corporate policy, code of conduct, guidelines, or contractual term that is similar in intent to a code of ethics shall be treated as equivalent for the purposes of this metric.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss mechanisms to ensure compliance with its code, such as training (including the degree and frequency) and enforcement (e.g., inspections or review committees).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Enforcement, including inspection, compliance, and review committees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation of corrective actions when a code is violated
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Training, including degree and frequency

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: If the entity has adopted a second- or third-party code of ethics such as PhRMA’s Code on Interactions with Healthcare Professionals, it may reference this code without describing the content.

Accounting Metric: Payload fuel economy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its aggregate payload fuel economy for its transportation fleet.

Accounting Metric: Payload fuel economy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate payload fuel economy across its delivery fleet, limited to vehicles used for the delivery of products (excluding vehicles used primarily for the transportation of passengers).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall disclose payload fuel economy for vehicles it operates (e.g., owns or long-term leases) and specify if all or a portion of its logistics operations are outsourced.

Accounting Metric: Payload fuel economy
Technical Protocol: Payload fuel economy shall be calculated as: total gallons of fuel consumed / revenue tons miles (RTM), where revenue ton miles (RTM) = total weight of paid tonnage transported (payload) × total distance in miles goods were transported.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Payload includes the weight of paid tonnage and excludes the vehicle weight.

Accounting Metric: Payload fuel economy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall aggregate payload fuel economy for types of transportation, which include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Air transportation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Marine transportation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Rail transportation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Road transportation

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the environmental impact of logistics
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its programs and initiatives to reduce the environmental impact of its logistics operations.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the environmental impact of logistics
Technical Protocol: Relevant efforts to describe include, but are not limited to, upgrades to fleet (fuel efficiency), usage of alternative and/or renewable fuels, optimized logistics routes, and idling reduction programs.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the environmental impact of logistics
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether it is a participant in the EPA SmartWay program, or a similar program. If the entity is a participant in the EPA SmartWay program, it should describe the nature of its participation, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: SmartWay Carriers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: SmartWay Logistics Companies
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: SmartWay Shippers

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. False Claims Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with product safety
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize health and safety risks of products sold associated with toxicity/chemical safety, high abuse potential, or delivery
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe all relevant aspects, such as the structure, goals, implementation, and scope, of efforts aimed at minimizing the health and safety risks of the products it distributes.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize health and safety risks of products sold associated with toxicity/chemical safety, high abuse potential, or delivery
Technical Protocol: Relevant risks to discuss may include, but are not limited to those related to the toxicity of chemicals or materials in the products it distributes, those related to the use of the products, and those related to delivery of the products to customers, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure related to toxicity may include efforts to reduce the sale of products containing Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation, and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) substances of very high concern.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Disclosure related to product use may include products that have a high potential for abuse or side effects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Disclosure related to product delivery may include ensuring proper dosage is dispensed, proper labeling, and that products are not reused on multiple patients when such re-use is not appropriate.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize health and safety risks of products sold associated with toxicity/chemical safety, high abuse potential, or delivery
Technical Protocol: Relevant initiatives may include labeling, training, education, and “right-sizing” of packaged dosages.

Accounting Metric: Description of methods and technologies used to maintain traceability of products throughout the distribution chain and prevent counterfeiting
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the type and sophistication of technology it uses to maintain traceability and serialization of its products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Traceability refers to the ability to track identifying information (e.g., chemical composition, supplier, production date, production location, and/or processing history) of a product throughout various stages of manufacturing and distribution such as raw material sourcing, manufacturing, distribution, and retail.

Accounting Metric: Description of methods and technologies used to maintain traceability of products throughout the distribution chain and prevent counterfeiting
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss other methods it uses to minimize the risk of counterfeit products entering the supply chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Counterfeit drugs are defined as drugs sold under a product name without proper authorization. Counterfeiting can apply to both brand name and generic products, where the identity of the source is mislabeled in a way that suggests that it is the authentic, approved product. Counterfeit products may include products that lack the active ingredient, contain an insufficient or excessive quantity of the active ingredient, contain the wrong active ingredient, or have fake packaging.

Accounting Metric: Description of methods and technologies used to maintain traceability of products throughout the distribution chain and prevent counterfeiting
Technical Protocol: Relevant processes to discuss may include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vendor inspection and supply chain audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Traceability, radio frequency identification (RFID) tagging, and bar code systems (including those related to Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA) compliance)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Participation in industry partnerships and initiatives, such as audit sharing programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Implementation of alert systems
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Training programs for pharmacists and other supply chain employees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Coordination with law enforcement
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Customer feedback tools
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: Purchasing directly from the manufacturer

Accounting Metric: Discussion of due diligence process to qualify suppliers of drug products and medical equipment and devices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its process for identifying, screening, and approving product suppliers.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of due diligence process to qualify suppliers of drug products and medical equipment and devices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the use of processes, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Questionnaires
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Codes of conduct
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Inspections or audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Third-party certifications for current good manufacturing processes (cGMP)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Third-party certifications for quality management systems

Accounting Metric: Discussion of due diligence process to qualify suppliers of drug products and medical equipment and devices
Technical Protocol: The entity may briefly discuss its screening requirements related to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Customers include, but are not limited to, patients and physicians.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Business partners include, but are not limited to, suppliers, wholesalers, retailers, and hospitals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Counterfeit drugs are defined as drugs sold under a product name without proper authorization. Counterfeiting can apply to both brand name and generic products, where the identity of the source is mislabeled in a way that suggests that it is the authentic, approved product. Counterfeit products may include products that lack the active ingredient, contain an insufficient or excessive quantity of the active ingredient, contain the wrong active ingredient, or have fake packaging.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall include recommended actions for the respective parties to minimize risks of counterfeiting.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process for alerting customers and business partners of potential or known risks associated with counterfeit products
Technical Protocol: The scope of the disclosure shall include a description of the entity’s mechanisms for product recall.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging throughout its lifecycle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe policies, initiatives, designs, or vendor requirements related to reducing the environmental impact of packaging of the products it distributes.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging throughout its lifecycle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall indicate the degree of control or influence it has over packaging choices for these products such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Primary
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Secondary
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Tertiary

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging throughout its lifecycle
Technical Protocol: Where the entity has direct control over packaging choices, relevant efforts to describe may include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Dematerialization
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Using recycled content materials
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Using certified paper products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Designing packaging with materials that can be readily recycled or composted
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Using packaging strategies that allow for consolidated shipping
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Shipping products in reusable containers

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging throughout its lifecycle
Technical Protocol: Where the entity does not have direct control over packaging choices of the products it distributes, the entity may describe vendor requirements that relate to efforts to reduce the environmental impacts of packaging.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to reduce the environmental impact of packaging throughout its lifecycle
Technical Protocol: The entity may include quantitative measures of performance with respect to waste reduction strategies, which include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Percentage reductions in weight
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Number of times containers are reused before disposal or recycling
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The ratio of packaging to product weight

Accounting Metric: Amount (by weight) of products accepted for take-back and reused, recycled, or donated
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of its products that it accepted for take-back and then reused (refurbished), recycled, or donated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure shall include drugs and medical devices and supplies.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall exclude products that were accepted for take-back but were ultimately discarded as waste.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The entity may indicate, however, if it reclaimed any products that it was unable to recycle or reuse because proper, safe disposal was necessary (e.g., mercury-containing products, sharps, and expired drug products).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The amount shall be calculated as: the weight of material reused + the weight of material recycled or remanufactured (through treatment or processing) + the weight of material donated.

Accounting Metric: Amount (by weight) of products accepted for take-back and reused, recycled, or donated
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately disclose the amounts, in metric tons, of its (1) drugs and (2) medical devices and supplies that it accepted for take-back and then reused (refurbished), recycled, or donated.

Accounting Metric: Amount (by weight) of products accepted for take-back and reused, recycled, or donated
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe programs and initiatives it implements, funds, or participates in that are related to product take-back for end-of-life management of its products.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize conflicts of interest and unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the content of its code of conduct related to corruption, bribery, or other unethical business practices, including but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Business competition
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Business intelligence
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Interactions with government officials
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Marketing

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize conflicts of interest and unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the scope of its code of conduct related to corruption, bribery, or other unethical business practices, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Type of staff to which the code of conduct relates
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Percentage of staff to which the code of conduct relates

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize conflicts of interest and unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope, degree, and frequency of mechanisms to ensure compliance with its code, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Education
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Training

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to minimize conflicts of interest and unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss mechanisms of enforcement of its code of conduct, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Compliance or review committees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation of corrective action when the code is violated
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Inspection

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or ethical business regulations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. False Claims Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to securing customer protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII), with a specific focus on how it addresses the collection, usage, and retention of customers’ information, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PHI is defined in U.S. law 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (“Privacy”) of the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: the information (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse; and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that (A) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse, and (B) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U.S.C. 1232g (a)(4)(B)(iv), and employment records held by a drug retailer in its role as employer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records and any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information.
TP_BP2 Footnote: Privacy: Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information, GAO Report 08-536, May 2008.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect individuals’ privacy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: With respect to data collection, the entity may discuss which data or types of data are collected without consent of an individual, which require opt-in consent, and which require opt-out action from the individual.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: With respect to usage of data, the entity may discuss which data or types of data are used by the entity internally and under what circumstance the entity shares, sells, rents, or otherwise distributes data or information to third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: With respect to retention, the entity may discuss which data or types of data it retains, the length of time of retention, and practices used to ensure that data is stored securely.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the systems it uses to ensure compliance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules and the HITECH Act, including policies and practices related to the collection, usage, storage, and disposal of PHI and PII.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its efforts to ensure compliance in the context of how it implements the following three categories of system security:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Administrative safeguards, which are defined as documented, formal policies and procedures that are intended to manage the selection and execution of security measures to protect data and manage the conduct of personnel in relation to the protection of data.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Physical safeguards, which are defined as the protection of physical computer systems and the buildings holding such systems from natural and environmental hazards and inappropriate intrusion or removal.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Technical safeguards, which are defined as processes put in place to protect information, authenticate users, and control individual access to information.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: Relevant practices to discuss include internal monitoring practices, technology and security programs to prevent data breaches, training programs and protocols in place for employees who handle PHI or PII, and disposal methods for paper and electronic PHI records.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose if it employs heightened security measures to ensure the security of PHI, including a discussion of those additional measures.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity should not include in its disclosure any information that compromises the security of its systems or its enrollees’ PHI or PII.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity’s expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (a) personally identifiable information (PII), but not protected health information (PHI), was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including: (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PHI is defined in U.S. 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (‘Privacy’) of the U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH Act) as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: The information (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse and relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the U.S. Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U.S.C. 1232g (a)(4)(B)(iv), and employment records held by a covered entity in its role as employer.
• PHI is a subset of PII.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (a) PII, but not PHI, was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Directive 2002/58/EC (ePrivacy Directive) of the U.S. Federal Trade Commission Privacy Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Program

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Office for Civil Rights

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe any practices or policies it has implemented to mitigate the introduction of counterfeit or compromised drugs into its supply chain, including, but not limited to, implementation of or updates to internal controls and updates to operations, management, processes, products, business partners, training, or technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: Compromised drugs include counterfeit drugs and other drugs that are recalled or that are of substandard quality because of a health or other safety hazard, mislabeling or improper packaging, potential contamination, or poor manufacturing.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Counterfeit drugs are defined as drugs sold under a product name without proper authorization. Counterfeiting can apply to both brand name and generic products, where the identity of the source is mislabeled in a way that suggests that it is the authentic, approved product. Counterfeit products may include products that lack the active ingredient, contain an insufficient or excessive quantity of the active ingredient, contain the wrong active ingredient, or have fake packaging.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: Relevant processes to discuss include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vendor inspection and supply chain audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Traceability and bar code systems, including those related to U.S. Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA) compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Participation in industry partnerships and initiatives, such as audit sharing programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Implementation of alert systems
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Training programs for pharmacists and other supply chain employees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Coordination with law enforcement
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Customer feedback tools

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its practices to identify compromised drugs in the supply chain differ between its private-label products and national brand products.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: The entity shall specifically discuss its plan for achieving complete implementation of the DSCSA within the DSCSA-mandated timeframe, including implementation of measures as they align with requirements of Title II of the Drug Quality and Security Act, which outlines critical steps to build an electronic, interoperable system to identify and trace certain prescription drugs as they are distributed in the U.S.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to reduce the occurrence of compromised drugs within the supply chain
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its implementation of the DSCSA provisions across its operations, including any measures it has implemented to meet requirements for product identification, product tracing, product verification, detection and response, notification, and licensing.

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of recalls for drug products that the entity retails, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Drugs are defined by the U.S. FD&C Act sec. 201(g)(1) as articles intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease and articles (other than food) intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of man or other animals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Drugs include pharmaceutical prescription products as well as over-the-counter medications. Recalls are defined as actions taken by a firm to remove a product from the market, including those conducted on the entity’s own initiative, by FDA request, or by FDA order under statutory authority.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: A recall is defined as removal or correction of a marketed product that the FDA considers to be in violation of the laws it administers and against which the agency would initiate legal action.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Removal means the physical removal of a device from its point of use to some other location for repair, modification, adjustment, relabeling, destruction, or inspection.
• Correction means repair, modification, adjustment, relabeling, destruction, or inspection of a product without its physical removal to some other location.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope includes all recalls of drugs for sale by the entity, whether initiated by the FDA or voluntarily by the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The scope of recalls excludes market withdrawals, which are defined as an entity’s removal or correction of a distributed product that involves a minor violation that would not be subject to legal action by the U.S. FDA or that involves no violation (e.g., normal stock rotation practices).

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes voluntary recalls initiated by the entity and recalls requested or mandated by the FDA (or other relevant government agency).

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of drug product units available for sale by the entity that were subject to a recall.

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of the total number of units recalled that were for private-label products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Private-label is defined as a product containing the entity's brand name and label, whether manufactured by a third-party vendor or by the entity's own facilities.

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose, in addition to the total number of drug recalls, the percentage of recalls that were:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: FDA requested
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: FDA mandated

Accounting Metric: Number of drug recalls issued, total units recalled, percentage for private-label products
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of the total number of units recalled that were part of Class I recalls, where a Class I recalls is defined as a situation in which there is a reasonable probability that the use of, or exposure to, a violative product will cause serious adverse health consequences or death.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed for which a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database was queried
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of controlled substance prescriptions that it dispensed for which a pharmacist queried a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database prior to dispensing the prescription, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Controlled substances are defined in §802(6) of Title 21, U.S. Code (U.S.C.) as drugs that have some potential for abuse or dependence and are regulated by the federal Controlled Substances Act (CSA). Controlled substances exclude distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, or tobacco, as those terms are defined or used in subtitle E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A PDMP is defined as an electronic database that collects designated data about controlled substances dispensed, typically on a statewide level. PDMPs are housed by specified statewide regulatory, administrative, or law enforcement agencies, and this housing agency distributes data from the database to individuals who are authorized under state law to receive the information for purposes of their profession.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: A PDMP shall be considered queried if the entity has a record that an authorized individual accessed the applicable PDMP system prior to dispensing a prescription in an effort to locate patient prescription history information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Patients and circumstances of a type that are excluded from PDMP reporting and querying, based on waiver or exemption established by state law, shall be excluded from the scope of this calculation.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed for which a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database was queried
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage as the number of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed for which a PDMP was queried divided by the total number of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Patients and circumstances that are excluded from PDMP reporting and querying based on state exemptions shall not be included in the number of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed where a PDMP was queried or the total number of controlled substance prescriptions dispensed.
