Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as the U.S. Controlled Substances Act.

Accounting Metric: First fill adherence rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its customer first fill adherence rate, where the rate is calculated as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage of customer prescriptions that are required by the prescriber to have one or more refill(s) and were refilled by the entity at least once after the initial fill divided by the total number of customer prescriptions that were initially filled by the entity and were required by the prescriber to have at least one additional refill, regardless of whether the prescription was refilled.

Accounting Metric: First fill adherence rate
Technical Protocol: The scope includes prescriptions that were initially filled in the entity's pharmacies and excludes prescriptions that were transferred into the entity's pharmacy from another pharmacy, and out of the entity’s pharmacy after the initial fill.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to prevent prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and practices to prevent prescription dispensing errors in its pharmacies and for any mail order dispensing activities, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A dispensing error is defined as a discrepancy between the medicine indicated on a prescription and the medicine that the pharmacy delivers to the patient, including the dispensing of a medicine with inferior pharmaceutical or informational quality.
TP_BP1 Footnote: ACG Egberts and PMLA van den Bemt, “Drug-related problems: definitions and classification,” EJHP Practice, Vol. 13, 2007, pp. 62– 64.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to prevent prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: Relevant policies and practices to describe include, but are not limited to, implementation of quality assurance protocols, use of bar coding, automation of processes, use of data verification systems, training of key employees, and improvements to the accuracy of recordkeeping.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to prevent prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The entity may also choose to discuss observed trends or high-risk practices that could lead to dispensing errors as well the number of dispensing errors identified.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A dispensing error is a discrepancy between a prescription and the medicine that the pharmacy delivers to the patient, including the dispensing of a medicine with inferior pharmaceutical or informational quality.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with prescription dispensing errors
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, federal, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as individual State Boards of Pharmacy in the U.S.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of medical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of medical waste generated, in metric tons, aggregated for all facilities it owns and operates.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of medical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: Medical waste (also known as regulated medical waste, infectious waste, biomedical waste, or biohazardous waste), that may be subject to federal or state level regulation, shall be defined according to the expired Medical Waste Tracking Act of 1988 and includes:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Cultures and Stocks — Cultures and stocks of infection agents and associated biological cultures, including cultures from medical and pathological laboratories, and stocks of infectious agents from research and industrial laboratories, waste from the production of biological, discarded live and attenuated vaccines, and culture dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate, and mix cultures.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Pathological Wastes — Human pathological wastes, including tissues, organs, body parts, and body fluids that are removed during surgery and autopsy, or other medical procedures, and specimens of body fluids and their containers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Human Blood and Blood Products — (1) Liquid waste human blood; (2) products of blood; (3) items saturated and/or dropping with human blood; or (4) items that were saturated and/or dripping with human blood that are now caked with dried human blood, including serum, plasma, and other blood components, and their containers that were used or intended for use in patient care, testing and laboratory analysis, or the development of pharmaceuticals. Intravenous bags are also included in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Sharps — Sharps that have been used in animal or human patient care or treatment, or in medical research or industrial laboratories, including hypodermic needles, syringes (with or without the attached needle), Pasteur pipettes, scalpel blades, blood vials, needles with attached tubing, and culture dishes (regardless of presence of infectious agents). Also included are other types of broken or unbroken glassware that were in contact with infectious agents, such as used slide and cover slips.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Animal Waste — Contaminated animal carcasses, body parts, and bedding of animals that were known to have been exposed to infectious agents during research (including research in veterinary hospitals), production of biologicals, or testing of pharmaceuticals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Isolation Wastes — Biological waste and discarded materials contaminated with blood, excretion, exudates, or secretions from humans who are isolated to protect others from certain highly communicable diseases, or isolated animals known to be infected with highly communicable diseases.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Unused Sharps — The following unused discarded sharps: hypodermic needles, suture needles, syringes, and scalpel blades.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of medical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentages of medical waste by their final disposition method as the total weight of medical waste generated that was (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled, divided by the total weight of medical waste generated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Recycling or treatment shall include disposal via recycling facility, treatment facility, or other (e.g., return to a supplier or commercial composting).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of medical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: If the entity utilizes a waste transport service, broker, or intermediary to handle its medical waste, it shall make a good faith effort to determine the final disposition method.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of: (1) hazardous and (2) non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated, in metric tons, aggregated for all facilities it owns and operates, and the percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hazardous waste includes listed Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) waste and non-listed, characteristic waste.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Listed RCRA waste is defined as waste that appears on one of the four hazardous wastes lists (F-list, K-list, P-list, or U-list) found in regulation 40 CFR Part 261.
• Non-listed, characteristic waste is defined as waste that exhibits at least one of four characteristics: ignitibility, corrosivity, reactivity, or toxicity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall follow the most recent version of definitions provided by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Management Standards for Hazardous Waste Pharmaceuticals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the percentages of hazardous pharmaceutical waste by their final disposition method as the total weight of hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated that was (a) incinerated, (b) recycled/treated, and (c) landfilled, divided by the total weight of hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Recycling or  treatment shall include disposal via recycling facility, treatment facility, or other (e.g., return to a supplier or commercial composting).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of: (1) hazardous and (2) non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total amount of non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated, in metric tons, aggregated for all facilities it owns and operates, and the percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Non-hazardous (solid) waste is defined as any garbage or refuse, sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility and other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semi-solid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations, and from community activities. It may require special handling because it is a controlled substance or poses an environmental or human health effect.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the percentages of non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste by their final disposition method as the total weight of non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated that was (a) incinerated, (b) recycled/treated, and (c) landfilled, divided by the total weight of non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste generated.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Recycling or treatment shall include disposal via recycling facility, treatment facility, or other (e.g., return to a supplier or commercial composting).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of: (1) hazardous and (2) non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: If there are other disposition methods for hazardous or non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste (e.g., composting or permanent long-term storage), then the entity should disclose these.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of: (1) hazardous and (2) non-hazardous pharmaceutical waste, percentage (a) incinerated, (b) recycled or treated, and (c) landfilled
Technical Protocol: If the entity utilizes a waste transport service, broker, or intermediary to handle its pharmaceutical waste, it shall make a good faith effort to determine the final disposition method.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of patient records that are Electronic Health Records (EHR) that meet "meaningful use" requirements
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose the percentage of records that are electronic health records (EHR) in “meaningful use.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Meaningful use is defined in 42 CFR (Public Health) Part 495 (Standard for the Electronic Health Record Technology Incentive Program) and promulgated by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) as part of its EHR Incentive Programs

Accounting Metric: Percentage of patient records that are Electronic Health Records (EHR) that meet "meaningful use" requirements
Technical Protocol: EHR systems that are certified by an authorized testing and certification body according to the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology (ONC HIT) Certification Criteria, which are listed on the Certified Health IT Product List (CHPL), shall be considered to meet the “meaningful use” requirements.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall indicate which edition of the ONC HIT Certification Criteria its EHR systems are certified to, if not the most currently available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of patient records that are Electronic Health Records (EHR) that meet "meaningful use" requirements
Technical Protocol: If the entity does not participate in the Medicare or Medicaid EHR Incentive Program and/or its EHR is not listed on the CHPL, it may demonstrate through an independent audit that its EHR meets the threshold and all of the requirements for “meaningful use.”

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to securing customer protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII), with a specific focus on how it addresses the collection, usage, and retention of customers’ information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PHI is defined in U.S. 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (“Privacy”) of the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: The information (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that (a) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse and (b) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U?.?S?.?C?.? 1232?g?(?a?)?(?4?)?(?B  ?)?(?iv?), and employment records held by a drug retailer in its role as employer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security number, date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records and any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information .

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect individuals’ privacy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: With respect to data collection, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data are collected without consent of an individual, which require opt-in consent, and which require opt-out action from the individual.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: With respect to data usage, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data are used by the entity internally and under what circumstance the entity shares, sells, rents, or otherwise distributes data or information to third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: With respect to data retention, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data it retains, the length of time of retention, and practices used to ensure that data are stored securely.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the systems it uses to ensure compliance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules and the HITECH Act, including policies and practices related to the collection, usage, storage, and disposal of PHI and PII.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its efforts to ensure compliance in the context of how it implements the following three categories of system security:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Administrative safeguards, which are defined as documented, formal policies and procedures that are intended to manage the selection and execution of security measures to protect data and manage the conduct of personnel in relation to the protection of data
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Physical safeguards, which are defined as the protection of physical computer systems and the buildings holding such systems from natural and environmental hazards and inappropriate intrusion or removal
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Technical safeguards, which are defined as processes put in place to protect information, authenticate users, and control individual access to information

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: Relevant practices to discuss include internal monitoring practices, technology and security programs to prevent data breaches, training programs and protocols in place for employees who handle PHI or PII, and disposal methods for paper and electronic PHI records.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose if it employs heightened security measures to ensure the security of PHI, including a discussion of those additional measures.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity should not include in its disclosure any information that compromises the security of its systems or its customers’ PHI or PII.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information, This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity’s expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (a) personally identifiable information (PII), but not protected health information (PHI), was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including: (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PHI is defined in U.S. 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (‘Privacy’) of the U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH Act) as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: The information (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse and relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the U.S. Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U.S.C. 1232g (a)(4)(B)(iv), and employment records held by a covered entity in its role as employer.
• PHI is a subset of PII.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (a) PII, but not PHI, was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Office for Civil Rights

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage the mix of patient insurance status
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategy to managing the impacts and effects of having patients with a mix of insurance statuses at its facilities.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage the mix of patient insurance status
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity should discuss its approach to managing risks and opportunities associated with patients within the following categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Those with private insurance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Those with government insurance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Those who are uninsured

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage the mix of patient insurance status
Technical Protocol: Alternative pricing mechanisms include, but are not limited to, discounted/sliding fee schedules, care given for charity (as a write-off), or discounts for prompt payment for uninsured customers.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy to manage the mix of patient insurance status
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss programs it implements for uninsured individuals, including, but not limited to financial assistance programs and participation in indigent care programs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Financial assistance programs are defined as those that are typically administered by hospitals that provide no-cost or discounted care for patients who demonstrate an inability to pay for health care services. Eligibility requirements may include proof of residency, an income at a fixed percentage (e.g., 250 percent) below the Federal Poverty Level (FPL), and ineligibility for programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, Children’s Health Insurance Programs (CHIP), or state-administered insurance programs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Indigent care programs are defined as those that are typically administered by country or state governments that provide financial discounts for patients who demonstrate an inability to pay for health care services. Eligibility requirements may include proof of residency, an income at a fixed percentage (e.g., 250 percent) below the Federal Poverty Level (FPL), and ineligibility for programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, Children’s Health Insurance Programs (CHIP), or state-administered insurance programs.

Accounting Metric: Amount of Medicare Disproportionate Share Hospital (DSH) adjustment payments received
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of payment adjustment that it received through the Center for Medicare Services’ (CMS) Disproportionate Share Hospital Program in the form of increases to its basic Medicare Advantage diagnosis-related group (MA-DRG) payment.

Accounting Metric: Amount of Medicare Disproportionate Share Hospital (DSH) adjustment payments received
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its payment adjustment as an aggregate figure for all eligible hospitals it operates.

Accounting Metric: Average Hospital Value-Based Purchasing Total Performance Score and domain score, across all facilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average Hospital Value-Based Purchasing (HVBP) Total Performance Score (TPS) across all hospitals it operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hospitals are defined as in Section 1886(d)(1)(B) of the Social Security Act.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: TPS is calculated according to the HVBP methodology, including achievement points and improvement points.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • For its calculations, the entity shall use HVBP scores after their weighting has been applied according to HVBP methodology.

Accounting Metric: Average Hospital Value-Based Purchasing Total Performance Score and domain score, across all facilities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose average score for each domain across all hospitals it operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Domains are defined and calculated according to HVBP methodology.

Accounting Metric: Average Hospital Value-Based Purchasing Total Performance Score and domain score, across all facilities
Technical Protocol: If applicable, the entity shall indicate if any hospitals it operates have been excluded from the HVBP program for reasons enumerated under Section 1886(o)(1)(C)(ii), including those (i) subject to payment reductions under Hospital Inpatient Quality Reporting, or (ii) cited for deficiencies during the performance period that pose immediate jeopardy to the health or safety of patients, without the minimum number of cases, measures, or surveys.

Accounting Metric: Average Hospital Value-Based Purchasing Total Performance Score and domain score, across all facilities
Technical Protocol: The entity may access many of the underlying data in a publicly available database via Hospital Compare, a service of Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.

Accounting Metric: Number of Serious Reportable Events (SREs) as defined by the National Quality Forum (NQF)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the aggregate number of Serious Reportable Events (SREs) that occurred during the reporting period at the health care facilities it operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: SREs are defined by the National Quality Forum (NQF) as serious, largely preventable, and of concern to both the public and health care providers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: SREs are identified by the NQF in a report entitled "Serious Reportable Events in Health Care," which includes 29 adverse events, classified under one of the following seven categories:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Surgical or invasive procedure
• Product or device
• Patient protection
• Care management
• Environmental
• Radiologic
• Potential criminal

Accounting Metric: Number of Serious Reportable Events (SREs) as defined by the National Quality Forum (NQF)
Technical Protocol: Where necessary to provide an accurate representation, the entity should disclose SRE figures for individual facilities (e.g., if a small subset of facilities constitutes a disproportionate number of the SREs).

Accounting Metric: Number of Serious Reportable Events (SREs) as defined by the National Quality Forum (NQF)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the NQF’s List of SREs as a normative reference, thus any subsequent updates to the scope or definitions shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Number of Serious Reportable Events (SREs) as defined by the National Quality Forum (NQF)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose SREs occurring in any setting under its operation, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hospitals
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Outpatient/office-based surgery centers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Ambulatory practice settings/office-based practices
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Long-term car/skilled nursing facilities

Accounting Metric: Hospital-Acquired Condition (HAC) Score per hospital
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the Hospital-Acquired Condition (HAC) Score for each of the hospitals it operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hospitals are defined as in Section 1886(d)(1)(B) of the Social Security Act.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The HAC Score shall be calculated per the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) HAC Reduction Program scoring methodology.

Accounting Metric: Hospital-Acquired Condition (HAC) Score per hospital
Technical Protocol: If applicable, the entity shall indicate if any hospitals it operates have been exempted from the HAC Reduction Program by CMS.

Accounting Metric: Hospital-Acquired Condition (HAC) Score per hospital
Technical Protocol: The entity may access many of the underlying data in a publicly available database via Hospital Compare, a service of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.

Accounting Metric: Excess readmission ratio per hospital
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the excess readmission ratio for each hospital it operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Readmission is defined per the Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program (HRRP) as an admission to a hospital within 30 days of a discharge from the same or another hospital.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hospitals are defined by Section 1886(d)(1)(B) of the Social Security Act.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The ratio shall be calculated, per the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), as the risk-adjusted predicted readmissions divided by the risk-adjusted expected readmissions.

Accounting Metric: Excess readmission ratio per hospital
Technical Protocol: The entity shall follow all methodology described by CMS, including the use of three years of trailing data to determine excess readmission ratios for the current reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Excess readmission ratio per hospital
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the CMS’s Inpatient Prospective Payment System (IPPS) Final Rules for each reporting period as normative references, thus each annual update to the adjustment factors, definitions, methodology, and scope shall be considered an update to this requirement.

Accounting Metric: Magnitude of readmissions payment adjustment as part of the Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program (HRRP)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the readmissions payment adjustment amount aggregated for all hospitals it operates.

Accounting Metric: Magnitude of readmissions payment adjustment as part of the Hospital Readmissions Reduction Program (HRRP)
Technical Protocol: The readmission payment adjustment amount shall be calculated per the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid definition as: (Base operating diagnosis-related group (DRG) payment amount × readmissions adjustment factor) – base operating DRG payment amount.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to manage the number of prescriptions issued for controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and practices related to the prescription of controlled substances, including the activities required to implement as well as the positions affected by such policies and practices, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Registration and use of state prescription drug monitoring programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope, positions affected, and percent of workforce covered by training programs related to controlled substances, including the evidence-based treatment of pain
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Programs implemented by the entity to identify and provide care for patients with substance abuse disorders
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Policies and procedures to ensure the safe storage and disposal of controlled substances
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Policies and programs related to the prescription of opioid antagonists (naloxone, naltrexone, and others) or other drugs that can counter the effects of controlled substances

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to manage the number of prescriptions issued for controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The entity may refer to the resources provided by the American Hospital Association to determine the extent to which its policies and practices are aligned with industry guidance as provided in “Stem the Tide: Addressing the Opioid Epidemic”.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to manage the number of prescriptions issued for controlled substances
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss factors that limit its ability to manage the number of prescriptions issued for controlled substances.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of controlled substance prescriptions written for which a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database was queried
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of controlled substance prescriptions that it wrote for which a physician or hospital staff queried a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database prior to issuing or filling the prescription.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Controlled substances are defined in §802(6) of Title 21, U.S. Code (U.S.C.) as drugs that have some potential for abuse or dependence and are regulated by the federal Controlled Substances Act (CSA). Controlled substances exclude distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, or tobacco, as those terms are defined or used in subtitle E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A PDMP is defined as an electronic database that collects designated data about the dispensing of controlled substances
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: PDMPs may be administered by specified statewide regulatory, administrative, or law enforcement agencies, from which data may be distributed by the specified agency to individuals who are authorized under state law to receive the information for purposes of their profession.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • A PDMP shall be considered queried if an applicable PDMP system was accessed by an authorized individual prior to writing a prescription to review patient prescription history information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Patients or circumstances that are excluded from PDMP reporting and querying, based on waiver or exemption established by state law, shall be excluded from the scope of this calculation.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of controlled substance prescriptions written for which a prescription drug monitoring program (PDMP) database was queried
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage as the number of controlled substance prescriptions written for which a PDMP was queried divided by the total number of controlled substance prescriptions written.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Patients or circumstances that are excluded from PDMP reporting and querying based on state exemptions shall not be included in the number of controlled substance prescriptions written where a PDMP was queried or the total number of controlled substance prescriptions written.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies or initiatives to ensure that patients are adequately informed about price before undergoing a procedure
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of policies and initiatives focused on transparency and clear communication of the price of procedures and/or treatment alternatives insofar as they may be related to the price of a procedure.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies or initiatives to ensure that patients are adequately informed about price before undergoing a procedure
Technical Protocol: The scope of initiatives disclosed may include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Providing price information to patients through written communication
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Posting information to a public website
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Providing in-person consultation to patients prior to services

Accounting Metric: Description of policies or initiatives to ensure that patients are adequately informed about price before undergoing a procedure
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe how information is provided to patients paying out-of-pocket versus those with insurance coverage. For those with insurance coverage, this may include coordinating with the patient’s insurer to determine the amount paid out-of-pocket and the amount paid by the insurer.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies or initiatives to ensure that patients are adequately informed about price before undergoing a procedure
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe if a precise total price, a range of prices, an estimate of price, or some other pricing information is provided to patients, such as the percentage (or amount) of the price for which the patient may be responsible.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of how pricing information for services is made publicly available
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the scope, format, and mechanism for making pricing information publicly available (e.g., via a public website and/or in cooperation with government initiatives to consolidate pricing data).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of how pricing information for services is made publicly available
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss if such information is made available for inpatient services and outpatient services (occurring in any ambulatory setting such as a hospital, clinic, or physician office).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of how pricing information for services is made publicly available
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose if the scope of information made available includes a precise total price, a range of prices, an estimate of price, or some other pricing information.

Accounting Metric: Number of the entity’s 25 most common services for which pricing information is publicly available, percentage of total services performed (by volume) that these represent
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of its 25 most common inpatient and outpatient service services for which it provides public pricing information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity’s most common services are defined as the most frequently billed services by count of procedures over the past three years, including the current reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Number of the entity’s 25 most common services for which pricing information is publicly available, percentage of total services performed (by volume) that these represent
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage of total services performed (by volume) that these represent.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of the entity’s 25 most common inpatient and outpatient services for which it provides public pricing information divided by its total number of procedures.

Accounting Metric: Number of the entity’s 25 most common services for which pricing information is publicly available, percentage of total services performed (by volume) that these represent
Technical Protocol: If the entity provides public pricing for more than 25 of its inpatient and outpatient services, the entity may disclose the number of services for which it provides public pricing.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: DART is defined as injury and illness cases with days away from work, or job transfer or restriction, or both. This definition is derived from U.S. CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: OSHA provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered DART in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) days away, restricted, or transferred (DART) rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location and type of employment, such as full-time, part-time, direct, contract, executive, labor, salary, hourly, and seasonal employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) physicians, (b) non-physician health care practitioners, and (c) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall separately disclose voluntary and involuntary employee turnover for physicians, for non-physician health care practitioners, and for all other employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Physicians include specialists and primary care physicians in the 29-1060 group of the Standard Occupation Classification (SOC) system from U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-physician health care practitioners include physician’s assistants and nurse practitioners within the following groups of the Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Occupations (29-0000) Major Group of the SOC system from the BLS:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• 29-1070 Physician Assistants
• 29-1080 Podiatrists
• 29-1120 Therapists
• 29-1140 Registered Nurses
• 29-1150 Nurse Anesthetists
• 29-1160 Nurse Midwives
• 29-1170 Nurse Practitioners
• 29-1180 Audiologists
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: All other employees includes employees that are not classified as physicians or non-physician health care practitioners.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) physicians, (b) non-physician health care practitioners, and (c) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For each category of employees, the entity shall disclose the annual voluntary turnover.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Monthly voluntary turnover shall be calculated as the total number of employee-initiated voluntary separations (e.g., resignation or retirement) for each month divided by the average number of employees for the month (the sum of the employees on the entity’s payroll at each pay period/number of pay periods).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The annual voluntary turnover rate shall be calculated by adding the 12 monthly turnover figures together and multiplying by 100 to arrive at a percentage.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for: (a) physicians, (b) non-physician health care practitioners, and (c) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For each category of employees, the entity shall disclose the annual involuntary turnover.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Monthly involuntary turnover shall be calculated as the total number of entity-initiated separations (e.g., dismissal, downsizing, redundancy, or expiry of contract) for each month divided by the average number of employees for the month (the sum of the employees on the entity’s payroll at each pay period / number of pay periods).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The annual involuntary turnover rate shall be calculated by adding the 12 monthly turnover figures together and multiplying by 100 to arrive at a percentage.

Accounting Metric: Description of talent recruitment and retention efforts for health care practitioners
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its efforts to attract and retain health care practitioners.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Health care practitioners include specialists, primary care physicians, physician’s assistants, and nurse practitioners with the 29-0000 Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Occupations (Major Group) — Standard Occupation Classification (SOC) system from U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• 29-1060 Physicians and Surgeons
• 29-1070 Physician Assistants
• 29-1080 Podiatrists
• 29-1120 Therapists
• 29-1140 Registered Nurses
• 29-1150 Nurse Anesthetists
• 29-1160 Nurse Midwives
• 29-1170 Nurse Practitioners
• 29-1180 Audiologists

Accounting Metric: Description of talent recruitment and retention efforts for health care practitioners
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Flexible scheduling
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Leadership development initiatives
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Loan repayment programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Mental and physical health support
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Mentorship programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: ‘No call’ positions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Part-time employment

Accounting Metric: Description of talent recruitment and retention efforts for health care practitioners
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the following elements of its programs, including disclosure of any quantitative metrics:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Overview
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Participation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Effectiveness

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health & Infrastructure
Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to address: (1) the physical risks due to an increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events and (2) changes in the morbidity and mortality rates of illnesses and diseases, associated with climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to addressing the risks to physical infrastructure and assets presented by changes in the frequency, severity, type, and geographic location of extreme weather events such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks to physical infrastructure that is located in flood prone low-lying and/or hurricane-prone areas
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Risks to physical infrastructure based on facility design, such as having key medical equipment in basements or the availability of backup power

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health & Infrastructure
Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to address: (1) the physical risks due to an increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events and (2) changes in the morbidity and mortality rates of illnesses and diseases, associated with climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to addressing the risks presented by the changes in prevalence, geography, and severity of certain diseases that are likely to be impacted by climate change, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The need for added and/or flexible capacity due to influx of patients due to heat-related illness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Obtaining the necessary facilities and expertise to identify and treat changing disease profiles in patients, such as for:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Malaria, dengue fever, and other vector borne diseases that affect tropical populations, but due to climate change may target non-tropical regions in the future
• Heat-related diseases (e.g., lung diseases such as asthma caused by increases in ground level ozone)
• Waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera due to increased flooding incidence)
• Human developmental disorders (e.g., malnutrition due to decreased food availability)

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health & Infrastructure
Accounting Metric: Percentage of health care facilities that comply with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Emergency Preparedness Rule
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of the health care facilities that it owns or operates that are in compliance with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Emergency Preparedness Rule.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The rule and the terms of compliance are determined by the CMS in the Medicare and Medicaid Programs Emergency Preparedness Requirements for Medicare and Medicaid Participating Providers and Suppliers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall consider the Emergency Preparedness Rule as a normative reference; therefore, any updates made year-on-year shall be considered as updates to this guidance.

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health & Infrastructure
Accounting Metric: Percentage of health care facilities that comply with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) Emergency Preparedness Rule
Technical Protocol: The entity shall indicate the number of health care facilities it owns or operates which have been excluded from the Emergency Preparedness Rule.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the False Claims Act
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the U.S. False Claims Act.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the False Claims Act
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the False Claims Act
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the False Claims Act
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with Medicare and Medicaid fraud under the False Claims Act
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as the U.S. False Claims Act.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to securing customer protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII), with a specific focus on how it addresses the collection, usage, and retention of customers’ information, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PHI is defined by U.S. law in 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (“Privacy”) of the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: The information: (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse; and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that (A) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse, and (B) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U.S.C. 1232g (a)(4)(B)(iv), and employment records held by a drug retailer in its role as employer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security number, date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records and any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information.
TP_BP2 Footnote: Privacy: Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information, GAO Report 08-536, May 2008.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect individuals’ privacy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: With respect to data collection, the entity may describe which data or types of data are collected without consent of an individual, which require opt-in consent, and which require opt-out action from the individual.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: With respect to usage of data, the entity may describe which data or types of data are used by the entity internally and under what circumstance the entity shares, sells, rents, or otherwise distributes data or information to third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: With respect to retention, the entity may describe which data or types of data it retains, the length of time of retention, and practices used to ensure that data is stored securely.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the systems it uses to ensure compliance with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules and the HITECH Act, including policies and practices related to the collection, usage, storage, and disposal of PHI and PII.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its efforts to ensure compliance in the context of how it implements the following three categories of system security:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Administrative safeguards, which are defined as documented, formal policies and procedures that are intended to manage the selection and execution of security measures to protect data and manage the conduct of personnel in relation to the protection of data
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Physical safeguards, which are defined as the protection of physical computer systems and the buildings holding such systems from natural and environmental hazards and inappropriate intrusion or removal
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Technical safeguards, which are defined as processes put in place to protect information, authenticate users, and control individual access to information

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: Relevant practices to discuss include: internal monitoring practices; technology and security programs to prevent data breaches; training programs and protocols in place for employees who handle PHI or PII; and disposal methods for paper and electronic PHI records.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose if it employs heightened security measures to ensure the security of PHI, including a discussion of those additional measures.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices to secure customers’ protected health information (PHI) records and other personally identifiable information (PII)
Technical Protocol: The entity should not include in its disclosure any information that compromises the security of its systems or its enrollees’ PHI or PII.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity’s expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (a) personally identifiable information (PII), but not protected health information (PHI), was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including: (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PHI is defined in U.S. 45 CFR 160.103 and referenced in Section 13400 of Subtitle D (‘Privacy’) of the U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH Act) as information that is a subset of health information, including demographic information collected from an individual, that meets the following criteria: The information (1) is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, employer, or health care clearinghouse and (2) relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of an individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual; and (i) identifies the individual or (ii) there is a reasonable basis to believe the information can be used to identify the individual.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Health information is defined as any information, whether oral or recorded in any form or medium, that is created or received by a health care provider, health plan, public health authority, employer, life insurer, school or university, or health care clearinghouse and relates to the past, present, or future physical or mental health or condition of any individual, the provision of health care to an individual, or the past, present, or future payment for the provision of health care to an individual.
• PHI includes information that is transmitted by electronic media, maintained in electronic media, or transmitted or maintained in any other form or medium.
• PHI excludes individually identifiable health information in education records covered by the U.S. Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (20 U.S.C. 1232g), records described at 20 U.S.C. 1232g (a)(4)(B)(iv), and employment records held by a covered entity in its role as employer.
• PHI is a subset of PII.
