Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (a) PII, but not PHI, was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches in which the customers’ (b) PHI was subject to the data breach.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving (a) personally identifiable information (PII) only and (b) protected health information (PHI), (3) number of customers affected in each category, (a) PII only and (b) PHI
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health (HITECH) Act

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with data security and privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Office for Civil Rights

Accounting Metric: Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its Medical Loss Ratio (MLR).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Medical Loss Ratio (MLR) is defined by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) in Title 45: Public Welfare Part 158 – Issuer Use of Premium Revenue: Reporting and Rebate Requirements (45 CFR Part 158), Section § 158.221 Formula for calculating an issuer’s medical loss ratio.

Accounting Metric: Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The disclosure shall be subject to the aggregation of data requirements and credibility adjustment, as specified by HHS in 45 CFR Part 158.

Accounting Metric: Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose MLR consolidated for all business lines and for each of the entity’s business segments according to its disaggregation of financial information, as outlined by US GAAP Topic 280 (Segment Reporting), including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Small employer group
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Large employer group
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Individual retail

Accounting Metric: Total amount of rebates accrued and paid due to non-compliance with the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of rebates owed to policyholders as calculated by Title 45: Public Welfare Part 158 – Issuer Use of Premium Revenue: Reporting and Rebate Requirements (U.S. 45 CFR Part 158), Section § 158.240 Rebating premium if the applicable medical loss ratio standard is not met.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Medical Loss Ratio (MLR) is defined by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) in Title 45: Public Welfare Part 158 – Issuer Use of Premium Revenue: Reporting and Rebate Requirements (45 CFR Part 158).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of rebates accrued and paid due to non-compliance with the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the aggregate amount of all forms of rebate, whether it was in the form of a premium credit, lump-sum check, or reimbursement to credit card or bank account.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of rebates accrued and paid due to non-compliance with the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rebate amount accrued for the reporting period as well as the amount paid during the reporting period for rebate liabilities from the previous reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of rebates accrued and paid due to non-compliance with the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act for Medical Loss Ratio (MLR)
Technical Protocol: The entity should discuss the reason for any differences between the amount paid during the reporting period and the amount accrued during the previous reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of proposed rate increases receiving “not unreasonable” designation from Health and Human Services (HHS) review or state review
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose “not unreasonable” rate increase requests as a percentage of all rate increase requests made by the entity during the fiscal period.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of proposed rate increases receiving “not unreasonable” designation from Health and Human Services (HHS) review or state review
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose only for requests for which review has been completed during the reporting period and conducted as per U.S. Title 45: Public Welfare Part 154 — Health Insurance Issuer Rate Increases: Disclosure and Review Requirements.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of proposed rate increases receiving “not unreasonable” designation from Health and Human Services (HHS) review or state review
Technical Protocol: The entity may access the publicly available, searchable database of rate increase requests, which includes reviews conducted by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and state designees.

Accounting Metric: Average Medicare Advantage plan rating for each of the following plan types: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average Overall Plan Rating for each of the following plan types that it offers:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Health Maintenance Organization (HMO)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Preferred Provider Organization (PPO)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Private Fee-for-Service (PFFS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Special Needs Plans (SNP)

Accounting Metric: Average Medicare Advantage plan rating for each of the following plan types: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include in the calculation all plans of each type receiving a Medicare Advantage plan rating.

Accounting Metric: Average Medicare Advantage plan rating for each of the following plan types: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The average rating shall be disclosed rounded to the nearest tenth (one place after the decimal point).

Accounting Metric: Average Medicare Advantage plan rating for each of the following plan types: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: Plan ratings are publicly available on Medicare’s “Medicare Plan Finder” website.

Accounting Metric: Average Medicare Advantage plan rating for each of the following plan types: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of its plans, by type, that are “Five Star Plans” - those plans that receive the highest Medicare Advantage plan rating.

Accounting Metric: Enrollee retention rate by plan type, including: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its enrollee retention rate.

Accounting Metric: Enrollee retention rate by plan type, including: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The enrollee retention rate is calculated as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: (Total number of enrollees at close of reporting period – total number of new enrollees added during the reporting period) / (total number of enrollees at the close of the previous reporting period – total number of enrollees involuntarily terminated during the reporting period – attrition of employees in employee sponsored plans), where:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Involuntarily terminated enrollees – those whose plans were terminated by the entity due to fraud or intentional misrepresentation of material facts – shall be excluded from the calculation.
• Attrition of enrollees in employer sponsored group plans due to turnover (voluntary or involuntary) shall be excluded from the calculation.

Accounting Metric: Enrollee retention rate by plan type, including: (1) HMO, (2) local PPO, (3) regional PPO, (4) PFFS, and (5) SNP
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose retention rates by plan type, which may include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Health Maintenance Organization (HMO)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Local Preferred Provider Organization (PPO)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Regional Preferred Provider Organization (PPO)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Private Fee-for-Service (PFFS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Special Needs Plans (SNP)

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of claims it denied that enrollees appealed and for which the entity reversed its decision having determined the denial to be invalid.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: The percentage of reversed claims shall be calculated as: the total number of claims that were denied and successfully appealed by enrollees during the reporting period divided by the number of claims that were denied and appealed by enrollees during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A successful appeal is one in which the entity reversed its decision, having determined the denial to be invalid.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure of denied claims excludes claims that were denied for a billing error, appealed and resubmitted, and ultimately paid.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall not consider ongoing claims appeals—only those that were resolved during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes both appeals of denials at preauthorization and denials at the time of payment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Preauthorization denials occur when a determination is made that: (1) the consumer is not eligible to receive the requested service because, for example, the service is not covered under the individual’s policy, or (2) the service is not appropriate, meaning that it is not medically necessary or is experimental or investigational.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: For the purposes of this metric, if the appeal relates to denial of a portion of a claim, the entity shall consider it in the same manner as an appeal to an entire claim denial.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: For the purposes of this metric, complaints, such as those with a state department of insurance which can also result in a reversal of denial, shall be considered in the same manner as an appeal. Complaints in this context shall only include those related to denial of coverage.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of claims denied that were appealed by customers and ultimately reversed
Technical Protocol: Multiple appeals to the same claim shall not be counted separately for calculations.

Accounting Metric: Plan enrollee grievance rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the plan enrollee grievance rate.

Accounting Metric: Plan enrollee grievance rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the grievance rate as: the number of grievances reported during the reporting period / (monthly average enrollees / 10,000), where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Grievance is defined as any complaint or dispute, other than an entity determination, expressing dissatisfaction with the manner in which the entity or delegated entity provides health care services, regardless of whether any remedial action can be taken
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: An enrollee or his/her representative may make the complaint or dispute, either orally or in writing, to the entity
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Grievances may include complaints regarding the timeliness, appropriateness, access to, and/or setting of a provided health service, procedure, or item
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Grievance issues may also include complaints that a covered health service procedure or item during a course of treatment did not meet accepted standards for delivery of health care

Accounting Metric: Plan enrollee grievance rate
Technical Protocol: Monthly average enrollees is calculated as the total number of member months (one member being enrolled in an entity's plan for one month) / by 12 months.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of enrollees in wellness programs by type: (1) diet and nutrition, (2) exercise, (3) stress management, (4) mental health, (5) smoking or alcohol cessation, or (6) other
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose enrollee participation in wellness programs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Wellness programs are defined as those that foster:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Primary prevention by promoting health-related behaviors (e.g., immunizations), healthy body mass index, or healthy lifestyle (e.g., exercise or smoking cessation)
• Secondary prevention by promoting early-stage disease detection and management

Accounting Metric: Percentage of enrollees in wellness programs by type: (1) diet and nutrition, (2) exercise, (3) stress management, (4) mental health, (5) smoking or alcohol cessation, or (6) other
Technical Protocol: The percentage of enrollees in wellness programs participation shall be calculated as the number of unique, individual enrollees participating in a wellness program divided by the monthly average number of enrollees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The monthly average number of enrollees is calculated as the total number of member months (one member being enrolled in an entity’s plan for one month) divided by 12 months.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of enrollees in wellness programs by type: (1) diet and nutrition, (2) exercise, (3) stress management, (4) mental health, (5) smoking or alcohol cessation, or (6) other
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of participation for each of the following types of wellness program:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Diet and nutrition
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Exercise
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Stress management
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Mental health
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Smoking or alcohol cessation
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: All other wellness programs

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total value of claims paid for preventative services covered under Section 2713 of the U.S. Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), including services rated “A” or “B” by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF).

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total value of claims paid for preventive services outside the scope of Section 2713 of the PPACA, and for which it may require cost-sharing from enrollees.

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall additionally disclose the percentage of the total cost of these services that its coverage constituted as follows:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The total cost of coverage for all medical expenses divided by the total cost of preventive services.

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: Services are considered preventive if they are:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Coded with a Current Procedural Terminology (CPT®) code that contains the modifier “33,” denoting a preventive service
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Specifically identified as preventive
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Inherently preventive in nature

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall not include in its calculation those services that are conducted in response to a symptom, even if it is the same service that can be administered as a preventive measure.

Accounting Metric: Total coverage for preventive health services with no cost sharing for the enrollees, total coverage for preventive health services requiring cost-sharing by the enrollee, percentage of enrollees receiving Initial Preventive Physical Examinations (IPEE) or Annual Wellness Visits (AWV)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of enrollees receiving wellness screenings, as CPT® / HCPCS coded for Initial Preventive physical examination (G0402, G0403, G0404, G0450) or Annual Wellness Visit (G0438, G0439).

Accounting Metric: Number of customers receiving care from Accountable Care Organizations or enrolled in Patient-Centered Medical Home programs
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include in its calculation enrollees in Accountable Care Organizations (ACOs) that meet the eligibility requirements of, and participate in, Medicare’s Shared Savings Program for Fee-For-Service beneficiaries.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ACOs are defined by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services as a group of health care providers who give coordinated care, chronic disease management, and thereby improve the quality of care patients get. The organization's payment is tied to achieving health care quality goals and outcomes that result in cost savings.

Accounting Metric: Number of customers receiving care from Accountable Care Organizations or enrolled in Patient-Centered Medical Home programs
Technical Protocol: The entity may also include enrollees in ACOs not participating in the Medicare program, provided that such ACOs include, at a minimum, the coordination of care from a variety of health care providers (including primary care physicians, specialists, and a hospital), and have the ability to administer payments, set benchmarks and measure outcome-based performance, and distribute shared savings.

Accounting Metric: Number of customers receiving care from Accountable Care Organizations or enrolled in Patient-Centered Medical Home programs
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include in its calculation enrollees receiving care from Patient-Centered Medical Homes (PCMH) that meet the recognition and accreditation guidelines published by the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP), American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), American College of Physicians (ACP), and American Osteopathic Association (AOA).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Patient-Centered Medical Home is defined as a reimbursement model founded on an outcome-based care delivery, “pay for coordination,” system in which payment is based on the coordination of services and comprehensive care that is coordinated through a physician (or physician assistant or registered nurse).

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health
Accounting Metric: Discussion of the strategy to address the effects of climate change on business operations and how specific risks presented by changes in the geographic incidence, morbidity, and mortality of illnesses and diseases are incorporated into risk models
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategic business approach to addressing significant risks related to the effects of climate change, including, but not limited to, changes in the following aspects of illnesses and diseases:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Geographic incidence
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Morbidity
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Mortality

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health
Accounting Metric: Discussion of the strategy to address the effects of climate change on business operations and how specific risks presented by changes in the geographic incidence, morbidity, and mortality of illnesses and diseases are incorporated into risk models
Technical Protocol: Relevant disclosure may include, but is not limited to, discussion of the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Increases in allergic responses, asthma rates, and heat-induced illness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Migration of tropical diseases such as malaria, dengue fever, and other vector-borne tropical diseases to non-tropical regions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Increases in waterborne diseases, such as cholera, due to increased natural disaster incidence
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Increased rates of human developmental diseases such as malnutrition due to decreased food availability

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health
Accounting Metric: Discussion of the strategy to address the effects of climate change on business operations and how specific risks presented by changes in the geographic incidence, morbidity, and mortality of illnesses and diseases are incorporated into risk models
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss any projected impacts on revenue, costs, or plan affordability.

Disclosure Topic: Climate Change Impacts on Human Health
Accounting Metric: Discussion of the strategy to address the effects of climate change on business operations and how specific risks presented by changes in the geographic incidence, morbidity, and mortality of illnesses and diseases are incorporated into risk models
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss it how it incorporates the effects of climate change into its risk assessment and risk adjustment activities.

Accounting Metric: Ratio of weighted average rate of net price increases (for all products) to the annual increase in the U.S. Consumer Price Index
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the ratio of weighted average rate of net price increases (for all products) to the annual increase in the U.S. Consumer Price Index.

Accounting Metric: Ratio of weighted average rate of net price increases (for all products) to the annual increase in the U.S. Consumer Price Index
Technical Protocol: The average net price increases should be weighted based on sales volume of all of the entity’s medical device products sold in the U.S. during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The annual average net price increase shall be calculated as percent change versus the prior reporting period and for each product weighted by list price across the entity’s U.S. portfolio of medical device products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The net price shall represent the average wholesale acquisition cost (WAC) minus rebates, discounts, and returns and shall represent the average WAC minus rebates, discounts, and returns for the reporting period in which it is being calculated.

Accounting Metric: Ratio of weighted average rate of net price increases (for all products) to the annual increase in the U.S. Consumer Price Index
Technical Protocol: The entity should use the annual change (December to December increase) in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumer (CPI-U) for the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Description of how price information for each product is disclosed to customers or to their agents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of policies and initiatives related to providing price information to customers, specifically indicating if aspects of the price (e.g., the range, median, or typical price) are provided to customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Customers shall include those purchasing directly from the entity or through intermediaries, such as group purchasing organizations (GPOs) or consultants negotiating on behalf of the customer.

Accounting Metric: Description of how price information for each product is disclosed to customers or to their agents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the frequency with which it uses confidentiality clauses in purchasing agreements with heath care providers that restrict them from sharing with third parties the price they paid for the entity’s products.

Accounting Metric: Description of how price information for each product is disclosed to customers or to their agents
Technical Protocol: The entity may explain the factors that affect price, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Product volume
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Geographic market of customer
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Type of facility the customer is operating

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of recalls for medical device products that it manufactures.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Recalls are defined as actions taken by a firm to remove a product from the market, including those conducted on the entity's own initiative, by FDA request, or by FDA order under statutory authority.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Medical devices are defined by the U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetics (FD&C) Act sec. 201(h) as an instrument, apparatus, implement, machine, contrivance, implant, in vitro reagent, or other similar or related article, including a component part, or accessory which is recognized in the official National Formulary, or the U.S. Pharmacopoeia, or any supplement to them, intended for use in the diagnosis of disease or other conditions, or in the cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease, in man or other animals, or intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of man or other animals, and which does not achieve its primary intended purposes through chemical action within or on the body of man or other animals, and which is not dependent upon being metabolized for the achievement of its primary intended purposes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall include recalls associated with all devices manufactured by the entity or by its subsidiaries.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss notable recalls, such as those that affected a significant number of units of one product or those related to serious injury or fatality. For such recalls the entity may provide:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Description and cause of the recall issue
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The total number of units recalled
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The cost to remedy the issue
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Whether the recall was initiated voluntarily or at the request of the FDA or non-U.S. national regulatory authority
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Corrective actions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any other significant outcomes (e.g., legal proceedings or customer fatalities)

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify all products manufactured by it or its subsidiaries for which it is listed as the Recalling Firm in the “Devices” product type in the weekly Enforcement Reports published by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which contain all recalls by Product Type, Product Description, Code Info, Classification, Reason for Recall, and Recalling Firm.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose recalls in non-U.S. markets that have been initiated voluntarily, at the request of a non-U.S. national regulatory authority, or by order of a non-U.S. national regulatory authority under statutory authority.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose recalls initiated voluntarily that have not been reported to the FDA (or to a national regulatory authority) and/or are not listed in an FDA Enforcement Report.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of device units that were subject to a recall.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose, in addition to the total number of drug recalls, the percentage of recalls that were:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: FDA requested
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: FDA mandated

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: For FDA-initiated recalls, the entity may disclose the FDA classification of each recall, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Class I
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Class II
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Class III

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: For each recalled product, the entity may disclose revenues from 12 months prior to the date of recall. This 12-month period may extend beyond the reporting period for which the entity is disclosing; the figure is intended to indicate annual revenues associated with the product such that the financial impact of the recall can be gauged.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: If a recall relates to only a subset of a product (e.g., specific lots or a particular style), then the entity should indicate the scope of the recall; and, if the entity is disclosing revenue associated with the recall, it should be limited to the portion of the product affected by the recall.

Accounting Metric: List of products listed in the FDA’s MedWatch Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products database
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose all listings associated with the entity that appear in the “Medical Devices” category of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)’s MedWatch Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products database.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes all listings associated with the entity or its subsidiaries, including trade names for which the entity has patents or classes of products that it manufactures and markets.

Accounting Metric: List of products listed in the FDA’s MedWatch Safety Alerts for Human Medical Products database
Technical Protocol: If the entity manufactures a product in a product class listed in the database but has evidence that the listing does not apply to its specific products, it may provide such evidence.

Accounting Metric: Number of fatalities related to products as reported in the FDA Manufacturer and User Facility Device Experiencedatabase
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of fatalities associated with device products it manufactures.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the disclosure shall include all fatalities that occurred during the reporting period for which it is disclosing, even if the adverse event began in a prior period.

Accounting Metric: Number of fatalities related to products as reported in the FDA Manufacturer and User Facility Device Experiencedatabase
Technical Protocol: The entity may access a list of fatalities through the FDA Manufacturer and User Facility Device Experience (MAUDE) database.

Accounting Metric: Number of FDA enforcement actions taken in response to violations of current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMP), by type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number and type of U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) enforcement actions taken during the reporting period in response to current Good Manufacturing Practice (or regional equivalent) violations at its facilities, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Form 483s
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Warning letters
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Seizures
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Recalls
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Consent decrees

Accounting Metric: Number of FDA enforcement actions taken in response to violations of current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMP), by type
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes facilities that are owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false marketing claims
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as the U.S. False Claims Act.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the aspects of its code of ethics that relate to ethical marketing and off-label promotion, including describing how it defines and/or what it considers “off-label promotion.”

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: A corporate policy, code of conduct, guideline, or contractual term that is similar in intent to a code of ethics shall be treated as equivalent for the purposes of this metric.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing promotion of off-label use of products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the mechanisms it has in place to ensure compliance with its code, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disciplinary actions for violations
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Internal audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Regulatory review committees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Training

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to addressing specific environmental and human health impacts of its products, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Energy efficiency of products during use
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Disposal of the products
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Material efficiency
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Product packaging
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Toxicity of materials

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall only describe design considerations that it can determine will deliver a specific, demonstrable environmental benefit.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental benefits shall be taken to mean those related to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Energy consumption
• Environmental health
• Human health
• Waste generation
• Water use

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide an indication of how central the environmental benefit imparted is to functionality of products.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall make its determination in good faith and clarify whether the benefit relates to the product, package, or service, avoiding a general statement of environmental benefits and following guidance from applicable laws and statues, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Federal Trade Commission’s “Green Guides” (16 C.F.R. Part 260: Guides for the Use of Environmental Marketing Claims)

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall specify during which lifecycle stage(s) it takes into account the environmental impacts associated with its products.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall reference the mechanism through which it implements efforts, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Use of design protocols
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Procurement policies
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Restricted substances lists (RSLs)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Certifications
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Product take-back programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Packaging take-back

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: For efforts related to the end-of-life of product management, the entity shall discuss only design-related considerations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to assess and manage environmental and human health considerations associated with chemicals in products, and meet demand for sustainable products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of products, by revenue, for which it has integrated the aforementioned environmental considerations into the design.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of products accepted for take-back and reused, recycled, or donated, broken down by: (1) devices and equipment and (2) supplies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of its products that it recovered and reused (refurbished), recycled, or donated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: This figure shall be broken down into: (1) devices and equipment and (2) supplies.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Devices and equipment include high-value machines and advanced devices.
• Supplies include simple supplies and low-cost equipment (e.g., scalpels, gloves, and thermometers).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: This figure shall exclude products that were accepted for take-back but were ultimately discarded as waste.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The entity may indicate if it reclaimed any products it was unable to reuse or recycle because proper, safe disposal was necessary.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of products accepted for take-back and reused, recycled, or donated, broken down by: (1) devices and equipment and (2) supplies
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe programs and initiatives it implements, funds, or participates in that are related to product take-back for end-of-life management of its products.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) entity's facilities and (2) Tier I suppliers' facilities participating in third-party audit programs for manufacturing and product quality
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the percentage of its facilities that participate in third-party audit programs intended to maintain the quality of manufacturing, management, and/or products, including materials and components.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A third-party audit program is one conducted by an external auditing agency to a recognized, independent standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes facilities that are owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of (1) entity's facilities and (2) Tier I suppliers' facilities participating in third-party audit programs for manufacturing and product quality
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of its Tier I suppliers’ facilities that participate in third-party audit programs, such as to ISO 13485:2003 Medical devices — Quality management systems — Requirements for regulatory purposes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Tier I suppliers are those that transact directly with the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may limit its disclosure to those suppliers that in aggregate account for greater than or equal to 90 percent of its supplier spending.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to maintain traceability within the distribution chain
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the type and sophistication of technology it uses to maintain traceability of its products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Traceability refers to the ability to track identifying information of a product throughout various stages of manufacturing and distribution.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant stages of manufacturing and distribution include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Raw material sourcing
• Production
• Point of delivery at the health care provider
• Product retail and wholesale
• Transportation logistics

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to maintain traceability within the distribution chain
Technical Protocol: Discussion may include, but is not limited to, the use of:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Barcode technology
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Chain of custody audits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Radio frequency identification (RFID) tagging

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to managing its risks associated with the use of critical materials in its products, including physical limits on availability and access, changes in price, and regulatory and reputational risks, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical material is defined as a material that is both essential in use and subject to the risk of supply restriction. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Research Council of the National Academies’ Minerals, Critical Minerals, and the U.S. Economy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of critical materials include, but are not limited to, the following as defined by the National Research Council:

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify the critical materials that present a significant risk to its operations, the type of risk(s) they represent, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate the risk(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant strategies may include diversification of suppliers, stockpiling of materials, development or procurement of alternative and substitute materials, and investments in recycling technology for critical materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity's ability to maintain confidential information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For example, if an entity determines not to identify a specific critical material that presents a significant risk to its operations due to competitive harm that could result from the disclosure, the entity shall disclose the existence of such risk(s), the type of risk(s), and the strategies used to mitigate the risk(s), but is not required to disclose the relevant critical material.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Federal Anti-Kickback Statute
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe aspects of any code of ethics that relate to its interactions with health care professionals.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Health care professionals include individuals or entities that are involved in the provision of health care services and/or items to patients, such as physicians, dentists, pharmacists, and nurses. Additionally, the term includes those who purchase, lease, recommend, use, arrange for the purchase or lease of, or prescribe the entity’s products, but do not necessarily provide health care services directly, such as purchasing agents, practice managers, and group purchasing organizations (GPOs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of the disclosure shall include the content (topics such as food and entertainment, training and education, and participation in committees that set formularies) and scope (type and percentage of staff to which it relates) of the code of ethics.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: A corporate policy, code of conduct, guideline, or contractual term that is similar in intent to a code of ethics shall be treated as equivalent for the purposes of this metric.

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss mechanisms to ensure compliance with its code of ethics, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Enforcement, including inspection, compliance, and review committees
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Implementation of corrective actions when a code is violated
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Training, including degree and frequency

Accounting Metric: Description of code of ethics governing interactions with health care professionals
Technical Protocol: If the entity has adopted a second- or third-party code of ethics, such as AdvaMed’s Code of Ethics on Interactions with Healthcare Professionals, it may reference this code without describing the content.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with environmental permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of instances of non-compliance associated with the environment, including, but not limited to, violations of permits, standards, and/or regulations associated with waste, air quality and/or emissions, water discharges, water withdrawal exceedances, effluent limit exceedances (such as waste load allocation), violation of wastewater pretreatment requirements, oil or hazardous substance spills, land use, and endangered species.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with environmental permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents governed by national, state, and local statutory permits and regulations.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with environmental permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents of non-compliance received by the entity and by subcontractors under the entity’s direct supervision.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with environmental permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: An incident of non-compliance shall be disclosed regardless of whether it resulted in an enforcement action (e.g., fine and/or warning letter).

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance with environmental permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: An incident of non-compliance, regardless of the measurement methodology or frequency, shall be disclosed. These include violations for one-time violations, continuous discharges, and non-continuous discharges.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the processes it employs to assess and manage the environmental risks associated with project siting, design and construction.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Environmental risks may include, but are not limited to, ecological impacts, biodiversity impacts, emissions to air, discharges to water, slope disturbance, soil disturbance and erosion, storm water management, waste management, natural resource consumption, and hazardous chemical usage.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the due diligence practices it employs to assess the environmental risks of projects, where relevant due diligence practices include environmental impact assessments and stakeholder engagement practices.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant items to discuss include, but are not limited to: practices to assess the baseline environmental considerations of the project site; feasible, environmentally preferable alternatives for the project; local legal requirements; the protection of biodiversity; use of renewable natural resources; use of hazardous substances; and efficient production, delivery and use of energy.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the operational practices it employs to the minimize environmental impacts during project siting, design, and construction, which may include, but are not limited to: waste management, reducing biodiversity impacts, emissions to air, discharges to water, natural resource consumption, and hazardous chemical usage.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to operating in compliance with all applicable environmental regulations and permits.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant items to discuss include, but are not limited to: employee training on relevant regulations and cleanup procedures, quality control processes on project sites, internal mechanisms for reporting and following up on environmental incidents, and maintenance and reporting of accurate data.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the use of codes, guidelines, and standards to assess and minimize environmental impacts of project siting, design, and construction, where applicable. Relevant codes, guidelines, and standards may include, but are not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: BREEAM®
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Equator Principles
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: International Finance Corporation’s Environmental and Social Performance Standards and Guidance Notes
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Institute for Sustainable Infrastructure’s (ISI) Envision® rating system
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: International Organization for Standardization (ISO) environmental standards
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: United Nations Development Programme’s Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: United Nations Global Compact’s Environmental Principles
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: U.S. Green Building Council’s LEED® certification

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to managing projects that have heightened environmental and/or social due diligence requirements or are expected to have significant adverse environmental and/or social impacts, including additional measures or policies it employs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An example of a project type that has heightened environmental and/or social impacts are “Category A” projects categorized by the International Finance Corporation (IFC).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may describe its approach to categorizing the severity of environmental risk for its projects, including how it determines if a project has heightened environmental risk.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: Where applicable and relevant, the entity shall describe differences between policies and practices for its different operating regions, project types, and business segments.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of processes to assess and manage environmental risks associated with project design, siting, and construction
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes project stages associated with siting, design, and construction that the entity is involved with through contractual responsibility, including, but not limited to, feasibility studies, proposals, design and planning, subcontractor procurement, and construction.

Accounting Metric: Amount of defect- and safety-related rework costs
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of defect- and safety-related rework costs incurred.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Rework is defined, consistent with the Construction Industry Institute’s definition, as activities in the field that have to be done more than once in the field or activities that remove work previously installed as part of the project.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of rework costs excludes costs resulting from client- or project-owner-driven modifications including, but not limited to, change orders, revisions to scope, or revisions to design.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of rework costs includes, but is not limited to, costs associated with labor, materials, design, equipment, and subcontractors.

Accounting Metric: Amount of defect- and safety-related rework costs
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss projects with significant rework costs relative to actual or projected total project costs. Relevant context to provide may include, but is not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Root causes of rework
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Corrective actions implemented
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Financial impacts to company

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with defect- and safety-related incidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with defect- and safety-related incidents and allegations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with defect- and safety-related incidents
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with defect- and safety-related incidents
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with defect- and safety-related incidents
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fatality rate for work-related fatalities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rates by each of the following employee categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Direct employees, defined as those employees on the entity’s payroll, whether they are full-time, part-time, executive, labor, salary, hourly, or seasonal employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Contract employees, defined as those who are not on the entity’s payroll, but who are supervised by the entity on a day-to-day basis, including independent contractors and those employed by third parties (e.g., temp agencies and labor brokers).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of projects commissioned during the reporting period that were certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of third-party multi-attribute sustainability standards is limited to standards or certifications that, at a minimum, address the following aspects of building or infrastructure design and construction:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of third-party multi-attribute sustainability standards include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• BREEAM®
• Green Globes®
• Institute for Sustainable Infrastructure’s (ISI) Envision®
• LEED®

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of active projects that sought certification to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of active projects includes all buildings and infrastructure projects actively under development at the close of the reporting period, including, but not limited to, those in the design and construction stages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of active projects excludes projects that were commissioned during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard(s) to which projects are certified or seeking certification.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to projects in which the entity had a direct role in design, engineering, procurement and/or construction of the building or infrastructure project.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes buildings (such as residential, commercial and retail, government, healthcare, and offices) and other infrastructure projects (such as transportation, oil and gas, electrical grid, renewable energy, water supply distribution, and water treatment).

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) commissioned projects certified to a third-party multi-attribute sustainability standard and (2) active projects seeking such certification
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss sustainability standards or guidelines that it implements into its building and infrastructure project design and construction that are not third-party verified.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to incorporate operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations into project planning and design
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide a discussion of the process it uses to incorporate operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations into project planning and design.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations are solutions aimed at reducing and optimizing operational use of energy and water, including, but not limited to, water collection and reuse designs, repair and retrofits, improved insulation and material use, shading devices, energy procurement, and use of energy- and water-efficient devices and lighting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant information to disclose includes, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• The actions taken to incorporate such considerations, such as design solutions, technological solutions, material use, modeling of energy and water use
• The geographic markets where the entity operates in, including current and expected future energy and water efficiency regulations, potential constraints on water and/or energy resources, and stakeholder demands in those markets
• Whether these energy and water efficiency solutions serve as competitive advantages in project bids and proposals, and how the entity communicates performance—including any perceived competitive advantages—to project owners
• How the entity communicates long-term cost-benefit analyses to project owners or developers, including the potential savings from energy efficiency projects based on past performance of energy efficiency projects

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to incorporate operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations into project planning and design
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to assessing risks associated with operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations, including internal policies, practices, and procedures.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to incorporate operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations into project planning and design
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its use of codes, guidelines, and standards that address operational-phase energy and water efficiency, where applicable.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may discuss how its energy and water efficiency efforts exceed building code requirements.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of process to incorporate operational-phase energy and water efficiency considerations into project planning and design
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes environmental impacts associated with project construction, as well as codes, guidelines, and standards associated with project construction, which are both included within the scope of IF-EN-160a.2.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of its backlog associated with (1) hydrocarbon-related projects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Backlog is defined as the value of projects not completed as of the close of the reporting period (i.e., revenue contractually expected in the future but that has not been recognized), or is defined by the entity, consistent with its existing disclosure of backlog. Backlog may also be referred to as revenue backlog or unsatisfied performance obligations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hydrocarbon-related projects are defined as any type of project directly associated with the hydrocarbon value chain, including, but not limited to: hydrocarbon exploration, extraction, development, production, and/or transportation; hydrocarbon infrastructure services and maintenance; hydrocarbon power generation; and hydrocarbon-related downstream services.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Examples of hydrocarbon-related projects include, but are not limited to: any project directly associated with oil, gas, or coal production; transportation; refining; and fossil fuel-based electricity generation.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: If a significant portion of the entity’s backlog in hydrocarbon-related projects is associated with natural gas power generation projects, the entity may provide supplemental disclosures describing this proportion of backlog and the sustainability impacts of such projects relative to alternatives or baseline scenarios.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide a description of the sustainability implications of hydrocarbon-related projects, including, but not limited to, project descriptions, categorizations by resource type, expected sustainability impacts, and risks related to project completion and/or conversion to revenue.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of its backlog associated with (2) renewable energy projects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, consistent with U.S. Environmental Agency Protection (EPA) definitions, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: The entity shall exclude from its calculations and disclosures of backlog any amount of an order backlog cancellation that re-enters order backlog during the same reporting period as a result of a project owner’s successful re-planning of the project.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog for (1) hydrocarbon-related projects and (2) renewable energy projects
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to projects where the entity provided engineering, architecture, design, construction, installation, planning, consulting, repair, and/or maintenance services, or other similar services.

Accounting Metric: Amount of backlog cancellations associated with hydrocarbon-related projects
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of its total backlog associated with hydrocarbon-related projects of any type that was cancelled during the reporting period for any reason.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Backlog is defined as the value of projects not completed as of the close of the reporting period (i.e., revenue contractually expected in the future but that has not been recognized), or is defined by the entity, consistent with its existing disclosure of backlog. Backlog may also be referred to as revenue backlog or unsatisfied performance obligations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Backlog cancellations are defined as the amount of backlog cancelled, reduced, terminated, or deferred such that it no longer meets the definition of backlog, or removed from the backlog for any reason other than conversion to revenue or currency exchange rate fluctuations.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Backlog cancellations include cancellations that occur for any reason, including, but not limited to, a customer’s failure to obtain necessary project permitting or financing, a customer’s voluntary project cancellation, and reduction in project scope due to financial constraints.
• The scope of backlog cancellations excludes cancellations associated with decommissioning projects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Hydrocarbon-related projects are defined as any type of project directly associated with the hydrocarbon value chain, including, but not limited to: hydrocarbon exploration, extraction, development, production, and/or transportation; hydrocarbon infrastructure services and maintenance; hydrocarbon power generation; and hydrocarbon-related downstream services.
