Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Operational control is defined, consistent with the 2018 GRESB® Real Estate Assessment Reference Guide, as an instance when the real estate owner has “the ability to introduce and implement operating policies, health and safety policies, and/or environmental policies.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Energy and sustainability services are defined as services provided to clients directly related to resource efficiency (including energy, water, and waste), utility data management, energy procurement, obtaining and retaining sustainability and resource-related certifications, environmental reporting, and corporate sustainability consulting and training.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of energy and sustainability services excludes services that impart improved energy and sustainability performance in an ancillary, indirect, or minimal way, as well as environmental services that are part of the ordinary operation and maintenance of buildings (e.g., facilities maintenance and/or janitorial services).

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management provided with energy and sustainability services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of buildings for which it provided energy and sustainability-related services during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Buildings under management is defined as distinct buildings or real estate assets where property management services are provided and where the real estate owner has operational control.

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management provided with energy and sustainability services
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes the total floor area and all buildings that were actively provided with energy and sustainability services during the reporting period, regardless of the date of inception of such services.

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management that obtained an energy rating
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the floor area under management that obtained an energy rating during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Floor area under management is defined as the gross rentable floor area where property management services are provided and for which the real estate owner has operational control.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Operational control is defined consistent with the 2018 GRESB® Real Estate Assessment Reference Guide as an instance when the real estate owner has “the ability to introduce and implement operating policies, health and safety policies, and/or environmental policies.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management that obtained an energy rating
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of buildings that obtained an energy rating during the reporting period, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The number of buildings under management is defined as distinct buildings or real estate assets where property management services are provided and where the real estate owner has operational control.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: An energy rating is defined, consistent with the 2018 GRESB® Real Estate Assessment Reference Guide, as a scheme that measures the energy performance of buildings.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of energy rating schemes includes:

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management that obtained an energy rating
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is aligned with the 2018 GRESB® Real Estate Assessment Reference Guide in that it “only include[s] energy ratings that were awarded before or during the reporting period (pre-assessments or other unofficial forms of pre-certification are not valid). Some energy ratings are valid for a limited period only—the rating should be effective and official during the reporting period.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Floor area and (2) number of buildings under management that obtained an energy rating
Technical Protocol: The entity shall consider the GRESB® Real Estate Assessment Reference Guide as a normative reference, thus any updates made year-on-year shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Brokerage revenue from dual agency transactions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its revenue from real estate sales brokerage services that directly resulted from dual agency transactions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Brokerage services that directly resulted from dual agency (also referred to as “dual representation”) transactions are defined as transactions in which the entity represents both the buyer and the seller in the same real estate brokerage transaction.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Brokerage revenue from dual agency transactions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes leasing transactions, insurance transactions, and any other form of brokerage revenue not directly resulting from real estate sales.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Brokerage revenue from dual agency transactions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes property management revenue, appraisal revenue, and any other form of revenue resulting from a real estate sales transaction other than brokerage revenue.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Revenue from transactions associated with appraisal services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of revenue generated from transactions (excluding appraisal services revenue) where it also provided appraisal services for the property subject to the transaction.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Appraisal services are defined, based on the Appraisal Institute’s definition, "as the act or process of developing an opinion of value."
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of revenue generated from transactions includes revenue from brokerage services, financing services, and consulting or market-analysis services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of revenue generated from transactions excludes revenue that directly resulted from appraisal services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of revenue generated from transactions excludes property management services.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Revenue from transactions associated with appraisal services
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes revenue generated from services for properties for which the entity provided appraisal services, regardless of when the entity conducted the appraisal and recognized the revenue (i.e., during a previous reporting period).

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity or duty of care, including, but not limited to, those related to negligence, malpractice, data security or loss, fraud, corruption, and bribery.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Disclosure Topic: Transparent Information & Management of Conflict of Interest
Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with professional integrity, including duty of care
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its (1) gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts(April 2018).

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of its gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions that are covered under an emissions-limiting regulation or program that is intended to directly limit or reduce emissions, such as cap-and-trade schemes, carbon tax/fee systems, and other emissions control (e.g., command-and-control approach) and permit-based mechanisms.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Examples of emissions-limiting regulations include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• California Cap-and-Trade (California Global Warming Solutions Act)
• European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS)
• Quebec Cap-and-Trade (Draft Bill 42 of 2009)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the total amount of gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions (CO2-e) that are covered under emissions-limiting regulations divided by the total amount of gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions (CO2-e).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • For emissions that are subject to multiple emissions-limiting regulations, the entity shall not account for those emissions more than once.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of emissions-limiting regulations excludes emissions covered under voluntary emissions-limiting regulations (e.g., voluntary trading systems), as well as reporting-based regulations [e.g., the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) GHG Reporting Program].

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of its gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions that are covered under emissions reporting-based regulations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions reporting-based regulations are defined as regulations that demand the disclosure of GHG emissions data to regulators and/or the public, but for which there is no limit, cost, target, or controls on the amount of emissions generated (e.g., the U.S. EPA Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the total amount of gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions (CO2-e) that are covered under emissions reporting-based regulations divided by the total amount of gross global Scope 1 GHG emissions (CO2-e).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • For emissions that are subject to multiple emissions reporting-based regulations, the entity shall not account for those emissions more than once.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of emissions reporting-based regulations does not exclude emissions covered under emissions-limiting regulations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: (1) Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under (2) emissions-limiting regulations, and (3) emissions-reporting regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total landfill gas generated, (2) percentage flared, (3) percentage used for energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount, in millions of British Thermal Units (MMBtu), of landfill gas generated from its owned or operated facilities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Landfill gas is defined, consistent with U.S. 40 CFR 98.6, as gas produced as a result of anaerobic decomposition of waste materials in the landfill.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total landfill gas generated, (2) percentage flared, (3) percentage used for energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of landfill gas that was flared.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount (in MMBtu) of landfill gas that was flared divided by the total amount (in MMBtu) of landfill gas generated.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Flared landfill gas includes gas that is flared through air injection and is defined, consistent with U.S. 40 CFR 98.6, as gas that is combusted through the use of an open flame with combustion air provided by uncontrolled ambient air around the flame and/or air that is blown into the flare to induce complete combustion.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total landfill gas generated, (2) percentage flared, (3) percentage used for energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of landfill gas that was used for energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount (in MMBtu) of landfill gas that was captured and used for energy divided by the total amount (in MMBtu) of landfill gas generated.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Landfill gas used for energy includes gas that is combusted for use in on-site energy or heat production, conveyed through pipelines for off-site combustion, and any other on-site or off-site use as a fuel.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total landfill gas generated, (2) percentage flared, (3) percentage used for energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall use the calculation methodology in U.S. 40 CFR 98.340-348 Subpart HH to calculate the amount of landfill gas generated, the percentage flared, and the percentage used for energy.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard, Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how lifecycle GHG emissions factor into its management of Scope 1 emissions and overall business strategy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant aspects to discuss include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The trade-offs between lifecycle emissions and Scope 1 emissions
• How such trade-offs are evaluated within the context of the entity’s business strategy and operational areas of focus (e.g., landfill gas management, waste-to-energy, recycling, composting)
• The extent to which the trade-offs factor into the entity’s business strategy, including identified areas of opportunity for growth and its capital expenditure strategy
• Whether the short-term management of Scope 1 emissions or the long-term management of lifecycle emissions is prioritized by the entity
• The impact of waste-to-energy (WTE) operations on lifecycle emissions versus Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may disclose related quantitative measures, which may include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Avoided emissions (e.g., Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement)
• Estimated future Scope 1 emissions from landfills

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss risks and opportunities arising out of lifecycle emissions and Scope 1 emissions, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks arising out of future Scope 1 emissions over the long-term resulting from landfills
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Risks arising out of short-term increases in Scope 1 emissions resulting from WTE facilities
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Opportunities arising out of long-term decreases in lifecycle emissions resulting from WTE facilities, recycling, and composting

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 and lifecycle emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of fuel consumed by its fleet vehicles as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The calculation methodology for fuel consumed shall be based on actual fuel consumed as opposed to design parameters.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Acceptable calculation methodologies for fuel consumed include, but are not limited to, methodologies based on:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Adding fuel purchases made during the reporting period to beginning inventory at the start of the reporting period, less any fuel inventory at the end of the reporting period
• Tracking fuel consumed by vehicle
• Tracking fuel expenses

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of fuel consumed that is natural gas.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of natural gas consumed (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of fuel consumed that was renewable fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable fuel is defined, consistent with the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard (U.S. 40 CFR 80.1401), as fuel that meets all of the following requirements:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of renewable fuel includes fuel that qualifies for Renewable Identification Numbers (RINs) under the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of renewable fuel consumed (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to fuel consumed by vehicles owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: In calculating energy consumption from fuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the U.S. Department of Energy, or the U.S. Energy Information Agency.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fleet fuel consumed, (2) percentage natural gas, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of alternative fuel vehicles in fleet
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its fleet vehicles that are alternative fuel vehicles.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Alternative fuel vehicles are defined by the U.S. Energy Policy Act and the U.S. Natural Defense Authorization Act of 2008 as vehicles powered by biodiesel, denatured alcohol, electricity, hydrogen, methanol, mixtures containing up to 85 percent methanol or denatured ethanol, natural gas, or propane (liquefied petroleum gas). Alternative energy vehicles also include any vehicle achieving a significant reduction in petroleum consumption, advanced lean burn technology vehicles, fuel cell vehicles, and hybrid electric vehicles.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of alternative energy vehicles in its fleet divided by the total number of vehicles in its fleet.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOX), reported as NOX.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOX includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) oxides of sulfur (SOX), reported as SOX.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of SOX includes SO2 and SO3.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (3) non-methane volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: VOCs are defined as any compound of carbon, excluding carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, carbonic acid, metallic carbides or carbonates, ammonium carbonate, and methane, that participates in atmospheric photochemical reactions, except those designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as having negligible photochemical reactivity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• This definition is aligned with U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, where a list of compounds that have been determined to have negligible photochemical reactivity can be obtained.
• Where applicable regulatory definitions of VOCs may conflict with this definition, such as the EU Paints Directive (Directive 2004/42/EC), and Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act 1999, the entity may define VOCs as per the applicable regulatory definition.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: HAPs are defined by the EPA as those pollutants that are known or suspected to cause cancer or other serious health effects, such as reproductive effects or birth defects, or adverse environmental effects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The EPA provides a list of HAPs in “The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 List of Hazardous Air Pollutants.”

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and (4) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Number of facilities in or near areas of dense population
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of facilities in or near areas of dense population.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An area of dense population is defined as an area with a densely settled core and contiguous territory that together have a minimum population of 50,000 persons (definition adapted from the U.S. Census Bureau’s definition of urbanized area).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• In the U.S., areas of dense population are urbanized areas, as defined by the U.S. Census Bureau in Federal Register, Vol. 76, No. 164, Part II (August 24, 2011). A list of urbanized areas based on census results from 2010 is available in Federal Register, Vol. 77, No. 59, Part IV (March 27, 2012).
• In the absence of available or accurate census data, the entity may use global population density data available from the NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center’s (SEDAC) Gridded Population of the World (GPW), v4.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A facility is considered to be located near an area of dense population if it is located within five kilometers of an area of dense population.

Accounting Metric: Number of facilities in or near areas of dense population
Technical Protocol: The scope of facilities includes, but is not limited to, landfills (both active and closed) and waste-to-energy facilities owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with air emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of instances of non-compliance associated with air emissions, including violations of technology-based standards and exceedances of quality-based standards.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with air emissions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents governed by national, regional, and local statutory permits and regulations including, but not limited to, the U.S. Clean Air Act and the U.S. Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and other national, state, or local air quality legislation on odor, ozone precursors, and non-methane organic compounds produced by landfills.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with air emissions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents of non-compliance associated with odor.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with air emissions
Technical Protocol: An incident of non-compliance shall be disclosed regardless of whether it resulted in an enforcement action (e.g., fine or warning letter).

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with air emissions
Technical Protocol: All violations, regardless of their measurement methodology or frequency, shall be disclosed. These include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Continuous emissions, limitations, standards, and prohibitions that are generally expressed as maximum daily, weekly average, and monthly averages
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-continuous emissions, limitations that are generally expressed in terms of frequency, total mass, maximum rate of discharge, and mass or concentration of specified pollutants
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: False or inaccurate reporting
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Failure to obtain permits

Accounting Metric: (1) Total Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) releases, (2) percentage released to water
Technical Protocol: The entity shall report its (1) total toxic release inventory (TRI), in metric tons.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A release is defined, consistent with U.S. 40 CFR 372.3, as any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping, or disposing into the environment (including abandonment or discarding of barrels, containers, and other closed receptacles) of any toxic chemical.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • A toxic chemical includes any chemical or chemical category listed in U.S. 40 CFR 372.65 or non-U.S. equivalent, including at a minimum the “Short Chemical List” established by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) through Guidance Document on Elements of a PRTR: Part I .

Accounting Metric: (1) Total Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) releases, (2) percentage released to water
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of TRI releases to water.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount (in metric tons) of TRI releases to water divided by the total amount (in metric tons) of TRI releases.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to those facilities owned or operated by the entity that are covered under the reporting requirements of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) TRI regulations, or non-U.S. equivalent, where covered facilities must:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) releases, (2) percentage released to water
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate its total TRI and the percentage released to water consistent with the estimation methodologies employed to report its TRI information to the EPA, or non-U.S. equivalent.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) releases, (2) percentage released to water
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from estimates of waste treatment efficiencies, actual operating data, engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Number of corrective actions implemented for landfill releases
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of corrective actions for landfill releases it has conducted at its facilities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Corrective actions are defined as control and cleanup of landfill releases of constituents detected at a statistically significant level above the established background level (as defined in Appendix I of U.S. 40 CFR Part 258) to achieve the groundwater protection standards in U.S. 40 CFR Part 258.50 Subpart E—Ground-Water Monitoring and Corrective Action.

Accounting Metric: Number of corrective actions implemented for landfill releases
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes corrective actions for Subtitle C landfills as defined in U.S. 40 CFR Part 258.50 Subpart E—Ground-Water Monitoring and Corrective Action for municipal solid waste landfills and Subtitle D landfills as defined in U.S. 40 CFR Part 264.100—Corrective Action Program.

Accounting Metric: Number of corrective actions implemented for landfill releases
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes corrective actions implemented for active landfills and closed landfills.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of instances of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts (excluding air pollution), including violations of technology-based standards and exceedances of quality-based standards.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents associated with the environment, such as those related to enforcement of U.S. laws and regulations on ground and surface water contamination; hazardous waste transport, containment, or disposal; leachate treatment, transport, containment, or disposal; and public disclosure of contamination events, including violations of the U.S. Clean Water Act and the RCRA, among others.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes instances of non-compliance associated with air pollution and odor, which are covered in IF-WM-120a.3.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall only include incidents of non-compliance that resulted in a formal enforcement action(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Formal enforcement actions are defined as statutorily recognized actions that address a violation or threatened violation of water quality laws, regulations, policies, or orders, and include administrative penalty orders, administrative orders, and judicial actions, among others. For example, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides guidance on the scope of formal enforcement actions in, Informal and Formal Actions, Summary Guidance and Portrayal on EPA Websites.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with environmental impacts
Technical Protocol: Violations, regardless of their measurement methodology or frequency, shall be disclosed. These include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Continuous emissions, limitations, standards, and prohibitions that are generally expressed as maximum daily, weekly, and monthly averages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For non-continuous emissions, limitations that are generally expressed in terms of frequency, total mass, maximum rate of discharge, and mass or concentrations of specified pollutants.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: False or inaccurate reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Failure to obtain permits.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its employees in the active workforce that were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Active workforce is defined as the maximum number of unique employees employed at any time during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Collective bargaining agreements are defined as a mechanism or tool of negotiation by which a union has a collective interest in negotiations to the benefit of several employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in the active workforce who were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period divided by the active workforce.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees employed by the entity, including full-time, part-time, and temporary employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of work stoppages involving 1,000 or more workers lasting one full shift or longer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of work stoppages includes strikes and lockouts.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• A strike is defined as a temporary stoppage of work by a group of employees (not necessarily union members) to express a grievance or enforce a demand.
• A lockout is defined as a temporary withholding or denial of employment during a labor dispute to enforce terms of employment upon a group of employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total days idle as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Days idle is defined as the aggregate number of work days lost as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Total days idle shall be calculated as the sum of the products of the number of workers involved in each work stoppage and the number of days the respective work stoppage was in effect.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fatality rate for work-related fatalities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for work-related near misses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Employees that operate company vehicles as their primary job function are excluded from the scope of the NMFR.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A near miss is defined as an unplanned incident in which no property or environmental damage or personal injury occurred, but where damage or personal injury easily could have occurred but for a slight circumstantial shift.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. National Safety Council (NSC) provides guidance on implementing near miss reporting, including in, “Near Miss Reporting Systems.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting near misses.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rates by each of the following employee categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Direct employees, defined as those employees on the entity’s payroll, whether they are full-time, part-time, executive, labor, salary, hourly, or seasonal employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Contract employees, defined as those who are not on the entity’s payroll, but who are supervised by the entity on a day-to-day basis, including independent contractors and those employed by third parties (e.g., temp agencies and labor brokers).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location (with the exception of employees that operate company vehicles as their primary job function, which are excluded from the scope of the NMFR).

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentile score calculated by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) Safety Measurement System (SMS) for the following Behavior Analysis and Safety Improvement Categories (BASICs):
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Unsafe Driving
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hours-of-Service (HOS) Compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Driver Fitness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Controlled Substances/Alcohol
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Vehicle Maintenance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Hazardous Materials (HM) Compliance

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its percentile in each BASIC for the month ending the most recent reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its percentile in relation to FMCSA’s Intervention Thresholds.

Accounting Metric: Number of road accidents and incidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total aggregate number of road accidents and incidents involving its direct and/or contracted employees during hours of employment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Direct employees, defined as those employees on the entity’s payroll, whether they are labor, executive, hourly, salary, part-time, seasonal, or migrant workers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Contract employees, defined as those who are not on the entity’s payroll, but who are supervised by the entity on a day-to-day basis, including independent contractors and those employed by third parties (e.g., temp agencies and labor brokers).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: An accident is defined, consistent with U.S. 49 CFR 390.50, as an occurrence involving a commercial motor vehicle operating on a highway in interstate or intrastate commerce that results in:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: An accident does not include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• An occurrence involving only boarding and alighting from a stationary motor vehicle; or
• An occurrence involving only the loading or unloading of cargo.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: An incident is defined as any event involving a licensed motor vehicle while on business use that results in an recordable incident (as defined by the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration), vehicle damage, or other property damage.

Accounting Metric: (1) Amount of waste incinerated, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage used for energy recovery
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of waste incinerated at its owned or operated facilities, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Incineration is defined, consistent with U.S. 40 CFR 240, as the controlled process in which combustible solid, liquid, or gaseous wastes are burned and changed into noncombustible gases.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Waste includes both solid waste, as defined by U.S. 40 CFR 261.2, and hazardous waste, as defined by U.S. 40 CFR 261.3.

Accounting Metric: (1) Amount of waste incinerated, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage used for energy recovery
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of hazardous waste that was incinerated during the reporting year.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage of hazardous waste incinerated shall be calculated as the total amount, in metric tons, of hazardous waste that was incinerated divided by the total amount of waste incinerated.

Accounting Metric: (1) Amount of waste incinerated, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage used for energy recovery
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of waste that was incinerated and used for energy recovery.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Energy recovery is defined, consistent with 40 CFR 60, as the process of recovering thermal energy from combustion for useful purposes including, but not limited to, steam generation or process heating.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage of waste incinerated and used for energy recovery shall be calculated as the total amount, in metric tons, of waste incinerated for energy recovery at its owned or operated facilities divided by the total amount of waste incinerated.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • For the purpose of this disclosure, waste incinerated for energy recovery shall include recovery from both solid and hazardous wastes.

Accounting Metric: (1) Amount of waste incinerated, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage used for energy recovery
Technical Protocol: The entity should disclose the technologies (e.g., mass burn facilities, modular systems, refuse-derived, and/or fuel systems) and practices employed in the incineration of waste.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of customers receiving (1) recycling and (2) composting services, by customer type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its customers, by customer category, that receive (1) recycling, and separately, (2) composting services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Customer categories include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Municipal
• Commercial
• Industrial
• Residential
• All other customers
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of the residential customer category is limited to include those residential customers that have direct contracts with the entity. For the purposes of this disclosure, residential customers serviced through contracts with a municipality shall be considered municipal customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of each customer type shall be consistent with the entity’s financial reporting.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of customers receiving (1) recycling and (2) composting services, by customer type
Technical Protocol: Recycling services are defined as operations whereby the entity collects, transports, or otherwise partakes in the process of recycling materials:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The process of recycling includes that of solid and hazardous materials.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The recycling of solid materials, consistent with the definition in U.S. 40 CFR 261.2, results in materials that are:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The recycling of hazardous materials, consistent with the definition provided in U.S. 40 CFR 240.43, results in materials that:

Accounting Metric: Percentage of customers receiving (1) recycling and (2) composting services, by customer type
Technical Protocol: For the purposes of this disclosure, waste-to-energy (WTE) shall be excluded from the scope of recycled material.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: WTE is defined as the conversion of non-recyclable waste materials into useable heat, electricity, or fuel through a variety of processes, including combustion, gasification, pyrolization, anaerobic digestion, and landfill gas (LFG) recovery.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: WTE using anaerobic digestion may be considered within the scope of recycled material if the residual materials resulting from the anaerobic digestion process are used in a productive manner (e.g., compost or fertilizer) as opposed to landfilling.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of customers receiving (1) recycling and (2) composting services, by customer type
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the types of recycling it offers, such as single-stream and multi-stream services, including the number of customers served by each.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of customers receiving (1) recycling and (2) composting services, by customer type
Technical Protocol: Composting services are defined as operations whereby the entity collects, transports, or otherwise partakes in the process of composting materials.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Compost is defined by either:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The applicable national or local laws where the composting services are provided; or
• The U.S. Compost Council, as the product resulting from the controlled biological decomposition of organic material that has been sanitized through the generation of heat and stabilized to the point that it is beneficial to plant growth.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of compost excludes natural decay of organic solid waste under uncontrolled conditions.

Accounting Metric: Amount of material (1) recycled, (2) composted, and (3) processed as waste-to-energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of material that it collected for (1) recycling.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Material collected for recycling includes both solid materials, as defined according to U.S. 40 CFR 241.2, and hazardous materials, defined according to U.S. 40 CFR 260.10.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Recycled solid materials, consistent with the definition provided in U.S. 40 CFR 261.2, include those materials that are:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Recycled hazardous materials, consistent with the definition provided in 40 CFR 240.43, include those materials that:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, waste-to-energy (WTE) shall be excluded from the scope of recycled material.

Accounting Metric: Amount of material (1) recycled, (2) composted, and (3) processed as waste-to-energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of material that it (2) composted.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Compost is defined by either:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The applicable national or local laws where the composting services are provided; or
• The U.S. Compost Council, as the product resulting from the controlled biological decomposition of organic material that has been sanitized through the generation of heat and stabilized to the point that it is beneficial to plant growth.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of compost excludes natural decay of organic solid waste under uncontrolled conditions.

Accounting Metric: Amount of material (1) recycled, (2) composted, and (3) processed as waste-to-energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of (3) material that was used as an input in WTE operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: WTE is defined as the conversion of non-recyclable waste materials into useable heat, electricity, or fuel through a variety of processes, including combustion, gasification, pyrolization, anaerobic digestion, and landfill gas (LFG) recovery.

Accounting Metric: Amount of electronic waste collected, percentage recovered through recycling
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in metric tons, of electronic waste collected.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Electronic waste includes waste from electronic products such as computers, televisions, phones, stereos, copiers, and fax machines, among others.

Accounting Metric: Amount of electronic waste collected, percentage recovered through recycling
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of materials recovered from electronic waste through recycling.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of recycled materials recovered from electronic waste divided by the total amount of electronic waste collected.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Recycled materials, consistent with U.S. 40 CFR 261.2, include those materials that are:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all water, wastewater, and stormwater operations and services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may break out its disclosures by water, wastewater, and/or stormwater services.

Accounting Metric: Water main replacement rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water main replacement rate for the distribution system(s) that it owns and/or operates.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The distribution system is defined, consistent with the definition provided by the American Water Works Association’s (AWWA) Water-Distribution Research and Applied Development Needs, as including all water utility components for the distribution of finished or potable water to customers or other users. This includes the distribution of water for non-potable uses, including fire suppression.

Accounting Metric: Water main replacement rate
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the total length of pipe replaced during the reporting period divided by the total length of water mains in its distribution system.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of water main replacements includes complete main replacements, as well as rehabilitations and/or renewals that substantially extend the life of the water main.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of water main replacements excludes water main repairs.

Accounting Metric: Water main replacement rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to water operations and services (i.e., wastewater and stormwater services are excluded).

Accounting Metric: Volume of non-revenue real water losses
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount, in cubic meters, of non-revenue real water losses from the distribution system.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Non-revenue real water losses are defined, consistent with the American Water Works Association (AWWA) Water Audits and Loss Control Program, Fourth Edition (M36 Manual), as the physical water losses, which are not billed and produce no revenue, from the pressurized system and the utility’s storage tanks up to the point of customer consumption, which is the customer meter for those utilities that meter their customers. In unmetered systems, the delineation is the point at which the customer becomes responsible for customer service connection piping maintenance and repairs. Real losses include leakage from mains and service connections and storage tank overflows.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall consider guidance such as the AWWA M36 Manual as normative references, thus any updates made year-on-year shall be considered updates to this guidance.

Accounting Metric: Volume of non-revenue real water losses
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the amount of non-revenue real water losses according to national, state, or local regulations where such loss occurs. Relevant guidance includes, but is not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: California Senate Bill 555
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Texas Water Code Section 16.012
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Georgia Senate Bill 370

Accounting Metric: Volume of non-revenue real water losses
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to water operations and services (i.e., wastewater and stormwater services are excluded).

Accounting Metric: Volume of non-revenue real water losses
Technical Protocol: Where national, state, or local regulations do not exist, the entity shall calculate the amount of real losses according to voluntary initiatives, where relevant guidance includes, but is not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The AWWA M36 Manual

Accounting Metric: Volume of non-revenue real water losses
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the technique(s) it employs to measure non-revenue water from real losses and the amount calculated according to each technique it employs.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with water effluent quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of instances of non-compliance with water effluent permits, standards, and regulations, including violations of a technology-based standard and exceedances of quantity and/or quality-based standards.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with water effluent quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes incidents governed by national, state, and local statutory permits and regulations, including, but not limited to, the discharge of a hazardous substance, failure to monitor wastewater effluent, or effluent limit exceedances (e.g., waste allocation or whole effluent toxicity).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For purpose of this disclosure, violations of the U.S. Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) and violations of other drinking water quality standards shall be limited to non-compliance with effluent requirements such as those relating to combined filter effluent requirements set forth in U.S. 40 CFR 141.550-.553.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with water effluent quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall only include incidents of non-compliance that resulted in a formal enforcement action(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Formal enforcement actions are defined as governmental actions that address a violation or threatened violation of water quantity and/or quality laws, regulations, policies, or orders, and can result in administrative penalty orders, administrative orders, and judicial actions, among others. For example, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides guidance on the scope of formal enforcement actions in, Informal and Formal Actions, Summary Guidance and Portrayal on EPA Websites.

Accounting Metric: Number of incidents of non-compliance associated with water effluent quality permits, standards, and regulations
Technical Protocol: Violations shall be disclosed, regardless of their measurement methodology or frequency. These include violations for:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Continuous discharges, limitations, standards, and prohibitions that are generally expressed as maximum daily, weekly average, and monthly averages
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-continuous discharges and limitations that are generally expressed in terms of frequency, total mass, maximum rate of discharge, and mass or concentration of specified pollutants

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to manage effluents of emerging concern
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategy and approach to managing effluents that may be of emerging human health and/or environmental concern to the public, regulators, and/or others (e.g., non-governmental organizations and/or scientific researchers).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Effluents of emerging concern may include, but are not limited to, those identified by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in Treating Contaminants of Emerging Concern, such as residuals of pharmaceuticals, personal care products, flame retardants, detergents, pesticides, hormones, and other compounds including those that disrupt the endocrine system.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to manage effluents of emerging concern
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to managing effluents of emerging concern including whether management is characterized by a hazard-based, risk-based, or another approach, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A hazard-based approach to effluent management is defined as the process of identifying and managing the usage of effluents based on the inherent human-health and environmental toxicological characteristics of effluent ingredients, including specific exposure routes (e.g., oral, dermal, or inhalation) and dosages (amounts) of a substance it takes to cause an adverse effect.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A risk-based approach to effluent management is defined as managing the usage of effluents based on the integration of effluent hazard information with an assessment of effluent exposure (i.e., route, frequency, duration, and magnitude) to assess the probability and magnitude of harm to a given population(s) arising from exposure to a chemical, given attendant uncertainties.
TP_BP2 Footnote: Definition adapted from “Environmental Health Criteria 222 | Biomarkers In Risk Assessment: Validity And Validation,” International Programme on Chemical Safety (IPCS), World Health Organization, 2001 and “Understanding Risk and Hazard When it Comes to Chemicals,” American Chemistry Council, accessed March 15, 2016, http://chemicalsafetyfacts.org/understanding-risk/
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Other approaches may include the usage of hazard-based and risk-based approaches depending on the effluent in question, product category, business segment, operating region, and/or intended product user.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to manage effluents of emerging concern
Technical Protocol: Relevant actions to discuss include, but are not limited to, the following where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The practices employed to determine and monitor effluents of emerging concern, including a discussion of the contaminants of emerging concern in the effluent stream that are currently being monitored and any thresholds the entity may have developed for acceptable concentrations of such effluents
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The use of pretreatment requirements among industrial customers

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to manage effluents of emerging concern
Technical Protocol: Relevant wastewater treatment processes include, but are not limited to, conventional wastewater treatment and advanced wastewater treatment technologies such as granular activated carbon, ozonation, advanced oxidation, membrane treatment, and/or investments in research and development of treatment technologies or methods for emerging contaminants.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategies to manage effluents of emerging concern
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the risks and/or opportunities associated with the potential for emerging contaminants to come under effluent regulations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant information to provide includes, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Identification of the emerging contaminants the entity anticipates may come under regulation in the future
• Current ability to treat and/or manage such contaminants
• Risks (e.g., potential for fines, challenges to community relations, and cost associated with compliance)
• Opportunities (e.g., potential for infrastructure expansions and new treatment methods to be covered by rates)

Accounting Metric: Average retail water rate for (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its average retail water rate per 100 cubic feet (1 Ccf) of water delivered to retail customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate its average retail water rate as the total revenue directly resulting from water delivered to retail customers divided by the amount of corresponding water delivered (in 100 cubic foot increments).

Accounting Metric: Average retail water rate for (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its average retail water rate separately for each type of customer, where customers are classified as (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of each customer type shall be consistent with the entity’s financial reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Each customer type shall be disclosed as an aggregate for all customers within that respective customer type.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• If the entity’s financial reporting combines commercial and industrial customers into one category, then the entity may combine the commercial and industrial customer types.
• The entity may disclose sub-classifications of customer types. For example, in addition to the average retail water rate for commercial customers, the entity may provide further disclosures by small commercial customers and large commercial customers.

Accounting Metric: Average retail water rate for (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to water operations and services (i.e., wastewater and stormwater services are excluded).

Accounting Metric: Average retail water rate for (1) residential, (2) commercial, and (3) industrial customers
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose additional customer types if such customer types exist that do not fall within the scope of the customer types described above. For example, the entity may additionally disclose average water rate for agricultural customers.

Accounting Metric: Typical monthly water bill for residential customers for 10 Ccf of water delivered per month
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the typical monthly water bill for the first 1,000 cubic feet (10 Ccf) of water delivered to its residential customers per month.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the typical monthly water bill for residential customers as the sum of revenue directly resulting from the first 10 Ccf of water delivered to residential customers each month over the course of the reporting period (based on seasonal rates), divided by the number of months in the reporting period, divided by the weighted average number of residential customers during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Typical monthly water bill for residential customers for 10 Ccf of water delivered per month
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to water operations and services (i.e., wastewater and stormwater services are excluded).
