Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location and type of employment, such as full-time, part-time, direct, contract, executive, labor, salary, hourly, and seasonal employees.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce the exposure of employees to human health hazards including, but not limited to, solvents, corrosives, lead (and its compounds), arsenic (and its compounds), cadmium, and sulfuric acid, as well as known or suspected carcinogens, teratogens, and mutagens, and efforts to reduce the occurrence of events including, but not limited to, fires, explosions, freeze burns, and electrocution.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its management approach in the context of short-term (i.e., acute) risks and long-term (i.e., chronic) risks.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: Relevant efforts to describe include, but are not limited to, risk assessments, risk monitoring, participation in long-term health studies, implementation of technology to control worker exposure, worker use of personal protective equipment (PPE), automation of processes, and phasing out, substituting, or using alternative materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall include a description of risk-monitoring policies as they apply to workforce lead exposure, including the monitoring of workforce blood lead levels (BLL) where lead exposure may exist.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The scope of the workforce shall focus on employees and contract employees in manufacturing or recycling plants but may discuss other members of the workforce as relevant.

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss company policies regarding maximum workforce BLL thresholds and testing frequencies, including, but not limited to, the following aspects:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: How the entity ensures compliance with maximum workforce BLL thresholds and testing frequencies as established by regulatory agencies and governmental or nongovernmental organizations, such as OSHA and the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygenists (ACGIH)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether any elements of company policies are more stringent than regulatory requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Whether policies differ across locations with varying regulatory requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: How policies are responsive to evolving regulatory requirements

Accounting Metric: Description of efforts to assess, monitor, and reduce exposure of workforce to human health hazards
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its performance in adhering to maximum workforce BLL thresholds and testing frequencies as established by company policies and/or applicable regulations, including any legal or regulatory fines or settlements and instances of non-compliance.

Accounting Metric: Average storage capacity of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average storage capacity of batteries by product application and technology type, weighted by unit sales volume per product application and technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Storage capacity shall be measured as the specific energy, or gravimetric energy density, of batteries, and is calculated as the ratio of nominal energy in watt-hours to the mass of the product in kilograms: watt-hours / kilograms (Wh/kg).

Accounting Metric: Average storage capacity of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall measure and disclose performance in accordance with the applicable product application and/or technology type standard(s), and shall disclose the standard(s) utilized for performance measurement.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Applicable standard(s) may include SAE J240—Automotive storage batteries and SAE J2185—Heavy-duty storage batteries.

Accounting Metric: Average storage capacity of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose performance by the following application types, where applicable: portable, motive, stationary, and “all other,” each further categorized by the following technology types, where applicable: lead-based, nickel-based, lithium-based, sodium-based, and “all other.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may include additional categories of application types and/or technology types where appropriate, including categories for new products with low sales volumes but strategic importance in terms of product efficiency or other attributes.

Accounting Metric: Average energy efficiency of fuel cells as (1) electrical efficiency and (2) thermal efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average energy efficiency of fuel cells as (1) electrical efficiency and (2) thermal efficiency, weighted by unit sales volume per product application and technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Electrical efficiency is calculated as net electricity produced divided by total fuel energy input.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Thermal efficiency is calculated as net useful power output divided by total fuel energy input.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall use lower heating values (LHV) in the calculation of electrical efficiency and thermal efficiency, and shall disclose the heating values used.

Accounting Metric: Average energy efficiency of fuel cells as (1) electrical efficiency and (2) thermal efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall measure and disclose electrical and thermal efficiency in accordance with standard(s) applicable to the product application and/or technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Applicable standard(s) may include IEC 62282-3-200—Stationary fuel cell power systems and SAE J2615—Testing Performance of Fuel Cell Systems for Automotive Applications.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall disclose the standard(s) utilized for energy efficiency measurements.

Accounting Metric: Average energy efficiency of fuel cells as (1) electrical efficiency and (2) thermal efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose electrical and thermal efficiency by the following application types, where applicable: portable, motive, stationary, and “all other,” each further categorized by the following technology types, where applicable: direct methanol (DMFC), polymer electrolyte (PEM), alkaline (AFC), phosphoric acid (PAFC), molten carbonate (MCFC), solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC), and “all other.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may include additional categories of application types and/or technology types where appropriate, including categories for new products with low sales volumes but strategic importance in terms of product efficiency or other attributes.

Accounting Metric: Average energy efficiency of fuel cells as (1) electrical efficiency and (2) thermal efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose any other fuel cell outputs that have economic value (e.g., hydrogen), including an appropriate measurement of sales-weighted average value, by product application and technology type.

Accounting Metric: Average battery efficiency as coulombic efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average energy efficiency of batteries as coulombic efficiency, weighted by unit sales volume per product application and technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Coulombic efficiency is calculated as energy removed from a battery during discharge divided by the energy used during charging to restore the original capacity.

Accounting Metric: Average battery efficiency as coulombic efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall measure and disclose coulombic efficiency in accordance with standard(s) applicable to the product application and/or technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Applicable standard(s) may include SAE J240—Automotive storage batteries and SAE J2185—Heavy-duty storage batteries.

Accounting Metric: Average battery efficiency as coulombic efficiency, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose coulombic efficiency by the following application types, where applicable: portable, motive, stationary, and “all other,” each further categorized by the following technology types, where applicable: lead-based, nickel-based, lithium-based, sodium-based, and “all other.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may include additional categories of application types and/or technology types where appropriate, including categories for new products with low sales volumes but strategic importance in terms of product efficiency or other attributes.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of fuel cells, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average operating lifetime of fuel cells, weighted by unit sales volume per product application and technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Operating lifetime of fuel cells is calculated as operating hours until 20% net power degradation occurs.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of fuel cells, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall measure and disclose operating lifetime in accordance with standard(s) applicable to the product application and/or technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Applicable standard(s) may include IEC 62282-3-200—Stationary fuel cell power systems and SAE J2615—Testing Performance of Fuel Cell Systems for Automotive Applications.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of fuel cells, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose operating lifetime by the following application types, where applicable: portable, motive, stationary, and “all other,” each further categorized by the following technology types, where applicable: direct methanol (DMFC), polymer electrolyte (PEM), alkaline (AFC), phosphoric acid (PAFC), molten carbonate (MCFC), solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC), and “all other.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may include additional categories of application types and/or technology types, where appropriate, including categories for new products with low sales volumes but strategic importance in terms of product efficiency or other attributes.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average operating lifetime of batteries, weighted by unit sales volume per product application and technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The operating lifetime of batteries is calculated as the number of times the battery can be fully charged and discharged, or “cycles,” until 20% capacity degradation occurs.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall measure and disclose operating lifetime in accordance with standard(s) applicable to the product application and/or technology type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Applicable standard(s) may include SAE J240—Automotive storage batteries and SAE J2185—Heavy-duty storage batteries.

Accounting Metric: Average operating lifetime of batteries, by product application and technology type
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose performance by the following application types, where applicable: portable, motive, stationary, and “all other,” each further categorized by the following technology types, where applicable: lead-based, nickel-based, lithium-based, sodium-based, and “all other.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may include additional categories of application types and/or technology types where appropriate, including categories for new products with low sales volumes but strategic importance in terms of product efficiency or other attributes.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable or reusable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of products, by weight in metric tons, that are reusable or recyclable, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: “Reusable” is defined as a product or packaging that has been conceived and designed to accomplish, within its lifecycle, a certain number of trips, rotations, or uses for the same purpose for which it was conceived, consistent with definitions in ISO 14021:1999, Environmental labels and declarations—Self-declared environmental claims (Type II environmental labelling).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: “Recyclable” is defined a product or packaging that can be diverted from the waste stream through available processes and programs and can be collected, processed, and returned to use in the form of raw materials or products, consistent with definitions in ISO 14021:1999, Environmental labels and declarations—Self-declared environmental claims (Type II environmental labelling).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable or reusable
Technical Protocol: For products or product materials that are partially made of recyclable or reusable materials, the entity shall classify the portion of the material that is recyclable or reusable based on a calculation (or estimate, where appropriate) of the weight of each portion.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable or reusable
Technical Protocol: A product or its components shall be considered recyclable or reusable if this claim is aligned with U.S. 16 CFR Part 260, Guides for the Use of Environmental Marketing Claims; Final Rule (also known as the “FTC Green Guides”), including the following elements:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A product or package shall not be marketed as recyclable unless it can be collected, separated, or otherwise recovered from the waste stream through an established recycling program for reuse or use in manufacturing or assembling another item.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: When recycling facilities are available to a substantial majority (i.e., 60 percent) of consumers, communities where the item is sold, or commercial and industrial customers through established collection infrastructure (public or private), the entity may consider the product (or product component) recyclable without a qualification.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: When recycling facilities are available to less than a substantial majority of customers or communities where the product is sold, the entity shall only consider the product (or product components) recyclable if it makes the appropriate qualification to its customers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For items that are partially made of recyclable components, the entity shall only consider those components recyclable if (a) it clearly and prominently qualifies the recyclable claim to avoid deception about which portions are recyclable, and (b) no components significantly limit the ability to disassemble and recycle the product or components of the product (e.g., the size, shape, or assembly method).

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the weight, in metric tons, of materials recovered, including those recovered through recycling services, product take-back programs, and refurbishment services, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure shall include products, materials, and parts at the end of their useful life that would have otherwise been disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery, but have instead been collected.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include both materials physically handled by the entity and materials of which the entity does not take physical possession, but for which it has contracted with a third party the task of collection for the express purpose of reuse, recycling, or refurbishment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall exclude products and parts that are in warranty and have been collected for repairs.

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The percentage recycled shall be calculated as the weight of incoming material that was reused or reclaimed, plus the weight of material recycled or remanufactured (through treatment or processing) by the entity, plus the weight of material sent externally for further recycling, divided by the total weight of incoming recovered material, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A material is recycled if it is used, reused, or reclaimed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Reclaimed materials are defined as materials processed to recover or regenerate a usable product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Reused materials are defined as recovered products or components of products that are used for the same purpose for which they were conceived.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Recycled and remanufactured materials are defined as waste materials that have been reprocessed or treated by means of production or manufacturing processes and made into a final product or a component for incorporation into a product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Materials sent for further recycling include those materials that are transferred to a third party for the express purpose of reuse, recycling, or refurbishment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The scope of recycled and remanufactured products includes primary recycled materials, co-products (outputs of equal value to primary recycled materials), and by-products (outputs of lesser value than primary recycled materials).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Portions of products and materials that are disposed of in landfills are not considered recycled. Only the portions of products that are directly incorporated into new products, co-products, or by-products shall be included in the percentage recycled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 8: Materials incinerated, including for energy recovery, are not considered reused, recycled, or reclaimed. Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration, with or without other waste, but with recovery of the heat.

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: Electronic waste material (e-waste) shall be considered recycled only if the entity can demonstrate that this material was transferred to entities with third-party certification to a standard for e-waste recycling such as Basel Action Network’s e-Steward® standard or the U.S. EPA’s Responsible Recycling Practices (R2) standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall disclose the standard(s) with which the entities the entity has transferred e-waste to are compliant with.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to manage use, reclamation, and disposal of hazardous materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategies to manage the use of hazardous materials, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hazardous materials include both hazardous secondary materials, per U.S. 40 CFR 260.10, and waste that meets the definition of hazardous waste under Subtitle C of the U.S. EPA’s Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), per 40 CFR 261.3.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hazardous materials include those that display the following characteristics: ignitability, corrosivity, reactivity, or toxicity.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to manage use, reclamation, and disposal of hazardous materials
Technical Protocol: The entity may identify which hazardous materials are used, its strategies to mitigate risks associated with the use of hazardous materials, and its approach to design for reducing use or substituting with non-hazardous materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to manage use, reclamation, and disposal of hazardous materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to design and its process to ensure proper and safe disposal and/or reclamation and recycling of hazardous materials at the product end-of-life stage, including take-back programs and direct contracts with third-party hazardous waste reclamation services.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to manage use, reclamation, and disposal of hazardous materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the root cause and its corrective actions for any incidences when its use, reclamation, and/or disposal of hazardous materials deviated from its expected outcomes, such as those resulting in a release into the environment, regulatory non-compliance, and/or human health and safety impacts.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to managing its risks associated with the use of critical materials in its products, including physical limits on availability and access, changes in price, and regulatory and reputational risks, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical material is defined as a material that is both essential in use and subject to the risk of supply restriction. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Research Council of the National Academies’ Minerals, Critical Minerals, and the U.S. Economy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of critical materials include, but are not limited to, the following as defined by the National Research Council:

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify the critical materials that present a significant risk to its operations, the type of risk(s) they represent, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate the risk(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant strategies may include diversification of suppliers, stockpiling of materials, development or procurement of alternative and substitute materials, and investments in recycling technology for critical materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity's ability to maintain confidential information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For example, if an entity determines not to identify a specific critical material that presents a significant risk to its operations due to competitive harm that could result from the disclosure, the entity shall disclose the existence of such risk(s), the type of risk(s), and the strategies used to mitigate the risk(s), but is not required to disclose the relevant critical material.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland certified to a third-party forest management standard, percentage certified to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total forestland area, in acres, that is certified to a third-party forest management standard, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope includes forestlands owned, leased, and/or managed by the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Third-party forest management standards are those that certify that forests are harvested in a sustainable manner and cover environmental and social criteria including legal compliance, land rights, community and worker relations, environmental impact and biodiversity, forest management plans and practices, land use, wildlife habitat conservation, and water conservation, among others.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Third-party forest management certifications include, but are not limited to, those promulgated by the following organizations (or the equivalent):
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• American Tree Farm System (ATFS)
• Forest Stewardship Council (FSC)
• Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC)
• Forest certification systems endorsed by the PEFC
• Sustainable Forest Initiative (SFI)

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland certified to a third-party forest management standard, percentage certified to each standard
Technical Protocol: If a forestland area is certified to multiple certification standards, the entity shall not account for the acreage more than once when calculating the total forestland area certified to a third-party forest management standard.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland certified to a third-party forest management standard, percentage certified to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of the total certified forestland that is certified to each forest management standard (e.g., FSC, SFI, PEFC, and ATFS) and indicate the associated certification(s) (e.g., FSC Forest Management Certification, SFI Forest Management Standard, PEFC Sustainable Forest Management certification, or ATFS Individual Third-Party certification).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the percentage of forestland certified to each forest management standard as the number of acres that are third-party certified to the respective standard divided by the total number of certified acres owned, leased, and/or managed by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland certified to a third-party forest management standard, percentage certified to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of acres that are certified to multiple certification schemes.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland with protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the area of its owned, leased, and/or managed forestland (by acreage) that has protected conservation status, where an area is considered to have protected conservation status if it is located within any of the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Areas legally designated as protected by government regulation, including national parks, national wildlife refuge sites, wilderness areas, state forests, state parks, and areas under conservation easement, as well as sites categorized as such by NatureServe and State Natural Resource Agencies, and agencies associated with the network of Natural Heritage or Conservation Data Centers, or Natura 2000 sites.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • These sites may be listed in the World Database of Protected Areas (WDPA) and mapped on ProtectedPlanet.net .

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland with protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The scope includes areas of conservation status that are actively managed by or for the entity and excludes areas of conservation status that are exclusively set aside for conservation and are not actively managed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope includes areas of conservation status that are government-owned and managed by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland with protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of the area of forestland with protected conservation status that is certified to a third-party forest management standard.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland with protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the likelihood of a change to the area of its owned, leased, and/or managed forestland that is considered to have protected conservation status.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland with protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately identify forestland areas with additional ecological, biodiversity, or conservation designations, such as those listed by the A-Z Guide of Areas of Biodiversity Importance prepared by the United Nations Environment Programme’s World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC).

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the area of its owned, leased, and/or managed forestland (by acreage) that is located in endangered species habitat.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the likelihood of a change to the area of its owned, leased, and/or managed forestland that is considered to be an endangered species habitat.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Discussion includes, but is not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Whether there are endangered or threatened species habitat (s) near, but not currently in, the entity’s forestlands, and whether the habitat (s) could overlap with the entity’s forestlands
• Whether there are species in or near the entity’s forestlands that are classified as endangered or threatened in non-government regulatory lists, but not currently by government regulatory lists, and whether these species may be classified as endangered or threatened by a regulatory endangered species list
• Whether the current endangered or threatened species habitat in the entity’s forestlands is expected to change and/or expand in the future
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may disclose the likelihood of these changes occurring and the area of its forestlands that could be affected.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: Forestlands are considered to be an endangered species habitat if a species that is classified by national, state, or local law as endangered or threatened inhabits the entity’s forestlands.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes forestlands owned, leased, and/or managed by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: An endangered species is defined in the U.S. Endangered Species Act as any species that is in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: A threatened species is defined in the U.S. Endangered Species Act as any species that is likely to become an endangered species within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: Endangered species habitats includes critical habitat areas where the entity owns, leases, and/or manages forestlands that are officially designated by applicable state and/or federal regulations including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Endangered Species Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The Canada Species at Risk Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Applicable regulatory endangered species lists in the regions where the entity owns, leases, and/or manages forestlands

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the types of endangered or threatened species in its forestlands.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose whether there is any overlap between the areas identified in RR-FM-160a.2 and RR-FM-160a.3.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide discussion around forestlands that are located in endangered species habitats, but present low risk to biodiversity or ecosystem services.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to optimizing opportunities from ecosystem services provided by forestlands
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategy to optimize the opportunities created by the ecosystem services that its forestlands provide, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ecosystem services are defined by the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment as the benefits obtained from ecosystems, which include: provisioning services (i.e., goods or products obtained from ecosystems), such as food, fresh water, timber, and fiber; regulating services (i.e., benefits obtained from an ecosystem’s control of natural processes), such as climate, erosion, and pollination; cultural services (i.e., nonmaterial benefits obtained from an ecosystem), such as recreational and spiritual benefits; and supporting services (i.e., services that maintain the other ecosystem services), such as nutrient cycling, primary production, and water cycling.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Opportunities from effective ecosystem services management can include higher land value, increased productivity and timber yield, direct payments for timber and non-timber forest products, and improved relationships with stakeholders.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to optimizing opportunities from ecosystem services provided by forestlands
Technical Protocol: For ecosystems services that the entity currently does not receive direct payments for, the entity shall describe its approach to managing these ecosystem services. The discussion shall include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The type(s) of ecosystem service(s) the entity currently manages, where types of ecosystem services include, but are not limited to: air quality, soil stabilization and erosion control, and cultural value.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity’s management actions, including decisions about harvesting, management of conservation areas or areas of high biodiversity, or conserving forested watershed.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to optimizing opportunities from ecosystem services provided by forestlands
Technical Protocol: For the ecosystem services that the entity does receive direct payments for, the entity may disclose the amount the entity receives for non-timber ecosystem goods and services and the type of compensation it receives, which can include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Public payments to landowners (from the government);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Voluntary payments to landowners (from businesses, individuals, and non-governmental organizations); and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Compliance-driven payments (payments made to comply with government regulations).

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to optimizing opportunities from ecosystem services provided by forestlands
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose whether it expects the revenues received from these non-timber or timber ecosystem services to change in the future and the methods or models used to develop these scenarios, including the use of global models or scientific research provided by governmental and non-governmental organizations.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to optimizing opportunities from ecosystem services provided by forestlands
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss how management of non-timber ecosystem services is expected to affect tree growth and timber yield.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in indigenous land
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the area by acreage of its owned, leased, and/or managed forestlands that are located in areas that are considered to be indigenous peoples’ land.

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in indigenous land
Technical Protocol: Indigenous lands are defined as those occupied by people who self-identify as indigenous and likely have one or more of the following characteristics based on the working definition of “Indigenous Peoples” adopted by the United Nations:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Historical continuity with pre-colonial and/or pre-settler societies
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A strong link to territories and surrounding natural resources
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Distinct social, economic, or political systems
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Distinct language, culture, and beliefs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Form non-dominant groups of society
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: A resolve to maintain and reproduce ancestral environments and systems as distinctive peoples and communities

Accounting Metric: Area of forestland in indigenous land
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose if there are adjacent indigenous communities that may be impacted by the entity’s operations and/or may pose a risk to the entity’s logging operations.

Accounting Metric: Description of engagement processes and due diligence practices with respect to human rights, indigenous rights, and the local community
Technical Protocol: Due diligence processes and practices the entity employs to ensure compliance can include, but are not limited to:, impact evaluations, assessment reports, monitoring and audits, processes to receive and respond to public inquiries, partnerships and agreements with indigenous peoples and local communities, community meetings and multi-stakeholder dialogues, or other industry-specific practices.

Accounting Metric: Description of engagement processes and due diligence practices with respect to human rights, indigenous rights, and the local community
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its due diligence practices and procedures with respect to upholding the principles covered in human rights frameworks, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: International Labour Organization (ILO) Declaration on Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work and the fundamental ILO conventions on freedom of association (No. 87), collective bargaining (No. 98), forced labor (No. 29 and No. 105), child labor (No. 138 and No. 182), fair wages (No. 100), and discrimination (No. 111)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, specifically Human Rights Due Diligence (Principle 17a-c)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: FSC International Standard Principle 4: Community
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: SFI Forest Management Standard Objective 12: Community Involvement and Landowner Outreach
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: PEFC International Forestry Management Standard Criterion 6: Maintenance of other socioeconomic functions and conditions

Accounting Metric: Description of engagement processes and due diligence practices with respect to human rights, indigenous rights, and the local community
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its due diligence practices and procedures with respect to indigenous rights of communities in which it operates or intends to operate, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Upholding ILO Convention No. 169
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Use of free, prior, and informed consent (or consultation) processes
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: FSC International Standard Principle 3: Indigenous Rights
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: SFI Forest Management Standard Objective 8: Recognize and Respect Indigenous Peoples’ Rights

Accounting Metric: Description of engagement processes and due diligence practices with respect to human rights, indigenous rights, and the local community
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its processes and practices with respect to the communities in areas where it conducts business, including practices to protect the following principles:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Economic rights and interests, including the right to employment opportunities, training, fair wages, payment transparency, and respect for infrastructure and agricultural land
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Environmental rights and interests, including the right to clean, local air and water, as well as safe discharge and disposal of waste
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Social rights and interests, including the right to adequate health care, education, and housing
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Cultural rights and interests, including the right to protection of places of cultural significance (e.g., sacred sites or burial sites)

Accounting Metric: Description of engagement processes and due diligence practices with respect to human rights, indigenous rights, and the local community
Technical Protocol: The discussion shall include how practices apply to business partners, such as contractors, sub-contractors, suppliers, and joint venture partners.

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the risks and/or opportunities that are presented by climate change scenarios to its owned, leased, and/or managed forestlands, including, where relevant, those presented by:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Physical impacts including, but not limited to: increased temperatures, changes in growth rates, changes in seasonality, availability of water, pest migration, increased frequency of fires, and increased frequency of extreme weather events
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Existing and potential legislation and regulation related to climate change, including those that limit emissions, tax emissions, set up cap-and-trade systems, affect the demand for the entity’s products, or otherwise affect the entity
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: International accords relating to climate change
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Indirect consequences of regulation or business trends, including legal, technological, or other developments related to climate change
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Other political and social risks, such as increased harvesting restrictions, or stakeholder perceptions or concerns (e.g., those from local communities, non-governmental organizations, and regulatory agencies)

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall be additional but complementary to the U.S. SEC’s Commission Guidance Regarding Disclosure Related to Climate Change.

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: For each of the risks and/or opportunities identified, the entity shall provide the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A description of the risk or opportunity, including an explanation and qualitative assessment of current and anticipated (long-term and short-term) significant risks or opportunities associated with climate change
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Disclosure corresponds to CDSB Climate Change Reporting Framework 4.9, 4.10, and 4.11.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Strategic analysis of the long-term and short-term impact climate change actually and potentially has on the entity’s strategic objectives
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Disclosure corresponds to CDSB Climate Change Reporting Framework 4.6.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The potential impact (direct or indirect) the risk or opportunity may have on the entity’s business, and the projected magnitude of the impact
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Where the entity has quantified the potential financial impacts of the risk or opportunity (Disclosure corresponds to CDSB Climate Change Reporting Framework 4.7.)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timeframe in which the risk or opportunity is expected to manifest
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4: • Disclosure corresponds to CDSB Climate Change reporting framework 4.11.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The likelihood that the risk or opportunity will manifest
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Disclosure corresponds to CDP Climate Change Questionnaire CC5.1 and CC6.1.

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss how potential climate change risks or opportunities may vary among the following, and how it prioritizes the risks and opportunities identified (disclosure corresponds to CDP Climate Change Questionnaire CC2.1c):
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The geographic regions where the entity owns, leases, and/or manages forestlands
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity’s products, services, and/or markets
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The types of tree species harvested by the entity
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The entity’s plantation forestlands and its natural forestlands

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall provide a discussion of the scenarios it uses to determine the risks and opportunities presented by climate change, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The methods or models used to develop these scenarios, including the use of global models or scientific research provided by governmental and non-governmental organizations (e.g., Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Climate Scenario Process)

Accounting Metric: Description of strategy to manage opportunities for and risks to forest management and timber production presented by climate change
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its risk management procedures with respect to climate change risks and opportunities, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: How far into the future risks are considered
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The frequency of monitoring
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity’s alleviation strategies, which may include, but are not limited to: use of insurance; diversification of tree species; actions to strengthen the adaptive capacity of forestlands; strategies to reduce the risk and intensity of pest, disease, and fire outbreaks; or plans to reduce risk and intensity of potential damage
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The entity’s adaptation strategies, which may include, but are not limited to: improving ecosystem management and biodiversity; monitoring changes; developing tolerant tree varieties; and optimizing the timing of planting and harvesting
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The costs associated with these actions
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Disclosure corresponds with CDSB Climate Change Reporting Framework 4.12.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Disclosure corresponds to CDP Climate Change Questionnaire CC2.1.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as whether they pertain differently to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOx), reported as NOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOx includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) oxides of sulfur (SO2)

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (3) non-methane volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: VOCs are defined as any compound of carbon, excluding carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, carbonic acid, metallic carbides or carbonates, ammonium carbonate, and methane, that participates in atmospheric photochemical reactions, except those designated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as having negligible photochemical reactivity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• This definition is aligned with U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, where a list of compounds that have been determined to have negligible photochemical reactivity can be obtained.
• Where applicable regulatory definitions of VOCs may conflict with this definition, such as EC Directive 1999/13/EC and Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act 1999, the entity may define VOCs as per the applicable regulatory definition.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (4) particulate matter (PM), reported as total filterable PM emissions as determined by U.S. EPA Method 5, or equivalent methodology.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: HAPs are defined by the EPA as those pollutants that are known or suspected to cause cancer or other serious health effects, such as reproductive effects or birth defects, or adverse environmental effects.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The EPA provides a list of HAPs in “The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 List of Hazardous Air Pollutants.”

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SO2, (3) volatile organic compounds (VOCs), (4) particulate matter (PM), and (5) hazardous air pollutants (HAPs)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied by biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as biomass energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from biomass sources is limited to the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Energy from biomass sources that meets at least one of the following criteria:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Certification to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System)
• Classification as an “eligible renewable” according to the Green-e Energy National Standard Version 2.5 (2014)
• Eligibility for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (4) the percentage of energy it consumed that was renewable energy, excluding biomass energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, and hydro.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro sources is limited to sources that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (5) the amount of energy self-generated by the entity as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity may disclose the amount of self-generated energy that it sold to an electric utility or end-use customer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity may disclose the amount of self-generated energy that was renewable energy, where renewable energy is defined above.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage from biomass, (4) percentage from other renewable energy, (5) total self-generated energy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was withdrawn from all sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water sources include surface water (including water from wetlands, rivers, lakes, and oceans), groundwater, rainwater collected directly and stored by the entity, and water and wastewater obtained from municipal water supplies, water utilities, or other entities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose portions of its supply by source if, for example, significant portions of withdrawals are from non-freshwater sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fresh water may be defined according to the local laws and regulations where the entity operates. Where there is no legal definition, fresh water shall be considered to be water that has less than 1,000 parts per million of dissolved solids per the U.S. Geological Survey.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Water obtained from a water utility in compliance with U.S. National Primary Drinking Water Regulations can be assumed to meet the definition of fresh water.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was consumed in its operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water consumption is defined as:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall analyze all of its operations for water risks and identify activities that withdraw and consume water in locations with High (40–80 percent) or Extremely High (>80 percent) Baseline Water Stress as classified by the World Resources Institute’s (WRI) Water Risk Atlas tool, Aqueduct.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water withdrawn in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water withdrawn.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water consumed in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water consumed.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its water management risks associated with water withdrawals, water consumption, and discharge of water and/or wastewater.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks associated with water withdrawals and water consumption include risks to the availability of adequate, clean water resources, including, but not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Environmental constraints—such as operating in water-stressed regions, drought, concerns of aquatic impingement or entrainment, interannual or seasonal variability, and risks due to the impact of climate change
• Regulatory and financial constraints—such as volatility in water costs, stakeholder perceptions and concerns related to water withdrawals (e.g., those from local communities, non-governmental organizations, and regulatory agencies), direct competition with and impact from the actions of other users (e.g., commercial and municipal users), restrictions to withdrawals due to regulations, and constraints on the entity’s ability to obtain and retain water rights or permits
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Risks associated with the discharge of water and/or wastewater, include, but are not limited to, the ability to obtain rights or permits related to discharges, compliance with regulations related to discharges, restrictions to discharges, the ability to maintain control over the temperature of water discharges, liabilities and/or reputational risks, and increased operating costs due to regulation, stakeholder perceptions and concerns related to water discharges (e.g., those from local communities, non-governmental organizations, and regulatory agencies).

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe water management risks in the context of:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: How risks may vary by withdrawal source, including surface water (including water from wetlands, rivers, lakes, and oceans), groundwater, rainwater collected directly and stored by the entity, and water and wastewater obtained from municipal water supplies, water utilities, or other entities; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: How risks may vary by discharge destinations, including surface water, groundwater, or wastewater utilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the potential impacts that water management risks may have on its operations and the timeline over which such risks are expected to manifest.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Impacts may include, but are not limited to, those associated with costs, revenues, liabilities, continuity of operations, and reputation.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its short-term and long-term strategies or plan to mitigate water management risks, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of its strategy, plans, goals and/or targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or water-consuming operational processes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Any water management goals and/or targets it has prioritized, and an analysis of performance against those goals and/or targets.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Goals and targets may include, but are not limited to, those associated with reducing water withdrawals, reducing water consumption, reducing water discharges, reducing aquatic impingements, improving the quality of water discharges, and regulatory compliance.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The activities and investments required to achieve the plans, goals and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Disclosure of strategies, plans, goals, and/or targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: For water management targets, the entity shall additionally disclose:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Whether the target is absolute or intensity-based, and the metric denominator if it is an intensity-based target.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The timelines for the water management plans, including the start year, the target year, and the base year.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The percentage reduction or improvement from the base year, where the base year is the first year against which water management targets are evaluated toward the achievement of the target.

Accounting Metric: Description of water management risks and discussion of strategies and practices to mitigate those risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its water management practices result in any additional lifecycle impacts or tradeoffs in its organization, including tradeoffs in land use, energy production, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and why the entity chose these practices despite lifecycle tradeoffs.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of wood fiber sourced from (1) third-party certified forestlands and percentage to each standard and (2) meeting other fiber sourcing standards and percentage to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its total wood-fiber-based materials that have been sourced from forestlands that are certified to forest management standards, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Third-party forest management standards are those that certify that forests are harvested in a sustainable manner and that cover environmental and social criteria including legal compliance, land rights, community and worker relations, environmental impact and biodiversity, forest management plans and practices, land use, wildlife habitat conservation, and water conservation, among others.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Third-party forest management certifications include, but are not limited to, those promulgated by the following organizations (or the equivalent):
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• American Tree Farm System (ATFS) (i.e., ATFS Certification)
• Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) (i.e., FSC Forest Management and Chain of Custody certifications)
• Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC) (i.e., PEFC Chain of Custody certifications)
• Forest certification systems endorsed by the PEFC
• Sustainable Forest Initiative (SFI) (i.e., SFI Forest Management and Chain of Custody certifications)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of wood-fiber-based materials includes all inputs that are processed to be sold as a finished good, including recycled raw materials, virgin raw materials, and goods that will be consumed directly in the production process and excluding biomass for energy.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of wood fiber sourced from (1) third-party certified forestlands and percentage to each standard and (2) meeting other fiber sourcing standards and percentage to each standard
Technical Protocol: The percentage of wood-fiber-based materials from third-party certified forestlands shall be calculated as the total weight (in air dried metric tons) of the entity’s wood-fiber-based materials that have been sourced from third-party certified forestlands divided by the total weight (in air dried metric tons) of wood-fiber-based materials sourced.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of wood fiber sourced from (1) third-party certified forestlands and percentage to each standard and (2) meeting other fiber sourcing standards and percentage to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of the total wood-fiber-based materials from third-party certified forestlands that is certified to each standard (e.g., FSC Chain of Custody, PEFC Chain of Custody, and SFI Chain of Custody).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate the percentage of wood-fiber-based materials certified to each standard as the amount of wood-fiber-based materials that is third-party certified to the respective standard divided by the total amount of wood fiber sourced by the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Where wood-fiber is certified to multiple third-party certifications, the entity shall include the amount of such fiber in its calculations for each relevant certification.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of wood fiber sourced from (1) third-party certified forestlands and percentage to each standard and (2) meeting other fiber sourcing standards and percentage to each standard
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its total wood-fiber-based materials that is sourced from non-third-party certified forestlands but meets other fiber sourcing standards, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Responsible fiber sourcing standards (e.g., SFI Fiber Sourcing Standard)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Controlled wood standards (e.g., FSC Controlled Wood Certification, PEFC Controlled Wood)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Recycled fiber standards that include post- and pre-consumer reclaimed material (e.g., PEFC Controlled Sources, FSC Recycled Label, and SFI Recycled Label)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Any other due diligence standards that cover sourcing requirements for fiber from non-certified forestlands

Accounting Metric: Percentage of wood fiber sourced from (1) third-party certified forestlands and percentage to each standard and (2) meeting other fiber sourcing standards and percentage to each standard
