Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.K. Bribery Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977 (FCPA) 15 U.S.C. § 78dd-1, et seq.).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior, such as those related to enforcement of laws and regulations on price fixing, antitrust behavior (e.g., exclusivity contracts), patent misuse, or network effects and bundling of services and products to limit competition.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fatality rate for work-related fatalities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for work-related near misses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A near miss is defined as an unplanned incident in which no property or environmental damage or personal injury occurred, but where damage or personal injury easily could have occurred but for a slight circumstantial shift.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. National Safety Council (NSC) provides guidance on implementing near miss reporting, including in, “Near Miss Reporting Systems.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting near misses.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count x 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location and type of employment, such as full-time, part-time, direct, contract, executive, labor, salary, hourly, and seasonal employees.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted fleet fuel efficiency for medium- and heavy-duty vehicles
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its sales-weighted average fleet fuel efficiency for medium- and heavy-duty vehicles, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fleet fuel efficiency is defined as the average fuel economy of its medium- and heavy-duty commercial vehicles, weighted by the number of each sold during the reporting period and measured in gallons per 1,000 ton-miles.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes vehicles in the fleet that weigh 8,500 pounds or more, and which are covered under the U.S. Heavy Duty (HD) National Program, including combination tractors (commonly known as semi-trucks), heavy-duty pickup trucks and vans, and vocational vehicles.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Where fleet averages are calculated by model year for regulatory purposes, the entity shall use these performance data.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: In the absence of regulatory guidance on calculating a fleet average, the entity shall calculate performance based on the fuel economy of vehicles sold during the reporting period, weighted by sales volume.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted fleet fuel efficiency for medium- and heavy-duty vehicles
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the sales-weighted fuel efficiency requirement for its medium- and heavy-duty vehicles, pursuant to U.S. HD National Program Fuel Consumption Standards, as issued and regulated by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted fuel efficiency for non-road equipment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its sales-weighted average fuel efficiency for its non-road equipment and vehicles, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fuel efficiency is defined as the average fuel economy of its non-road equipment, weighted by the number of each unit sold during the reporting period and measured in gallons of fuel consumed per hour of operation (gallons per hour).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• In calculating gallons per hour, the entity shall use the model-rated fuel efficiency value for each piece of equipment where available.
• Where model-rated fuel efficiency values are not available, the entity shall calculate a gallons-per-hour operational efficiency for the equipment, assuming normal, reasonable operating conditions (e.g., for load factor, speed, and environmental conditions).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Non-road equipment includes, but is not limited to, excavators and other construction equipment, farm tractors and other agricultural equipment, heavy forklifts, airport ground service equipment, and utility equipment such as generators, pumps, and compressors.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted fuel efficiency for stationary generators
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the sales-weighted average fuel efficiency of its stationary generators, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Sales-weighted fuel efficiency is the average fuel efficiency of stationary generators sold during the reporting period, measured in watts per gallon.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted fuel efficiency for stationary generators
Technical Protocol: Sales-weighted fuel efficiency is calculated as the harmonic mean of design fuel efficiency in watts per gallon, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The harmonic mean captures the average amount of fuel needed by each generator to produce a given amount of power.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The harmonic mean is the reciprocal of the average of the reciprocal values.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted emissions of: (1) nitrogen oxides (NOx) and (2) particulate matter (PM) for: (a) marine diesel engines, (b) locomotive diesel engines, (c) on-road medium- and heavy-duty engines, and (d) other non-road diesel engines
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the sales-weighted average emissions of (1) nitrogen oxides (NOx) and (2) particulate matter (PM) for each of the following product categories: (a) marine diesel engines, (b) locomotive diesel engines, (c) on-road heavy-duty engines, and (d) other non-road diesel engines, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions are calculated as the average emissions of (1) NOx and (2) PM for engines, weighted by the number of each sold during the reporting period and measured in grams per kilowatt hour.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Marine diesel engines are defined as those that are addressed within the scope of U.S. 40 CFR Part 1042, 40 CFR Part 94, 40 CFR Part 89, or non-U.S. equivalent.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Locomotive diesel engines are defined as those that are addressed within the scope of U.S. 40 CFR Part 1033, or non-U.S. equivalent.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: On-road heavy-duty engines are defined as those that are addressed within the scope of U.S. 40 CFR Chapter 1 Subchapter C Part 86, or non-U.S. equivalent.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Other non-road diesel engines are defined as those that are addressed within the scope of U.S. 40 CFR Part 1039, or non-U.S. equivalent, and typically include excavators and other construction equipment, farm tractors and other agricultural equipment, heavy forklifts, airport ground service equipment, and utility equipment such as generators, pumps, and compressors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Emissions shall be calculated according to the test method described in U.S. 40 CFR Part 1065, or non-U.S. equivalent.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The entity may disclose if any products do not meet current emission standards established in the above-referenced U.S. 40 CFR Part 1042, 40 CFR Part 94, and 40 CFR Part 89 for marine diesel engines; 40 CFR Part 1033 for locomotive diesel engines; 40 CFR Part 86 Subpart A for heavy-duty on-road engines; 40 CFR Part 1039 for other non-road diesel engines, or non-U.S. equivalents.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted emissions of: (1) nitrogen oxides (NOx) and (2) particulate matter (PM) for: (a) marine diesel engines, (b) locomotive diesel engines, (c) on-road medium- and heavy-duty engines, and (d) other non-road diesel engines
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its progress toward, and readiness for, future U.S. federal- and state-level, or non-U.S. equivalent, emissions standards that could affect its products.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to managing its risks associated with the use of critical materials in its products, including physical limits on availability and access, changes in price, and regulatory and reputational risks, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical material is defined as a material that is both essential in use and subject to the risk of supply restriction. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Research Council of the National Academies’ Minerals, Critical Minerals, and the U.S. Economy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of critical materials include, but are not limited to, the following as defined by the National Research Council:

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify the critical materials that present a significant risk to its operations, the type of risk(s) they represent, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate the risk(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant strategies may include diversification of suppliers, stockpiling of materials, development or procurement of alternative and substitute materials, and investments in recycling technology for critical materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain confidential information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For example, if an entity determines not to identify a specific critical material that presents a significant risk to its operations due to competitive harm that could result from the disclosure, the entity shall disclose the existence of such risk(s), the type of risk(s), and the strategies used to mitigate the risk(s), but is not required to disclose the relevant critical material.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from remanufactured products and remanufacturing services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of revenue from products that are remanufactured and services associated with remanufacturing goods, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A remanufactured product is defined as an end-of-life product or component (i.e., one that was previously sold, worn, or non-functional) that has undergone an industrial process to be returned to original working condition (i.e., is considered “like new”).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Remanufacturing services are defined as providing the service of repairing, restoring, and/or remanufacturing end-of-life goods to original working condition.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from remanufactured products and remanufacturing services
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes servicing of products that are in-warranty and have been collected for repairs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies and practices relating to behavioral advertising and consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to the privacy of consumer information, with a specific focus on how the entity addresses the collection, usage, and retention of consumers’ personally identifiable information (PII) and its approach to behavioral advertising.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Consumer information includes information that pertains to a user’s attributes or actions, including, but not limited to, records of communications, content of communications, demographic data, behavioral data, location data, or PII.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Demographic data are defined as the quantifiable statistics that identify and distinguish a given population. Examples of demographic data include gender, age, ethnicity, knowledge of languages, disabilities, mobility, home ownership, and employment status.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Behavioral data are defined as the product of tracking, measuring, and recording individual behaviors such as consumers’ online browsing patterns, buying habits, brand preferences, and product usage patterns, among others.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Behavioral advertising makes use of data that were the product of tracking, measuring, and recording individual behaviors such as consumers’ online browsing patterns, buying habits, brand preferences, and product usage patterns, among others.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Location data are defined as data describing the physical location or movement patterns of an individual, such as Global Positioning System coordinates or other related data that would enable identifying and tracking of an individual’s physical location.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: The scope of disclosure includes information from first-, second-, and third-party sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies and practices relating to behavioral advertising and consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect individuals’ privacy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: With respect to data collection, the entity may discuss which data or types of data are collected without the consent of an individual, which require opt-in consent, and which require opt-out action from the individual.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: With respect to data usage, the entity may discuss which data or types of data are used by the entity internally and under what circumstances the entity shares, sells, rents, or otherwise distributes data or information to third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: With respect to data retention, the entity may discuss which data or types of data it retains, the length of time of retention, and practices used to ensure that data are stored securely.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies and practices relating to behavioral advertising and consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the degree to which its policies and practices address similar issues as those outlined in the OMB Guidance for Implementing the Privacy Provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002 (M-03-22), including use of Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A PIA is an analysis of how information is handled that ensures handling conforms to applicable legal, regulatory, and policy requirements regarding privacy; determines the risks and effects of collecting, maintaining, and disseminating information in identifiable form in an electronic information system; and examines and evaluates protections and alternative processes for handling information in order to mitigate potential privacy risks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: As outlined by OMB M-03-22, PIAs must analyze and describe: (a) what information is to be collected, (b) why the information is being collected, (c) the intended use of the information, (d) with whom the information will be shared, (e) what opportunities individuals have to decline to provide information (i.e., where providing information is voluntary) or to consent to particular uses of the information (other than required or authorized uses) and how individuals can grant consent, and (f) how the information will be secured, among other government-specific requirements.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of policies and practices relating to behavioral advertising and consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: With respect to behavioral advertising, the entity may describe how it addresses the following principles, described by the cross-industry Self-Regulatory Principles for Online Behavioral Advertising:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Education—participation in educational efforts for consumers about behavioral online advertising
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Transparency—clearly disclosing information about data collection and data-use practices
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Consumer control—allowing users to choose whether data is collected or transferred to non-affiliates
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Data security—providing basic security provisions and having clear policies relating to the retention of consumer information
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Material changes—obtaining consent before applying changes to policies that are less restrictive than existing ones
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Sensitive data—abiding by the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) and handling consumer data such as financial information, Social Security numbers, and medical information
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Accountability—participation in self-regulatory organizations such as the Direct Marketing Association

Accounting Metric: Percentage of online advertising impressions that are targeted to custom audiences
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its advertising impressions that are targeted to custom audiences.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Advertising impressions are defined as a measure of the number of opportunities that a viewer, listener, or reader has to see or hear an online advertisement.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Custom audiences are defined as individuals to whom advertisers target their advertisements based on consumer information pertaining to a user’s attributes or actions, including, but not limited to, records of communications, content of communications, demographic data, behavioral data, location data, or personally identifiable information (PII).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Demographic data are defined as the quantifiable statistics that identify and distinguish a given population. Examples of demographic data include gender, age, ethnicity, knowledge of languages, disabilities, mobility, home ownership, and employment status.
• Behavioral data are defined as the product of tracking, measuring, and recording individual behaviors such as consumers’ online browsing patterns, buying habits, brand preferences, and product usage patterns, among others.
• Location data are defined as data describing the physical location or movement patterns of an individual, such as Global Positioning System coordinates or other related data that would enable identifying and tracking of an individual’s physical location.
• PII is defined as any information about an individual maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information  .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall calculate the percentage as the total number of advertising impressions that are targeted to custom audiences, divided by the total number of advertising impressions.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • The total number of advertising impressions shall be calculated in accordance with the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s (IAB) Interactive Audience Measurement and Advertising Campaign Reporting and Audit Guidelines as the sum of impressions that are targeted to custom audiences and impressions that are not targeted to custom audiences, such as those targeted according to publisher (e.g., contextual advertising).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of online advertising impressions that are targeted to custom audiences
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to impressions from advertising campaigns delivered online, including through mobile devices or Internet-based TV services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Advertising campaigns include (1) campaigns made directly by the entity and (2) campaigns the entity has made on behalf of its customers, including those resulting from ad inventory sold on networks and exchanges operated by the entity, ad space purchased on behalf of customers through platform buying services, and media plans developed by the entity that specify the locations and type of ad placement.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with incidents relating to customer privacy.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with consumer privacy
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Directive 2002/58/EC (ePrivacy Directive)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S.-EU Safe Harbor Program
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Privacy Act

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false, deceptive, or unfair advertising
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with incidents relating to false, deceptive, or unfair advertising.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false, deceptive, or unfair advertising
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false, deceptive, or unfair advertising
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false, deceptive, or unfair advertising
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with false, deceptive, or unfair advertising
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C §§ 41-58, as amended), which requires that (1) advertising must be truthful and non-deceptive, (2) advertisers must have evidence to back up their claims, and (3) advertisements cannot be unfair
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.K. Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations 2008 No. 1277
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: New Zealand Fair Trading Act 1986

Accounting Metric: Percentage of campaigns reviewed for adherence with the Advertising Self-Regulatory Council (ASRC) procedures, percentage of those in compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its advertising and marketing campaigns, by revenue, that were reviewed by the Advertising Self-Regulatory Council (ASRC) for adherence to the ASRC voluntary self-regulatory procedures, which are directed at performance of advertisers (e.g., the clients of advertising agencies).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ASRC procedures are defined as those associated with the following self-regulatory programs:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Children’s Advertising Review Unit (CARU)
• Electronic Retailing Self-Regulation Program (ERSP)
• National Advertising Division (NAD)
• National Advertising Review Board
• Online Interest-Based Advertising Accountability Program (Accountability Program)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is all advertising and marketing campaigns and associated recommendations by the entity (e.g., placement of ads).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage is calculated as the revenue associated with advertising and marketing campaigns that were reviewed by ASRC for adherence to the ASRC procedures, divided by the total advertising and marketing revenue.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of campaigns reviewed for adherence with the Advertising Self-Regulatory Council (ASRC) procedures, percentage of those in compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its ASRC-reviewed advertising and marketing campaigns by revenue that were found by ASRC to be in compliance with ASRC procedures.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of campaigns that promote alcohol or tobacco products
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its advertising and marketing campaigns that promote alcohol or tobacco products.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Tobacco products are defined by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration as any product made or derived from tobacco that is intended for human consumption, including any component, part, or accessory of a tobacco product. This includes, among other products, cigarettes, cigarette tobacco, roll-your-own tobacco, and smokeless tobacco.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Alcohol products are any product capable of being consumed containing more than a half percent of ethanol or ethyl alcohol by volume.
TP_BP2 Footnote: Definition adapted from the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission’s guidance.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of campaigns that promote alcohol or tobacco products
Technical Protocol: The percentage is calculated as the total revenue generated from advertising and marketing campaigns that promote alcohol or tobacco products, divided by the total revenue from all advertising and marketing campaigns.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of campaigns that promote alcohol or tobacco products
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its approach to managing potential impacts from specific rules, prohibitions, media restrictions, labeling disclosures, and warning requirements applicable to advertising for alcohol or tobacco products (e.g., bans on outdoor advertisements for tobacco products in the U.S. and EU).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose gender representation for all employees and racial/ethnic group representation for its U.S. employees by employee category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The following employee categories shall be used: (1) management, (2), professionals, and (3) all other employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: Gender and racial/ethnic group representation shall be disclosed in percentages, where the percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in each gender or racial/ethnic group in each employee category divided by the total number of employees in the respective employee category.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet, where each employee category for disclosure is defined by corresponding job categories and descriptions in the Instruction Booklet:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Management includes the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Executives/Senior Level Officials and Managers: individuals who plan, direct and formulate policies, set strategy and provide the overall direction of enterprises/organizations for the development and delivery of products or services, within the parameters approved by boards of directors or other governing bodies. Residing in the highest levels of organizations, these executives plan, direct or coordinate activities with the support of subordinate executives and staff managers. They include, in larger organizations, those individuals within two reporting levels of the CEO, whose responsibilities require frequent interaction with the CEO. Examples of these kinds of managers are: chief executive officers, chief operating officers, chief financial officers, line of business heads, presidents or executive vice presidents of functional areas or operating groups, chief information officers, chief human resources officers, chief marketing officers, chief legal officers, management directors and managing partners.
• Non-executive management includes First/Mid Level Officials and Managers: individuals who serve as managers, other than those who serve as Executive/Senior Level Officials and Managers, including those who oversee and direct the delivery of products, services or functions at group, regional or divisional levels of organizations. These managers receive directions from the Executive/Senior Level management and typically lead major business units. They implement policies, programs and directives of executive/senior management through subordinate managers and within the parameters set by Executive/Senior Level management. Examples of these kinds of managers are: vice presidents and directors, group, regional or divisional controllers; treasurers; human resources, information systems, marketing, and operations managers. The First/Mid Level Officials and Managers subcategory also includes those who report directly to middle managers. These individuals serve at functional, line of business segment or branch levels and are responsible for directing and executing the day-to-day operational objectives of enterprises/organizations, conveying the directions of higher level officials and managers to subordinate personnel and, in some instances, directly supervising the activities of exempt and non-exempt personnel. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Professionals is defined as the following: most jobs in this category require bachelor and graduate degrees, and/or professional certification. In some instances, comparable experience may establish a person’s qualifications. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: All other employees includes those employees who are not classified as management or professionals.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For non-U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in a manner generally consistent with the definitions provided above, though in accordance with, and further facilitated by, any applicable local regulations, guidance, or generally accepted definitions.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the gender of its employees as female, male, or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall classify the racial/ethnic group of its U.S. employees in accordance with the EEO-1 Survey Instruction Booklet and use the following categories: Asian, Black or African American, Hispanic or Latino, White, Other (which includes Native American or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, and “Two or More Races” classifications), or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental disclosures on gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by country or region.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental contextual disclosures on factors that significantly influence gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation, such as the country or region where employees are located.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by employee category in the following table formats:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming facilities that implement the Responsible Gambling Index
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its gaming facilities by revenue that implement the Responsible Gambling Index (RG Index) criteria.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Gaming facility is defined as any entity-owned establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of accruing business revenue, excluding online gaming operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: RG Index criteria are those developed by the Responsible Gambling Council (RGC) Centre for the Advancement of Best Practices.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming facilities that implement the Responsible Gambling Index
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage of RG Index criteria achieved for each gaming facility as the number of RG Index criteria for which the facility is in compliance divided by the total number of criteria, as follows:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall consider the 47 criteria under the eight core standards: Responsible gambling policies (five criteria), Employee training (eight criteria), Self-exclusion (11 criteria), Assisting patrons who may have problems with gambling (four criteria), Informed decision-making (three criteria), Advertising and promotion (five criteria), Access to money (four criteria), and Venue and game features (seven criteria).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate a weighting factor for each gaming facility as the revenue from that facility divided by the entity’s total revenue across all gaming facilities.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage of criteria achieved by each facility shall be multiplied by its weighting factor and summed across all gaming facilities to determine the percentage for disclosure.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming facilities that implement the Responsible Gambling Index
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of its facilities, by revenue, for which RG Index certification has been attained.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of online gaming operations that implement the National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) Internet Responsible Gambling Standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its online gaming operations by revenue that implement the National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) Internet Responsible Gambling Standards.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Online games are defined as any entity-owned or operated online platform that enables individuals to place, receive, or otherwise knowingly transmit a bet or wager by any means that involve the use, at least in part, of the internet.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of online gaming operations that implement the National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) Internet Responsible Gambling Standards
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the percentage of NCPG criteria achieved for each online gaming website as the number of NCPG criteria for which the facility is in compliance divided by the total number of criteria, as follows:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall consider the 34 criteria, which are counted as each sub-element under the eight core standards: Policy (three criteria), Staff training (two criteria), Informed decision-making (four criteria), Assisting players (two criteria), Self-exclusion (eight criteria), Advertising and promotion (three criteria), Game and site features (11 criteria), and Research (one criterion).
TP_BP1 Footnote: The NCPG Internet Responsible Gambling Standards sub-elements are generally designated as a topic followed by a colon (:) and further explanation of the topic.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate a weighting factor for each online gaming website as the revenue from that online gaming website divided by the entity's total revenue across all online gaming websites.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage of criteria achieved by each online gaming website is multiplied by its weighting factor and summed across all online gaming websites to determine the percentage for disclosure.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming floor where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its gaming floor where smoking is permitted (i.e., areas where smoking is not banned by law or designated by the entity as non-smoking).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Gaming floor is defined as any entity-owned establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of accruing business revenue.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Designated non-smoking areas are defined as areas within the casino’s gaming floor that are clearly marked “non-smoking,” are actively monitored for smoking violations, and that are separately ventilated from enclosed indoor areas where smoking is allowed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure excludes areas adjacent to the gaming floor, such as any hallway, reception area, retail space, bar, nightclub, restaurant, hotel, entertainment venue, or office space.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming floor where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The percentage is calculated as the gaming floor area where smoking is permitted divided by the total gaming floor area.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming floor where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of its gaming floor area that is mandated by law to be designated non-smoking, calculated as the gaming floor area that is required by law to be designated as non-smoking divided by the total gaming floor area.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming staff who work in areas where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its gaming staff, on an hours-worked basis, who work in areas where smoking is permitted (i.e., areas where smoking is not banned by law or designated by the entity as non-smoking).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Gaming staff is defined as any person (1) who is employed by an operator or retailer that hosts gaming to work directly with the gaming portion of its business and (2) who must be twenty-one years of age or older and hold a support license.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Gaming staff include, but are not limited to, dealers; change and counting room personnel; cashiers; floormen; cage personnel; slot machine repairmen or mechanics; persons who accept or transport revenue from a slot, blackjack, or poker-table drop or dropbox; security personnel; shift or pit bosses; floor managers; supervisors; slot machine and slot booth personnel; and any other employees whose main work station is located in a gaming facility.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gaming floor is defined as any entity-owned establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of accruing business revenue.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Designated non-smoking areas are defined as areas within the casino’s gaming floor that are clearly marked “non-smoking,” are actively monitored for smoking violations, and that are separately ventilated from enclosed indoor areas where smoking is allowed.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming staff who work in areas where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The percentage of staff is calculated as the number of gaming staff man-hours worked on the casino’s gaming floor in areas that are not designated as non-smoking, divided by the total number of gaming staff man-hours.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gaming staff who work in areas where smoking is allowed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its gaming staff mandated by law to be stationed in a designated non-smoking area, calculated as the number of gaming staff who are mandated by law to be stationed for work in the casino’s designated non-smoking gaming facilities, divided by the total number of gaming staff.

Accounting Metric: Description of anti-money laundering policies and practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and practices for assessing and managing money laundering risks internally as well as those associated with business partners in its value chain.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant business partners include customers, suppliers, contractors, and subcontractors.

Accounting Metric: Description of anti-money laundering policies and practices
Technical Protocol: Relevant management practices include:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Barring cash-for-cash exchanges above a set threshold or for the purchase of casino checks
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Conducting a risk assessment
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Customer due diligence, including patron identification and verification and know-your-customer protocols
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Employee awareness and training programs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Enforcing a cap on ticket-in and ticket-out redemptions at slot machine kiosks
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Mechanisms for recordkeeping, reporting to government agencies (Financial Crimes Enforcement Network or others), and investigation of suspicious activities and red flags
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: Transaction monitoring

Accounting Metric: Description of anti-money laundering policies and practices
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the implementation of one or more of the following:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: American Gaming Association (AGA) Best Practices for Anti-Money Laundering Compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: AGA Code of Conduct for Responsible Gaming
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: e-CFR “Know Your Customer” Guidance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Guidance on Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Measures and Financial Inclusion
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: FATF Guidance on the Risk-Based Approach for Casinos
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: U.S. Department of the Treasury Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) Guidance on Preparing a Complete & Sufficient Suspicious Activity Report Narrative
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 7: FinCEN Suspicious Activity Reporting Guidance for Casinos

Accounting Metric: Description of anti-money laundering policies and practices
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the effectiveness of its programs and practices and any associated outcomes, including but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Third-party auditing of the casino’s overall program
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The number of customers who have undergone due diligence procedures
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The number and types of due diligence reports performed
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The number of Suspicious Activity reports filed to FinCEN

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with money laundering
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Anti-Money Laundering Law of the People's Republic of China
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Bank Secrecy Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems that pose a data security risk.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, and/or implementation that could be exploited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data security risk is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, or nations through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities it has identified, including, but not limited to, operational procedures, management processes, structure of products, selection of business partners, employee training, and use of technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the degree to which its approach is aligned with an external standard or framework and/or legal or regulatory framework for managing data security, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ISO/IEC 27001:2013—Information technology—Security techniques—Information security management systems—Requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, Version 1.1, April 16, 2018, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC's Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity's approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of student information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to student privacy, with a specific focus on how it addresses the collection, usage, and retention of student information, including demographic data and personally identifiable information (PII).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Student information includes information that pertains to a student’s attributes or actions, including, but not limited to, records of communications, content of communications, and demographic data.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Demographic data are defined as the quantifiable statistics that identify and distinguish a given population. Examples of demographic data include gender, age, ethnicity, knowledge of languages, disabilities, mobility, home ownership, and employment status.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office's Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of student information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction of information) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect students’ privacy.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of student information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the degree to which its policies and practices address similar issues as outlined in the OMB Guidance for Implementing the Privacy Provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002 (M-03-22), including use of Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A PIA is an analysis of how information is handled that ensures handling conforms to applicable legal, regulatory, and policy requirements regarding privacy; determines the risks and effects of collecting, maintaining, and disseminating information in identifiable form in an electronic information system; and examines and evaluates protections and alternative processes for handling information in order to mitigate potential privacy risks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: As outlined by OMB M-03-22, PIAs must analyze and describe: (a) what information is to be collected; (b) why the information is being collected; (c) the intended use of the information; (d) with whom the information will be shared; (e) what opportunities individuals have to decline to provide information (i.e., where providing information is voluntary) or to consent to particular uses of the information (other than required or authorized uses), including how individuals can grant consent; and (f) how the information will be secured, among other government-specific requirements.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of students affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity's expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of students affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office's Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which students were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of students affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique students who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same student shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of students affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Graduation rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the graduation rate, consistent with methodology outlined in the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act (P.L. 101-542) passed by the U.S. Congress on November 9, 1990, as the percentage of completers in the revised adjusted cohort who are conferred a formal award within 150 percent of normal time to completion.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Completers are defined as students who are conferred a degree, diploma, certificate, or other formal award.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Normal time to completion is defined by the U.S. Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) as the amount of time necessary for a student to complete all requirements for a degree or certificate according to the institution’s catalog. This is typically four years (eight semesters or trimesters, or 12 quarters, excluding summer terms) for a bachelor’s degree in a standard term-based institution; two years (four semesters or trimesters, or six quarters, excluding summer terms) for an associate’s degree in a standard term-based institution; and the various scheduled times for certificate programs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Cohort is defined consistent with the entity's reporting under the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act. If the entity does not report under this act, then cohort is defined as the collective group of students entering a particular program at the same time.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Revised cohort is defined as the initial cohort after revisions are made. Cohorts may be revised if an institution discovers that incorrect data were reported in an earlier year.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Adjusted cohort is defined as the result of removing any allowable exclusions from a cohort (or subcohort) in accordance with the definitions for the Graduation Rate component under the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • "Exclusions are defined as those students who may be removed (deleted) from a cohort (or subcohort). For the Graduation Rates reporting, students may be removed from a cohort if they left the institution for one of the following reasons: death or total and permanent disability; service in the armed forces (including those called to active duty); service with a foreign aid service of the federal government, such as the Peace Corps; or service on official church missions."
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The scope of disclosure includes those cohorts for which 150 percent of normal time to completion occurred during the reporting period, consistent with the Graduation Rate as reported in the IPEDS database.

Accounting Metric: Graduation rate
Technical Protocol: The graduation rate is calculated as the total number of completers within a cohort who are conferred a formal award within 150 percent of normal time to completion, divided by the revised adjusted cohort.

Accounting Metric: On-time completion rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the on-time completion rate as the percentage of completers who are conferred a formal award within 100 percent of normal time to completion.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Completers are defined as students who are conferred a degree, diploma, certificate, or other formal award.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Normal time to completion is defined by the U.S. Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) as the amount of time necessary for a student to complete all requirements for a degree or certificate according to the institution’s catalog. This is typically four years (eight semesters or trimesters, or 12 quarters, excluding summer terms) for a bachelor’s degree in a standard term-based institution; two years (four semesters or trimesters, or six quarters, excluding summer terms) for an associate’s degree in a standard term-based institution; and the various scheduled times for certificate programs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Cohort is defined consistent with the entity's reporting under the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act. If the entity does not report under this act, cohort is defined as the collective group of students entering a particular program at the same time.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Revised cohort is defined as the initial cohort after revisions are made. Cohorts may be revised if an institution discovers that incorrect data were reported in an earlier year.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Adjusted cohort is defined as the result of removing any allowable exclusions from a cohort (or subcohort) in accordance with the definitions for the Graduation Rate component under the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • "Exclusions are defined as those students who may be removed (deleted) from a cohort (or subcohort). For the Graduation Rates reporting, students may be removed from a cohort if they left the institution for one of the following reasons: death or total and permanent disability; service in the armed forces (including those called to active duty); service with a foreign aid service of the federal government, such as the Peace Corps; or service on official church missions."
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The scope of disclosure includes those cohorts for which 100 percent of normal time to completion occurred during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: On-time completion rate
Technical Protocol: The on-time completion rate is calculated as the total number of completers within a cohort who are conferred a formal award within 100 percent of normal time to completion, divided by the revised adjusted cohort.

Accounting Metric: Job placement rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the job placement rate for completers, consistent with the methodology required for short-term undergraduate programs (U.S. 34 CFR § 668.8(g)).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The job placement rate is calculated as the number of completers who were placed in jobs divided by the total number of completers.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Completers are defined as students who are conferred a degree, diploma, certificate, or other formal award.
• The number of completers who were placed in jobs is defined as the number who, within 180 days of the day they received their degree, certificate, or other recognized educational credential, (a) obtained gainful employment in the recognized occupation for which they were trained or in a related, comparable, recognized occupation and (b) are employed, or have been employed, for at least 13 weeks following receipt of the credential from the institution.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The measurement period for calculating the job placement rate covers the completers who are conferred a formal award at least 271 days before the end of the entity’s fiscal year, to allow for the job placement and retention timeframes outlined above. Completers who are conferred an award with fewer than 271 days remaining before the end of the entity’s fiscal year are counted in the job placement rate for the next fiscal year.
