Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: For an entity whose fiscal year is aligned with the calendar year, it shall include completers who are conferred a formal award on or before April 4 of the current year in its current year disclosure and completers conferred a formal award after April 4 in its disclosure for the next fiscal year. In general, for entities whose fiscal year is aligned with the calendar year, spring and winter graduates shall be included in the job placement rate for the fiscal year following program completion.

Accounting Metric: (1) Debt-to-annual earnings rate and (2) debt-to-discretionary income rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate the debt-to-annual earnings and debt-to-discretionary income rates in accordance with the methodology outlined in the U.S. Gainful Employment Rule § 668.404, 79 Fed. Reg. 64889 (October 31, 2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Debt-to-annual earnings rate is the percentage of a Gainful Employment (GE) program’s annual loan payment compared to the annual earnings of the students who completed the program, as calculated under §668.404.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Debt-to-discretionary income rate is the percentage of a GE program’s annual loan payment compared to the discretionary income of the students who completed the program, as calculated under §668.404.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of this disclosure applies to the entity’s educational programs that are classified as GE programs.

Accounting Metric: Program cohort default rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the program cohort default rate (pCDR) for all educational programs classified as Gainful Employment (GE) programs, in accordance with the methodology outlined in the U.S. Gainful Employment Rule § 668.403, 79 Fed. Reg. 64902 (October 31, 2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: pCDR is the percentage of borrowers in a cohort who defaulted on their loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Borrowers in a cohort for a fiscal year include all of an institution’s current and former students who, during that fiscal year, entered repayment on any U.S. Federal Stafford Loan, Federal Supplemental Loan for Students, Direct Subsidized Loan, or Direct Unsubsidized Loan that they received to enroll in the GE program, or on the portion of a loan made under the U.S. Federal Consolidation Loan Program or the Federal Direct Consolidation Loan Program that is used to repay those loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Borrowers in a cohort who are in default include any borrowers who, before the end of the second fiscal year following the fiscal year the borrower entered repayment, default on (a) any Federal Family Education Loan Program loan that was used to include the borrower in the cohort or on (b) any Federal Consolidation Loan Program loan that repaid a loan that was used to include the borrower in the cohort.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The measurement period for calculating the pCDR covers the borrowers who entered repayment three fiscal years prior to the year in which pCDR is calculated, and the percentage is based on those who defaulted by end of the subsequent two fiscal years. For example, the 2016 pCDR calculation would be based on the borrowers who entered repayment in fiscal year 2013, and the percentage would be those who defaulted by end of fiscal year 2015.

Accounting Metric: Program cohort default rate
Technical Protocol: The pCDR percentage is calculated by dividing the number of borrowers in the cohort who defaulted on their loans by the number of borrowers in the cohort.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies to assure disclosure of key performance statistics to prospective students in advance of collecting any fees and discussion of outcomes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the scope, format, and mechanisms for disclosing key performance statistics to prospective students in advance of collecting any fees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Key performance statistics are defined as performance metrics that are legally required to be disclosed to prospective students, such as may be required under the U.S. Gainful Employment Rule and the U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A prospective student is defined as someone who is considering attending a school, but is not yet enrolled.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies to assure disclosure of key performance statistics to prospective students in advance of collecting any fees and discussion of outcomes
Technical Protocol: Examples of relevant policies and practices include, but are not limited to, those relating to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Where information is made publicly available and how it is broadly disseminated, such as through inclusion of the key performance statistics on the entity’s website or in promotional materials.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: How information is communicated, such as by requiring disclosure in certain direct interactions with prospective students (e.g., requirements that recruiters and admissions staff disclose key performance statistics during student interviews).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Assuring the sufficiency of disclosures, such as through signed acknowledgements by prospective students indicating receipt and understanding of the key performance statistics.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies to assure disclosure of key performance statistics to prospective students in advance of collecting any fees and discussion of outcomes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss outcomes and impacts of these disclosure policies and practices, such as direct impacts on enrollment and U.S. Title IV eligibility and indirect impacts on tuition prices and offerings.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with advertising, marketing, and mandatory disclosures
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with violations of advertising, marketing, and other mandatory disclosure requirements.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with advertising, marketing, and mandatory disclosures
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with advertising, marketing, and mandatory disclosures
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with advertising, marketing, and mandatory disclosures
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with advertising, marketing, and mandatory disclosures
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Australian Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.K. Higher Education and Research Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Gainful Employment Rule
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Student Right-to-Know and Campus Security Act

Accounting Metric: (1) Instruction and student services expenses and (2) marketing and recruiting expenses
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its instruction and student services expenses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Instruction and student services expenses are all expenses that directly support educational quality or provide related services to current students, including:

Accounting Metric: (1) Instruction and student services expenses and (2) marketing and recruiting expenses
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its marketing and recruiting expenses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Marketing and recruiting expenses include recruiting (e.g., recruiter salaries) and marketing and advertising expenses (e.g., advertising expenses, compensation for marketing personnel, production of marketing materials, and activities for brand promotion purposes).

Accounting Metric: Revenue from: (1) Title IV funding, (2) GI Bill funding, and (3) private student loans
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its revenue from (1) Title IV funding, (2) GI Bill funding, and (3) private student loans.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Title IV funding is defined as money borrowed directly from the U.S. Department of Education to help cover the cost of higher education at a participating postsecondary institution under Title IV of the U.S. Higher Education Act. Funds include loans, grants, and work-study programs that are provided by the federal government to eligible borrowers through participating schools.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GI Bill funding is defined as any U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs education benefit earned by members of Active Duty, Selected Reserve and National Guard Armed Forces and their families, including but not limited to funding through the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the Montgomery GI Bill, the Reserve Educational Assistance Program (REAP), and the Veterans Educational Assistance Program (VEAP).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Private student loans (PSLs) are defined as any loans made for postsecondary education that are not Title IV or GI Bill funding, as defined above. As described by the U.S. Department of Education, PSLs are made by such lenders as banks, credit unions, state agencies, or schools. PSLs exclude 12-month payment plans that do not charge interest on short-term balances.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data, including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was withdrawn from all sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water sources include surface water (including water from wetlands, rivers, lakes, and oceans), groundwater, rainwater collected directly and stored by the entity, and water and wastewater obtained from municipal water supplies, water utilities, or other entities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose portions of its supply by source if, for example, significant portions of withdrawals are from non-freshwater sources.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fresh water may be defined according to the local laws and regulations where the entity operates. Where there is no legal definition, fresh water shall be considered to be water that has less than 1,000 parts per million of dissolved solids per the U.S. Geological Survey.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Water obtained from a water utility in compliance with U.S. National Primary Drinking Water Regulations can be assumed to meet the definition of fresh water.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of water, in thousands of cubic meters, that was consumed in its operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Water consumption is defined as:

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall analyze all of its operations for water risks and identify activities that withdraw and consume water in locations with High (40–80 percent) or Extremely High (>80 percent) Baseline Water Stress as classified by the World Resources Institute’s (WRI) Water Risk Atlas tool, Aqueduct.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water withdrawn in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water withdrawn.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total water withdrawn, (2) total water consumed, percentage of each in regions with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its water consumed in locations with High or Extremely High Baseline Water Stress as a percentage of the total water consumed.

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in or near areas of protected conservation status or endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of lodging facilities operated, owned, leased, or franchised in sites with protected conservation status, or areas of endangered species habitat.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Lodging facilities are considered to be located in areas of protected conservation status if they are located within:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Biosphere Reserves recognized within the framework of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's (UNESCO) Man and Biosphere (MAB) Programme
• International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Protected Areas (categories I-VI)
• Natura 2000 sites
• Ramsar Wetlands of International Importance
• Sites that meet the IUCN’s definition of a protected area: “A protected area is a clearly defined geographical space, recognized, dedicated, and managed through legal or other effective means to achieve the long term conservation of nature with associated ecosystem services and cultural values."
• UNESCO World Heritage Sites
TP_BP1_Sub Footnote: N. Dudley, (ed.), Guidelines for Applying Protected Areas Management Categories (Gland, Switzerland: IUCN, 2008), pp. 8-9.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: These sites may be listed in the World Database of Protected Areas (WDPA) and mapped on Protected Planet.

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in or near areas of protected conservation status or endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: Lodging facilities are considered to be located in or near endangered species habitat if they are in or near areas where species on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species that are classified as Critically Endangered (CR) or Endangered (EN) are extant.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A species is considered extant in an area if it is a resident, present during breeding or non-breeding seasons, or if it makes use of the area for passage.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For the purposes of this disclosure, “near” is defined as within five kilometers (km) of the boundary of an area of protected conservation status or an endangered species habitat.

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in or near areas of protected conservation status or endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately identify properties in areas with additional ecological, biodiversity, or conservation designations such as those listed by the A-Z Guide of Areas of Biodiversity Importance prepared by the United Nations Environment Programme’s World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC).

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in or near areas of protected conservation status or endangered species habitat
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide discussion around lodging facilities that are located in protected areas or endangered species habitat but that present low risk to biodiversity or ecosystem services. The entity may provide similar discussion for lodging facilities located in areas with no official designation of high biodiversity value but that present high biodiversity or ecosystem services risks.

Accounting Metric: Description of environmental management policies and practices to preserve ecosystem services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its environmental management policies and practices relating to preservation of ecosystem services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ecosystem service is defined as a service people obtain from the environment, based on the transformation of natural assets (soil, plants, animals, air, and water) into things that are directly valued. Ecosystem services can be viewed as (a) provisioning, which refers to use for resources such as food and water; (b) regulating, which refers to uses such as flood and disease control; (c) cultural, which refers to uses that are spiritual, recreational, or provide cultural benefits; or (d) supporting, which refers to those systems that maintain the conditions for life on Earth. This definition is derived from the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Commission on Ecosystem Management.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes, where relevant:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Lifecycle stages to which the policies and practices apply, such as: design, construction, commissioning, operation, decommissioning, closure, or, where applicable, post-closure.
• The topics addressed by the policies and practices, including: (a) policies to reduce impacts on the ecosystems, such as ecological and biodiversity impacts, waste generation, noise impacts, emissions to air, discharges to water, natural resource consumption, and tourism impacts; and (b) adaptation measures to minimize impact from changes in ecosystem services as may occur with climate change or other external pressures, such as changes in legal protections for sensitive areas or limitations on resource consumption.
• The underlying references for its policies and practices, including whether they are codes, guidelines, standards, or regulations and whether they were developed by the entity, an industry organization, a third-party organization (e.g., a non-governmental organization), a governmental agency, or some combination of these groups.

Accounting Metric: Description of environmental management policies and practices to preserve ecosystem services
Technical Protocol: For locations in areas of protected conservation status and/or areas of critical habitat, the entity shall discuss specific policies and practices that apply.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Areas of protected conservation status and/or areas of critical habitat are defined as areas of high biodiversity value, including (a) habitat of significant importance to Critically Endangered and/or Endangered species; (b) habitat of significant importance to endemic and/or restricted-range species; (c) habitat supporting globally significant concentrations of migratory species and/or congregatory species; (d) highly threatened and/or unique ecosystems; and/or (e) areas associated with key evolutionary processes. This definition is derived from the International Finance Corporation’s (IFC) Performance Standard 6.

Accounting Metric: Description of environmental management policies and practices to preserve ecosystem services
Technical Protocol: If the environmental management policies and practices do not apply to all of the entity’s sites or operations, the entity shall indicate the percentage of sites to which they are applied.

Accounting Metric: Description of environmental management policies and practices to preserve ecosystem services
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the degree to which its environmental management policies and practices are aligned with the IFC's Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability, specifically including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Performance Standard 1—Assessment and Management of Environmental and Social Risks and Impacts
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Performance Standard 3—Resource Efficiency and Pollution Prevention
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Performance Standard 6—Biodiversity Conservation and Sustainable Management of Living Natural Resources

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for lodging facility employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose employee turnover for lodging facility employees as a percentage.

Accounting Metric: (1) Voluntary and (2) involuntary turnover rate for lodging facility employees
Technical Protocol: Turnover shall be calculated and disclosed separately for (1) voluntary and (2) involuntary departures.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The (1) voluntary turnover rate shall be calculated as the number of employee-initiated separations (such as resignation or retirement) during the reporting period, divided by the total number of employees during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The (2) involuntary turnover rate shall be calculated as the number of entity-initiated separations (such as dismissal, downsizing, redundancy, or non-renewal of contract) during the reporting period, divided by the total number of employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations, such as those relating to wages, work hours, overtime, and meal and rest breaks.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise, in which the entity was involved.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.S. Department of Labor (DOL)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.K. Health and Safety Executive (HSE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: People’s Republic of China Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS)

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the average hourly wage for lodging facility employees for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Lodging facility employees are defined as non-manager employees earning an hourly wage.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The average hourly wage shall be calculated as the total wages, including tips, earned by lodging facility employees during the reporting period, divided by the number of hours worked by lodging facility employees during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage before tips for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Minimum wage is defined as the local or prevailing minimum wage applicable for each worker.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage divided by the total number of lodging facility employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: For countries or regions with no prevailing minimum wage requirement, the 10th percentile hourly wage of all wage earners in that country or region shall be used.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes employees of company-owned and franchise locations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes salaried and corporate employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the average minimum wage, weighted on an hours-worked basis, that applies to the entity's lodging facility employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Average hourly wage and (2) percentage of lodging facility employees earning minimum wage, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its sensitivity to future adjustments in the minimum wage, including what percentage of its employees would be affected by an increase in applicable minimum wage requirements.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and programs to prevent worker harassment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and programs for detecting and preventing worker harassment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Worker harassment is defined as employment discrimination that creates a work environment that a reasonable person would consider intimidating, hostile, or abusive.
TP_BP1 Footnote: Definition adapted from the U.S. Equal Opportunity Commission (EEOC)’s guidance on harassment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant policies to describe include, but are not limited to, those related to reporting channels and whistleblower protections.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Relevant programs to describe include, but are not limited to, employee training, use of panic buttons or other technology, maintaining lists of guests accused of harassing employees, investigations and audits, and partnerships and agreements with labor unions and employee representatives.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and programs to prevent worker harassment
Technical Protocol: The description shall include how policies and programs apply to business partners, such as franchisees and joint venture partners.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and programs to prevent worker harassment
Technical Protocol: The description shall include outcomes and impacts of these policies and practices, such as those related to worker efficiency and retention and indirect impacts on brand reputation and revenue.

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in 100-year flood zones
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of its lodging facilities that are located in 100-year flood zones.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: 100-year flood zones are defined as land areas subject to a one-percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. Such areas may also be referred to as being subject to the one-percent annual chance flood, the one-percent annual exceedance probability flood, or the 100-year flood.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Examples of 100-year flood zones may include, but are not limited to, coastal flood plains, flood plains along major rivers, and areas subject to flooding from ponding in low-lying areas.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For lodging facilities located in the U.S., 100-year flood zones shall include those land areas designated by the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) as special flood hazard areas (SFHA).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • SFHAs are defined as land area in the flood plain subject to a one-percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. The area may be designated in the applicable flood insurance rate map, as per the U.S. National Flood Insurance Program, as Zones A, AO, AH, A1-30, AE, A99, AR, AR/A1-30, AR/AE, AR/AO, AR/AH, AR/A, VO, V1-30, VE, and V. This definition is derived from U.S. 44 CFR 59.1.

Accounting Metric: Number of lodging facilities located in 100-year flood zones
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include all of the entity’s lodging facilities that are located in 100-year flood zones, regardless of the country of their location.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Fatality rate and (2) injury rate for customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its customer fatality rate.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Fatality shall exclude death by natural causes.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fatality rate and (2) injury rate for customers
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its customer injury rate.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Injury is defined as harm to people requiring professional medical treatment beyond first aid, consistent with the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration guidance in OSHA Form 300.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fatality rate and (2) injury rate for customers
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes fatalities and injuries that were sustained by customers when entering, exiting, riding, or otherwise interacting with any of the entity’s leisure facilities and features therein.

Accounting Metric: (1) Fatality rate and (2) injury rate for customers
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: statistic count / million customers.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of facilities inspected for safety, percentage of facilities that failed inspection
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of facilities that were inspected for facility safety by a relevant regulatory oversight authority during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Facility safety inspections are defined as those relating to the physical condition and appropriate design of buildings and structures with respect to sufficiency of entry or exit areas, capacity of space consistent with use, and adequacy of sprinkler systems and other fire suppression equipment, among other aspects related to the safety of the facility.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of facility safety includes the safe and proper functioning of any features contained within facilities, such as rides, ski lifts, or monorails, in accordance with applicable standards and with respect to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Design and Manufacture
• Testing
• Operation
• Maintenance
• Inspection
• Quality Assurance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Applicable standards may vary by facility type. Examples of amusement park standards for mechanical safety include the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission and National Safety Council park safety standards set forth by ASTM International (e.g., ASTM F24 Standards), as well as local building code standards for permanent rides. Examples of standards for ski lift safety include the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) B77 and the Canadian Z98 standards. For monorails, the International Monorail Association recommends the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) standards for Automated People Movers (APM).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Relevant regulatory oversight authorities include, but are not limited to, federal agencies, state agencies (e.g., a state tramway board), or local agencies (e.g., local fire and building departments).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of facilities inspected for safety, percentage of facilities that failed inspection
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of facilities that were inspected for facility safety that failed safety inspections.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A safety inspection is considered “passing” if no restrictions were placed on the entity’s operations and no follow-up inspections were required following the initial inspection. A safety inspection that does not meet these criteria is considered “failing.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the total number of facilities that failed a safety inspection divided by the total number of facilities that were inspected for safety.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of facilities inspected for safety, percentage of facilities that failed inspection
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes any facilities owned or operated by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of facilities inspected for safety, percentage of facilities that failed inspection
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe its approach to assuring facility safety within its operations in regions where inspections are not routinely conducted.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for work-related near misses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A near miss is defined as an unplanned incident in which no property or environmental damage or personal injury occurred, but where damage or personal injury easily could have occurred but for a slight circumstantial shift.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. National Safety Council (NSC) provides additional guidance on implementing near miss reporting, including in, “Near Miss Reporting Systems.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting near misses.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rates by each of the following employee categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Seasonal employees, defined as those individuals employed on a seasonal or other temporary basis with a known limited contract and employment end date.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Permanent employees, defined as all other employees not meeting the criteria for seasonal employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for (a) permanent employees and (b) seasonal employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose gender representation for all employees and racial/ethnic group representation for its U.S. employees by employee category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The following employee categories shall be used: (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: Gender and racial/ethnic group representation shall be disclosed in percentages, where the percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in each gender or racial/ethnic group in each employee category divided by the total number of employees in the respective employee category.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet, where each employee category for disclosure is defined by corresponding job categories and descriptions in the Instruction Booklet:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Executives includes the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Executives/Senior Level Officials and Managers: individuals who plan, direct and formulate policies, set strategy and provide the overall direction of enterprises/organizations for the development and delivery of products or services, within the parameters approved by boards of directors or other governing bodies. Residing in the highest levels of organizations, these executives plan, direct or coordinate activities with the support of subordinate executives and staff managers. They include, in larger organizations, those individuals within two reporting levels of the CEO, whose responsibilities require frequent interaction with the CEO. Examples of these kinds of managers are: chief executive officers, chief operating officers, chief financial officers, line of business heads, presidents or executive vice presidents of functional areas or operating groups, chief information officers, chief human resources officers, chief marketing officers, chief legal officers, management directors and managing partners.
• Non-executive management includes First/Mid Level Officials and Managers: individuals who serve as managers, other than those who serve as Executive/Senior Level Officials and Managers, including those who oversee and direct the delivery of products, services or functions at group, regional or divisional levels of organizations. These managers receive directions from the Executive/Senior Level management and typically lead major business units. They implement policies, programs and directives of executive/senior management through subordinate managers and within the parameters set by Executive/Senior Level management. Examples of these kinds of managers are: vice presidents and directors, group, regional or divisional controllers; treasurers; human resources, information systems, marketing, and operations managers. The First/Mid Level Officials and Managers subcategory also includes those who report directly to middle managers. These individuals serve at functional, line of business segment or branch levels and are responsible for directing and executing the day-to-day operational objectives of enterprises/organizations, conveying the directions of higher level officials and managers to subordinate personnel and, in some instances, directly supervising the activities of exempt and non-exempt personnel. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Professionals is defined as the following: most jobs in this category require bachelor and graduate degrees, and/or professional certification. In some instances, comparable experience may establish a person’s qualifications. The EEO-1 Job Classification Guide provides examples of job titles in this category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: All other employees includes those employees who are not classified as management or professionals.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For non-U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in a manner generally consistent with the definitions provided above, though in accordance with, and further facilitated by, any applicable local regulations, guidance, or generally accepted definitions.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the gender of its employees as female, male, or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall categorize the racial/ethnic group of its U.S. employees in accordance with the EEO-1 Survey Instruction Booklet and use the following categories: Asian, Black or African American, Hispanic or Latino, White, Other (which includes Native American or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, and “Two or More Races” classifications), or not disclosed/available.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental disclosures on gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by country or region.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide supplemental contextual disclosures on factors that significantly influence gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation, such as the country or region where employees are located.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) management, (2) professionals, and (3) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose gender and/or racial/ethnic group representation by employee category in the following table formats:

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and procedures to ensuring pluralism in news media content
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its policies and procedures to ensure pluralism of news media content, where pluralism includes having a range of racial, ethnic, linguistic, gender, political, cultural, ideological, and other forms of diversity within the entity’s news media content
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For the purposes of this disclosure the concept of pluralism shall not include “external pluralism” or the size, degree of consolidation, and/or influence of the entity within the larger media system.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and procedures to ensuring pluralism in news media content
Technical Protocol: Relevant policies and procedures include, but are not limited to, those relating to hiring of news and other staff (both on-air and off-air); maintaining transparency of ownership structures, selection criteria for experts, pundits, and others who appear in media to offer insight, opinions, and perspectives on news events and political discourse; codes of ethics that commit to independence of editorial content and respect for freedom of expression; and review boards that assure adherence to these policies.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and procedures to ensuring pluralism in news media content
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the scope of these policies and procedures, the mechanisms and oversight used to ensure their implementation, and how performance against the criteria is measured or evaluated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Examples of how performance is measured or evaluated may include, but are not limited to, documentation of changes to produced or distributed content that demonstrated improved pluralism, measures of performance relative to stated targets, or discussion of compliance in jurisdictions where pluralism of media is subject to regulation.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with libel or slander
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with libel or slander.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Libel and slander are defined per the legal or regulatory framework(s) applicable within the jurisdiction(s) where the incident occurred.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• For the purposes of determining whether a given incident constitutes libel, the entity may refer to the Legal Information Institute (LII), which defines libel as a method of defamation expressed by print, writing, pictures, signs, effigies, or any communication embodied in physical form that is injurious to a person's reputation, exposes a person to public hatred, contempt or ridicule, or injures a person in his/her business or profession.
• For the purposes of determining whether a given incident constitutes slander, the entity may refer to the LII, which defines slander as a false statement, usually made orally, which defames another person.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with libel or slander
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with libel or slander
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with libel or slander
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from embedded advertising
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its revenue from embedded advertising.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Embedded advertising is defined, consistent with the U.S. Federal Communications Commission’s Sponsorship Identification Rules and Embedded Advertising as the inclusion of sponsored brands into entertainment and editorial media content, including product placement, product integration, and sponsored content. Product placement is defined as the insertion of branded products into programming in exchange for fees or other consideration, and includes the placement of a visual or aural reference to a commercial product, brand, or service in media content as a prop.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Product integration is defined as the prominent positioning of a commercial product, brand, or service into media content.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Sponsored content is defined as advertisements that are designed to blend in with regular editorial content.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from embedded advertising
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the degree to which its policies and practices address similar issues to those outlined in the U.S. Federal Trade Commission's Enforcement Policy Statement on Deceptively Formatted Advertisements.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach for ensuring journalistic integrity of news programming related to: (1) truthfulness, accuracy, objectivity, fairness, and accountability, (2) independence of content and/or transparency of potential bias, and (3) protection of privacy and limitation of harm
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include all news programming produced or distributed by the entity (e.g., international, national, and regional news as well as political news, financial news, and entertainment news) across all forms of produced media (e.g., television, radio, and internet).

Accounting Metric: Description of approach for ensuring journalistic integrity of news programming related to: (1) truthfulness, accuracy, objectivity, fairness, and accountability, (2) independence of content and/or transparency of potential bias, and (3) protection of privacy and limitation of harm
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to ensuring the journalistic principles of truthfulness, accuracy, objectivity, fairness, and accountability, including policies to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Assure that copyright protection is maintained across all the entity's produced media, such that all disseminated content acknowledges and respects the intellectual property rights of all authors
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Mitigate and disclose potential conflicts of interest
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Address corruption and any related codes of conduct

Accounting Metric: Description of approach for ensuring journalistic integrity of news programming related to: (1) truthfulness, accuracy, objectivity, fairness, and accountability, (2) independence of content and/or transparency of potential bias, and (3) protection of privacy and limitation of harm
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to ensuring the journalistic principles of independence of content and/or transparency of potential bias, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Disclosure and transparency around sponsorship identification, paid product placement, and political advertising as well as the concentration of media ownership, among other topics
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Policies and processes to maintain editorial independence from the influence of government, business, or interest groups
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Transparent discussion of potential bias where such potential bias may exist
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Approach to receiving benefits, including inducement, charging for coverage, and, in the case of journalists, paying sources illicitly for news content

Accounting Metric: Description of approach for ensuring journalistic integrity of news programming related to: (1) truthfulness, accuracy, objectivity, fairness, and accountability, (2) independence of content and/or transparency of potential bias, and (3) protection of privacy and limitation of harm
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to ensuring the journalistic principles of protection of privacy and limitation of harm, including:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Privacy of people (especially children) who may appear or are referenced in content
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Privacy in gathering content and undertaking business activities (e.g., maintaining the confidentiality of sources, protecting sources’ privacy when taken to court, and avoiding violation of privacy during news gathering)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Privacy in agreements for information provided by sources (e.g., on-the-record, off-record, Chatham House Rule, or embargos)

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to ensuring intellectual property (IP) protection
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to the protection of its intellectual property (IP).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes legal and non-compliance-based approaches to IP protection.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of legal approaches to IP protection include, but are not limited to, reliance on patent, copyright, trademark, and trade secret laws and licenses as well as other agreements with employees, customers, suppliers, and other parties to establish and maintain a company’s intellectual property rights in content, technology, and products and services used to conduct businesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Examples of non-compliance-based approaches to IP protection include, but are not limited to, Digital Rights Management (DRM) systems, licensing agreements with entities that may otherwise pirate materials, adjusted pricing structures in markets with less stringent IP protection, and developing new technologies that encourage legitimate media purchases to be favored over pirated materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to ensuring intellectual property (IP) protection
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the risks and opportunities associated with technological developments that (1) enable media delivery without a subscription or direct purchase, and that (2) satisfy the requirement under copyright law that the transmissions be private performances (e.g., consumer-owned antennas that capture signals for private use).

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems that pose a data security risk.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, and/or implementation that could be exploited.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Data security risk is defined as any circumstance or event with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, or reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, or nations through an information system via unauthorized access, destruction, disclosure, modification of information, and/or denial of service.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities it has identified, including, but not limited to, operational procedures, management processes, structure of products, selection of business partners, employee training, and use of technology.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe the degree to which its approach is aligned with an external standard or framework and/or legal or regulatory framework for managing data security, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ISO/IEC 27001:2013—Information technology—Security techniques—Information security management systems—Requirements
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Framework for Improving Critical Infrastructure Cybersecurity, Version 1.1, April 16, 2018, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC’s Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity’s approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity’s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of customer information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the nature, scope, and implementation of its policies and practices related to customer privacy, with a specific focus on how it addresses the collection, usage, and retention of customer information, including demographic data, confidential business information (CBI), and personally identifiable information (PII).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Customer information includes information that pertains to a customer’s attributes or actions, including, but not limited to, records of communications, content of communications, demographic data, personally identifiable information, or confidential business information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Demographic data are defined as the quantifiable statistics that identify and distinguish a given population. Examples of demographic data include gender, age, ethnicity, knowledge of languages, disabilities, mobility, home ownership, and employment status.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: CBI is defined as information that concerns or relates to the trade secrets, processes, operations, identification of customers, inventories, or other information of commercial value, the disclosure of which is likely to cause substantial harm to the competitive position of the person, firm, partnership, or corporation from which the information was obtained. This definition is derived from U.S. 19 CFR 201.6.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • The term “confidential business information” includes “proprietary information” within the meaning of section 777(b) of the U.S. Tariff Act of 1930 ( 19 U.S.C. 1677f (b) ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office’s Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of customer information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the information “lifecycle” (i.e., collection, use, retention, processing, disclosure, and destruction of information) and how information-handling practices at each stage may affect individuals’ privacy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: With respect to data collection, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data are collected without the consent of an individual, which require opt-in consent, and which require opt-out action from the individual.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: With respect to data usage, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data are used by the entity internally, and under which circumstances the entity shares, sells, rents, or otherwise distributes data or information to third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: With respect to data retention, it may be relevant for the entity to discuss which data or types of data it retains, the length of time of retention, and what practices are used to ensure that data are stored securely.

Accounting Metric: Description of policies and practices relating to collection, usage, and retention of customer information
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe the degree to which its policies and practices address similar issues as outlined in the U.S. OMB Guidance for Implementing the Privacy Provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002 (M-03-22), including use of Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A PIA is an analysis of how information is handled that ensures handling conforms to applicable legal, regulatory, and policy requirements regarding privacy; determines the risks and effects of collecting, maintaining, and disseminating information in identifiable form in an electronic information system; and examines and evaluates protections and alternative processes for handling information in order to mitigate potential privacy risks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: As outlined by OMB M-03-22, PIAs must analyze and describe: (a) what information is to be collected; (b) why the information is being collected; (c) the intended use of the information; (d) with whom the information will be shared; (e) what opportunities individuals have to decline to provide information (i.e., where providing information is voluntary) or to consent to particular uses of the information (other than required or authorized uses), including how individuals can grant consent; and (f) how the information will be secured, among other government-specific requirements.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving customers' confidential business information (CBI) or personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall calculate and disclose (1) the total number of data breaches identified during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Data breach is defined as the unauthorized movement or disclosure of sensitive information to a party, usually outside the organization, that is not authorized to have or see the information This definition is derived from the U.S. National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) glossary.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to data breaches that resulted in a deviation from the entity's expected outcomes for confidentiality and/or integrity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving customers' confidential business information (CBI) or personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of data breaches in which confidential business information (CBI) or personally identifiable information (PII) was subject to the data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: CBI is defined as information that concerns or relates to the trade secrets, processes, operations, identification of customers, inventories, or other information of commercial value, the disclosure of which is likely to cause substantial harm to the competitive position of the person, firm, partnership, or corporation from which the information was obtained. This definition is derived from U.S. 19 CFR 201.6.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • CBI includes “proprietary information” within the meaning of section 777(b) of the U.S. Tariff Act of 1930 ( 19 U.S.C. 1677f (b) ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: PII is defined as any information about an individual that is maintained by an entity, including (1) any information that can be used to distinguish or trace an individual’s identity, such as name, Social Security Number (SSN), date and place of birth, mother’s maiden name, or biometric records; and (2) any other information that is linked or linkable to an individual, such as medical, educational, financial, and employment information. This definition is derived from the U.S. Government Accountability Office's Report to Congressional Requesters, Alternatives Exist for Enhancing Protection of Personally Identifiable Information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure shall include incidents in which encrypted data were acquired with an encryption key that was also acquired, as well as if there is a reasonable belief that encrypted data could be readily converted to plaintext.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Encryption is defined as the process of transforming plaintext into ciphertext. This definition is derived from the NICCS glossary .
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure is limited to breaches in which customers were notified of the breach, either as required by law or voluntarily by the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving customers' confidential business information (CBI) or personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the total number of unique customers who were affected by data breaches, which includes all those whose personal data was compromised in a data breach.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Accounts that the entity cannot verify as belonging to the same customer shall be disclosed separately.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of data breaches, (2) percentage involving customers' confidential business information (CBI) or personally identifiable information (PII), (3) number of customers affected
Technical Protocol: The entity may delay disclosure if a law enforcement agency has determined that notification impedes a criminal investigation or until the law enforcement agency determines that such notification does not compromise the investigation.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management and (2) all other employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose gender representation for all employees and racial/ethnic group representation for its U.S. employees by employee category.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The following employee categories shall be used: (1) executive management and (2) all other employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management and (2) all other employees
Technical Protocol: Gender and racial/ethnic group representation shall be disclosed in percentages, where the percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in each gender or racial/ethnic group in each employee category divided by the total number of employees in the respective employee category.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of gender and racial/ethnic group representation for (1) executive management and (2) all other employees
Technical Protocol: For U.S. employees, the entity shall categorize the employees in accordance with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission’s Employer Information EEO-1 report (EEO-1 Survey) Instruction Booklet, where each employee category for disclosure is defined by corresponding job categories and descriptions in the Instruction Booklet:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Executive management includes Executives/Senior Level Officials and Managers: individuals who plan, direct and formulate policies, set strategy and provide the overall direction of enterprises/organizations for the development and delivery of products or services, within the parameters approved by boards of directors or other governing bodies. Residing in the highest levels of organizations, these executives plan, direct or coordinate activities with the support of subordinate executives and staff managers. They include, in larger organizations, those individuals within two reporting levels of the CEO, whose responsibilities require frequent interaction with the CEO. Examples of these kinds of managers are: chief executive officers, chief operating officers, chief financial officers, line of business heads, presidents or executive vice presidents of functional areas or operating groups, chief information officers, chief human resources officers, chief marketing officers, chief legal officers, management directors and managing partners.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: All other employees includes those employees who are not classified as executive management.
