• Identification of the specific cybersecurity risk management standard (s) that have been implemented or are otherwise in use
• Description of the extent of its use of cybersecurity risk management standard (s), such as by applicable operations, business unit, geography, product, or information system
• The role of cybersecurity risk management standards in the entity’s overall approach to identifying vulnerabilities in its information systems and addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities
• If the third-party verification of the use of cybersecurity risk management standards is conducted, including independent examinations or audits
• Ongoing activities and initiatives related to increasing the use of cybersecurity risk management standards, even if such standards are not currently in use

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks, including use of third-party cybersecurity standards
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss trends it has observed in type, frequency, and origination of attacks to its data security and information systems.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks, including use of third-party cybersecurity standards
Technical Protocol: The U.S. SEC’s Commission Statement and Guidance on Public Company Cybersecurity Disclosures may provide further guidance on disclosures on the entity’s approach to addressing data security risks and vulnerabilities.

Accounting Metric: Description of approach to identifying and addressing data security risks, including use of third-party cybersecurity standards
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain data privacy and security.

Accounting Metric: (1) Materials recovered through take back programs, percentage of recovered materials that were (2) reused, (3) recycled, and (4) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the weight, in metric tons, of materials recovered through product take-back programs and recycling services.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure shall include products, materials, and parts that are at the end of their useful life and would have otherwise been disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery, but have instead been collected.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure shall include both materials physically handled by the entity and materials of which the entity does not take physical possession, but for which it has contracted with a third party the task of collection for the expressed purpose of reuse, recycling, or refurbishment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure excludes products and parts that are in-warranty and have been collected for repairs.

Accounting Metric: (1) Materials recovered through take back programs, percentage of recovered materials that were (2) reused, (3) recycled, and (4) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of materials recovered that were reused.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Reused materials are defined as those recovered products or components of products that are used, or are intended to be used in the future, by the entity or by a third-party for their originally intended purpose.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Percentage shall be calculated as the weight of the recovered materials that were reused divided by the total weight of all recovered materials.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of reused materials includes products donated and/or refurbished by the entity or third parties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure includes reuse by the entity or by third-parties through direct contract with the entity.

Accounting Metric: (1) Materials recovered through take back programs, percentage of recovered materials that were (2) reused, (3) recycled, and (4) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of materials recovered that were recycled or remanufactured.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Recycled and remanufactured materials are defined as materials that have been reprocessed or treated by means of a production or manufacturing process and made into a final product or made into a component for incorporation into a product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Percentage shall be calculated as the weight of the recovered materials that were recycled or remanufactured divided by the total weight of all recovered materials.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure includes recycling conducted by the entity or by third parties through direct contract with the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Portions of products and materials that are disposed of in landfills are not considered recycled; only the portions of products that are directly incorporated into new products, co-products, or by-products shall be included in the percentage recycled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Materials incinerated, including for energy recovery are not considered recycled.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration with or without other waste but with recovery of the heat.

Accounting Metric: (1) Materials recovered through take back programs, percentage of recovered materials that were (2) reused, (3) recycled, and (4) landfilled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (4) the percentage of materials recovered that were landfilled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Percentage shall be calculated as the weight of the recovered materials that were landfilled divided by the total weight of all recovered materials.

Accounting Metric: (1) Materials recovered through take back programs, percentage of recovered materials that were (2) reused, (3) recycled, and (4) landfilled
Technical Protocol: Electronic waste material (e-waste) shall be considered recycled only if the entity can demonstrate that this material was transferred to entities with third-party certification to a standard for e-waste recycling such as Basel Action Network’s e-Steward® standard or the U.S. EPA’s Responsible Recycling Practices (R2) standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall disclose the standard(s) to which the entities it has transferred e-waste are compliant.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior, including, but not limited to, price fixing, anti-trust behavior (e.g., exclusivity contracts), patent misuse, or network effects and bundling of services and products to limit competition.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Articles 101 to 109 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Japan’s Act on Prohibition of Private Monopolization and Maintenance of Fair Trade
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The U.S. Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The U.S. Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Japan Fair Trade Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Federal Trade Commission

Accounting Metric: Average actual sustained download speed of (1) owned and commercially-associated content and (2) non-associated content
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its average actual sustained download speed in Megabits per second (Mbps), for delivery of (1) owned and commercially-associated content and (2) non-associated content.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Actual sustained download speed is defined as throughput, in Mbps, utilizing three concurrent TCP connections measured at the 25-30 second interval of a sustained data transfer, consistent with the U.S. Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) Measuring Broadband America program.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The entity shall disclose its methodology for measuring download speed, such as the time period over which the test was conducted, sample size, whether it reflects peak versus non-peak speeds, whether the measurement isolates the effects of transient performance-enhancing features (e.g., throttling or “burst” speeds), and limits on accuracy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Owned and commercially-associated content is defined as content that is owned the by entity directly, such as content created through media-production business segments of the entity, its parent, or its subsidiaries, and content that is owned by companies with whom the entity has commercial agreements, such as pay-for-priority agreements or content delivery network peering agreements.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Non-associated content is defined as any content that is not owned by or commercially-associated with the entity, as described above.

Accounting Metric: Average actual sustained download speed of (1) owned and commercially-associated content and (2) non-associated content
Technical Protocol: The average actual sustained download speed is calculated as the sales-weighted aggregate of average actual sustained download speeds of each tier of service on a per-user account basis (i.e., weighted by number of user accounts in each tier of service, not actual usage).

Accounting Metric: Average actual sustained download speed of (1) owned and commercially-associated content and (2) non-associated content
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose its average advertised download speed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Average advertised download speed is defined as the download speed advertised for each user account based on the speed of the account type.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The average advertised speed is calculated as the average of monthly advertised download speeds on a sales-weighted user account basis (i.e., weighted by number of user accounts, not actual usage).

Accounting Metric: Description of risks and opportunities associated with net neutrality, paid peering, zero rating, and related practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe risks and opportunities associated with rules and regulations addressing net neutrality and open internet.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Net neutrality and open internet refers to principles that would prevent behavior that harms consumers or competition by limiting the openness of the Internet, as aligned with the U.S. Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) Title 47 – Telecommunications, Part 8 – Preserving the Open Internet.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Transparency: That all internet service providers (ISPs) must transparently disclose to their subscribers and users all relevant information as to the policies that govern their network.
• No Blocking: That no legal content may be blocked.
• No Unreasonable Discrimination: That ISPs may not act in a commercially unreasonable manner to harm the Internet, including favoring the traffic from an affiliated entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes, but is not limited to, the reclassification of ISPs as common carriers under Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, or the use of Section 706 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to regulate ISPs.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of risks includes, but is not limited to, potential limitations on an entity’s ability to deliver its own content, increased competition from edge providers that stream content, reputational harm with consumers, and/or possible restrictions on an entity’s ability to generate new revenue streams from peering and pay-for-priority agreements or earn capital needed to support a growing and evolving broadband infrastructure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of opportunities includes, but is not limited to, growth in delivery of owned and affiliated content, increased market penetration, and/or improved advertising revenues.

Accounting Metric: Description of risks and opportunities associated with net neutrality, paid peering, zero rating, and related practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its policies for engagement in paid peering agreements and settlement-free peering agreements.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Peering agreement is defined as an arrangement whereby one Internet operation connects directly to another so that the two can trade traffic.

Accounting Metric: Description of risks and opportunities associated with net neutrality, paid peering, zero rating, and related practices
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its policies for engagement in zero-rating.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Zero-rating is defined as an arrangement wherein customer data usage is not billed nor counted toward any customer data plan limit if they are accessing certain content affiliated with the mobile network operator or internet service provider.

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: (1) System average interruption frequency and (2) customer average interruption duration
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) system average interruption frequency as the average number of disruptions per customer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Average interruption frequency shall be calculated as the total number of customer interruptions divided by the total number of customers served.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The number of customer interruptions is the sum for all interruptions of the number of customer accounts that experienced an interruption in service during each incident (i.e., counting customer accounts multiple times if they experienced multiple service interruptions throughout the year).
• The number of customers served is the number of unique customer accounts with active service during the reporting period.

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: (1) System average interruption frequency and (2) customer average interruption duration
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) customer average interruption duration as the average number of hours per customer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Average interruption duration shall be calculated as the sum for all interruptions of the total downtime (in hours) of each interruption divided by the number of customer accounts affected by each interruption.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The number of customers served is the number of unique customer accounts with active service during the reporting period.

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: (1) System average interruption frequency and (2) customer average interruption duration
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is restricted to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Wireline communications services
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Wireless communications services
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Internet service provider (ISP) services

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: Discussion of systems to provide unimpeded service during service interruptions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss business continuity risks associated with technology disruptions affecting operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Examples of disruptions include, but are not limited to, those caused by technical failures, programming errors, cyber attacks, weather events, or natural disasters at hosting facilities. .

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: Discussion of systems to provide unimpeded service during service interruptions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss measures to address business continuity risks, including an identification of critical business operations and redundancies or other measures implemented to enhance resilience of the system or to reduce impact, including insurance against loss.

Disclosure Topic: Managing Systemic Risks from Technology Disruptions
Accounting Metric: Discussion of systems to provide unimpeded service during service interruptions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss estimated amount of potential loss, probability of that loss, and the associated timeframe. These estimates may be based on insurance figures or other third-party or internal assessments of potential loss.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant aviation-related activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, fuel optimization efforts such as the use of ground power and pre-conditioned air rather than auxiliary power units (APU) when parked at gate, adjusting flight speed to optimize fuel efficiency, route design (e.g., NextGen), use of winglets, reduction in aircraft weight, and upgrading of the fleet with new aircraft.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Relevant road transportation-related activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, fuel optimization efforts such as route and load optimization, adoption of technology such as engine and powertrain efficiency and aerodynamic improvements, use of electric- or natural gas-powered vehicles, weight reduction, improved tire rolling resistance, hybridization, and automatic engine shutdown.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the amount of fuel consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ), broken down by (1) road transport-related operations, and separately, (2) air transport-related operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The calculation methodology for fuel consumed shall be based on actual fuel consumed as opposed to design parameters.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Acceptable calculation methodologies for fuel consumed include, but are not limited to, methodologies based on:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Adding fuel purchases made during the reporting period to beginning inventory at the start of the reporting period, less any fuel inventory at the end of the reporting period
• Tracking fuel consumed by vehicles
• Tracking fuel expenses

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: In disclosing fuel consumed by (1) road transport-related operations, the entity shall additionally disclose the percentage of fuel consumed that is (a) natural gas.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of fuel consumed by road transport-related operations that was natural gas (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed by road transport-related operations (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: In disclosing fuel consumed by (1) road transport-related operations, the entity shall additionally disclose the percentage of fuel consumed that is (b) renewable fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable fuel is defined by the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard (U.S. 40 CFR 80.1401), as fuel that meets all of the following requirements:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of renewable fuel includes fuel that qualifies for Renewable Identification Numbers (RINs) under the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of renewable fuel consumed by road transport-related operations (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed by road transport-related operations (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: In disclosing fuel consumed by (2) air transport-related operations, the entity shall additionally disclose the percentage of fuel consumed that is (a) alternative fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Alternative fuel is defined by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) as fuel from sources other than petroleum that has the potential to generate lower carbon emissions than petroleum-based fuel on a life cycle basis.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of alternative fuel consumed by air transport-related operations (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed by air transport-related operations (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: In disclosing fuel consumed by (2) air transport-related operations, the entity shall additionally disclose the percentage of fuel consumed that was (b) sustainable fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Sustainable fuel is defined as a subset of alternative fuel that meets all of the following criteria described by ICAO:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of sustainable fuel consumed by air transport-related operations (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed by air transport-related operations (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to fuel directly consumed by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: In calculating energy consumption from fuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the U.S. Department of Energy, or the U.S. Energy Information Agency.

Accounting Metric: Fuel consumed by (1) road transport, percentage (a) natural gas and (b) renewable, and (2) air transport, percentage (a) alternative and (b) sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels).

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOx), reported as NOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOx includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) oxides of sulfur (SOx), reported as SOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of SOx includes SO2 and SO3.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (3) particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter (PM10), reported as PM10.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PM10 is defined, according to U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, as any airborne finely divided solid or liquid material with an aerodynamic diameter less than or equal to a nominal 10 micrometers.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of drivers classified as independent contractors
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its drivers that are classified by the entity as independent contractors.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Independent contractors shall be defined using a methodology consistent with the U.S. Internal Revenue Service’s (IRS) ”20 Factor test,” or an applicable equivalent methodology.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• For a methodology to be considered equivalent, it is required to evaluate the level of control an entity has over a worker by considering facts with respect to behavioral factors, financial factors, and type of relationship.
• Examples of equivalent methodologies include, but are not limited to, the State of California Employment Development Department’s “ Employment Determination Guide ,” and the State of Michigan Talent Investment Agency’s “ Independent Contractor or Employee .”

Accounting Metric: Percentage of drivers classified as independent contractors
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the full-time equivalent (FTE) of drivers who are independent contractors divided by the FTE of total drivers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: FTE is defined as total hours reported divided by the maximum number of compensable hours in a full-time schedule.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: FTE of total drivers is defined as the sum of the FTE of drivers who are regular, direct drivers and the FTE of drivers who are third-party drivers.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Regular, direct drivers include all full-time and part-time employees whose status group in the human resources information system (HRIS) is “active” and includes active, paid leave, and unpaid leave employees.
• Third-party drivers include independent contractors, leased employees, temp (agency) workers, and consultants and outsourced workers (provided that the consultants or outsourced workers spend most of their time on the entity’s work).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations, such as those relating to wages, work hours, overtime, and meal and rest breaks.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise, in which the entity was involved.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: EU Regulation (EC) No 561/2006
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: People’s Republic of China Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security (MOHRSS)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Department of Labor (DOL)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.K. Health and Safety Executive (HSE)

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fatality rate for work-related fatalities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool.”

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the rates by each of the following employee categories:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Direct employees, defined as those employees on the entity’s payroll, whether they are full-time, part-time, executive, labor, salary, hourly, or seasonal employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Contract employees, defined as those who are not on the entity’s payroll, but who are supervised by the entity on a day-to-day basis, including independent contractors and those employed by third parties (e.g., temp agencies and labor brokers).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR) and (2) fatality rate for (a) direct employees and (b) contract employees
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of carriers with BASIC percentiles above the FMCSA intervention threshold
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of carriers the entity contracts with that have one or more U.S. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) Behavior Analysis and Safety Improvement Category (BASIC) percentiles over the Intervention Threshold.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of carriers the entity contracts with that have one or more BASIC percentiles over the Intervention Threshold divided by the total number of carriers the entity contracts with.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of carriers with BASIC percentiles above the FMCSA intervention threshold
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes carriers with which the entity has contracted for transportation services during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the complete tank-to-wheels greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint in metric tons of CO2-e per metric ton-kilometer.

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: Tank-to-wheels emissions relate to vehicle processes and exclude upstream emissions associated with primary energy production (i.e., well-to-tank emissions).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The entity shall calculate its disclosure according to EN 16258:2012, Methodology for calculation and declaration of energy consumption and GHG emissions of transport services (freight and passengers).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Calculations shall be consistent with the methodology used to calculate the “tank-to-wheels GHG emissions (Gt)” result that is described in EN 16258:2012.
• Determination of transportation system scope, boundaries, and any necessary allocations shall be consistent with the methodology described in EN 16258:2012.

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes emissions from all freight transportation and logistics activities, including those from the entity’s own assets (Scope 1) and those from contract carriers and outsourced freight forwarding services.

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes emissions from all modes of transportation, such as road freight, air freight, barge transport, marine transport, and rail transport.

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: Consistent with EN 16258:2012, disclosure may be based on calculations from a mix of categories of emissions values (i.e., specific measured values, transport operator vehicle-type- or route-type-specific values, transport operator fleet values, and default values).

Accounting Metric: Total greenhouse gas (GHG) footprint across transport modes
Technical Protocol: Where relevant and necessary for interpretation of disclosure, the entity shall describe its allocation methods, emissions values, boundaries, mix of transport services used, and other information.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its implementation of a Safety Management System (SMS) across its aviation operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An SMS is defined according to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in U.S. 14 CFR 5.5, and/or the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) in Safety Management Manual, Fourth edition, 2018, and at a minimum, includes:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Safety policy
• Safety risk management
• Safety assurance
• Safety promotion

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall specifically describe implementation of an SMS as it aligns with FAA and/or ICAO guidance, but may also focus broadly on processes and procedures to avoid and manage emergencies, accidents, and incidents that could have catastrophic impacts on human health, the local community, and the environment.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include a description of the SMS implementation level that the entity has achieved as well as the entity’s plan for achieving complete implementation within the ICAO-recommended period of five years.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: SMS implementation levels are:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Level 0: Orientation & Commitment
• Level 1: Planning & Organization
• Level 2: Reactive Processes
• Level 3: Proactive Processes
• Level 4: Continuous Improvement

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose whether the SMS has been audited by the International Air Transport Association’s (IATA) Operational Safety Audit (IOSA), and if so, the entity may describe relevant findings from the audit.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the outcomes of its SMS, including, the (a) number of safety risks and hazardous situations that it identified and (b) the percentage of safety risks and hazardous situations identified that it mitigated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks and hazardous situations are broadly defined as any existing or potential condition that could lead to an accident or incident.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe any actions or measures it has implemented to mitigate safety risks and hazardous situations identified, including, but not limited to, specific changes in controls, operations, management, processes, products, business partners, training, or technology.

Accounting Metric: Number of aviation accidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of aviation accidents.

Accounting Metric: Number of aviation accidents
Technical Protocol: An accident is defined according to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) in Annex 13 – Aircraft Accident and Investigation as an occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft that takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such persons have disembarked, in which conditions (a), (b), and/or (c) are met.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: (a) A person is fatally or seriously injured as a result of: being in the aircraft; direct contact with any part of the aircraft, including parts which have become detached from the aircraft; or direct exposure to jet blast.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Except when the injuries are from natural causes, self-inflicted or inflicted by other persons, or when the injuries are to stowaways hiding outside the areas normally available to the passengers and crew.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: (b) The aircraft sustains damage or structural failure which: adversely affects the structural strength, performance, or flight characteristics of the aircraft; and would normally require major repair or replacement of the affected component.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Except engine failure or damage when the damage is limited to the engine, its cowlings, or accessories, or for damage that is limited to propellers, wing tips, antennas, tires, brakes, fairings, small dents or puncture holes in the aircraft skin.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: (c) The aircraft is missing or is completely inaccessible.

Accounting Metric: Number of road accidents and incidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of road transport-related accidents and incidents.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An accident is defined, consistent with U.S. 49 CFR 390.5T, as an occurrence involving a commercial motor vehicle operating on a highway in interstate or intrastate commerce that results in:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• A fatality; or
• Bodily injury to a person who, as a result of the injury, immediately receives medical treatment away from the scene of the accident; or
• One or more motor vehicles incurring disabling damage as a result of the accident, requiring the motor vehicle (s) to be transported away from the scene by a tow truck or by other motor vehicle.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: An accident does not include:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• An occurrence involving only boarding and alighting from a stationary motor vehicle; or
• An occurrence involving only the loading or unloading of cargo.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: An incident is defined as any event involving a licensed motor vehicle while on business use that results in a recordable incident (as defined by the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration), vehicle damage, or other property damage.

Accounting Metric: Number of road accidents and incidents
Technical Protocol: At a minimum, the scope of disclosure includes accidents and incidents reported to the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board or to an equivalent national authority.

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentile score calculated by the U.S. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) Safety Measurement System (SMS) for the following Behavior Analysis and Safety Improvement Categories (BASICs):
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Unsafe Driving
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hours-of-Service (HOS) Compliance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Driver Fitness
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Controlled Substances/Alcohol
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Vehicle Maintenance
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Hazardous Materials (HM) Compliance

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its percentile in each BASIC for the month ending the most recent reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Safety Measurement System BASIC percentiles for: (1) Unsafe Driving, (2) Hours-of-Service Compliance, (3) Driver Fitness, (4) Controlled Substances/Alcohol, (5) Vehicle Maintenance, and (6) Hazardous Materials Compliance
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its percentile in relation to FMCSA’s Intervention Thresholds.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, fuel optimization efforts such as the use of ground power and pre-conditioned air rather than auxiliary power units (APU) when parked at gate, adjusting flight speed to optimize fuel efficiency, route design (e.g., NextGen), use of winglets, reduction in aircraft weight, and upgrading of the fleet with new aircraft.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total fuel consumed, (2) percentage alternative, (3) percentage sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of fuel consumed from all sources as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The calculation methodology for fuel consumed shall be based on actual fuel consumed as opposed to design parameters.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Acceptable calculation methodologies for fuel consumed include, but are not limited to, methodologies based on:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Adding fuel purchases made during the reporting period to beginning inventory at the start of the reporting period, less any fuel inventory at the end of the reporting period
• Tracking fuel consumed by vehicles
• Tracking fuel expenses

Accounting Metric: (1) Total fuel consumed, (2) percentage alternative, (3) percentage sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of fuel consumption that is alternative fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Alternative fuel is defined by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) as fuel from sources other than petroleum that has the potential to generate lower carbon emissions than petroleum-based fuel on a life cycle basis.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of alternative fuel consumed (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total fuel consumed, (2) percentage alternative, (3) percentage sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of fuel consumed that is sustainable fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Sustainable fuel is defined as a subset of alternative fuel that meets all of the following criteria described by ICAO:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of sustainable fuel consumed (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total fuel consumed, (2) percentage alternative, (3) percentage sustainable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to fuel directly consumed by the entity. In calculating energy consumption from fuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the U.S. Department of Energy, or the U.S. Energy Information Agency.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total fuel consumed, (2) percentage alternative, (3) percentage sustainable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels).

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its employees in the active workforce that were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Active workforce is defined as the maximum number of unique employees employed at any time during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Collective bargaining agreements are defined as a mechanism or tool of negotiation by which a union has a collective interest in negotiations to the benefit of several employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in the active workforce who were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period divided by the active workforce.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees employed by the entity, including full-time, part-time, and temporary employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide a breakdown of employees covered under collective bargaining agreements by employee position, such as pilots, flight attendants, or customer service representatives.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of work stoppages involving 1,000 or more workers lasting one full shift or longer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of work stoppages includes strikes and lockouts.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• A strike is defined as a temporary stoppage of work by a group of employees (not necessarily union members) to express a grievance or enforce a demand.
• A lockout is defined as a temporary withholding or denial of employment during a labor dispute to enforce terms of employment upon a group of employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total days idle as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Days idle is defined as the aggregate number of work days lost as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Total days idle shall be calculated as the sum of the products of the number of workers involved in each work stoppage and the number of days the respective work stoppage was in effect.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior, such as those related to enforcement of laws and regulations on price fixing, anti-trust behavior (e.g., exclusivity contracts), patent misuse, or network effects, as well as bundling of services and products to limit competition.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Articles 101 to 109 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Japan’s Act on Prohibition of Private Monopolization and Maintenance of Fair Trade
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: U.S. Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Japan Fair Trade Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Federal Trade Commission

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its implementation of a Safety Management System (SMS) across its aviation operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An SMS is defined according to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in U.S. 14 CFR 5.5, and/or the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) in Safety Management Manual, Fourth edition, 2018, and at a minimum, includes:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Safety policy
• Safety risk management
• Safety assurance
• Safety promotion

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall specifically describe implementation of an SMS as it aligns with FAA and/or ICAO guidance, but may also focus broadly on processes and procedures to avoid and manage emergencies, accidents, and incidents that could have catastrophic impacts on human health, the local community, and the environment.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: Disclosure shall include a description of the SMS implementation level that the entity has achieved as well as the entity’s plan for achieving complete implementation within the ICAO-recommended period of five years.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: SMS implementation levels are:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Level 0: Orientation & Commitment
• Level 1: Planning & Organization
• Level 2: Reactive Processes
• Level 3: Proactive Processes
• Level 4: Continuous Improvement

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose whether the SMS has been audited by the International Air Transport Association’s (IATA) Operational Safety Audit (IOSA), and if so, the entity may describe relevant findings from the audit.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the outcomes of its SMS, including, the (a) number of safety risks and hazardous situations that it identified and (b) the percentage of safety risks and hazardous situations identified that it mitigated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Risks and hazardous situations are broadly defined as any existing or potential condition that could lead to an accident or incident.

Accounting Metric: Description of implementation and outcomes of a Safety Management System
Technical Protocol: The entity may describe any actions or measures it has implemented to mitigate safety risks and hazardous situations identified, including, but not limited to, specific changes in controls, operations, management, processes, products, business partners, training, or technology.

Accounting Metric: Number of aviation accidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of aviation accidents.

Accounting Metric: Number of aviation accidents
Technical Protocol: An accident is defined according to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) in Annex 13 – Aircraft Accident and Investigation as an occurrence associated with the operation of an aircraft that takes place between the time any person boards the aircraft with the intention of flight until such time as all such persons have disembarked, in which conditions (a), (b), and/or (c) are met.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: (a) A person is fatally or seriously injured as a result of: being in the aircraft; direct contact with any part of the aircraft, including parts which have become detached from the aircraft; or direct exposure to jet blast.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Except when the injuries are from natural causes, self-inflicted or inflicted by other persons, or when the injuries are to stowaways hiding outside the areas normally available to the passengers and crew.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: (b) The aircraft sustains damage or structural failure which: adversely affects the structural strength, performance, or flight characteristics of the aircraft; and would normally require major repair or replacement of the affected component.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Except engine failure or damage when the damage is limited to the engine, its cowlings, or accessories, or for damage that is limited to propellers, wing tips, antennas, tires, brakes, fairings, small dents or puncture holes in the aircraft skin.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: (c) The aircraft is missing or is completely inaccessible.

Accounting Metric: Number of governmental enforcement actions of aviation safety regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of enforcement actions from the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), or the equivalent national authorities that are related to aviation safety regulations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosures includes, but is not limited to, maintenance, transportation of hazardous materials, drug testing, records and reports, training, and noise.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes the following enforcement actions: civil penalties, consent order, certificate suspension, and certificate revocation.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from grid electricity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as purchased grid electricity consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
