• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage grid electricity, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total amount of waste from manufacturing, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of waste generated, in metric tons, from its manufacturing operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Waste is defined as anything for which the entity has no further use and which is discarded or released to the environment.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total amount of waste from manufacturing, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of waste generated from manufacturing operations that is hazardous.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hazardous wastes are defined per the legal or regulatory framework(s) applicable within the jurisdiction(s) where the waste is generated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of hazardous waste generated from manufacturing operations, divided by the total weight of waste generated from manufacturing operations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total amount of waste from manufacturing, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of waste generated from manufacturing operations that was recycled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of waste generated from manufacturing operations that was recycled divided by the total weight of waste generated from manufacturing operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Recycled waste (including remanufactured waste) is defined as waste material that has been reprocessed or treated by means of production or manufacturing processes and made into a final product or a component for incorporation into a product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recycled waste includes material that was reused.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Reused material is defined as recovered products or components of products that are used for the same purpose for which they were conceived.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of recycled waste excludes portions of products and materials that are disposed of in landfills.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The scope of recycled waste excludes materials that were incinerated, including for energy recovery.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration, with or without other waste, but with recovery of the heat.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The scope of recycled material includes primary recycled material, co-products (outputs of equal value to primary recycled materials), by-products (outputs of lesser value to primary recycled materials), and material sent externally for further recycling.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total amount of waste from manufacturing, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity may use the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s Resources Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) or the EU Waste Framework Directive (Directive 2008/98/EC on waste, including its subsequent amendments), for the purposes of defining hazardous waste and/or recycled waste for operations located in jurisdictions that lack applicable legal or regulatory definitions.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total amount of waste from manufacturing, (2) percentage hazardous, (3) percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately disclose the percentage of waste generated that was incinerated.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of recalls issued, including voluntary recalls and involuntary recalls.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary recalls are recalls initiated by entity, but not mandated by a regulatory authority.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Involuntary recalls are those mandated by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) or by an equivalent regulatory authority or agency when (a) a motor vehicle or item of motor vehicle equipment does not comply with a governmental motor vehicle safety standard, or (b) when there is a safety-related defect in the vehicle or equipment.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of units that were subject to a recall.

Accounting Metric: Number of recalls issued, total units recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of recalls that were (1) voluntary and (2) involuntary.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products designed to increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total revenue from products that are designed to increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions during their use phase.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Products designed to increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions are defined as those that the entity has tested, modeled, or otherwise shown to improve fuel efficiency and/or eliminate or lower emissions of greenhouse gases (GHG), nitrogen oxide (NOx), particulate matter (PM), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other air pollutants during their use phase.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The use phase is defined as the course over which the product is used by a customer or consumer as a final product and/or to generate a final product (e.g., in a manufacturing or production process).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure includes products that impart an incremental improvement to fuel efficiency and/or emission reduction, insofar as the entity can demonstrate that the improvement is meaningful, such as through alignment with the milestones set forth in Section 5, “Key Sectors / Ensuring efficient mobility” of the European Commission‘s Road Map to a Resource Efficient Europe and/or with EU Directive 2012/27/EU (Energy Efficiency Directive).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure excludes products that offer improved fuel efficiency and/or reduced emissions in an ancillary or indirect way (e.g., a conventional product that is slightly lighter than the previous generation of the product).

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products designed to increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions
Technical Protocol: Examples of products that may increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions include, but are not limited to, those relating to: electrification of auxiliary systems such as oil and water pumps, waste heat recovery, improved aerodynamics, hybrid and advanced fuel technologies, improvements to combustion efficiency, idle reduction, alternative cooling systems, electric power steering, hybrid-enabled braking technologies, low rolling resistance (LRR) new and retread tire technologies, and engine management systems/products.

Accounting Metric: Revenue from products designed to increase fuel efficiency and/or reduce emissions
Technical Protocol: For products designed to both increase fuel efficiency and reduce emissions, the entity shall only account for the products’ revenue once.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to managing its risks associated with the use of critical materials in its products, including physical limits on availability and access, changes in price, and regulatory and reputational risks, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical material is defined as a material that is both essential in use and subject to the risk of supply restriction. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Research Council of the National Academies’ Minerals, Critical Minerals, and the U.S. Economy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of critical materials include, but are not limited to, the following as defined by the National Research Council:

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify the critical materials that present a significant risk to its operations, the type of risk(s) they represent, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate the risk(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant strategies may include diversification of suppliers, stockpiling of materials, development or procurement of alternative and substitute materials, and investments in recycling technology for critical materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity‘s ability to maintain confidential information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For example, if an entity determines not to identify a specific critical material that presents a significant risk to its operations due to competitive harm that could result from the disclosure, the entity shall disclose the existence of such risk(s), the type of risk(s), and the strategies used to mitigate the risk(s), but is not required to disclose the relevant critical material.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of products sold, by revenue, that are recyclable.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the revenue from products sold that are recyclable divided by the revenue from all products sold.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Material is recyclable if it can be reprocessed for the original purpose or for other purposes at a reasonable cost with technology widely available in the markets in which the products are sold.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Materials that are typically recyclable include ferrous and non-ferrous metals, glass, and certain plastics.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of recyclable material includes material that is reusable or able to be remanufactured.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Materials and components that are typically reusable or able to be remanufactured include engines, transmissions, catalysts, tires (including retreadable tires), batteries, and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recycled material includes scrap tires classified as non-hazardous secondary material and able to be collected via established tire collection programs, as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (CFR Title 40, Chapter I, Subchapter I, Part 241, Subpart A, Section 241.2).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of recyclable material excludes recoverable material (except where noted above), which consistent with the EU End of Life Vehicle Directive (Annex IIB to Directive 75/442/EEC), is defined as material that can be salvaged for further use, including for energy recovery.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration, with or without other waste, but with recovery of the heat.
• Materials that are typically disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery include fluids, hazardous materials, automotive shredder residue (including glass, foam, and fabric), automotive safety glass, and certain plastics.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of products sold that are recyclable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure is limited to products that are automotive parts, components, and materials.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of input materials from recycled or remanufactured content
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of input materials that are derived from recycled or remanufactured content.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of input materials includes all inputs that are processed to be sold as a finished good, including but not limited to, recycled, remanufactured, and virgin input materials.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of input materials from recycled or remanufactured content
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of input materials consumed that are derived from recycled or remanufactured content divided by the total weight of all input materials consumed.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Recycled content is defined, consistent with definitions in ISO 14021:2016, Environmental labels and declarations—Self-declared environmental claims (Type II environmental labelling), as the portion, by mass, of recycled or recovered material in a product or packaging.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Recycled material is defined as pre-consumer or post-consumer material that has been reprocessed from recovered (or reclaimed) material by means of a manufacturing process and made into a final product or a component for incorporation into a product.
• Pre-consumer material is defined as material that has been diverted from the waste stream during a manufacturing process. Excluded are materials such as rework, regrind, or scrap that is generated in a process and is capable of being reclaimed within the same process in which it was generated.
• Post-consumer material is defined as material generated by households or by commercial, industrial, and institutional facilities in their role as end-users of the product that can no longer be used for its intended purpose. This includes returns of material from the distribution chain.
• Recovered material is defined as material that would have otherwise been disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery, but has instead been collected and recovered (or reclaimed) as a material input, in lieu of new primary material, for a recycling or manufacturing process.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Remanufactured content is defined, consistent with definitions in U.S.16 CFR Part 20, as an end-of-life product or component (i.e., one that was previously sold, worn, or non-functional) that undergoes an industrial process to be returned to original working condition (i.e., is considered “like new”).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recycled or remanufactured content excludes virgin input material.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Virgin input material is defined as material that has never been processed into any form of end-use product.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of input materials from recycled or remanufactured content
Technical Protocol: The weight of input materials may be calculated using the amount of materials in inventory at the beginning of the reporting period, plus any purchase of materials made during the reporting period, less any materials in input materials inventory on hand at the end of the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations, such as those related to enforcement of laws and regulations on price fixing, anti-trust behavior (e.g., exclusivity contracts), patent misuse, or network effects, as well as bundling of services and products to limit competition.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Articles 101 to 109 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Japan’s Act on Prohibition of Private Monopolization and Maintenance of Fair Trade
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: U.S. Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Japan Fair Trade Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Federal Trade Commission

Accounting Metric: Percentage of vehicle models rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its vehicle models rated by an New Car Assessment Program (NCAP) with an overall 5-star safety rating, by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of vehicle models that are rated by an NCAP program with an overall 5-star rating divided by the total number of vehicle models that are rated by an NCAP program.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes existing vehicles and newly introduced vehicles that have received a rating by an NCAP program, including carry-over vehicles.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Carry-over vehicles are defined as vehicles that have been tested under an NCAP program in previous years and whose design has not changed (i.e., they retain their safety rating).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure excludes vehicles that do not have an applicable NCAP rating.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of vehicle models rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Geographic regions are defined as the regions for which the entity conducts segment financial reporting and which are subject to an NCAP, including, but not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Australia and New Zealand New Car Assessment Program (ANCAP)
• China New Car Assessment Program (C-NCAP)
• European New Car Assessment Programme (Euro NCAP)
• Japan New Car Assessment Program (JNCAP)
• Korean New Car Assessment Program (KNCAP)
• Latin New Car Assessment Program (Latin NCAP)
• The New Car Assessment Program for Southeast Asian Countries (ASEAN NCAP)
• U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s (NHTSA) New Car Assessment Program (NCAP) 5-Star Safety Ratings Program

Accounting Metric: Percentage of vehicle models rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: If a low number of the entity’s vehicle models are rated in a region (i.e., one or two), the entity may disclose this information in order to provide necessary context for the percentage.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of vehicle models rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its vehicles’ use of advanced crash avoidance technologies and features that are not considered as part of NCAP ratings.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Technologies and features include, but are not limited to, electronic stability control, lane departure warning, and forward collision warning.

Accounting Metric: Number of safety-related defect complaints, percentage investigated
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of safety-related defect complaints.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A safety-related defect, as defined by the U.S. Code for Motor Vehicle Safety (Title 49, Chapter 301), is a problem that exists in a motor vehicle or an item of motor vehicle equipment that (a) poses a risk to motor vehicle safety and (b) may exist in a group of vehicles of the same design or manufacture, or in an item of equipment of the same type and manufacture.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes safety-related defect complaints received by the entity, by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), or by another governmental or regulatory authority.

Accounting Metric: Number of safety-related defect complaints, percentage investigated
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of safety-related defect complaints that were investigated.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Investigated complaints include any complaint that was investigated by the NHTSA Office of Defects Investigation (ODI) or by another governmental or regulatory authority, including complaints in any of the following stages of the investigative process:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Screening, which is a preliminary review of consumer complaints and other information related to alleged defects to determine whether an investigation should be opened
• Petition Analysis, which is an analysis of any petitions calling for defect investigations and/or reviews of safety-related recalls
• Investigation, which is the investigation of alleged safety defects
• Recall Management, which is the investigation of the effectiveness of safety recalls
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of safety-related defect complaints that were investigated divided by the total number of safety-related defect complaints.

Accounting Metric: Number of vehicles recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of vehicles that were subject to a voluntary or involuntary recall.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary recalls are those initiated by the vehicle manufacturer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Involuntary recalls are those mandated by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) or by an equivalent regulatory authority or agency when (a) a motor vehicle or item of motor vehicle equipment does not comply with a governmental motor vehicle safety standard, or (b) when there is a safety-related defect in the vehicle or equipment.

Accounting Metric: Number of vehicles recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of recalls that were (1) voluntary and (2) involuntary.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its employees in the active workforce that were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Active workforce is defined as the maximum number of unique employees employed at any time during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Collective bargaining agreements are defined as a mechanism or tool of negotiation by which a union has a collective interest in negotiations to the benefit of several employees.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of employees in the active workforce who were covered under collective bargaining agreements during any part of the reporting period divided by the active workforce.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of active workforce covered under collective bargaining agreements
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees employed by the entity, including full-time, part-time, and temporary employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of work stoppages involving 1,000 or more workers lasting one full shift or longer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of work stoppages includes strikes and lockouts.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• A strike is defined as a temporary stoppage of work by a group of employees (not necessarily union members) to express a grievance or enforce a demand.
• A lockout is defined as a temporary withholding or denial of employment during a labor dispute to enforce terms of employment upon a group of employees.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number of work stoppages and (2) total days idle
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total days idle as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Days idle is defined as the aggregate number of work days lost as a result of work stoppages.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Total days idle shall be calculated as the sum of the products of the number of workers involved in each work stoppage and the number of days the respective work stoppage was in effect.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted average passenger fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average fuel economy of its passenger and light-duty vehicle fleet, weighted for the footprint of vehicles sold, by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The average fuel economy shall be calculated by model year as required for regulatory purposes.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: In the absence of regulatory guidance on calculating a fleet average, the entity shall calculate performance based on the fuel economy of vehicles sold during the reporting period weighted by sales volume.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The calculation shall be made on a fleet-average basis regardless of whether regulations are based on vehicle weight.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted average passenger fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Geographic regions are defined as the regions for which the entity conducts segment financial reporting and which are subject to fleet fuel economy, fuel consumption, or emissions standards.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted average passenger fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: Disclosure may be provided in different units for each geographic region, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Grams of carbon dioxide per kilometer (gCO2 / km) for (1) passenger cars and (2) light commercial vehicles sold in the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Liters of petrol per kilometer (L / km) for passenger vehicles sold in Japan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Miles per gallon (mpg) for (1) domestic passenger cars, (2) imported passenger cars, and (3) light trucks sold in the U.S. and subject to Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards, where these vehicle categories are defined in U.S. 49 CFR Part 523
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Kilometers per liter (km / L) for passenger vehicles sold in New Zealand

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted average passenger fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include all vehicles subject to national passenger vehicle standards for fleet fuel economy, fuel consumption, or emissions.

Accounting Metric: Sales-weighted average passenger fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose fleet performance for other vehicle segments such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Cargo vehicles in Japan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Heavy-duty vehicles in the U.S.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Light commercial vehicles in the EU

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) zero emission vehicles (ZEV), (2) hybrid vehicles, and (3) plug-in hybrid vehicles sold
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of vehicles sold during the reporting period that can be classified as: (1) zero emission vehicles (ZEV), (2) hybrid vehicles, and (3) plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: ZEVs are vehicles driven only by an electric motor that are powered by advanced-technology batteries or hydrogen fuel cell, and have no tailpipe emissions over their entire lifetime under any and all possible operational modes and conditions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Hybrid vehicles (hybrid electric vehicle or HEVs) are vehicles that can draw propulsion energy from both of the following on-vehicle sources of stored energy: (a) a consumable fuel and (b) an energy storage device such as a battery, capacitor, or flywheel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles are vehicles that offer electric driving with an electric motor powered by a large battery pack that is charged by plugging into a source of electricity.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) zero emission vehicles (ZEV), (2) hybrid vehicles, and (3) plug-in hybrid vehicles sold
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all vehicles sold globally that are eligible to be classified in accordance with the above guidance.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its strategy for improving the fuel economy and reducing the use-phase emissions of its fleet.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Use-phase emissions include greenhouse gasses and air pollutants such as carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds, and particulate matter.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: Relevant aspects of the strategy include improvements to existing vehicles and technologies, the introduction of new technologies, research and development efforts into advanced technologies, and partnerships with peers, academic institutions, and/or customers.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: Relevant technologies include, but are not limited to, those related to materials design and engineering, advanced powertrains, renewable fuels, energy storage and batteries, aerodynamic design, fuel injection systems, particulate filters, and products and fuels that otherwise result in reduced emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Advanced powertrain technologies include vehicles and vehicle components that are electric, hybrid electric, plug-in hybrid, dual-fuel, and zero-emissions (e.g., fuel cell).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Renewable fuels and energy technologies are those that operate on sources that are capable of being replenished in a short time through ecological cycles, including biomass (including ethanol, first-generation biofuels, and advanced biofuels).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Products that result in reduced emissions include any vehicle or technology that achieves a significant reduction in fuel consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Fuels that result in reduced emissions further include biodiesel, ethanol, natural gas, propane, and hydrogen, as described in the U.S. Energy Policy Act of 2005.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: Internal combustion engines include those equipped with technology (e.g., selective catalytic reduction) to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Particulate filters (e.g., wall-flow filter or partial flow filter) include those that reduce emissions (including carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, and particulate matter).
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 6: • Where relevant, the entity shall discuss the technologies it is prioritizing to improve the fuel economy and reduce emissions of its vehicles, such as the specific type of fuel systems it is developing (e.g., hybrid, electric, or fuel cell).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the factors influencing fuel economy and emissions efforts, such as meeting customer demand and/or meeting regulatory requirements of the markets it operates in, or plans to operate in.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant programs and initiatives include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• California Low-Emission Vehicle Program – LEV III
• China VI emission standard
• Euro 6 standards for light duty vehicles
• U.S. Clean Air Act
• U.S. Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether it is meeting fuel economy and use-phase regulatory obligations, whether such existing regulations require future improvements, progress toward meeting such regulations, and strategies to maintain compliance with emerging regulations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all vehicles subject to national and local vehicle standards.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of strategy for managing fleet fuel economy and emissions risks and opportunities
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the benchmarks it uses to measure improvements in fuel economy and emissions reductions, including targets for fuel economy improvements and emissions reductions.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall describe its strategic approach to managing its risks associated with the use of critical materials in its products, including physical limits on availability and access, changes in price, and regulatory and reputational risks, where:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A critical material is defined as a material that is both essential in use and subject to the risk of supply restriction. This definition is derived from the U.S. National Research Council of the National Academies’ Minerals, Critical Minerals, and the U.S. Economy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Examples of critical materials include, but are not limited to, the following as defined by the National Research Council:

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: The entity shall identify the critical materials that present a significant risk to its operations, the type of risk(s) they represent, and the strategies the entity uses to mitigate the risk(s).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant strategies may include diversification of suppliers, stockpiling of materials, development or procurement of alternative and substitute materials, and investments in recycling technology for critical materials.

Accounting Metric: Description of the management of risks associated with the use of critical materials
Technical Protocol: All disclosure shall be sufficient such that it is specific to the risks the entity faces but disclosure itself would not compromise the entity’s ability to maintain confidential information.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For example, if an entity determines not to identify a specific critical material that presents a significant risk to its operations due to competitive harm that could result from the disclosure, the entity shall disclose the existence of such risk(s), the type of risk(s), and the strategies used to mitigate the risk(s), but is not required to disclose the relevant critical material.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of waste from manufacturing, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of waste generated, in metric tons, from its manufacturing operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Waste is defined as anything for which the entity has no further use and which is discarded or released to the environment.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of waste from manufacturing, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of waste generated from manufacturing operations that was recycled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of waste generated from manufacturing operations that was recycled divided by the total weight of waste generated from manufacturing operations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Recycled waste (including remanufactured waste) is defined as waste material that has been reprocessed or treated by means of production or manufacturing processes and made into a final product or a component for incorporation into a product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recycled waste includes material that was reused.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Reused material is defined as recovered products or components of products that are used for the same purpose for which they were conceived.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of recycled waste excludes portions of products and materials that are disposed of in landfills.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The scope of recycled waste excludes materials that were incinerated, including for energy recovery.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 5: • Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration, with or without other waste, but with recovery of the heat.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: The scope of recycled material includes primary recycled material, co-products (outputs of equal value to primary recycled materials), by-products (outputs of lesser value to primary recycled materials), and material sent externally for further recycling.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of waste from manufacturing, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes end-of-life recovered material accounted for in TR-AU-440b.2.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of waste from manufacturing, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately disclose the percentage of waste generated that was incinerated.

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the weight, in metric tons, of end-of-life material that was recovered.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: End-of-life material that was recovered is defined as products, materials, and parts, that at the end of their useful life are collected would have otherwise been disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery, but have instead been collected.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of recovered material includes materials physically handled by the entity.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recovered material excludes materials that the entity did not take physical possession of, but were collected by a third party for the expressed purpose of reuse, recycling, or refurbishment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of recovered material excludes materials that were collected for repair or that are in-warranty and subject to recall.

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of end-of-life material that was recovered and subsequently recycled.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of end-of-life material that was recovered and subsequently recycled divided by the total weight of end-of-life material that was recovered.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Recycled material (including remanufactured material) is defined as waste material that has been reprocessed or treated by means of production or manufacturing processes and made into a final product or a component for incorporation into a product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recycled material includes material that was reused or reclaimed.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Reused material is defined as recovered products or components of products that are used for the same purpose for which they were conceived, including products donated and/or refurbished by the entity or by third parties.
• Reclaimed material is defined as material processed to recover or regenerate a usable product.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of recycled material includes primary recycled material, co-products (outputs of equal value to primary recycled materials), by-products (outputs of lesser value to primary recycled materials), and material sent externally for further recycling.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The scope of recycled material excludes portions of products and materials that are disposed of in landfills.

Accounting Metric: Weight of end-of-life material recovered, percentage recycled
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure excludes waste materials accounted for in TR-AU-440b.1.

Accounting Metric: Average recyclability of vehicles sold
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average recyclability of vehicles sold as a percentage.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure is limited to passenger and light-duty vehicle models.

Accounting Metric: Average recyclability of vehicles sold
Technical Protocol: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of components and materials in vehicles sold that are recyclable divided by the total weight of all vehicles sold.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Material is recyclable if it can be reprocessed for the original purpose or for other purposes at a reasonable cost with technology widely available in the markets in which the vehicles are sold.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Materials that are typically recyclable include ferrous and non-ferrous metals, glass, and certain plastics.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of recyclable material includes material that is reusable or able to be remanufactured.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Materials and components that are typically reusable or able to be remanufactured include engines, transmissions, catalysts, tires (including retreadable tires), batteries, and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of recyclable material excludes recoverable material, which consistent with the EU End of Life Vehicle Directive (Annex IIB to Directive 75/442/EEC), is defined as material that can be salvaged for further use, including for energy recovery.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration, with or without other waste, but with recovery of the heat.
• Materials that are typically disposed of as waste or used for energy recovery include fluids, hazardous materials, automotive shredder residue (including glass, foam, and fabric), automotive safety glass, and certain plastics.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, route optimization, use of alternative fuels and energy sources, system improvements, optimization of ship operation, improving efficiency through ship design and propulsion systems (including hull and propeller improvements), and upgrading the fleet with new ships.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage onshore power supply (OPS), (4) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage onshore power supply (OPS), (4) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from heavy fuel oil.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Heavy fuel oils are defined per the U.S. Energy Information Administration as heavier oils that remain after distillate fuel oils and lighter hydrocarbons are distilled away in refinery operations, and which conform to ASTM Specifications D 396 and D 975 and Federal Specification VV-F-815C, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• No. 5 Residual fuel oil, a residual fuel oil of medium viscosity, also known as “Navy Special” and defined in Military Specification MIL-F-859E, including Amendment 2 (NATO Symbol F-770)
• No. 6 Residual fuel oil, which includes Bunker C fuel oil
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as heavy fuel oil consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage onshore power supply (OPS), (4) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is onshore power supply (OPS).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OPS includes the shoreside electrical power consumed by a ship at berth while its main and auxiliary engines are turned off.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as OPS consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage onshore power supply (OPS), (4) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (4) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage onshore power supply (OPS), (4) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Average Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) for new ships
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) for new ships in grams of carbon dioxide per ton-nautical mile.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An EEDI value is the product of power installed, specific fuel consumption, and carbon conversion, divided by the product of available capacity and vessel speed at design load.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the average EEDI as a simple average of the EEDI value of all new ships added to the entity’s fleet during the reporting period.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • New ships are limited to those built after 2013 and for which the International Maritime Organization (IMO) has adopted EEDI as a metric.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall follow calculation methodologies outlined in IMO MEPC 66/21/Add.1, Annex 5, 2014 Guidelines on the Method of Calculation of the Attained Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) For New Ships.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOx), reported as NOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOx includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) oxides of sulfur (SOx), reported as SOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of SOx includes SO2 and SO3.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (3) particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter (PM10), reported as PM10.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PM10 is defined, according to U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, as any airborne finely divided solid or liquid material with an aerodynamic diameter less than or equal to a nominal 10 micrometers.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of ship waste discharged to the environment, percentage treated prior to discharge
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of ship waste discharged to the environment, in metric tons.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ship waste is defined as anything that was used on board the ship (or intended for use on the ship) that is discarded or released to the environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes sewage, bilge water, ballast water, graywater, hazardous waste, used oil, food, packaging, and other solid waste.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure includes materials incinerated, including materials incinerated for energy recovery.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3: • Energy recovery is defined as the use of combustible waste as a means to generate energy through direct incineration with or without other waste but with recovery of the heat.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure excludes gaseous wastes, waste disposed of on shore, and waste that is reused or recycled by the entity or by vendors or partners into new products, co-products, or by-products.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of ship waste discharged to the environment, percentage treated prior to discharge
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of ship waste discharged to the environment that was treated prior to discharge.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the weight of waste material that was treated by the entity to at least the minimum legal requirements set by the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) and by other relevant regulators, divided by the total weight of waste material.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Treated waste shall exclude materials incinerated, even if the incinerated waste may be legally discharged at sea.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of fleet implementing ballast water (1) exchange and (2) treatment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its fleet that has (1) implemented ballast water exchange.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ballast water exchange is defined by Regulation D1 of the International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships' Ballast Water and Sediments (BWM) and requires that ships performing ballast water exchange do so with an efficiency of at least 95 percent volumetric exchange of ballast water. The three accepted methods of ballast water exchange are the sequential method, the flow-through method, and the dilution method.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of ships in the entity’s fleet that have implemented ballast water exchange that meets the Regulation D1 exchange standard divided by the total number of ships in the fleet.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of fleet implementing ballast water (1) exchange and (2) treatment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its fleet that has (2) implemented ballast water treatment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ballast water treatment includes implementation of an integrated system of ballast water treatment equipment that is approved by the U.S. Coast Guard or by another governmental administration to meet the performance criteria in Regulation D2 of the BWM.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Approved systems must discharge (a) less than 10 viable organisms per cubic meter that are greater than or equal to 50 micrometers in minimum dimension and (b) less than 10 viable organisms per milliliter that are less than 50 micrometers in minimum dimension and greater than or equal to 10 micrometers in minimum dimension.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of ships in the entity’s fleet that have implemented ballast water treatment systems that meet the Regulation D2 performance standard divided by the total number of ships in the fleet.

Accounting Metric: Cruise duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the cruise duration spent in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Cruise duration is the sum of the travel days (24-hour periods or fractions thereof), including time spent docked at ports.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A marine protected area is defined according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as any area of the intertidal or subtidal terrain, together with its overlying water and associated flora, fauna, and historical and cultural features, which has been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment. Marine protected areas include areas internationally established and regulated in International Maritime Organization (IMO) Conventions as well as areas established nationally by member states, such as:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Areas to be Avoided established by IMO Safety of Life at Sea Convention (SOLAS), Chapter V, regulation 10
• Areas with Mandatory Ship Reporting Systems established by IMO SOLAS, Chapter V, regulation 11
• Emission Control Areas under MARPOL Annex VI
• No Anchoring Areas established by IMO SOLAS Chapter V, regulation 10
• Particularly Sensitive Sea Areas (PSSAs) designated by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the IMO in accordance with IMO Guidelines for the Identification and Designation of Particularly Sensitive Sea Areas (resolution A.982(24))
• Special Areas designated under the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL Annexes I, II, and IV)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: An area of protected conservation status, which may be listed in the World Database of Protected Areas (WDPA) and mapped by Protected Planet, is defined as an area located within one or more of the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Biosphere Reserves recognized within the framework of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's (UNESCO) Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Programme
• International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Protected Areas (categories I-VI)
• Marine sanctuaries
• National parks
• Marine Natura 2000 sites
• Ramsar Wetlands of International Importance
• Sites that meet the IUCN’s definition of a protected area: “A protected area is a clearly defined geographical space, recognized, dedicated, and managed, through legal or other effective means, to achieve the long-term conservation of nature with associated ecosystem services and cultural values”
• UNESCO marine World Heritage sites
• Other areas where discharges are restricted or subject to local agreements
TP_BP3_Sub Footnote: N. Dudley (ed.), Guidelines for Applying Protected Areas Management Categories, (Gland, Switzerland: IUCN, 2008), pp. 8-9.

Accounting Metric: Cruise duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately identify cruise duration in areas with additional ecological, biodiversity, or conservation designations such as those listed by the A-Z Guide of Areas of Biodiversity Importance, prepared by the United Nations Environment Programme’s World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC).

Accounting Metric: Cruise duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its cruise activities in marine protected areas and areas of protected conservation status that present low risk to biodiversity or ecosystem services.

Accounting Metric: Cruise duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its cruise activities in areas that have no official designation but that present high biodiversity or ecosystem services risks.

Accounting Metric: Number of notices of violations received for dumping
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of notices of violations received for dumping.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Notices of violations include those issued by the entity’s flag state and by any government enforcement agency at ports where the entity’s vessels visit.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The scope of disclosure includes violations of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) Annexes I through V and other relevant national or regional environmental legislation (e.g., Alaska Department of Environmental Quality Notices of Violations) related to wastewater pollution, illegal dumping of oil, untreated sewage, hazardous waste, other pollutants (e.g., nickel, copper, zinc and ammonia), or falsification of Oil Record Books.
• The scope of disclosure excludes violations of environmental legislation related to excessive emissions and air quality.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Dumping is defined by the International Maritime Organization 1996 Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter (as amended in 2006) as any deliberate disposal into the sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms, or other man-made structures at sea.

Accounting Metric: Number of notices of violations received for dumping
Technical Protocol: A violation shall be disclosed regardless of whether it resulted in an enforcement action (e.g., fine or warning letter).

Accounting Metric: Number of alleged crime incidents involving passengers or employees
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of alleged crime incidents involving passengers or employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: For cruise ships that embark and disembark in the U.S., alleged crimes are defined as those involving homicide, suspicious death, a missing U.S. national, kidnapping, assault resulting in serious bodily injury, sexual assault, firing or tampering with a vessel, or theft of money and property in excess of $10,000 U.S. dollars. This definition is derived from the U.S. Cruise Vessel Security and Safety Act of 2010 (CVSSA).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: For cruise ships that do not embark and disembark in the U.S. and are therefore outside the jurisdiction of the CVSSA, alleged crimes shall be defined by the appropriate oversight authority for cruise ship criminal activity in the jurisdiction where the crime occurred.

Accounting Metric: Fleet average CDC Vessel Sanitation Program inspection score, percentage of inspections failed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Vessel Sanitation Program (VSP) inspection score for its fleet.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The average CDC VSP inspection score shall be calculated as the sum of inspection scores for all inspected ships divided by the number of ships that were inspected.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • For a ship that was inspected multiple times during the reporting period, the entity shall use the average annual inspection score for that ship in the calculation of the fleet average score.

Accounting Metric: Fleet average CDC Vessel Sanitation Program inspection score, percentage of inspections failed
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of inspections for public health, food safety, and/or environmental sanitation conducted by a relevant regulatory oversight authority that received a failing sanitation inspection score.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the total number of inspections that received a failing score divided by the total number of inspections that were conducted.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • For a ship that was inspected multiple times during the reporting period, the entity shall use the lowest inspection score for that ship in the calculation of the percentage.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes any ship that was inspected by a relevant regulatory oversight authority. Agencies that may have conducted such inspections include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Brazilian ANVISA program
• European SHIPSAN program
• Health Canada Cruise Ship Inspection program
• U.S. CDC VSP

Accounting Metric: (1) Serious injuries per million passengers and (2) number of voyages with a gastrointestinal illness count exceeding 2%
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of serious injuries per million passengers.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Serious injuries are defined as injuries resulting in incapacitation for more than 72 hours commencing within seven days from the date of injury, consistent with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) Code for the Investigation of Marine Casualties and Incidents.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure is limited to serious injuries that are caused by, or occur in connection with, the operations of a ship.

Accounting Metric: (1) Serious injuries per million passengers and (2) number of voyages with a gastrointestinal illness count exceeding 2%
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total number of voyages on which the gastrointestinal illness count exceeded two percent of the total number of passengers or crew on board.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Vessel Sanitation Program (VSP) defines gastrointestinal illness (GI) cases as those evaluated by the medical staff before the ship arrives at a U.S. port when sailing from a foreign port.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The VSP applies to ships with more than 13 customers that are either flagged in the U.S. or are foreign ships that have U.S. ports on their itineraries. Under the program, ships must follow guidelines for public health practices, submit to both scheduled and unannounced inspections, and report GI outbreaks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The number of GI cases used in the calculation shall be the total for the entire voyage, not the number of active (symptomatic) GI cases at any given port of call or at disembarkation.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Two percent of the total number of passengers or crew on board represents the threshold for which a separate notification is required by the cruise ship.

Accounting Metric: Average hourly wage for seafarers, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average hourly wage for seafarers for each geographic region for which it conducts segment financial reporting.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Seafarers are defined as non-manager or director-level shipboard employees.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Seafarers exclude shoreside and corporate employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The average hourly wage is calculated as the total seafarer wages for the reporting period, including gratuities, divided by the number of hours worked by seafarers during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of seafarers working maximum hours
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of seafarers who worked maximum allowable hours at least once during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Seafarers are defined as non-manager or director-level shipboard employees.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Seafarers exclude shoreside and corporate employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The maximum allowable hours of work for seafarers are 14 hours of work per 24-hour period and 72 hours of work per 7-day period, consistent with the International Labour Organization (ILO) Maritime Labour Convention, Standard A2.3, Paragraph 5(a), “Hours of work and hours of rest.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of seafarers that worked maximum allowable hours at least once during the reporting period divided by the number of seafarers that worked at least once during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of seafarers paid for overtime
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of seafarers who were paid for overtime at least once during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Seafarers are defined as non-manager or director-level shipboard employees.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Seafarers exclude shoreside and corporate employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Overtime means time worked in excess of the normal hours of work.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated in accordance with International Labour Organization (ILO) Maritime Labour Convention Guideline B2.2.2, “Calculation and payment.”

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations, such as those relating to wages, work hours, overtime, and meal and rest breaks.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
