Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual)

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with labor law violations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: International Labour Organization (ILO) Maritime Labour Convention
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Seaman’s Wage Act

Accounting Metric: Seafarer lost time incident rate (LTIR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its lost time incident rate (LTIR) for seafarers for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A lost time incident is an incident that results in absence from work beyond the date or shift when it occurred.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Seafarers are defined as non-manager or director-level shipboard employees.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • The scope of disclosure excludes shoreside and corporate employees.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The rate shall be calculated as: (lost time incidents) / (1,000,000 hours worked)

Accounting Metric: Seafarer lost time incident rate (LTIR)
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting lost time incidents.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The International Chamber of Shipping and the International Maritime Organization International Safety Management Code (ISM Code) provide additional guidance in implementing lost time incident reporting.

Accounting Metric: Number of Conditions of Class or Recommendations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of Conditions of Class or Recommendations it has received from a Flag Administration or a Recognized Organization (RO) that has been delegated the authority to issue such findings.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Conditions of Class or Recommendations are understood to be interchangeable terms, defined as requirements imposed by an Administration (or its delegate, such as a Classification Society) that are to be carried out within a specific time limit in order to retain vessel Class, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Repairs and/or renewals related to damages that affect Classification (e.g., grounding, structural damages, machinery damages, and wastage over the allowable limits)
• Supplementary survey requirements
• Temporary repairs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes all Conditions of Class regardless of whether they resulted in withdrawal, suspension, or invalidation of a vessel’s Class certificate.

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the number of deficiencies it received from regional port state control (PSC) organizations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A deficiency is defined as a condition found not to be in compliance with the requirements of one or more of the following conventions:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973, as modified by the Protocols of 1978 and 1997 relating thereto, as amended (MARPOL)
• International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS)
• International Convention on Load Lines (Load Lines)
• International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification, and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978, as amended (STCW)
• International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-Fouling Systems on Ships (AFS)
• International Convention on Tonnage Measurement of Ships, 1969 (Tonnage)
• International Labour Organization (ILO) Maritime Labour Convention, 2006

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of detentions it received from regional PSC organizations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A detention is defined as an intervention action by the port state, taken when the condition of a ship or its crew does not correspond substantially with the applicable conventions. A detention ensures that the ship will not sail until it can proceed to sea without presenting a danger to the ship or persons on board, or without presenting an unreasonable threat of harm to the marine environment, whether or not such action affects the normal schedule of the ship’s departure.

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes deficiencies and detentions issued by PSC organizations that are signatories to memoranda of understanding (MoU) of regional PSC (e.g., Paris MoU, Tokyo MoU, Acuerdo de Viña del Mar, Caribbean MoU, Abuja MoU, Black Sea MoU, Mediterranean MoU, Indian Ocean MoU, or Riyadh MoU) or by the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG).

Accounting Metric: Number of marine casualties, percentage classified as very serious
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of marine casualties in which its fleet was involved.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A marine casualty is defined, based on the International Maritime Organization (IMO)'s Code of International Standards and Recommended Practices for a Safety Investigation into a Marine Casualty or Marine Incident Resolution MSC 255(84), paragraph 2.9, chapter 2 of the General provisions, as an event, or sequence of events, that occurs directly in connection with the operations of a ship and results in one or more of the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The death of, or serious injury to, a person
• The loss of a person from a ship
• The loss, presumed loss, or abandonment of a ship
• Material damage to a ship
• The stranding or disabling of a ship, or the involvement of a ship in a collision
• Material damage to marine infrastructure external to a ship that could seriously endanger the safety of the ship, another ship, or an individual
• Severe damage to the environment, or the potential for severe damage to the environment, brought about by the damage of a ship or ships

Accounting Metric: Number of marine casualties, percentage classified as very serious
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of marine casualties classified as very serious marine casualties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A very serious marine casualty is defined as a marine casualty involving the total loss of the ship, a death, or severe damage to the environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of very serious marine casualties divided by the total number of marine casualties.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of rental fleet vehicles rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its rental fleet rated by a New Car Assessment Program (NCAP) with an overall 5-star safety rating, by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of vehicles in its rental fleet that are rated by an NCAP program with an overall 5-star rating divided by the total number of vehicles in its rental fleet that are rated by an NCAP program.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes existing vehicles and newly introduced vehicles in the entity’s rental fleet that have received a rating by an NCAP program, including carry-over vehicles.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • Carry-over vehicles are defined as vehicles that have been tested under an NCAP program in previous years and whose design has not changed (i.e., they retain their safety rating).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure includes vehicles available for rent through the entity’s franchises.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The scope of disclosure excludes vehicles that do not have an applicable NCAP rating.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of rental fleet vehicles rated by NCAP programs with an overall 5-star safety rating, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Geographic regions are defined as the regions for which the entity conducts segment financial reporting and which are subject to an NCAP, including, but not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Australia and New Zealand New Car Assessment Program (ANCAP)
• China New Car Assessment Program (C-NCAP)
• European New Car Assessment Programme (Euro NCAP)
• Japan New Car Assessment Program (JNCAP)
• Korean New Car Assessment Program (KNCAP)
• Latin New Car Assessment Program (Latin NCAP)
• The New Car Assessment Program for Southeast Asian Countries (ASEAN NCAP)
• U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s (NHTSA) New Car Assessment Program (NCAP) 5-Star Safety Ratings Program

Accounting Metric: Number of vehicles recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of vehicles in its rental fleet that were subject to a voluntary or involuntary recall.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Voluntary recalls are those initiated by the vehicle manufacturer.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Involuntary recalls are those mandated by the U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) or by an equivalent regulatory authority or agency when (a) a motor vehicle or item of motor vehicle equipment does not comply with a governmental motor vehicle safety standard, or (b) when there is a safety-related defect in the vehicle or equipment.

Accounting Metric: Number of vehicles recalled
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include vehicles available for rent through the entity’s franchises.

Accounting Metric: Number of vehicles recalled
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose the percentage of recalls that were (1) voluntary and (2) involuntary.

Accounting Metric: Rental day-weighted average rental fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average fuel economy of its passenger vehicle rental fleet, weighted for the rental days of each vehicle model during the reporting period, by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The average fuel economy shall be calculated as the rental day-weighted harmonic mean of vehicle fuel efficiency.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The harmonic mean is calculated as the reciprocal of the average of the reciprocals.
• Rental day weighting is performed by incorporating into calculations a factor for the fraction of total rental days for which each vehicle model accounted.

Accounting Metric: Rental day-weighted average rental fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average fuel economy of its passenger vehicle rental fleet by geographic region.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Geographic regions are defined as the regions for which the entity conducts segment financial reporting and which are subject to fleet fuel economy, fuel consumption, or emissions standards.

Accounting Metric: Rental day-weighted average rental fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: Disclosure may be provided in different units for each geographic region, including, but not limited to:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Grams of CO2 per kilometer (gCO2 / km) for (1) passenger cars and (2) light commercial vehicles in the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Liters of petrol per kilometer (L / km) for passenger vehicles in Japan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Miles per gallon (mpg) for (1) domestic passenger cars, (2) imported passenger cars, and (3) light trucks in the U.S. that are subject to Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) standards, where these vehicle categories are defined in U.S. 49 CFR Part 523
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: Kilometers per liter (km / L) for passenger vehicles in New Zealand

Accounting Metric: Rental day-weighted average rental fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include all vehicles subject to national passenger vehicle standards for fleet fuel economy, fuel consumption, or emissions.

Accounting Metric: Rental day-weighted average rental fleet fuel economy, by region
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose fleet fuel economy for other vehicle segments such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Cargo vehicles in Japan
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Heavy-duty vehicles in the U.S.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: Light commercial vehicles in the EU

Accounting Metric: Fleet utilization rate
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fleet utilization rate.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The rate shall be calculated as the total number of rental days divided by the total number of available rental days.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Rental days are defined as the number of 24-hour periods—or portions thereof—that vehicles were rented.
• Available rental days are defined as the number of 24-hour periods—or portions thereof—that vehicles were offered for rental during the reporting period. This figure shall exclude the time when vehicles were undergoing inspection, cleaning, or maintenance, and any time when they were subject to recall.

Accounting Metric: Fleet utilization rate
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes vehicles at all of the entity’s rental locations, including airport locations, off-airport locations, and vehicles in the entity’s car-sharing fleet.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, route optimization, use of alternative fuels and energy sources, system improvements, optimization of ship operation, improving efficiency through ship design and propulsion systems (including hull and propeller improvements), and upgrading the fleet with new ships.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total amount of energy it consumed as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of energy consumption includes energy from all sources, including energy purchased from sources external to the entity and energy produced by the entity itself (self-generated). For example, direct fuel usage, purchased electricity, and heating, cooling, and steam energy are all included within the scope of energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of energy consumption includes only energy directly consumed by the entity during the reporting period.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: In calculating energy consumption from fuels and biofuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), or the U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA).

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the percentage of energy it consumed that was supplied from heavy fuel oil.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Heavy fuel oils are defined per the U.S. Energy Information Administration as heavier oils that remain after distillate fuel oils and lighter hydrocarbons are distilled away in refinery operations, and which conform to ASTM Specifications D 396 and D 975 and Federal Specification VV-F-815C, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• No. 5 Residual fuel oil, a residual fuel oil of medium viscosity, also known as “Navy Special” and defined in Military Specification MIL-F-859E, including Amendment 2 (NATO Symbol F-770)
• No. 6 Residual fuel oil, which includes Bunker C fuel oil
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as heavy fuel oil consumption divided by total energy consumption.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (3) the percentage of energy it consumed that is renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable energy is defined as energy from sources that are replenished at a rate greater than or equal to their rate of depletion, such as geothermal, wind, solar, hydro, and biomass.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as renewable energy consumption divided by total energy consumption.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of renewable energy includes renewable fuel the entity consumed, renewable energy the entity directly produced, and renewable energy the entity purchased, if purchased through a renewable power purchase agreement (PPA) that explicitly includes renewable energy certificates (RECs) or Guarantees of Origin (GOs), a Green?e Energy Certified utility or supplier program, or other green power products that explicitly include RECs or GOs, or for which Green?e Energy Certified RECs are paired with grid electricity.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• For any renewable electricity generated on-site, any RECs and GOs must be retained (i.e., not sold) and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• For renewable PPAs and green power products, the agreement must explicitly include and convey that RECs and GOs be retained or replaced and retired or cancelled on behalf of the entity in order for the entity to claim them as renewable energy.
• The renewable portion of the electricity grid mix that is outside of the control or influence of the entity is excluded from the scope of renewable energy.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: For the purposes of this disclosure, the scope of renewable energy from hydro and biomass sources is limited to the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 4:
• Energy from hydro sources is limited to those that are certified by the Low Impact Hydropower Institute or that are eligible for a state Renewable Portfolio Standard;
• Energy from biomass sources is limited to materials certified to a third-party standard (e.g., Forest Stewardship Council, Sustainable Forest Initiative, Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification, or American Tree Farm System), materials considered eligible sources of supply according to the Green-e Framework for Renewable Energy Certification, Version 1.0 (2017) or Green-e regional standards, and/or materials that are eligible for an applicable state renewable portfolio standard.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total energy consumed, (2) percentage heavy fuel oil, (3) percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels) and conversion of kilowatt hours (kWh) to GJ (for energy data including electricity from solar or wind energy).

Accounting Metric: Average Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) for new ships
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the average Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) for new ships in grams of carbon dioxide per ton-nautical mile.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An EEDI value is the product of power installed, specific fuel consumption, and carbon conversion, divided by the product of available capacity and vessel speed at design load.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall calculate the average EEDI as a simple average of the EEDI value of all new ships added to the entity’s fleet during the reporting period
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2: • New ships are limited to those built after 2013 and for which the International Maritime Organization (IMO) has adopted EEDI as a metric.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity shall follow calculation methodologies outlined in IMO MEPC 66/21/Add.1, Annex 5, 2014 Guidelines on the Method of Calculation of the Attained Energy Efficiency Design Index (EEDI) For New Ships.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOx), reported as NOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOx includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) oxides of sulfur (SOx), reported as SOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of SOx includes SO2 and SO3.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (3) particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter (PM10), reported as PM10.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PM10 is defined, according to U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, as any airborne finely divided solid or liquid material with an aerodynamic diameter less than or equal to a nominal 10 micrometers.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O), (2) SOx, and (3) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Shipping duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the shipping duration spent in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Shipping duration is the sum of the travel days (24-hour periods or fractions thereof), including time spent docked at ports.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: A marine protected area is defined according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as any area of the intertidal or subtidal terrain, together with its overlying water and associated flora, fauna, and historical and cultural features, which has been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment. Marine protected areas include areas internationally established and regulated in International Marine Organization (IMO) Conventions and areas established nationally by member states, such as:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Areas to be Avoided established by IMO Safety of Life at Sea Convention (SOLAS), Chapter V, regulation 10
• Areas with Mandatory Ship Reporting Systems established by IMO SOLAS, Chapter V, regulation 11
• Emission Control Areas under MARPOL Annex VI
• No Anchoring Areas established by IMO SOLAS Chapter V, regulation 10
• Particularly Sensitive Sea Areas (PSSAs) designated by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the IMO in accordance with IMO Guidelines for the Identification and Designation of Particularly Sensitive Sea Areas (resolution A.982(24))
• Special Areas designated under the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) Annexes I, II, and IV
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: An area of protected conservation status, which may be listed in the World Database of Protected Areas (WDPA) and mapped on Protected Planet, is defined as an area located within one or more of the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 3:
• Biosphere Reserves recognized within the framework of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's (UNESCO’s) Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Programme
• International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Protected Areas (categories I-VI)
• Marine sanctuaries
• National parks
• Marine Natura 2000 sites
• Ramsar Wetlands of International Importance
• Sites that meet the IUCN’s definition of a protected area: “A protected area is a clearly defined geographical space, recognized, dedicated, and managed, through legal or other effective means, to achieve the long-term conservation of nature with associated ecosystem services and cultural values”
• UNESCO marine World Heritage sites
• Other areas where discharges are restricted or subject to local agreements
TP_BP3_Sub Footnote: N. Dudley (ed.), Guidelines for Applying Protected Areas Management Categories, (Gland, Switzerland: IUCN, 2008), pp. 8-9.

Accounting Metric: Shipping duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may separately identify shipping duration in areas with additional ecological, biodiversity, or conservation designations such as those listed by the A-Z Guide of Areas of Biodiversity Importance, prepared by the United Nations Environment Programme’s World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC).

Accounting Metric: Shipping duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its shipping activities in marine protected areas and areas of protected conservation status that present low risk to biodiversity or ecosystem services.

Accounting Metric: Shipping duration in marine protected areas or areas of protected conservation status
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss its shipping activities in areas that have no official designation but that present high biodiversity or ecosystem services risks.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of fleet implementing ballast water (1) exchange and (2) treatment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its fleet that has (1) implemented ballast water exchange.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ballast water exchange is defined by Regulation D1 of the International Convention for the Control and Management of Ships' Ballast Water and Sediments (BWM) and requires that ships performing ballast water exchange do so with an efficiency of at least 95 percent volumetric exchange of ballast water. The three accepted methods of ballast water exchange are the sequential method, the flow-through method, and the dilution method.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of ships in the entity’s fleet that have implemented ballast water exchange that meets the Regulation D1 performance standard divided by the total number of ships in the fleet.

Accounting Metric: Percentage of fleet implementing ballast water (1) exchange and (2) treatment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of its fleet that has (2) implemented ballast water treatment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Ballast water treatment includes implementation of an integrated system of ballast water treatment equipment that is approved by the U.S. Coast Guard or by another governmental administration to meet the performance criteria in Regulation D2 of the BWM.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • Approved systems must discharge (a) less than 10 viable organisms per cubic meter that are greater than or equal to 50 micrometers in minimum dimension and (b) less than 10 viable organisms per milliliter that are less than 50 micrometers in minimum dimension and greater than or equal to 10 micrometers in minimum dimension.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of ships in the entity’s fleet that have implemented ballast water treatment systems that meet the Regulation D2 performance standard divided by the total number of ships in the fleet.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) aggregate volume of spills and releases to the environment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of spills and releases to the environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Spills and releases include releases overboard that are intentional or accidental, including:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Those resulting from sabotage, earthquakes, or other events outside of the entity’s operational control
• Those resulting from leakage over time (which shall be counted once at the time the leak is identified)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes spills and releases that, based on U.S. Code of Federal Regulations 46 CFR 4.03-65 definitions, result in “significant harm to the environment,” including spills or releases of:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Hazardous substances in quantities equal to or exceeding, in any 24-hour period, the reportable quantity determined in U.S. 40 CFR part 117
• Noxious liquid substances presenting major hazard (Category X) or minor hazard (Category Y) according to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) Annex II
• Oils, excluding those that are: (a) from a properly functioning vessel engine and any discharges of such oil accumulated in the bilges of a vessel discharged in compliance with MARPOL 73/78, Annex I; or (b) permitted under MARPOL 73/78, Annex I, as provided in U.S. 33 CFR part 151, subpart A

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) aggregate volume of spills and releases to the environment
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the aggregate volume of spills and releases to the environment in cubic meters.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The volume shall be calculated as the total estimated amount spilled that reached the environment, without netting the amount of such material that was subsequently recovered, evaporated, or otherwise lost.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) aggregate volume of spills and releases to the environment
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity may provide a breakdown of spills and releases by type, such as: (1) hydrocarbons, (2) hazardous substances, and (3) MARPOL Annex II noxious liquid substances.

Accounting Metric: (1) Number and (2) aggregate volume of spills and releases to the environment
Technical Protocol: The entity may provide a breakdown of spills and releases by their proximity to land, such as: (1) those 24 nautical miles or closer to shore and (2) those greater than 24 nautical miles from shore.

Accounting Metric: Lost time incident rate (LTIR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its lost time incident rate (LTIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A lost time incident is an incident that results in absence from work beyond the date or shift when it occurred.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The rate shall be calculated as: (lost time incidents) / (1,000,000 hours worked)

Accounting Metric: Lost time incident rate (LTIR)
Technical Protocol: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting lost time incidents.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The International Chamber of Shipping and the International Maritime Organization (IMO) International Safety Management Code (ISM Code) provide additional guidance in implementing lost time incident reporting.

Accounting Metric: Lost time incident rate (LTIR)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location.

Accounting Metric: Number of calls at ports in countries that have the 20 lowest rankings in Transparency International’s Corruption Perception Index
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of calls at ports in countries that have the 20 lowest rankings in Transparency International’s Corruption Perception Index (CPI).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: In the event that two or more countries share the 20th lowest ranking, all shall be included in the scope of disclosure.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The entity shall use the most current version of the CPI available from Transparency International.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery, corruption, or other unethical business practices.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.K. Bribery Act 2010
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with bribery or corruption
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: U.K. Serious Fraud Office
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Department of Justice
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission

Accounting Metric: Number of marine casualties, percentage classified as very serious
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total number of marine casualties in which its fleet was involved.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A marine casualty is defined, based on the United Nations International Maritime Organization (IMO)'s Code of International Standards and Recommended Practices for a Safety Investigation into a Marine Casualty or Marine Incident Resolution MSC 255(84), paragraph 2.9, chapter 2 of the General provisions, as an event, or sequence of events, that occurs directly in connection with the operations of a ship and results in one or more of the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• The death of, or serious injury to, a person
• The loss of a person from a ship
• The loss, presumed loss, or abandonment of a ship
• Material damage to a ship
• The stranding or disabling of a ship, or the involvement of a ship in a collision
• Material damage to marine infrastructure external to a ship, that could seriously endanger the safety of the ship, another ship or an individual
• Severe damage to the environment, or the potential for severe damage to the environment, brought about by the damage of a ship or ships

Accounting Metric: Number of marine casualties, percentage classified as very serious
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of marine casualties classified as very serious marine casualties.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A very serious marine casualty is defined as a marine casualty involving the total loss of the ship, a death, or severe damage to the environment.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The percentage shall be calculated as the number of very serious marine casualties divided by the total number of marine casualties.

Accounting Metric: Number of Conditions of Class or Recommendations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of Conditions of Class or Recommendations it has received from a Flag Administration or a Recognized Organization (RO) that has been delegated the authority to issue such findings.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Conditions of Class or Recommendations are understood to be interchangeable terms, defined as requirements imposed by an Administration (or its delegate, such as a Classification Society) that are to be carried out within a specific time limit in order to retain vessel Class, including, but not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Repairs and/or renewals related to damages that affect Classification (e.g., grounding, structural damages, machinery damages, and wastage over the allowable limits)
• Supplementary survey requirements
• Temporary repairs
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes all Conditions of Class regardless of whether they resulted in withdrawal, suspension, or invalidation of a vessel’s Class certificate.

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of deficiencies it received from regional port state control (PSC) organizations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A deficiency is defined as a condition found not to be in compliance with the requirements of one or more of the following conventions:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973, as modified by the Protocols of 1978 and 1997 relating thereto, as amended (MARPOL)
• International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (SOLAS)
• International Convention on Load Lines
• International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978, as amended (STCW)
• International Convention on the Control of Harmful Anti-Fouling Systems on Ships (AFS)
• International Convention on Tonnage Measurement of Ships, 1969 (Tonnage)
• International Labour Organization (ILO) Maritime Labour Convention, 2006

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the number of detentions it received from regional PSC organizations.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A detention is defined as an intervention action by the port state, taken when the condition of a ship or its crew does not correspond substantially with the applicable conventions. A detention ensures that the ship will not sail until it can proceed to sea without presenting a danger to the ship or persons onboard or without presenting an unreasonable threat of harm to the marine environment, whether or not such action affects the normal schedule of the ship’s departure.

Accounting Metric: Number of port state control (1) deficiencies and (2) detentions
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes deficiencies and detentions issued by PSC organizations that are signatories to memoranda of understanding (MoU) of regional PSC (e.g., Paris MoU, Tokyo MoU, Acuerdo de Viña del Mar, Caribbean MoU, Abuja MoU, Black Sea MoU, Mediterranean MoU, Indian Ocean MoU, or Riyadh MoU) or by the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the activities and investments required to achieve the plans and/or targets, and any risks or limiting factors that might affect achievement of the plans and/or targets.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Relevant activities and investments may include, but are not limited to, operational improvements (such as decreased idling, trip optimization, and maximizing loads) and fleet enhancements (such as new engines, fuel optimization technology and aerodynamic fleet modifications, and upgrading the fleet with new locomotives).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss the scope of its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets, such as how they relate to different business units, geographies, or emissions sources.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss whether its strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets are related to, or associated with, emissions limiting and/or emissions reporting-based programs or regulations (e.g., the EU Emissions Trading Scheme, Quebec Cap-and-Trade System, California Cap-and-Trade Program), including regional, national, international, or sectoral programs.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: Disclosure of strategies, plans, and/or reduction targets shall be limited to activities that were ongoing (active) or reached completion during the reporting period.

Accounting Metric: Total fuel consumed, percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of fuel consumed from all sources as an aggregate figure, in gigajoules (GJ).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The calculation methodology for fuel consumed shall be based on actual fuel consumed as opposed to design parameters.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Acceptable calculation methodologies for fuel consumed include, but are not limited to, methodologies based on:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 2:
• Adding fuel purchases made during the reporting period to beginning inventory at the start of the reporting period, less any fuel inventory at the end of the reporting period
• Tracking fuel consumed by vehicles
• Tracking fuel expenses

Accounting Metric: Total fuel consumed, percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the percentage of fuel consumed that is renewable fuel.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Renewable fuel is defined by the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard (U.S. 40 CFR 80.1401), as fuel that meets all of the following requirements:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of renewable fuel includes fuel that qualifies for Renewable Identification Numbers (RINs) under the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage shall be calculated as the amount of renewable fuel consumed (in GJ) divided by the total amount of fuel consumed (in GJ).

Accounting Metric: Total fuel consumed, percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure only includes fuel directly consumed by the entity.

Accounting Metric: Total fuel consumed, percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: In calculating energy consumption from fuels, the entity shall use higher heating values (HHV), also known as gross calorific values (GCV), which are directly measured or taken from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the U.S. Department of Energy, or the U.S. Energy Information Agency.

Accounting Metric: Total fuel consumed, percentage renewable
Technical Protocol: The entity shall apply conversion factors consistently for all data reported under this disclosure, such as the use of HHVs for fuel usage (including biofuels).

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O) and (2) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of air pollutants, in metric tons per pollutant, that are released into the atmosphere.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes air pollutants associated with the entity’s direct air emissions resulting from all of the entity’s activities and sources of emissions, including, but not limited to, stationary and mobile sources, production facilities, office buildings, and transportation fleets.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O) and (2) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (1) oxides of nitrogen (NOx), reported as NOx.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of NOX includes NO and NO2, but excludes N2O.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O) and (2) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its emissions of (2) particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter (PM10), reported as PM10.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: PM10 is defined, according to U.S. 40 CFR Part 51.100, as any airborne finely divided solid or liquid material with an aerodynamic diameter less than or equal to a nominal 10 micrometers.

Accounting Metric: Air emissions of the following pollutants: (1) NOx (excluding N2O) and (2) particulate matter (PM10)
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as whether data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its total recordable incident rate (TRIR) for work-related injuries and illnesses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An injury or illness is considered a recordable incident if it results in any of the following: death, days away from work, restricted work or transfer to another job, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. Additionally, a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional is considered a recordable incident, even if it does not result in death, days away from work, restricted work or job transfer, medical treatment beyond first aid, or loss of consciousness. This definition is derived from U.S. 29 CFR 1904.7.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) provides additional resources for determining if injuries or illnesses are considered recordable incidents in its guidance for OSHA Forms 300, 300A, and 301.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its fatality rate for work-related fatalities.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its near miss frequency rate (NMFR) for work-related near misses.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A near miss is defined as an unplanned incident in which no property or environmental damage or personal injury occurred, but where damage or personal injury easily could have occurred but for a slight circumstantial shift.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The U.S. National Safety Council (NSC) provides guidance on implementing near miss reporting, including in, “Near Miss Reporting Systems.”
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The entity may disclose its process for classifying, identifying, and reporting near misses.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: Rates shall be calculated as: (statistic count × 200,000) / hours worked
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides additional guidance for the calculation of rates in, “How to Compute a Firm’s Incidence Rate for Safety Management” and “Incidence Rate Calculator and Comparison Tool."

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes work-related incidents only.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: OSHA guidance for Forms 300, 300A, and 301 provides guidance on determining whether an incident is work-related, as well as definitions for exemptions for incidents that occur in the work environment but are not work-related.

Accounting Metric: (1) Total recordable incident rate (TRIR), (2) fatality rate, and (3) near miss frequency rate (NMFR)
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure includes all employees regardless of employee location and type of employment, such as full-time, part-time, direct, contract, executive, labor, salary, hourly, and seasonal employees.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the total amount of monetary losses it incurred during the reporting period as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations, such as those related to enforcement of laws and regulations on price fixing, antitrust behavior (e.g., exclusivity contracts), patent misuse, or network effects, as well as bundling of services and products to limit competition.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The legal proceedings shall include any adjudicative proceeding in which the entity was involved, whether before a court, a regulator, an arbitrator, or otherwise.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The losses shall include all monetary liabilities to the opposing party or to others (whether as the result of settlement or verdict after trial or otherwise), including fines and other monetary liabilities incurred during the reporting period as a result of civil actions (e.g., civil judgments or settlements), regulatory proceedings (e.g., penalties, disgorgement, or restitution), and criminal actions (e.g., criminal judgment, penalties, or restitution) brought by any entity (e.g., governmental, business, or individual).

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of monetary losses shall exclude legal and other fees and expenses incurred by the entity in its defense.

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Articles 101 to 109 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Japan’s Act on Prohibition of Private Monopolization and Maintenance of Fair Trade
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: U.S. Clayton Antitrust Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: U.S. Federal Trade Commission Act of 1914
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: U.S. Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890

Accounting Metric: Total amount of monetary losses as a result of legal proceedings associated with anti-competitive behavior regulations
Technical Protocol: The scope of disclosure shall include, but is not limited to, legal proceedings associated with the enforcement of relevant industry regulations promulgated by regional, national, state, and local regulatory authorities, such as:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Japan Fair Trade Commission
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: U.S. Federal Trade Commission

Accounting Metric: Number of accidents and incidents
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the aggregate number of accidents and incidents in which it was involved.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: An accident or incident is defined, according to U.S. Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) in U.S. 49 CFR 225.5, as one or more of the following:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Any impact between railroad on-track equipment and a highway user at crossings
• Any collision, derailment, fire, or other events involving the operation of railroad on-track equipment that results in reportable damage above thresholds established in 49 CRR 225.5
• Other incidents or exposures that result in fatality or injury to any person, or result in occupational illness of a railroad employee
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: In the U.S., the scope of accidents and incidents includes events that are required to be reported to the FRA, as per 49 CFR 225.5

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) accident releases and (2) non-accident releases (NARs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (1) the total number of accident releases of hazardous material.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Hazardous material is defined, according to U.S. 49 CFR 171.8, as a substance or material that the Secretary of Transportation has determined is capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety, and property when transported in commerce and has designated as hazardous under section 5103 of federal hazardous materials transportation law (49 U.S.C. 5103).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of hazardous materials includes hazardous substances, hazardous wastes, marine pollutants, elevated temperature materials, materials designated as hazardous in the Hazardous Materials Table (49 CFR 172.101), and materials that meet the defining criteria for hazard classes and divisions in 49 CFR 173.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: An accident release is defined as a release of hazardous material that is required to be reported to regulatory or governmental agencies.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) accident releases and (2) non-accident releases (NARs)
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose (2) the total number of non-accident releases (NARs) of hazardous material.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: A NAR is defined according to the Association of American Railroads (AAR) as the unintentional release of a hazardous material while in transportation, including loading and unloading while in railroad possession that is not caused by derailment, collision, or other rail-related accidents.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• NARs consist of leaks, splashes, and other releases from improperly secured or defective valves, fittings, and tank shells.
• NARs include venting of non-atmospheric gases from safety relief devices.
• NARs exclude normal safety venting of atmospheric gases such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen.

Accounting Metric: Number of (1) accident releases and (2) non-accident releases (NARs)
Technical Protocol: Where relevant, the entity may provide a breakdown of spills and releases by type, such as: (a) hydrocarbons and (b) hazardous substances.

Accounting Metric: Number of Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) Recommended Violation Defects
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the number of Recommended Violation Defects resulting from the U.S. Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) or state inspections or audits.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of disclosure includes, but is not limited to, violation defects for any safety-related issue, including those related to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• Accident reporting
• Grade-crossing signal safety
• Hazardous material regulations
• Industrial hygiene (e.g., occupational noise)
• Motive power and equipment (e.g., freight car safety, locomotive safety, and passenger equipment safety)
• Railroad operating practices (e.g., alcohol and drug use, hours of services laws, communications, and operating practices)
• Signal system safety
• Track safety
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes, but is not limited to, violation defects that both did and did not result in civil penalties.

Accounting Metric: Frequency of internal railway integrity inspections
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose the frequency with which it conducts inspections of its tracks.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Frequency of inspections of tracks shall be disclosed as the number of inspections per week, weighted for the number of main track miles on which those inspections took place.
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1: • The frequency shall be calculated as the sum for all track of: (weekly inspections × miles of track on which they took place) / (total main track miles)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of disclosure includes, but is not limited to, excepted main track; Class 1, 2, and 3 main track; and Class 4 and 5 main track inspections.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The scope of disclosure excludes track other than main track.

Accounting Metric: Frequency of internal railway integrity inspections
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the frequency of its inspections in relation to the following U.S. Federal Rail Administration (FRA) requirements:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: If the track has carried passenger trains, or more than 10 million gross tons of traffic during the preceding calendar year, the FRA requires twice-weekly inspections, with at least one calendar-day interval between inspections.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: If the track is used less than once a week, the FRA requires weekly inspections with at least a three calendar-day interval between inspections, or an inspection before every use.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity shall disclose its gross global Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions to the atmosphere of the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Emissions of all GHGs shall be consolidated and disclosed in metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (CO2-e), and calculated in accordance with published 100-year time horizon global warming potential (GWP) values. To date, the preferred source for GWP values is the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report (2014).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Gross emissions are GHGs emitted into the atmosphere before accounting for offsets, credits, or other similar mechanisms that have reduced or compensated for emissions.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: Scope 1 emissions are defined and shall be calculated according to the methodology contained in The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Acceptable calculation methodologies include those that conform to the GHG Protocol as the base reference, but provide additional guidance, such as industry- or region-specific guidance. Examples include, but are not limited to:
Sub-Bullet Points for Bullet Point 1:
• GHG Reporting Guidance for the Aerospace Industrypublished by International Aerospace Environmental Group (IAEG)
• Greenhouse Gas Inventory Guidance: Direct Emissions from Stationary Combustion Sources published by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
• India GHG Inventory Program
• ISO 14064-1
• Petroleum Industry Guidelines for reporting GHG emissions, 2nd edition, 2011, published by IPIECA
• Protocol for the quantification of greenhouse gas emissions from waste management activities published by Entreprises pour l’Environnement (EpE)
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: GHG emissions data shall be consolidated and disclosed according to the approach with which the entity consolidates its financial reporting data, which is generally aligned with the “financial control” approach defined by the GHG Protocol, and the approach published by the Climate Disclosure Standards Board (CDSB) described in REQ-07, “Organisational boundary,” of the CDSB Framework for reporting environmental information, natural capital and associated business impacts (April 2018).

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss any change in its emissions from the previous reporting period, including whether the change was due to emissions reductions, divestment, acquisition, mergers, changes in output, and/or changes in calculation methodology.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: In the case that current reporting of GHG emissions to the CDP or other entity (e.g., a national regulatory disclosure program) differs in terms of the scope and consolidation approach used, the entity may disclose those emissions. However, primary disclosure shall be according to the guidelines described above.

Accounting Metric: Gross global Scope 1 emissions
Technical Protocol: The entity may discuss the calculation methodology for its emissions disclosure, such as if data are from continuous emissions monitoring systems (CEMS), engineering calculations, or mass balance calculations.

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage its Scope 1 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: Scope 1 emissions are defined according to The Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (GHG Protocol), Revised Edition, March 2004, published by the World Resources Institute and the World Business Council on Sustainable Development (WRI/WBCSD).
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: The scope of GHG emissions includes the seven GHGs covered under the Kyoto Protocol—carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), and nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).

Accounting Metric: Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets
Technical Protocol: The entity shall discuss its emission reduction target(s) and analyze its performance against the target(s), including the following, where relevant:
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 1: The scope of the emission reduction target (e.g., the percentage of total emissions to which the target is applicable);
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 2: Whether the target is absolute- or intensity-based, and the metric denominator, if it is an intensity-based target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 3: The percentage reduction against the base year, with the base year representing the first year against which emissions are evaluated toward the achievement of the target;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 4: The timelines for the reduction activity, including the start year, the target year, and the base year;
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 5: The mechanism(s) for achieving the target; and
Technical Protocol Bullet Point 6: Any circumstances in which the target or base year emissions have been, or may be, recalculated retrospectively or the target or base year has been reset.
